description:
"Best Pizza in San Francisco"?  Definitely deserves that title! 
Came here on a Saturday evening around 8:30- had to wait in line for 15 min before we were able to be seated.

Venue: this neighborhood joint is quite on the small side; we were lucky to have a table in the window nook so that we don't feel too claustrophobic.  Most tables seat 4 at most but mostly r better for 2-3.  There are only 4 tables inside, 4 counter seats by the kitchen, and 4 tables outside (they have overhead heaters if it's cold outside), so do expect to wait for a table (NB: some days they do take-out and these hold up well).  That being said, the restaurant still has a neighborhood, cozy feel to it so that the tight space isn't unpleasant.  

Service: probably some of the charm of this place comes from the friendly staff.  They all realize that the place is popular / crowded and so take extra care to make sure service is excellent.  They try to be efficient with everything without making you feel too rushed.  Ask them for recommendations!

Food: I don't eat much in general, but one pizza is enough to make me feel satisfyingly full (maybe towards full full).  Probably recommend taking into account topping types if ordering multiple pizzas.  Overall, one of the best crusts I've tasted in general, almost comparable to what I would find in Italy- thin but puffy and not too doughy.  Not greasy / oily either; from the pizzas we've eaten so far (including take out), most of what we got have been clean tasting.  
-- Farm Egg, Sweet Corn, Chipotle Creme Fraiche, Chive, Cherry Tomato ($17.50) - surprisingly light given the egg!  The corn was a nice touch of sweetness to offset the chipotle creme fraiche, which essentially serves as the cheese.  Be prepared to get your hands messy with this one, especially since the egg is still runny when it comes out.

-- Tomato Sauce, Mozzarella, Basil w/ White Anchovy ($15.50) - highly recommend anchovies on this pizza!  Even without it, the pizza is very clean tasting; you can taste all ingredients in the pizza and appreciate a simple pizza done right.  

Highly recommend if you are looking for good, thin-crust pizza- it's worth the trek out here!
author: Audrey H.

description:
Tried to go to Pearl for brunch today, but ended up here instead.  What a great surprise!  I wasn't even in the mood for pizza, but it was sooooo good that I'm glad we ended up here.  

We had a sausage pizza and a cheese one with sheep's milk cheese.  The cheese one was better, as the sausage one was a little too salty (hence the minus star).  But both were delicious.
author: Ernest S.

description:
This is the best pizza I have ever had.

Seating is very limited, but the staff is gracious. Place has a nice neighborhood vibe. It's like discovering some secret local treasure. It's that good. I had the farmhouse pizza, which has sunnyside eggs and asparagus on it. Changed my life.
author: Wolf H.

description:
Went here after landing in SF. Service was wonderful as a first timer. We had the seasonal cheeseboard and devoured it before receiving our perfectly sized pizzetta (as they say).

I really loved the neighborhood ambiance and the coziness of the space. This isn't the fancy place that gives you plush velvet chairs in isolated booths. You're going to be cozy (read: don't invite someone you don't like or someone that has body odor,because you're gonna be all in each other's pores). It's a rest place to be with friends and drink wine while your pizza is prepared 11 inches away.
author: Whitney H.

description: Small adorable place in the Outer Richmond. The pizza is good, but it does get cold kind of quick (I think because the door was open). Hot or cold the pizza is still great! The line is out the door because the place is tiny. They play great music and the place is very homey. Below is the Farm Egg Pizza and Margarita pizza. Get there early so you don't have to wait!
author: Caitlyn S.

description:
Best dinner we've had in awhile.  Food, service, location, all were great.  The restaurant is very small and easy to miss. Although you don't want to miss this.  
Quality ingredients and you could tell.  It's a neighborhood restaurant.  Service is so good that you don't even mind the wait.  He makes you feel comfortable and taken care of while you wait.  I was impressed because I haven't seen that kind of service in a while, probably never. At least at a pizza joint.  

Pizzettas are all great.  We got the classic San Marzano tomato sauce, mascarpone, and wild arugula.  We also ordered the farm egg, pork chile verde, red onion, cotija, with cilantro crema.  It was hard to choose the pizzeta became they all sounded and looked so good.


For dessert, flourless chocolate cake of course.  I wish they were closer to where we live.  Really good pizza. Worth the wait or order take out to eat at home or the park if you really mind.  Order of over the phone and pick up if you don't want to wait. 

Definitely can't wait til we come back here here again.
author: Naty D.

description:
A small neighborhood pizza place

(+) waiter very courteous. Bathroom cleaned. 

(-) seats a bit small and uncomfortable though they have some pillows in corner seats. These thinly crusted Pizza took a while to come out (30ish minutes). Not sure if they just took the salad from
Box to table since we did not taste much dressing/taste with spring salad dish. Not much taste to pizzas (we ordered 3 types). Not much toppings pizza since  crust is so thin it tasted like eating crackers and not pizzas. I only tasted tasted salts. Kinda disappointed. 

We won't be back.
author: K P.

description: We came right as the place opened and although it took a little while to get situated and seated, it was worth it. The pizzas were delicious and so was the appetizer. We sat outside at a cute little table and had such an enjoyable lunch. My friends and I enjoyed our pizzas so much that I ordered another to take home to my husband - he was happy with the take-out pizza. Service was a tad slow but as long as you're not in a rush, you're in for an enjoyable, delicious meal!
author: Anne G.

description: The staff was polite and helpful. The atmosphere was peaceful and the pizza was awesome.
author: Dondraa O.

description:
What I love about San Francisco is that it's full of nooks and crannies. You can think you're walking through a plain ol' neighborhood and all of a sudden stumble across a piece of magic. Pizzetta 211, you're that celestial unicorn.

My order:

Warm Mixed Olives - I eat a lot of olives and I do order them quite a bit, but this particular sampler was simply beautiful. When I saw that single Red Bella di Cerignola olive delicately placed within this small dish, I was really pleased. 

Salad of the Day - Baby kale tossed in a light vinaigrette with thin shaved Parmesan, beets, and toasted Pepita seeds. Every single kale leaf was perfectly dressed and all the ingredients, although seemingly simple, brought so much intention to this starter. 

Farm Egg Pizzetta - This thin pizzetta had such contrast in flavors and textures that it was very pleasant to eat. I'm not sure how they do it, but they've completely mastered the outer and inner crust; soft yet still a little stiff in order to hold up against the toppings without it being the slight bit soggy. Crisped to perfection! As for the toppings, it came with thinly sliced steamed/baked potatoes which brought in some heartiness. The Parmesan cheese gave enough of a sharpness to cut through the potatoes and crust; all the while being sprinkled with pieces of chopped bacon, lending some saltiness and smokiness. To add another layer of complexity to this beautiful culinary dish, what better to go with bacon than two sunny side up eggs? The yokes were still runny, silky, and light, greatly enhancing the wonderful mix of juxtaposed textures.

When I came across this teeny restaurant in the middle of Richmond District, I didn't expect it to be this good. I mean, real good. In fact, I never even knew it was here! True definition of what you call a hidden gem. The chefs certainly have a deft hand with focused execution. 

Unicorn indeed. Truly deserving of 5 Stars!
author: Ann S.

description:
My partner and I tried to eat an early dinner here in June 2018 but was so put off by the service that I walked out. 

We were the only patrons. We waited ages to order drinks while our waiter ate a plate of pasta at the counter...

Then another couple arrived. The cc machine was broken, so it was cash-only for that night. The husband left to go get cash several blocks away. The wait staff refused to seat the woman until her husband returned. The restaurant was EMPTY! And he was absent only because he was accommodating he broken credit card machine! This poor woman had to stand in her heels outside the restaurant next to a tree. 

We couldn't support a restaurant that treats its customers like that, (and we STILL hadn't ordered our drinks) so we left.
author: Lady B.

description:
Friendly service and excellent pizza!
A jewel of a place in a cute setting right in a heart of Richmond district. 
We were there in the off hours and it was still busy. Place doesn't take reservations, so prepare to wait! They do have nice warm blankets for those chili San Francisco nights and days when summer turns into winter in 5 min.
author: Jada C.

description: This was one of my favorite pizza places in the city.  We've been coming here since it was opened by the previous owner.  Today was our worst experience.  Don't get me wrong, the pizza was excellent except for the olive pit I almost bit down on (mind you the pizza didn't have olives) and before that we had an eggplant appetizer that had a patch of the saltiest caramelized onions.  It was so salty I told two servers it could've choked a horse.  Apparently they couldn't care less as they had full house and had better things to do.  The waitperson did apologize but upon paying the bill, it didn't appear that he was sincere.
author: Tessie A.

description: Still think this place has some of the best pizza in SF.  I've been a few times and have always had a few stand out pizzas.  There's always a creative special to try out.  Its a small place to visit so seating is at a premium.  But its worth it.
author: David Z.

description:
The only reason for not giving this fabulous restaurant a 5 is due to the limited but absolutely delicious menu and it's limited space...but with that said,,,omg I am so sorry I did not take pictures,,
Had my birthday lunch there today with my hubby and dear friend. It is such a tiny place,,,so for us visiting on a off day time was crucial. From what I can tell and totally believe it is a long wait on peak hours. I think there are about 15 seats inside and half as much outside. Very intimate and personal touch from the owners. I am on a very restricted plant based diet and it was accommodated with ease. High high high marks for this. I ordered the melon arugula basil salad to start and a espresso and my friend ordered a lemonatta....the salad was Devine. Small but absolutely scrumptious. 
Each of us ordered our own pizza. Mine a all veggie with arugula on top,,,this was by far the best, delicate, flavorful, balanced, pizza I have ever eaten. My husband had a cheese pizza with sopressa and friend had the margarita. Wow.. totally exceeded pizza we have ever had. Mind you this was thin, delicate pizza.  So do not expect to walk away stuffed. I only ate half of mine as well as the others,,,but most people could probably eat the entire one. I did not have any cheese or oil...and it was so delightful. 
Thank you so much to the owners chef creators of this restaurant. I am so looking to come back soon. 
Try it,,,you will like it.
author: Ann L.

description:
After a weary weekend, some friends and I rolled in here in search of a good meal. And we got way more than we expected.

First off, the service is excellent. Despite being really busy, we were well taken care of and constantly had our water glasses refilled. 

The ambience is also lovely. It's perfect for a romantic night out or cozy evening with pals. And there's outdoor seating for nice weather nights!

And finally, the pizza. Wow. I had the asparagus one, which alone is worth going for. My friends' meals were also delicious (basil and Thai sausage), but the asparagus really took it home for me.

Hope to be back soon to this neighborhood gem!
author: Sarah G.

description:
We came here after the Veggie Festival at golden gate park. It was as good as the yelpers mentioned! We ordered 4 pizzettas for my husband, myself and two girls. The chipotle sauce pizza with corn was very delicious, the  one with the egg on it was good too, however it did taste like an omelette a bit, so I don't think I will order that again, but it was good to try for the first time. 
The place was clean and the atmosphere was calm and enjoyable. Its a small place but their service was fast and very nice!! I would come back when I am in town! But, there are so many food joints to try in SF so maybe I will come here with family from out of town. Lol.
author: Wajma Z.

description: Mostly just a wonderful atmosphere, the feeling of urban neighborhood joint, where locals are recognized and patrons have just walked down the street for a bite. Enjoyed the pizzas and dessert! Limited menu makes it an easy order. Was able to enjoy a glass of wine on the bench outside while waiting for a table. Lovely!
author: J K.

description:
Great neighborhood restaurant.

I like thin crust pizza and theirs is excellent. What really made my meal was discovering they also had excellent desserts-keep up the good work! It's so rare to find a great pizzeria where dessert is not just an afterthought.
author: Rachel C.

description:
After years of having this place bookmarked, I finally tried it last night. It was actually difficult to find as it was a very unassuming pizza place that blended in with the adjacent apartments and houses. I was surprised by how quiet it was when we got our table and even the waiter mentioned how strangely slow it was for that time of day. The restaurant is quite small and the I can't imagine the four small tables seating any more than 10 people. 

As cozy and small this place is, their menu is kept simple. There are a few pizzas that are stay on the menu and a few that rotate bi-weekly. We just so happened to visit on the last day of a rotation and thought to try some of the specials. The first was essentially a breakfast-inspired pizza topped with coppa meat, potatoes, goat cheese, arugula pesto and two farm eggs. The lack of a sauce made sure the salume, egg, and potato really came through along with the goat cheese, which was mild. The other pizza we tried was the house made pork sausage, roasted tomato sauce, red onion, caper oil. This second pie was a standard sausage, but I really loved the fresh mozzarella and the red sauce was wonderful.  

I loved the crust, dough, and everything about these pies. The thin-crust pizzas are roughly 10 inches, but one is just enough for one person. The prices are in line with any quick-bake pie places, but the ingredients here are far superior.
author: Bailey Z.

description: Crazy good pizza. Had one one of their weekly specialty pizzas - braised pork with guacamole- who knew?  Excellent pizza with amazing and friendly service. Will definitely go back!!!
author: Don K.

description: Super delicious, super small. Probably fits about 15 people max and they take their time. Perfect lunch time spot if there's no wait. Loved of corn, egg, bacon, cheese pizza! Crust is awesome.
author: Colton S.

description:
This is a small, artisanal pizza place in the Richmond.  There are only about 8 tables, so expect a wait even at off times.

They have a rotating selection of pies based on seasonal toppings. There are also cheese plates, a few other dishes, and some amazing desserts.  Wine is all reasonably priced, and the staff is very friendly.

While it's not the best pizza in SF, it's definitely the best pizza in the Richmond.
author: Rachel R.

description:
Great place and great wine list for a tiny joint !
Very friendly staff 
Always top notch pizza
author: Laurent G.

description: Best pizza in San Francisco- NO DOUBT.  But their other dishes!  Wonderful green and grain salads, soups, and their desserts are out of this world!  I am a Foodie for sure, eaten at all the high-end places in SF (and love them too), but Pizzetta will always be my go-to.  And the new place they opened next door, Pearl, shows their same attention to detail.  Delicious!
author: MidnightMunchies X.

description: Discovered this place returning from a walk across the Golden Gate Bridge. Dave our server was personable and engaging. The pizzas were nuanced and imaginative without being presumptuous - made me think of why I settle for assembly line chain pizza. Service was quick, and patrons (local) charming. We'll be bach!
author: S B.

description:
I love their thin crust pizzas, they're so delicious! But recently I went and had a seasonal special, an asparagus dish with chopped vegetables and seasoning on top, and I couldn't stop thinking about it! 

The location is small and popular, so we always go sometime in the morning before 12pm. Parking is not bad since California and Clement are both a street away. You can't go wrong dining here, even my grandparents vehemently tells everyone that they have the best pizza EVER. They like it so much that my grandma, who doesn't speak English, had me write down all the vegetarian pizza options available on a piece of paper so she can go whenever she wants by herself, to eat her favorite pizza. 

Long live Pizzette!
author: Gwendolyn F.

description:
How do you make the amazingness of pizza more amazing? THROW A FREAKIN FRIED EGG ON IT. Pizzetta was one of the best & most memorable pizza experiences I've had... and I've had plenty! :)

EATS
Seasonal pizzas on the menu, all sounded so delicious. I got the pizza with fried egg and the other I believe was a more standard pizza with arugula on top. The fried egg pizza was seriously so delicious (not a surprise considering pizza and egg are two of my favorite foods!). The pizza with arugula was also so impressive. Such fresh ingredients! After eating here, arugula is now one of my favorite pizza toppings lol.
I went with one friend and we got 2 pizzas expecting there to be leftovers, but this was actually a good amount. The pizzas are a little on the small side, especially for the price, but tbh the taste and quality more than make up for it. 

VIBE/DECOR
A small location in Outer Richmond. As someone who grew up in the Outer Sunset, this place felt very authentically SF, loved how low-key it was! 

No complaints on service -- fast & friendly! This was a perfect little spot for a chill weekend lunch. Coming at an odd hour is prob your best bet considering how small the space is! 

Definitely worth a visit. Can't wait to stop in again!
author: Greg J.

description: Absolutely love Pizzetta! My go to pizza and favorite pizza in the city for sure. The service is always great, food is always amazing and creative. Also so quaint and cute.
author: Brittany W.

description: I love my pizza thin with a good crust. This really hit the spot and great service too!
author: Julie Ann M.

description: DELICIOUS!!! My best friend and I had some amazing food that tasted as close to authentically Italian pizza as you can get!! A must visit!!
author: Clara K.

description: They truly love pizza here. Everything, from the crust to the medley of cleverly paired flavors, is delicious! I have yet to successfully save some for later.
author: Dilek I.

description:
As good as hipster pizza can get. My aunt and uncle took ME here when THEY were the ones that were visiting from Boston. They've had Pizzetta a few times before - and they are huge fans. Well, huge fans of good pizza.

We came here on a Thursday before they opened and we were first in line. There is only residential parking, as it's in the Richmond district - keep an eye out for those open, right angle'd curbs! Also, this place is NOT in a "downtown"/business area; it's smushed right in with the homes. So yeah, again, keep those eyez peeled. The actual restaurant is tiny, or comfortable should I say? It only has four tables.

We ordered the three specials - one for each of us. I don't remember the names quite frankly, but there was one was baked (or fried) egg on top, one with potatoes, and one with a bunch of Italian meats on it. And each item was about $15~ if I remember correctly.

10/10, would bring guests here next time - epitome of SF in a pizza restaurant.
author: Nicole D.

description:
We ordered two pizzas for take out on a Sunday night and it was ready in less than 15 min! 

We ordered: 

English Peas, Spring Onion, Curried Panna, Ricotta Salata, Mint just because it was different. Unfortunately, we weren't that impressed :/ 

San Marzano Tomato Sauce, Mascarpone, Wild Arugula, Olio Verde and added pepperoni! This was our favorite pizza! Cooked to perfection and the tomato sauce was top notch. So glad this pizza is always on their menu. 

Size wise- they are on the smaller size for $17.. I would definitely come back to try some of their other pizzas though
author: Michelle L.

description:
Exceptionally good pizza and good service, the place is definitely one my favorite pizza joint around. The small pizzas are unique, shareable, and delicious with a selection of good wine and appetizers, topping sauce is delicious, the cheese is great, and the anchovies are fresh and tart (not salty). If you can get over the crowded space and the usual wait to be seated, you're in for a treat
The pies here are 10" and serve 2-3 depending upon your appetite. We ordered the margherita and the quattro formaggi. Both were amazing though I preferred the quattro formaggi with prosciutto and sun-dried tomatoes. So savory and delicious. My date loved the more traditional margherita. These pies are like what you would get in Italy. They are smaller than most pizza chains but the quality is far superior. The staff use great ingredients and wood fire these thin pies to gently burnt-crisp perfection. I'll be sure to stop back in more often. Our waitress was very polite and helpful, and I enjoyed speaking with one of the pizza makers as he was putting out tomatoes to dry in the sun (he did reveal they had spent time in the oven to dry first). For your check, they used a simple clothespin. I really enjoyed the simplicity and whimsy of this choice. The place not much to look up from the outside, but this is truly one of the best pizzas I've had in the USA.
author: Aida S.

description: A solid margherita pizza at a popular, small restaurant (and you know what this means!) with service so good that the staff brought our order to my car. I'd like to venture here at an off time so I could experience dining in.
author: Paulina F.

description: If you don't like this place the problem is with you! So cute, so quaint, a literal hole in the wall. I recommnd going at the oddball dinner times to avoid the lines.
author: Jonah K.

description: Definitely my No. 1 favorite pizza restaurant. Love every pizza on their menu. They offer a small menu, but every single item is so good. Fresh ingredients, amazing quality, rotated seasonal items, friendly service, nice ambiance -- all incredible. Wish I live closer so I can visit more often.
author: Wenjing Y.

description:
This hidden gem in The Richmond District is a must visit. With amazing artisan pizzas and a stacked wine/beer menu, you can't go wrong with anything they offer. 

Although it's slightly overpriced and it often takes 30-45 min for a table, I still love coming here. Perfect date night spot!
author: Adam O.

description: Awesome pitzza with unique food presentation, I loved their specials too, must go if you are into pitzza and want to try a trendy place.
author: Jay G.

description:
I think Vice recommended this as SF's best pizza spot, and I agree. We swung by here around 4:30pm after a Saturday on the beach. We quickly nabbed a table outside -- at the hour, the tiny shop was maybe 80% full. 

We got the Tex-Mex pizza, which was surprisingly the star of the night. Usually I'm not a fan of 'creative' West Coast pizzas, but all the pizzas here had the al dente, thin, crunchy, chewy dough of the best New York-style slices.

The margharita with anchovies was fantastic as well, though I think next time I'll spare the anchovies, which overpowered the subtle flavors of the slice.

In short: come here on a beautiful sunny afternoon. You won't be disappointed.
author: Ken H.

description: The pizza is good. However, the lack of structure in the kitchen was appalling. I wish the kitchen wasn't open. Frankly, I don't want to see disgruntled employees drink, eat, and then make my pizza without washing their hands. They had a young lady who looked so miserable, I wanted to ask, "why are you even here?" . Next time I would definitely order to go. I enjoyed the pizza but would rather not see all the health code violations.
author: Lucia D.

description:
My friends and I came by here for a quick dinner per Laverne N.'s Yelp searching skills haha. I was a little shocked at how tiny this place was. I can see how SF natives would not find the size of this place surprising at all. The interior is very rustic and hipster-esque I guess you can say. 

The menu rotates every couple of weeks. We ordered the farm egg, tasso ham, sweet potato, brussel sprout, crescenza pizzetta ($17.50) and the roasted cauliflower, vandouvan, currants, almonds, mint yogurt pizzetta ($16). Both pizzas were good, but they didn't really blow my mind especially for the price point and portion that you receive. If I had to choose the better tasting pizza, it would've been the farm egg one. The other one tasted interesting to me - almost had like an Indian cuisine hint to it. 

The service here was attentive. I think the ambiance is really just not what I'm used to. I've had better pizzas, but it was a nice little place to try!
author: Joanne Y.

description:
Cuuuute little bistro. If you blink you'll miss it. I called in a pick up order of the Tomato, Mozzarella, Basil + pepperoni. This is a standard menu option but they rotate their menu every two weeks to offer a wider selection of options. Once we arrived there was a mesmerizing apple dessert something on the counter. The host said it was an apple galette, served with warmed salted caramel and home made whipped cream. Um, can I have that to go please and thank you!?

For me, the only downside to picking up food from any place is you either eat it semi-warm or you have to pop it in the broiler for 5. Honestly, I wasn't in the mood for pizza at lunchtime but can I tell you how perfectly proportioned and packed full of flavor this little pizza was! My 3 slices (there are 6, but I shared) were just not enough. I mean, they were but I wanted more!  Thin crust and crunchy. You know what I'm talking about. The entire pizza had texture. Even the amount of pepperoni was right. 

Good thing we added the apple galette to our pick up because it was delicious! Thin crust and crunchy pizza without being floppy. You know what I'm talking about. I don't think it's a regular item on the menu, so if they are offering it when you go, get it! 

The restaurant is small with not many other options nearby. Truly a locals spot. There are 2 small tables outside with maaaybe 3-4 inside. It's small. Totally worth checking out if you are in the area and in the mood for good pizza.
author: Jaylena P.

description: Love this tiny hole in the wall find!  Fresh ingredients, original creations...a quaint neighborhood treasure.  Every time I visit I am never disappointed.  Pizza, bites, salads, wines and beers, desserts!
author: Nancy M.

description: Was really excited to try this place.  Got there and there were two empty tables.  Told the server my boyfriend was on his way. Policy is no sitting until your party is all there.  I was ready to order wine app and our pizza.  Would not seat me..boyfriend arrives the same tables still available..still won't seat me..also a very rude and snitty attitude.  A total joke..too many other great places to eat and be treated in a more friendly way..took my money elsewhere .  no time for this bs
author: Nikki D.

description: The pizza and panna cotta was really good, and I loved the outdoor seating but the salad was a little bland. Also, at times the staff were talking about personal things going on among the other staff and it felt inappropriate for the customer to be within eat shot.
author: Tamar K.

description: I had the San Marzano Tomato Sauce pizzetta. The dollops of mascarpone were sooo good! So light and fluffy. It was like eating pillowy clouds of cream. The tomato sauce had a slight kick and was also delicious. I usually do not eat the crust on regular-sized pizzas unless there is dipping sauce. But the pizzetta was mostly topping with only a sliver of crust. And the pie was already thin to begin with so I happily devoured every last bit. A little pricey but I think worth the flavors, textures, and overall experience.
author: Lauren H.

description: Amazing quality! Fresh ingredients. You can taste every bite!! Can't wait to go back!! A little scary to say but it's the best pizza I've ever had. My friend agrees!
author: Yolanda O.

description: I will not be coming back due to the terrible attitude of the wait staff. It's not worth the hype that it has. I'll spend my money elsewhere where I can get treated with respect. Terrible experience overall.
author: Lindsey L.

description:
All of my Yelp reviews start with a 5 star review because in my eyes anyone who can be in business in SF deserves it.  However, maintaining a 5 star is up to each individual business. I calculate reviews by personal experience with ambiance, service, cleanliness, presentation, eating experience, and price.

This place is tiny and placed smack dab in the middle of the Richmond District.  There's small patio tables and chairs in front. It's super small inside and quite frankly I barely walked in before being escorted back outside. 

Ambiance is so so if you like sitting outside with parked cars

Service could be much better -- our server didn't seem to interested and almost seemed annoyed when we questioned items on the menu that were very vague ... like cheese plate? Really? -2 

Cleanliness NA as we weren't inside at all 

Presentation was ok it's just pizza 

Eating Experience - The pizza was ridiculously small ($15.50), over salted, soggy, and super greasy. I've had better pizza in Bali, Indonesia! -1

Price is way overcharged! 
 
I can't give this place more than 2 stars.
author: Bahvee V.

description:
Enjoyed a great dinner here. I'm a bit biased as I have been using the sauce and dough recipe that was featured in sunset magazine for like 10 years. Was in town with no dinner plans so decided to give it a shot. Adorable little storefront with no sign-- the crowd outside clues you in that something fabulous is happening inside though. The wait was surprisingly short and they will bring you wine and blankets while you wait. Loved sitting at the bar with a view of our food in process. We left about 9:30 just as they were closing and they were still full. 

Both pizzas were great as was the soup of the day (like seriously one of the best bowls of soup I've ever had!). The berry tart was in the basic french country style but it was amazing-- perfect crust and perfect crust:berry ratio. 

Go!

Oh, re: prices. Yep. You're gonna pay $15-20/individaul sized pie. This is not out of the norm for this type of pizza joint but if that gets your hackles up, do yourself a favor and skip this one!
author: Sara H.

description:
Hidden in a neighborhood, this tiny place is paaaaacked. Their little shop only holds maybe like 10 people, super cramped. It gives it personality, but it would still be nice for a couple more outside tables for seating or something. We came at 6:30ish and waited a little more than an hour. They gave us a menu to look at while waiting and it didn't take long to pick out what we wanted. The menu was super short and changes so often to keep things fresh and new with cooking things that are available. 

Once we were seated by our friendly waiter, we waited even more for the pizza to be freshly made. We ordered the farm egg pizza with pork carnitas, guac, and grilled corn and a basiz pizza of tomato, mozzarella, basil.  By the time it came, we were so hungry that we ate those pizzas in like 0.2 seconds. I wish I could have eaten slower to savor it and remember how it tasted, but NOPE all that comes to mind are the vague memories of HOT. CHEESY. YUM. BYE. Oh and I also really liked the corn because it added a bunch of unexpected subtle sweetness to the pizza. We ate so fast, that the server didn't even have time to check on us LOL I WILL JUST HAVE TO COME BACK.
author: Maleah M.

description:
I love this place so much that I almost want to not write a review so I can keep it all to myself. The food, the ambiance, the service-- all incredible. The only downside is the long wait, but nothing can be done about that. 

There are a couple pizzas on the menu that have been there since the restaurant opened according to our waiter-- I would do one of those and then one of the new pizza selections that they rotate out. Ask which is which. We had a pizza with roasted broccoli, burrata, chili oil, and garlic Breadcrumbs that was FIRE. 

This is perfect for date night and nicely out of the way if you're trying to avoid the hyped up/not that good SF restaurants. Just great food and good people. 10/10 would chug this pizza again
author: C.R. O.

description: Super awesome find. Unique flavors and rad place. I know it sound crazy.... but check out the WC.
author: Tiffanie P.

description:
Disclaimer: this review is for their ridiculous seating rule.

I was finding parking while my girlfriend went in to get a table and place our order. There were two open tables, and nobody else waiting.

They put her on a list and wouldn't let her sit until I was there. I can understand this if it's a busy night or for a large group, but the circumstances did not call for this.

I hope you learn some service and understanding, Pizetta, because you just lost a patron.
author: Zeke M.

description: Good pizza, seasonal menu, organic salads. Chef and wait staff are meticulous with the details to make a perfect pizza. We had the margarita with san Marzano tomato sauce, eggplant Parmesan pizza and organic greens salad. The pizza is very thing crust almost cracker like.All great. The valrhona chocolate cake like everything else is made in house. Only be prepared - Very small restaurant and long wait.
author: Tina L.

description:
I've been wanting to dine here ever since I moved to the Richmond District 5 years ago, and I finally had the chance recently.  The space is very intimate, and I've always passed by during peak hours.  I went right before the dinner rush, and my friend and I were seated within 15 minutes.

We ordered our own pizzas, and I would've ate the entire thing if I wasn't so full from stuffing myself the whole day.  I just got the mozzarella and basil pizza, and he got his with pepperoni. The pizza has that homemade, cooked-with-love feel, and it's delicious.  Service is extremely friendly and welcoming.

It looks like they're opening a larger space around the corner.  I'm happy for them, but I hope they don't lose their current space.  I like how it's tucked away between two houses.. definitely a neighborhood gem.  

I definitely want to get one of their rotating pizzas soon, probably to go so I can eat it along with one of my wines while binging Crazy Ex-Girlfriend on Netflix because I'm an introvert and that's what I do.
author: Vira P.

description: I love thin crust style pizzas with some fresh ingredients on top so my friends and I decided to order takeout from here so we can enjoy a relaxing Sunday dinner with great pizza and wine. We ordered the tomato, mozzarella, basil with anchovies and another one with pepperoni. They were absolutely delicious and the crust was perfect, the anchovies as topping complemented well on the pizza too. I would have given this place a 4 star but, our anchovies pizza seemed to have a missing slice on it? We kept wanting to think that maybe the pizza shrunk, but even the geometry of it confirmed that someone took a slice right out of our pizza...there is a picture of it that I uploaded in the photos section so you guys can maybe have another explanation for the missing section...I guess we should have checked in each box before just taking it home, but I think also, we should have expected better quality control. Anyway, I would definitely recommend this place again but hopefully this review will make people check their pizzas during takeout.
author: Nicole L.

description: Small dive, fantastic food. Get the "cheese salad" and split it for table to start. Save room for the delish dessert of the day. Great for lunch after visiting GG park, great value for the money.
author: Laura D.

description:
Really heartbroken here.

Pizzetta was an absolute 5 star joint for all the years I've lived in the neighborhood. I loved it to bits. It was at the top of my SF list. And I even would go as far as saying this was the best pizza I had had outside of Europe. I would go out of my way to bring friends and recommend it to them.  

But then sometime in the last few months they appear to have changed the crust recipe dramatically, reduced the size of the pies, and gotten less refined in their ingredient choices. Seems like a totally different set of people might be behind it. The first time we got these different pizzas we thought it was a fluke. But now two more tries later over the course of 6 weeks we can confirm the best pizza on the west coast appears to be gone for good.

In fairness, the pizzas there now are still a passable meal. You will think "oh, this is somewhere between fine and yum," especially if you hadn't had the former stuff. But if you were going there because someone told you it was amazing, or remember it being amazing yourself, be forewarned things have changed.

To Pizzetta: if you change things back I'll happily recant and resume sending all my friends your way.
author: Adam A.

description:
Cute and cozy. We were in the neighborhood and my boyfriend really wanted pizza! Found this place on yelp and we rushed over there because they were closing in 30 mins.

They had some empty tables so they sat us right away. We each picked a pizza and shared. The pizzas were really unique and yummy. I would definitely come back here but I don't think it's anything I would wait more than 20 mins for.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Daily starter is wonderful, we have two pizza and it is great.
This is lovely place to stay.
author: Ikea L.

description:
I love this pizza place. I order over the phone and it's ready in twenty minutes. That's roughly about how long it takes me to walk there anyway.

I especially enjoy their pizza (Tomato, Mozzarella, Basil 12.50 with Pepperoni 15.50) and their farm egg! Cost is average ~$18 (after tax) for your personal baked pizza. To be honest, I don't eat a whole lot but when I'm pretty hungry I can finish all but one piece of their pizza. If you are a hungry boy or girl that usually eat a lot I recommend ordering more than one pizza.

I tried their pizza with the ham in it and I didn't like it nearly as much as the Tomato, Mozzarella, Basil 12.50 with Pepperoni for $15.50. If you want to opt out of certain ingredients they are flexible too.

They are thin crusted and I LOVED the crunch. It's like eating toasted bread with the toppings that slid off of the slice that you just picked up. They don't overdo it with cheese and I love that! It's not super greasy and make you hate yourself after having just ate pizza.

If you want high-quality pizza that are not ready-made but made-to-order then this is the place for you! I'll be back for more!!!
author: Kimberly W.

description: I've had: Tony's, Capos, Little Star, De La Rosa, Patxis, Golden Boy, Gaspares, Delfina, North Beach,  Goat Hill, and many others. The San Marzano at Pizza 211 is the best. I've be fortunate to live within walking distance for the better part of 10 years. Love this tiny gem of a restaurant! Be prepared to wait on a busy day. Enjoy some wine or beer and one of their constantly changing Daily Starters.
author: Tyler S.

description:
I visited again recently and it's still a 5-star experience.

Delicious pizzas, excellent service, and dog-friendly (outdoor seating, anyway).
author: Charles R.

description:
Went here last night for dinner and got a delicious farm egg pizza!! Who knew eggs on pizza would taste good? I didn't until I tried Pizzetta. I normally don't like pizza crust but I ate all my crust here, it's perfect thin crispy pizza. Was a bit pricy, $17.95 for an average size pizza. 

The place is veryyyy tiny, seats probably 15ish people. It wasn't too chilly so we sat outside and there was heat lamps which felt great! The staff was very friendly, we called before to see if there was a wait and they said no so we walked over as fast as we could. Street parking available for those not as lucky people that can't walk here. Overall good local pizza spot.
author: Lauren M.

description: My boyfriend and I come here all the time! It's so close to the house. It's moving into a bigger location soon. We're so excited. But I should mention they should consider a local discount lol jk pushing my luck. We just order the pepperoni and the salad.
author: Sasha M.

description:
What's in a name?  Pizzetta 211 tells you what's on the menu, and the number on 23rd street that you can find the restaurant.  Clever eh?

The pizzetta's are good - as well as the wine.  I had the white anchovy - which is a high grade anchovy cured in a vinegar. Sofie had a rosemary pizzetta.  Both were good.  I had a glass of the Italian red - $10 for a small pour.

Tip: Buy the bottle for $30 if you want wine because you can get 10 of their $10 pours for that price.

This is a neighborhood "hole in the wall" place.  Rather charming - but rather costly.  The lunch was about $40 for us.
author: Steve S.

description: My absolute favorite neighborhood pizza place and one of my favorite restaurants in all of SF. The ambience is cozy and intimate. I recommend eating at the counter for an even more personable experience. The staff are all super friendly and cool.   The bacon and potato pizza that rotates off and on the menu is a MUST try! I've gone here for both lunch and for dinner, both great experiences. However, there is something special about this place in the evening. Makes a perfect date night! Can't wait to try their new sister restaurant right around the corner.
author: Christine C.

description:
This is one of my favourite spots in the city. Everything about this place is top notch--the pizza, salads and wine. It looks like they may be moving to a slightly bigger location close by and my hope is this doesn't affect what they do.
If you are in the Richmond and want pizza it doesn't get much better than this place.
author: Darren D.

description:
Oh. My. Pizza!!

I've had Pizzetta 211 in my bookmarks FOREVER, so I was so excited to give it a try. My friend and I came on a Wednesday night @ 7 p.m. and there was no line, and a table was just opening. Perfect! 

The server was really nice and attentive, but I kind of felt he was also a teensy tiny bit condescending. Maybe it was just me. Shrug. 

ANYWHOO, we each had a glass of wine and shared the charcuterie board. I forget what it all came with, but it was three kinds of meat (salami, prosciutto and one more), olives, pickled peppUers (spicy ones!), bread, and I believe honey djion mustard. The mustard was YUM. If they sold it, I'd buy a jar to take home haha

I had the San Marzano Tomato Sauce, Mascarpone, Wild Arugula, Olio Verde pizza and it was SO GOOD. I really wish it came with meat, or that there was the option to add meat =/ The tomato sauce is heavennnnnnn; it's ridiculously creamy and really gets you that nice tomato flavor without tasting kind of sour, if you get what I mean. The arugula on top was so fresh, crispy and crunchy. I believe there was also mozzarella on the pizza too. My friend had House Made Pork Sausage, Roasted Tomato Sauce, Red Onion, Caper Oil, Parmesan pizza and that was so good, too!

I'd definitely come early and come on a weekday to avoid a wait! Can't wait to come back and try their other pizzas.
author: Doris K.

description:
when it's time to pay, fold up your cash, stick it in the card swiper, & hand them the ipad back.

ffffin BOSSEST way to pay (http://bit.ly/2gEEbWF)

cook: "that's not how to use a square!"

yes it is, brah. yes it is.

made me sorely wish i had cash on me so i could've done the same thing as the ol lady.

y'all this whole place is epic:
sidemouth bro (ironically?) wearing a polo hat
beardman resembling one of my science school alums
dude who maybe maybe not had a role
gorge chick with clear frame eyeglasses
and to top it off manager looked like talking heads(!)

yeah the same talking heads that my esl thai frendo slayed in rockband

(^_^) Farm Egg Pizza $17.5 (http://bit.ly/2gV0QvV)
egg, ham, sweet potato, brussels sprout, crescenza
yes, yes, yes, yes, and yes

(-_^) Chicken Sage Sausage Pizza $16 (http://bit.ly/2g7g7Lu)
dat rubbery mozz doe
that was a compliment not a dis

get at least 2 pizzas per person. according to me.

quick cooking time.

dr seuss & silverstein books on the counter.

4 1/2 stars fun night i'll return.
author: Dan B.

description: Pizzeria 211 is maybe al little more expensive than your typical pizza place. But the higher price earns you a flavorful, satisfying meal that's equal (or better) than its competition. You'll always find a line of customers staking out the limited outdoor seating. Quality ingredients and preparation make for a pizza that's above the cut.
author: Thirsty C.

description:
I live so close to this place and I just tried it not too long ago! I can't believe how fresh and tasty these pizzas are! I love how it's seasonal and ingredients change on the menu often!

Cheese salad: 5/5: it was a pretty large salad with a great mix of cheese, olives and bread! I liked how everything worked well together, sometimes with salads it feels like it's lacking in something and this one was delicious! Well, if you like cheese that is! 

Farm egg pizza: 5/5: absolutely blown away, we finally tried the farm egg pizza that everyone raves about and it was delicious! The pizza had potato, bacon, lots of mozzarella cheese. It was the perfect balance. Didn't think potato would go well with it, but it was thinly sliced and tasted so good with the egg and cheese.

Curry pea pizza: 5/5: so good! It had a nice green curry sauce on the bottom, had some greens, peas and delicious mozzarella cheese on top! It was different but it was also delicious!

Definitely will be back here in the future to try more pizzas! One of my top choices for nearby pizza!

Total for 2: $50
author: Stella J.

description:
Practically closing my eyes as I'm about to inhale my slice of pizza, I open my eyes to find another table staring at me as I'm mid-bite. Uhh excuse me, please allow me to have some alone time with my pizza... but at the same time I wanted to say "yeah you should totally order this pizza, it's delicious, and I would probably be staring too!"

Winter version of the Farm egg pizza ooouu yeah that hit the pizza cravings. "Come to mama" was all I could think when I first laid my eyes on it. The crust is just so crisp and soft in the right areas and the combination of what is put on the pizza just works well together and is not exactly what I've had at other pizza places. It makes their menu choices stand out! 

Glad I came. Cute spot. I liked it :-)
author: Annie N.

description: Quaint neighborhood spot. Excellent thin crust pizza with friendly staff. We'll definitely be back,
author: Kip C.

description:
Such a cute little neighborhood spot, and undoubtedly comprised of a talented kitchen staff. Unfortunately, the waiter kind of ruined our experience, and given how expensive the food is, I doubt we'll be coming back. :/

We went on a Sunday around 6pm, just before the dinner rush. (I think we were second in line? Definitely not that busy.) It was our first visit, so we looked around for someone to talk to. We said hello to the man in the apron. He stared at us like we were crazy. "Can I help you?" he said coolly. I told him we'd like to eat (I mean, obviously, right?). He told us we'd need to wait. No big deal, we said.

He sat us at a table a few minutes later (not a clean one, though - not sure why, but he didn't wipe it off or set utensils before seating us). I told him we were ready to order, but we had a few questions. We asked how big the pizzettas were and what the appetizer of the day was. He sighed and curtly replied, "One pizzetta can feed one hungry person." No recommendations (again, this was our first visit). Okay, my friend said, we'll get two. When we flipped to the back of the menu to order some wine, he snapped, "Oh, you're 'READY' to order, huh?" (Wtf?)

He came back with our wine, and, eventually, our appetizer. I got the impression he was in a really bad mood. He asked us if we wanted an extra plate so we could split the appetizer, and when my friend said no, he rolled his eyes (!!!). I think he eventually realized he was out of line, because our busser ended up taking care of us for the rest of the meal.

Thankfully, the busser was awesome. He was so polite when bringing out our pizzettas, explaining what the ingredients were, wiping our table off for us, offering us more wine, etc. He was also the one who brought us our check. We did tip 20%, but I don't think it was an $80 well spent. I'm sure I'll get crucified for saying this, but it wasn't the best pizza I've had in my life. It wasn't *bad*, but it wasn't something I'd pick over Georgio's or Gaspare's. (It's also possible I was just turned off by the waiter.)

Oh well, I'm still glad we tried it. I'd honestly be willing to give it a second try, but I'd rather spend my money at a much friendlier establishment. (Thankfully, there are plenty of those in the Outer Richmond!)
author: L D.

description:
Pizzetta 211 is a teeny tiny adorable little hidden gem in the Outer Richmond. A friend who loves this restaurant recommended it to me, saying I would also love it and become obsessed. She was right! This place is a contender for the best pizza in SF!

Because of the small size of the place, wait times can be long. But we were lucky and only had to wait 10 minutes for a table. Our party of four decided to order wine and olives to start. Then we ordered four pizzas: 2 San Marzano pizzas, the Brussel Sprouts pizza (limited time pizza), and the Margarita pizza with added pepperoni. The pizzas were incredible! They had a delicious thin crispy crust, fresh ingredients, great flavor, and weren't at all greasy. The San Marzano was my fav of the night and possibly my fav pizza of all time!

After pizza, we all ordered coffees and one flourless chocolate cake to share for desert... wow, delicious! We ate the cake while enjoying our coffees. What a lovely way to end a truly enjoyable meal. We will definitely be back!
author: Ali M.

description:
Cutest little pizza place ever. I just moved down the street from this place and I'm super excited about it. My housemates and I wanted pizza so we ordered here. They told me it's amazing and it truly is. 

The pizza with pine nuts was amazing. I'll get it again soon! The cheese and crust was cooked to perfection. We ordered to go so we only went to pick it up. The place was super cozy and romantic. I will definitely be coming back. Inside it was super small; about 4-5 tables and a couple outside. The feel was super relaxing as well. 

This place is definitely a place to take a date, or if you live down the street like I do now! 5 stars for the service, atmosphere, and the food!
author: Lori R.

description:
I ate at Pizzetta 211 with my friend this afternoon after her meticulous yelping! We ordered the farm egg, amatriciana sauce, guanciale, smoked scamorza, and basil pizza ($17.50) to share and received after around 15 minutes. We were excited for those farm eggs and they did not disappoint! One of the eggs was more cooked than the other.. This might be on purpose however, because all of the other pictures of the farm egg pizzas have the two eggs cooked differently. As for the actual pizza, it was very good! The sauce was a little spicy and the guanciale (italian meat/salami from pork cheek) was very flavorful.... when we could find it. Unfortunately we felt like we barely got any meat, so that was a pretty big disappointment. I did like the thin and crispy crust though. 

The place is small so definitely try to come earlier or at least not during peak hours. It can probably only fit around 15 people at most. The price point is higher than your typical pizza, especially for a more personal size (10 inches). My stomach was content after eating half, but I could probably eat my own. I've heard good things about the rosemary and pine nuts pizza, maybe next time!
author: Tara A.

description:
Great small place to eat at. Came here this past sunday around 2 pm and were seated at the bar within 20 minutes. 

Food:

Started with the daily appetizer $9.50 which was toast with avocado and a sardine on top. This paired very well with a small arugula salad tossed in some sort of vinaigrette.

Ordered the farm egg pizza $17.50 that had some fingerling potatoes and prosciutto. The crust was thin and crunchy. The pizza overall was very well made and would probably order it again.

However the prices were up there and overall the price for a daily appetizer + pizza + tip came out to around $34 that still left me hungry.
author: Eric L.

description: I pass this spot often on my weekend bike ride and I've been meaning to come here for years. Luckily things haven't changed much there and it's far proximity may ensure things stay the same. The menu is updated weekly. One pizza per person seems the norm and probably the best way to avoid fights-- sharing only one may be tough here. We tried their unique farm egg, corn, shishito peppers, truffle pecorino cheese with roasted garlic panna. Though I am a firm believer all pizza must come with some sort of tomato, I did give this one a try because it sounded so damn good. It was. Our other pizza came with the classic San Marzano tomato sauce, mascarpone cheese and arugula. It was perfect: thin crust with a slight crisp and just the right amount of toppings. I could probably live on this. We added a little bit of chili oil just to spice things up a bit. For desert we scored their take on the classic panna cotta. This one had a slight, slight sour taste reminiscent of yoghurt and tastes a bit healthier than than a sibling version you may find in North Beach. The secret ingredient turned out to be buttermilk instead of heavy cream. Can't wait to venture here again-- worth the wait, just have a glass of pinot or some tea if it's cold out, which is a 50/50.
author: Brian J.

description:
This is a hidden gem in the Richmond neighborhood--they have 3 classic pizzas, and then rotate a few other selections bi-weekly. I tried one of the classics: San Marzano tomato sauce, mascarpone, wild arugula and olio verde. I've never had a mascarpone-base pizza before, and I was pleasantly surprised. It complimented the sweetness of the San Marzano tomatoes really well.

The restaurant is really small, but it's nice to be able to see your food being made. There's also a cool little library at the bar, where you can do light reading while waiting for your food.
author: Benjamin A.

description:
I thought pizza was just an OK Thing (I know, I know) but wowww. We got 6 pizzas to go for a party, I don't know which ones we got, but there's one with eggs on top and it is the very thing I will be dreaming of tonight. Only got one slice...guess I gotta go visit soon! 

Only downside: they canceled our initial order after 30+ minutes in an email because they didn't have a driver on staff. We reordered and picked up, but it was a bummer to have to wait that long.
author: Jasmine G.

description: The pizzas are imaginitive and delicious. It's not large but packed with flavor. The staff are warm and accommodating to any size group.
author: Emilee M.

description: Best italian wedding soup I've ever had. Pizza was delicious. Cozy atmosphere. Extremely friendly staff. Will be back!
author: Josh P.

description:
Food: 
They always have a few specialty pizzas that change up every two weeks. This is cool so that there's variety, but sad because they were so good; I would have loved to go back and order them again. Kind of pricey, but they use very creative ingredients like purple potatoes, Brussel sprouts, and a variety of cheeses. The crust is thin and each pizza is personal-sized. We ordered one pizza per person and shared. We did try one of the regular pizzas with rosemary and pine nuts--very yummy. 

Service: 
This varied depending on who we dealt with. One man was not very friendly, basically telling us to wait outside almost as soon as we walked in, but we had ordered to-go and needed to pay. Meanwhile, another man was calling one of us over to pay so it was very confusing. 

They told us our pizza would be ready 20 minutes after we called and even gave us a specific time. We arrived 10 minutes later than that time, and the pizzas still weren't ready. After waiting outside in the very chilly evening during winter, someone came out to tell us that one of our pizzas didn't make it onto the ticket so they were just starting it then. 

Eventually, a nice woman came out to ask if we drove because if so, we could wait in the car and double park to wait, then she'd bring our pizzas to the car. That was so nice of her. 

Ambiance: 
Super tiny restaurant. They had about 5 tables. Each table would comfortably fit 2 people, but some had 4 huddled around it. So if you're not comfortable with a tight eating situation, opt to get it as takeout. Granted, the weather was really, really cold that night so the three heated tables they had outside still weren't usable. If those could be used it would alleviate the cramped conditions a bit, but not by much. So if you have more than 3-4 people and don't want to eat outside, be prepared to wait.
author: Susan G.

description: Amazing pizza, super friendly service and arguably the coziest restaurant atmosphere in SF.
author: Daniel H.

description: I LOVE this place. Adorable cozy place that is great for a date night. The inside decor is perfect and I really love the outside lights above the tree. Their pizzas are incredible and include seasonal produce, and I was thrilled with the well put together cheese platter. The desserts were wonderful as well and had that homemade taste. Now that we live within walking distance, we will be back all the time.
author: ashley d.

description: For $17 plus dollars 6 pieces among 2 ppl, I'd expect the "pizetta"they advertise on the menu to be what they say it is. Came here for lunch on a Monday  no wait. I can only say this because I sat at the bar and watched them make the pizza. Let's be honest- deeply disappointed by the quality of the ingredients they used. The "prosciutto" was sliced up deli ham, the "pine nuts" was broken up pieces of almond, and that egg was definitely not from the "farm". If they're trying to appeal to the hipster bourgeois, do yourself a favor and don't bs someone that knows how to identify what ingredients look like.
author: Kai A.

description: Have been waiting for years to stop by here. Did not disappoint. Superb appetizers and great artisinal pizza. And who would would have thought great desserts as well!..........................
author: Fred M.

description: Ooo Amazing! Just fallen love with their pizzas !II tried San Marzano and Roasted Asparagus!Pizza base is excellent !Mascarpone cream cheese and fresh wild arugula is no doubt win my heart!what a balanced taste they made over the pizza! O ya I can't deny their service and interior which is also an eye/heart candy  Thank you team Pizzetta for increase my love for pizza .
author: Malobika R.

description:
I am always on the search for the best pizza spots in San Francisco. I decided to try out Pizzetta 211 on a whim while in the Richmond District. The restaurant is quite small and may fit no more than maybe 15 people at a given time. It's a bit concealed and sandwiched between residences in the Richmond, so I thought that was kind of a cool aspect of this place.

Food: 
I ordered 2 pizzas, (shared between 2 people)

Farm Egg, Fingerling Potato, Chard, Bacon             17.50

Tomato, Mozzarella, Basil 12.50 with Pepperoni        15.50

The pizzas are definitely on the smaller side, so if you're into hearty, heavy pizza this restaurant will not be ideal for you. I finished an entire pizza by myself, so yeah it was more like a personal pizza for me (keep in mind that I am indeed a light eater). I really did enjoy their regular pepperoni pizza, but I'm not sure it was extraordinary. I was so hungry by the time we got our food that I did devour it quite quickly. 

Service:
There is an outrageous wait. Because the restaurant is so tiny, be prepared to wait 1+ hours, especially during dinner time. We arrived at 6pm on a Saturday night and didn't get seated until around 7:15pm. Yeah, pretty crazy wait. So if you want to get seated right away maybe try avoiding the dinner rush; though, this place is so popular I bet there's always a wait. I think if I had been starving I would've been incredibly annoyed at the wait and probably left. An hour is quite a wait. 

There was only one girl waitressing and she did a great job at multitasking; she seated people, brought their food, took orders, signed people on the wait list...she did it all. She seemed a bit overwhelmed at times though making it easy for her to forget about people waiting for tables.

Atmosphere:
Quaint, cozy, charming. Again, it's not very spacious inside, meaning you'll almost be elbow to elbow with the table next to you. Not sure if that's my jam, but whatevs. Overall it's got a nice 'hole in the wall' kinda ambience. I'm not sure I'd be back due to the wait and the pretty good, but not incredible pizza.
author: Stefany Z.

description:
So, so good!!! Delicious, unique flavor combinations in a quaint, tiny neighborhoody restaurant.  There's usually a wait due to the teeny size, but it's so worth the wait.  Pizzas are on the small side, so we just order more pizzas to make up for that.  Problem solved.

One of the best pizza joints in the city!
author: Kim W.

description: Nice neighborhood joint! Super small interior with a couple of outdoor spots. We arrived around 1 on a Saturday and only had to wait 10 minutes or so for a table. Smallish menu (perhaps 7-8 pizzas, 5-6 appetizers, a few desserts). Good wine and beer list. Solid thin-crust pizza, friendly and attentive service. Would return again if I was in the area.
author: Jason C.

description: Adorably cozy (just like so many tiny New York restaurants I've known and loved) with all around spectacular food and a well curated beer list (wine as well!) Even though there's only enough space for maybe 20 max guests at a time, they fit our group of 5 in outside and we were perfectly comfy under the heat lamp. The cheese plate was amazing and of course the pizza is bomb, but I was personally floored by the gloriousness of their olive oil cake: light but rich, super moist with a delicious touch of crunch in the deep dark toast of the exterior. Also their teeny tiny bathroom is the cutest thing I have ever seen, with a little tv installed with scenes of Italy playing on loop along with ambient music, positioned over the toilet so those using it standing up, I assume, can watch (I felt a little jealous of men in this moment.) sort of wanted to just hang out in the bathroom as a result, hah. If you can make it over here and you're a party of two and especially if you are on a date and want somewhere charming and intimate, this is the move. Oh: and it's not too expensive! Double yay.
author: Nicole M.

description: Best pizza.. they have very savory crust nice and small great service I highly recommend to come here and get some delicious pizza
author: Joaquin J.

description: We tried Pizzetta 211 because it had great reviews. Little did we know it would be the most underwhelming bougie experience. This place was built for people that don't care about their money because at $17 for a personal pizza with a flake- cracker like crust and spots of cheese, you clearly have to be careless about spending money. Made for people that like Trader Joe's frozen pizza. The service was nice but when I asked about ranch he scoffed and looked at us and said what's that. It was weird to think that a pizza place didn't have one of the most used condiments.  10/10 would not come back again, save you're money and just go to Trader Joe's.
author: Landon R.

description: On the pricy side. The quality of ingredients was very good, I enjoyed the thin crispy crust and the lightness of the pizza. A lot of lower quality pizzas tend to be heavy and oily. However, I thought that the marinara sauce could have been more exciting and while the flavor combinations provided were good, they were not different from what other places have to offer.
author: Ian L.

description: My favorite neighborhood pizza place and one of my favorite pizza places in SF. Pizzas here are thin crust, almost like a flatbread/cracker. The menu is small but it changes so you get to try new pizzas the next time you come back. Ingredients are fresh every time! Only bad thing is that there's often a wait Bc the place is small, so just allow your mind and body to be prepared (dress warmly) for a wait!
author: Iris H.

description: Best service. Best pizza. Best ambiance. If I lived closer I'd want to go everyday. It's a hidden gem. Seriously I've been to all the greatest spots in little Italy and this takes the cake. So happy I found it!
author: K T.

description:
This place is a total threat to my paltry teacher's salary--I'm dog-sitting dangerously close by. Great tiny bistro currently ideal for the odd lovely day in the Outer Richmond--I'm thrilled to see that they're expanding into the beautiful, brightly lit corner space where it will be reliably pleasant to be year-round. 

Tantalizing menu--it's great that it rotates bi-weekly. The eggplant and burrata pie is excellent--the eggplant was well-breaded and still really moist. Another eggplant favorite was the eggplant, feta, harissa and mint. Great tomato and mascarpone pie too. Thin crust, judicious mix of toppings and flavors on each pie. Super friendly staff.
author: X-topher B.

description:
If you are considering this place just don't. They are taking your money and giving you a tiny pizza that ticks you off. 

However if you are about that good for you. 

Way to much money. Robbery! 

I have never been so ticked off in my life. Lol 

Just don't. You will be ticked off also.
author: Jay C.

description:
Friendliest waitstaff, EVER!

Pizzas are a bit different from the SF-esque, neopolitan with a slight-sourdough crust that you find everywhere these days. Instead, it seems to have more like a "farm to table" focus, with fresh vegetable-focused toppings, and the crust has less of that wood-fired, charred flavor and seems to be a bit sweeter (read: not sourdough) compared to other fancy pizza joints around here. That's not a bad thing by any means, and in fact, they do a pretty good job.

The salad, unfortunately, was a bit overpriced.. but the pizza was great!
author: Kazu O.

description: Best pizza I think i've ever had. The wait was long but I actually didn't have to wait myself so this may be a little bit biased. It was over an hour wait on Saturday night for a table for 5. They have rotator and staple pizzas and my favorites were the staples. Classic Mozzarella, tomato and basil.
author: Michael P.

description:
I would eat here everyday if I could. If they ever take that mascarpone pizza off the menu, I will honestly have a melt-down. I dream about that pizza... but everything I've tried here is amazing, so just order more than you think is appropriate.

Don't come with a group and dress warm in case you sit outside (they have blankies tho & heaters too!).
author: Brittany L.

description:
Pizzetta 211 is a hidden little (quite literally) restaurant in Outer Richmond. Found the restaurant after finishing a hike down to Baker's beach and needing to refuel with some pizza.  The restaurant is super tiny-- they could probably fit a party of max 9 people and would have only 2 more indoor tables left. If you come outside of peak hours, you're more likely to avoid a wait/ get a table. 

The pizzas are made on a nice thin crispy crust-- you could probably finish a whole one if you were pretty hungry. Otherwise, they can be shared with 2 people. We tried the eggplant pizza and the carnitas pizza that comes with two farm eggs, dollops of guac, and corn. It was my first time getting in on the eggs on pizza hype and I dig it. It's so satisfying to cut into a sunny side up egg and watch that yolk ooze on to your pizza. I love eggs and I love pizza and the two together are fantastic. This pizza had a unique combination of toppings which I really enjoyed and would recommend trying this one.

The eggplant pizza was good as well and had a bit of a curried flavor to it-- good option if you are vegetarian. The large chunks of creamy burrata went perfectly with the eggplant.

 Both of these pizzas are on their rotating menu so I'm glad we got to try them. I had to knock a star off because the place is just so tiny. The dining experience isn't the best as you have to keep getting up and moving your chair to let other patrons move around. If you can get take out, I'd recommend doing that. I also though the price was a bit steep for the size of the pizza and the amount of toppings ($16-$17.50), but hey you gotta treat yourself sometimes!

Definitely worth checking it out if you're in the hood.
author: Renu A.

description:
A cute, tiny pizza shop! When I say tiny, I mean TINY, pizza shop with its tables squished together. The place gives off a chill, relaxing vibe and the servers are friendly. I've only been here two times and was lucky enough to not have to wait - both times on a weeknight, early evening (around 6PM - 7PM). There's some seating inside (around 4 tables), bar stools, and a few tables outside. 

The restaurant has a small menu, but I believe the pizza choices change seasonally. Pizzas are thin crust, six slices, and fresh! The flavors aren't heavy or overwhelmed with sauce. I'd say that one pizza would be good enough per person. My boyfriend and I shared two different kinds of pizzas and our stomachs were content afterward. 

I highly recommend trying the Farm Egg Pizza!
author: Kristal D.

description: Closed Tuesdays! I came with a party of 7 which is way too large for a place like this. I noticed that a lot of people ordered take-out. Luckily, we came early and we were able to piece together 3-4 tables outdoors for some united seating. There are two outdoor heat lamps so that was very nice. The interior of the shop is tiny so this is not a great option for large parties. My family and I tried the arugula salad with crunchy fried rice pieces and candied nuts. It was delicious but small (enough for 1-2 people). We also had the cheeseboard which came with some Spanish cheese, olives and bread. They have staple pizzas as well as seasonal/specials. We tried a Farm pizza (Egg, House Made Pork Sausage Bolognese, Crescenza, Capers, Parmesan) for $17.50, a Rosemary pizza (with Fiore Sardo Cheese, Pine Nuts) for $14.50, and a Mortadella pizza (with Provolone, Pickled Goat Horn Peppers, Dijon Mustard, Tapenade) for $16. All of the pizzas were unique and delicious. The best part of the pizza is the definitely the thin/crispy crust. I felt like the waiter was a little impatient with our party (maybe because we were a larger party). They offer drinks and blankets outside with a bench/table around an outdoor tree for those waiting for a table.
author: Brenda L.

description:
The vibe in the place was very chill and calm. 
There is nothing wrong with the staff(they were nice and respectful), but, being a native Italian, I can tell you that on one of the pizzas the crust was just a bit too crunchy. My pizza was just perfect, but my dad's was too hard for my taste. 

Overall, I loved the place and food. 4 star for sure.
author: Lorenzo S.

description:
Pizzetta 211, home to some of the best pizza in San Francisco, thankfully hidden away from the hype and crowds in a corner of the Outer Richmond. 

I've wanted to try Pizzetta for years and finally made it here this weekend after my boyfriend moved within 2.5 blocks (best aspect of his new place). We walked over for a late dinner at 8:35 p.m. or so and were seated right away outside under a deliciously warm heating lamp. They close at 9 p.m. but as long as you're seated or even on the wait list before at by 9 p.m., you'll be served.

We tried the field green salad to start -- basic, but great dressing.

Next up: those damn pizzettas. Our server told us that half of the six pizzettas listed rotate, and the others are ones they've served for something like 17 years. 
We tried two of the rotating ones, though I wish we had dabbled in the OG 'zas. There's aways next time.

HIGHLY recommend the prosciutto cotto with gruyere, chives, whole grain mustard (trust them, it's incredible) topped with two luscious fried farm eggs. The other one we tried -- housemade pork sausage, roasted tomato sauce, baby kale, shaved parmesan -- was equally delicious. Great flavor combinations, fresh ingredients, thin crust, could have eaten a thousand slices. I'm salivating just thinking about it.

Pizzetta means "little pizza" so each is smaller than a typical pizza (Our waiter described the size as enough for "one very hungry adult.") Great for sharing and trying multiple pizzas.

Can't wait for my next Pizzetta experience.
author: Elena K.

description: Game changer. Best pizza I've had. Small place with limited choices but everything was amazing. Squash and eggs are something I've never had on a pizza but it was amazing. Egg pizzeta was like nothing I've had before. Small spot though you'll end up waiting a while. 4 tables on the inside.
author: Christopher K.

description: Wow. Best not only pizza but food I've had in a LONG time. I can't wait to go here again. Had the kale salad special, shared two pizzas - the San marzano/mascarpone/arugula one and the pine nuts/rosemary one. Delish for dessert had a lemon ricotta pound cake toasted in the oven with huckleberry compote and fresh whipped cream. Even the wine was exceptional. It's a must-go!
author: sara z.

description: This is my new favorite restaurant & it's vegetarian friendly!  We ordered their 2 daily specials for starters:  1) purple cauliflower salad w/ greens, farro, chopped almonds & creamy dressing, 2) sautéed broccolini w/ croutons & olive oil; for our main dish, we got 2 Pizzettas:  1)farm egg, mix mushroom, spinach & ricotta cheese; 2)margherita.  Everything was so fresh & delicious!  I highly recommend Pizzetta 211.  I bet you would want to come back for more once you get a taste of their delicious specials & pizzettas!
author: Ann E.

description:
We stumbled upon this cozy pizza joint and we have no regrets. 

I called beforehand and the woman told me that it would've been a 30 minute wait. We rushed over and put our name down and we became 4th on the list. The host was really nice and offered us the menu and drink options. I ordered an IPA and it was smooth and bold with a tang. We enjoyed our drinks outside on the seating that was provided around the tree, where we gazed at the tree lighting and waited.

We were seated at the bar in less than 30 minutes and had front row seats to see how the pizzas were made. It was amazing that they make the pizzas then and there as you order them. We started with a cauliflower salad, and had the Farm Egg pizza, and Hen of the Woods Mushroom pizza. I enjoyed the texture and nuts from the cauliflower salad but the dressing was thick and strong. The Farm Egg pizza had 2 eggs cracked on top and I thought that was an interesting touch but it was surprisingly bland to me. There wasn't a "wow" factor. But the Mushroom pizza... WHOA. This one definitely made our eyes wide. There were a perfect amount of mushrooms on top of the thin slice pizza, that every bite just tasted like mushroom heaven. The cheese was a good glue for the combination and I could not have been happier.

The atmosphere is small and very romantic, although there weren't many couples that came by. The service is really friendly and attentive if you wanted their attention. They are a small joint and they work really fast and hard for people to be seated and for people to get their to-go orders tentatively. I was really happy with my experience and will definitely return again.
author: Linda K.

description: Wow. The pizza is so good. I just ate some for breakfast. We had the butternut squash special and it was hands down one of the best thin crust pizzas we've ever had. Bravo!
author: Jason P.

description: Great pizza and amazing staff.  As pointed out by a lot of reviews, it's a small space with limited seating.  But it's absolutely worth it.  One of our go to places when we're in the City.
author: Tom N.

description:
This spot is tiny and wonderful. The food is just as amazing as the staff. I recommend getting there early or going on a bit odder of a day to get in. There is barely any seating and you for sure will be seated close to someone else and it's a bit funky. 

Our server was super helpful walking us through the menu and recommending an amazing pizza and wine. 

I left the meal extremely happy and cannot wait to be back. Hope to update my review closer to my visit as it was a while ago since I visited.
author: A R.

description: Worth the wait, worth the carbs, worth everything. The San Marzano is just heaven. There's no other way to describe it. Stop reading reviews and just go.
author: Christa C.

description: Extraordinarily cozy. Dim, warm lighting. Relaxed and casual, yet special and cared-for. Top notch thin crust pizzas with vibrant toppings. Hip, no-bullshit pizzamakers. One of the best atmospheres in San Francisco.
author: Wiley W.

description: Yummy personal-ish size pizzas. Limited seating but they offer takeout. I called ahead for a couple of pizzas and they were ready in 20min, so not a long wait time.
author: Dejana B.

description:
Cute little place hidden in the neighborhood. I might have driven by numerous times or walk right past by it without even realizing it was there. My sister told me to check out this place if it's comparable to Firehouse Pizza. Firehouse Pizza is a block from here and we love that place!

You won't find your usual pepperoni and cheese pizzas here, but farm eggs, wild arugula and margaritas as pizza toppings. The flavor is there, the choices are unique, and the ingredients are fresh.
