All the pizzas we ordered were delicious. However, the price is pretty hefty for a personalized sized pizza, especially for a thin crust.  With 4 pies, my boys were still hungry for more. We went home, digging through the pantry for more food.
author: Em T.

description: This is my favorite pizza in SF. The Rosemary pizza is amazing and the appetizers and deserts are always great too.
author: Derek I.

description:
Start with, Love the neighborhood small business vibe. 
Once we got there we were attended and asked if we wanted to wait for a table or sit at there counter. 
We decided to wait. There place is small, looks like 15 people can sit inside and they have about 2 to 3 small round 2 seat tables  outside and a really cute bench to wait. 
1st started with 
Field salad, all greens and balsamic vinaigrette dressing, YUMM ! Never have I ate a salad simple with so much flavor. 
2ed 
Pepperoni pizza, delicious! Looked like fresh pepperoni with cheese tomato sauce and the bread was thin crust . 

We only had water with our meals, 
they offer wine, beer, and soda drinks.
author: Jesse M.

description:
My favorite pizza place for eat in, or take out!
They are almost always very quick with take out orders, and it tastes just so good!!

Eating in is always nice too! They have heat lamps outside to keep your warm. Although the place is tiny the food makes up for it. I love trying the cheese board, and getting my regular San Marzano pizza!

*Be sure to use the bathroom, it is very cool inside! There is a tiny movie screen playing old time movies!
author: Larissa S.

description: Came here for a quick snack, and it was awesome! We split the pizza with house made pork sausage. The crust was thin and crispy, and the toppings all tasted very fresh. One person can easily finish one of these pizzas to make it a meal.  Service was also great- everyone was really friendly and took good care of us! Only reason it's not 5 stars is it is a little pricey. Overall, amazingly fresh and tasty, and I will definitely be coming back!
author: Rachel D.

description:
The roommate isn't a fan of frou frou pizzas. He'd rather have a good Round Table pie versus an artisan pie from some fancy pizza place. Me? I can get down with a good slice of Round Table, but I do love artisan pizzas as well. Arugula on top? Yes please! Farm egg too? Give it to me! Finally in August 2013, the roommate agreed to try Pizzetta 211. We got take out.

*San marzano tomato sauce, mascarpone, wild arugula, olio verde ($14.95)
I love pies with arugula on top so I couldn't resist ordering this. The crust was nice and thin. The sauce showcased the sweetness of the tomatoes and contrasted the mascarpone well. A great simple pizza!

*Farm egg, bacon, early girl tomato, collard green, gruyere ($15.95)
Another thing I can't resist?! Topping a pizza with egg! The egg added a nice creaminess to the bacon, greens and gruyere cheese. And the slight sweetness and acidity from the tomato cut into the richness well. Yum!

I had a hard time deciding what I wanted to order when looking through all the pizzas. I really wanted to order like 3 or 4 different ones, but I restrained myself. Glad Pizzetta 211 is so close to home. I can drop by again to try more pizzas!
author: Elena N.

description:
Giving 1 star because I actually never got to eat the food. My bitterness below: 

Reviews looked great so we were really excited. We got there and put our name on the list for 2 people. At that point the server/host said it would be from anywhere from 20min-hour, which is fine because it's a super tiny place (probably sits 15-20 people tops) so we wanted to wait.

So we waited, and waited, and waited, and waited. And hour went by and some people left the bar, so we thought we would be next, but then 3 'new' people arrived and the server/host told them the bar was available, SO THEY WALKED RIGHT IN AND SAT DOWN.

We were pissed. Here we are thinking the bar was part of the seating since it was so small and waiting patiently for them to seat us, but they never asked us if we wanted to sit at the bar! We were only 2 people and would have been more than happy to sit at the bar. HOW RUDE.

We were so irritated we LEFT. Walked to another restaurant shaking our heads.
author: Rachel T.

description: Good pizza but not amazing.  Small place, nice vibe but staff all seemed a little annoyed about something.  My girlfriend and I ordered two margarita style pizza's.  Bonus point for Arcade Fire playing in the background
author: Joe R.

description:
Went here for the 1st time with my husband tonight before a NYE party and we both were very satisfied! Pizza was yummy and hot, service was great, place was cute and people were friendly. We sat outside under the heater since it was packed inside, but no complaints. 

We had the arugula pizza with red sauce and the pine nuts pizza. Both were delicious!! Pretty awesome neighborhood pizza spot.
author: Shabana B.

description: Delicious food and a great atmosphere -- I went for an early Saturday lunch. We split a tarting with farm fresh eggs, arugula, and herbs. Then I had the pepperoni pizza.
author: Natalie H.

description: One of the best meals end to end I've had in SF. Pizza is outstanding. Make sure you get the flourless chocolate cake for dessert too!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I've grown up in the neighborhood so I frequently pass this place and all I have to say is...I regret not trying this place sooner. I got the Farm Egg, Fingerling Potato, Bacon, White Cheddar, Creme Fraiche, Chives Pizza & it is definitely one of the best quality pizzas I've ever had. The flavors complement each other incredibly well & i like that the crust is fairly thin. It's not the cheapest place for a pizza, priced at $17.50, but you're definitely getting what you pay for & it is absolutely worth it.

Seating here is scarce & I've seen it get incredibly crowded, luckily I live in the neighborhood so I ordered for take out & they were ready in 10 minutes!
author: Nicole L.

description: Wonderful! Everything we tried in this cozy pizzeria was absolutely wonderful. Wine is priced well per bottle, the pizzas are awesome, the cheese salad offered 2 types, different, but equally delicious. So good, we can't wait to go back soon.
author: Brianna S.

description: Great outdoor lunch spot with my dog before heading to golden gate park. Pizza and burrata  salad are good. Casual neighborhood spot with creative menu. Parking not easy to find though.
author: Queeny C.

description:
I came by a few weeks ago. The pictures of the pizza here convinced me, especially the farm egg pizza. They change up the menu every few weeks. The pizzas itself were delicious and the focus was more so on the ingredients then just the cheese. If you want a darn good pizza with darn good ingredients this is the place. It's quite small inside, but fortunately it doesn't feel warm or stuffy by the ovens.

I docked a few stars because our waiter was rude and probably shouldn't perform a job that involves interacting with people. He said something rude to me and I overheard him say a snark comment to a couple at the table next to us. 

Anyway, good pizza!
author: Micki H.

description: Really enjoyed their pizza! The dessert is maybe even better, it's hard to say.. The space being limited is the only difficult part of the whole experience but I'll be back for sure.
author: Vickay I.

description:
Such a cute little surprise in the middle of the block.

Highly recommend tasting the Farm Egg at least once.
author: Timothy N.

description:
Love tiny spots like this in the city.  I'd definitely recommend getting here when it opens though (especially if you have kids).  We got here a little before 5 (when it opened) and got the last seat to fit four.  The meal was awesome though.  We got the olives and organic green salad to start.  We got two pizzas - the rosemary one and the prosciutto one.  I've never had rosemary on a pizza before and it was subtle but delicious.

Great neighborhood pizza spot.
author: Blake B.

description:
The teeniest tiniest pizza place with some seriously delicious pie. 

We came on a Saturday night but surprisingly didn't have to wait that long for a table. Sure, 3 of us had to cram around a tiny table top but we did it. We ordered 2 pizzas amongst us to share--the margarita and the farm egg, asparagus, bacon, and fontina with lemon. OH EMZ. This pizza was a game changer. Great flavors and textures (a bit of crunch from the asparagus, gooey egg yolk, etc). The menu rotates regularly so this one might not be on the menu should you go but I highly recommend it if you see it. The margarita was also great. Simple but fresh. 

Paired with some great wine and you have yourself one tasty, seasonal meal.
author: Annette J.

description: I'm honestly astonished at how high the ratings for this restaurant are. The pizza is... fine. We ordered the farm egg pizza and the mascarpone. Mascarpone was decent but the sauce on the farm egg pizza was strange-- tasted almost like salsa. I was pretty underwhelmed. On top of that the food is way over priced for what they're serving. Two tiny pizzas for nearly $40. I also ordered a glass of rosé and the pour was pathetically stingy for $10.50. You can find the same quality or better at a lower price elsewhere.
author: Carson S.

description:
There's sure to be a wait for a table at this microscopic pizza joint, but order a glass of vino and perch outside on the footpath while you wait for your name to be called. It will be worth the wait I assure you.

The menu is simple, seasonal and enticing. Point wildly at a selection of goodies and share amongst your friends. Everything is made with care and beautifully presented, wine served in tumblers and the vibe perfectly relaxed and a little ramshackle. My idea of the perfect pizza venue.
author: Tresna L.

description: Although there is not much seating they do the best they can to get everyone at a table as soon as possible, and let you order wine while you are waiting!  We often get our pizzas to go, as well.  All of the pizzas are great, but whichever one has the fried egg on top is a must!
author: Kate T.

description: Very nice and cozy place with delicious food and surprisingly various and interesting starters. I just wish they had more space :-) Great place, great stuff! My family adores it!
author: Katerina K.

description: Great ambience, feels European, small, fresh rotating menu. Inside or outside seating, can't say enough, love.
author: Ryan G.

description:
Really awesome neighborhood spot :) The pizza is delicious!
Cracker thin crust and toppings/combos are on point.
Place is small- 4 inside tables, 4 bar seats, 4 outside tables so be prepared to wait during peak hours. They don't take reservations.
Seasonal menu so pizzas and apps rotate, can't wait to try this place again!

They take credit cards now via Square.
author: Angela D.

description: You can never go wrong with pizza. This place is small, but mighty. Their pizzas are unique and incredibly flavorful. My favorite pizza is the San Marzano tomato. It's so simple and extremely delicious. The salads are refreshing. Generally a good selection of beer.
author: Sarah S.

description: Fantastic pizza! The special salad (cauliflower, farro and toasted nuts) was so delicious, we ordered it twice. We wanted to order dessert but we were too full, maybe next time. The location is tiny but we were still seated in a timely manner. I highly recommend!
author: Espie M.

description: Try the San Marzano. I've never had a pizza like that in my life. The white sauce and red sauce was amazing. Unique flavor and tasted very fresh and homemade. The crust had a perfect crunch but softness to it as well. It's easy to pass by this place. Don't miss this opportunity.
author: Summer D.

description: Giving 5 stars to this Pizzetta. Very recommendable to my friends and family.
author: Mega Team R.

description: Hands down favorite pizza place ever! The menu is always changing so you never know what you're in store for but they never disappointed. Highly recommend making the trip.
author: Hedieh Z.

description:
This place is quickly becoming one of my favorite restaurants. This SMALL cozy place is very intimate with an open kitchen. Servers are always accessible and very friendly. There will be a wait, but it is worth it. 

They have a menu that changes every few weeks. Each list of pizzas has something for everyone. Each pizza that I've ordered has been just incredible. Flavors that have not been put together, definitely not on a pizza are presented to you and every time, they give me a new reason to wake up in the morning. Each flavor has its own place and works its way around your mouth in a way I've not consistently found. It all starts with the crust which is thin, crunchy, and lightly salted. It is a great vehicle to transport deliciousness into your mouth. 

If you like food, do yourself a favor and wait in line here to get their pizza.
author: Bryant C.

description: We had the cheeseboard, tomato basil pizza, and chocolate cake--- it was great! Service was a bit slower than ideal as I often had to ask for napkins, extra bread, and water. Overall I would come back!
author: Ivonne M.

description: Don't bother going, totally unfriendly service. Joint forgot customers pays the bills.
author: Wellington Y.

description: Closed for maintenance !?! Man, nothing was said about this plan or closure online or on their voicemail message when I called today. Came in from out of town to try out Pizza 211 and found sign on door :/ = closed.
author: Lauren S.

description:
I almost feel guilty writing a review, because I don't want to tell anybody about this place. I wanted it to be all mine. ;) I'm not sure if I would call it a hidden gem, because obviously a lot of people know about it, but it definitely has the feel of a discrete restaurant that nobody should know about - and it's awesome. It is located in a neighborhood, doesn't have any signs that mark where it is, and it is very, very small. I went to here with my family and we ordered two pizzas and a salad. We dined alfresco and really enjoyed our evening with good food on a quiet neighborhood street.

Everything we had on the menu was awesome. The pizzas were delicious. We got a plain cheese pizza and the bacon potato pizza. The crust is perfectly done. The entire product was very tasty.

A little warning, the pizzas are not very big and it's relatively expensive, $15-$20 per pizza. We had to eat again later that night because we were hungry.

Another warning is that the seating is very limited and you won't want to get there with your full party or you cannot be seated.

The service was very good. There was one waitress for the entire restaurant and had no problems.
author: David S.

description:
As said by my boyfriend on our last (out of many) dining experiences at Pizzetta 211, "This place is perfection." Everything about it creates a memorable dining experience - the homey chic atmosphere, the laid-back owner who alway exudes calm hospitality (with a little sass) no matter how crowded it is (and how eager/impatient the diners are), and obviously, the food. 

The pizzas are out of this world - the interesting rotating specials and delightfully delicious and simple constants. Each pizza is artfully crafted so that every slice contains the exact right amount of every ingredient to ensure that each bite contains the perfect combination of flavors. The crust is thin and holds up nicely to the ingredients on top, but has just a little doughy chew and is flavorful and satisfying in its own right. I am not a dessert person and I rarely like restaurant desserts. This place is the exception- we always order dessert - the specials are seasonal (always accompanied by fresh cream whipped by hand) and the constants (flourless chocolate cake, etc.) are also delicious.

Go. You won't regret it. Everything is thoughtfully crafted - so much care in this food and the experience.
author: Celeste B.

description: Okay, so i'll admit my pizza palette wasn't that great before - I considered Pizza Hut stuffed crust pan pizza the height of pizza deliciousness. I've been coming around to thin style pizza since trying a really good place in New York. Pizzetta has officially converted me. ITS SO GOOD!!! Oh my god I just had this yesterday and I want it again. I have a big appetite so 1 isn't enough, if there are 2 of you, 3 pizzas is perfect. Go for classic margherita and or pepperoni.
author: Eva C.

description: Absolutely the finest thin crust pizza in San Francisco.  I've been enjoying them for several years and have never been disappointed. Get there when they open or expect to wait.  It is the tiniest of restaurants with only 4 inside tables and four outside ones (heaters above are usually needed).  The pizzas vary from day to day while some are always on the menu. Salads and desserts are daily specials.  Parking can be a real bear. I envy those who live in the neighborhood!
author: Kristina H.

description:
Nice peeps, very little space, especially for the hearty prices. The soup, a thin bowl at 9.50, was the best thing served. I jokingly told one of the wait staff that their salad was the best pizza I have eaten of late! I screwed up - I should have ordered red sauce on the pie. Not worth the hype this day, hope to try again.

Maybe the crust will be like Delfina's.
author: Willi P.

description: Their pizza is sooo good . I mean I have been to Italy and had authentic Italian pizza and this is the closest to it here in SF. I just had the pizza to go but I couldn't resist it and had it just outside the restaurant near the tree with the  a glass of red wine .The size is small even for one if you're very hungry and having just a pizza but it's worth it .
author: Ani D.

description: Always has been the perfect small, cozy, intimate neighborhood pizza experience. The pizzas are imaginitive and tasty. The crust is nothing short of perfect. Cutest little pizza place ever. I just moved down the street from this place and I'm super excited about it.
author: Elijah N.

description: They know how to roast mushrooms and the pizzas are very good, they put actually roasted mushrooms on your pizza. The place is hiding behind the tree .
author: Ivan G.

description:
Pizzetta 211 has the best thin crust gourmet pizza.

They change their specials every other week. Some of the regulars are the Margherita pizza and the Tomato Sauce with Mascarpone & Wild Arugula pizza which both sound like great go-to's. 

Wine and cheese night? They have what you want too! Good selection of wine, beers, and even a cheese board! 

----------------------------------------
-- Specials / What I've tried -- 
- Farm egg with prosciutto, dijon mustard, gruyere cheese pizza: The dijon mustard is faint and there were two farm eggs cooked over easy. We popped the yolk over the rest of the pizza slices.

- Piadine, tomatoes, bacon pizza: Imagine freshly roasted garlic, spread onto Italian flatbread with a parmesan bacon salad on top. This was my favorite.

- (Daily Starter) Salad with avocado, almonds, green goddess dressing: Simple. The dressing and the almonds worked very well together!! 

- (Dessert) Panna Cotta: What seemed to be vanilla bean panna cotta came with raspberry and blueberry compote. Our other options were the semolina cake with roasted peaches and the flourless chocolate cake. 
----------------------------------------

Either arrive early or late to get a table quickly. But be forewarned, they could run out of dough. On a Monday night at 7:50 PM, we got seated outside within five minutes. Sitting outside might sound awful in the Richmond but it wasn't too bad because there were heaters right above the tables! 

This is a great spot for a date night, a girl's night out, or a philosophical dinner with friends (it has that Berkeley vibe).
author: Ingrid C.

description:
This place had been on my list for a long time, so I finally decided to check it out.  Some of these 4+ star places in the boondocks had underwhelmed so it was time to see if it was legit.  And it was.

We had two pizzas: the San Marzano Tomato Sauce, Mascarpone, Wild Arugula, Olio Verde and the Quattro Formaggi, Slow Roasted Tomatoes, Prosciutto, Garlic.  Both were excellent, the roasted tomatoes were incredible and the mascarpone was just heavenly.  Their salads were just so-so.

What stopped it short of being epic was the service, both on the phone and in person.  Learn how to smile and be a bit more cherry, guys, you're making pizzas, life is good!
author: Saminda W.

description: Place been here 18 yrs. Every detail is thoughtfully done - every bite of everything is uniquely delicious, including coffee. Down to earth staff. What a find!  We are jealous that we don't have a place like this in our neighborhood:(
author: Elvir C.

description:
Having ran around New York City on a pizza binge in the past, I am super critical and particular when it comes to pizza. Thin crust margherita (sometimes with and without pepperoni) is my go to pie and I benchmark how great a pizzeria is able to make this classic, whether or not I like the place or not.

We ordered one pie- tomato, mozzarella, basil, and pepperoni. The pie here is thin crust. The cheese at this pizzeria was not salty enough for my liking. The sauce not flavorful and dough not chewy enough. I didn't like that the basil came ground up into a pesto like consistency. Overall taste and presentation was nothing too special. Overpriced at $13.50 for a 10" not so tasty pie.

I do give plus points that there is outdoor seating for your pups and heat lamps so that you stay comfortable. My husband and I were glad we didn't order another pizza because we were disappointed with our first and were happy we saved our appetite for elsewhere.
author: Michelle T.

description: Easily the best pizza i have had in the bay area. A lot of options for vegetarians. Be prepared to wait as the restaurant is kinda small. Come hungry as the deserts are also AMAZING! :)
author: Preeti N.

description: Oh this place was amazing!! It's a small restaurant but it's so cute and cozy. Definitely worth trying and will definitely be coming back. Loved it!!!
author: Thanh V.

description: The best thin crust pizza in SF. The pepperoni pizza was insane.  The potato bacon pizza was ridiculous. I highly recommend coming here and enjoying this amazing carb heaven.
author: Alex G.

description:
My friend told me about how great the pizza were at Pizzetta 211. Since I've never been, when we met up to catch up over lunch, we decided to come here. The place is located in a residential area so it's really easy to miss, especially since it's hidden behind a tree. It's a small restaurant so there's only a few tables inside and a few more outside. They even have chairs for you to sit while you wait if there's no table. Around the tree, there's a wooden bench plus blankets. I'm not sure, but I think it's so you can have a picnic in the middle of the sidewalk. 

I can picture it. Glass of wine and pizza on a picnic blanket under the tree.

We decided on pizzas that were on a biweekly rotation. After all, we could always come back for the pizzas that were always on the menu. Once the biweekly pizzas are gone, you never know when they'll be back. 

We shared two pizzas: the The Farm Egg with ham, braised endive, gruyere, and mustard pizza and the Butternut Squash with bacon, chipotle creme fraiche, and pepitas. 

The Farm Egg with ham, braised endive, gruyere, and mustard was pretty good. I loved that there were two eggs, one for me and one for my friend. The eggs weren't overcook, it was still a little runny in the middle so it was perfect. It's slightly bigger than a personal pizza so one person can finish the pizza. Although for me, one pizza was a little too much. I thought it was pretty good. The pizza was definitely one of the most unique ones I've had. But I thought it was a little too salty. I'm not sure what it was, but it could have been the mustard. There were some seeds under the cheese and I think that was what made it a bit salty.

I absolutely loved the butternut squash with bacon, chipotle creme fraiche, and pepitas. It has to be one of my favorites. I have never had butternut squash before so I wasn't sure what to expect, but now, I want it in all my pizzas. The squash was creamy and sweet. The bacon was slightly salty. I felt that this pizza had it all. It played with my taste buds in a good way. And I really hope that the next time I come, that this pizza will be on the menu.

The service was very good too. Our server was very attentive. She made sure that we had everything that we need. She made sure that our jug of water was filled. 

I definitely recommend coming here for pizza. The ingredients are fresh. The pizza has ingredients that made me feel like I'm eating healthy. I mean, one of the pizzas even had brussels sprouts. The pizzas are a little pricy. About $12-16 for one. But I think it's completely worth it because the pizzas themselves are unique. 

Go try the pizzas during lunch if you can because it's less crowded during lunch. And bring a friend or two. That way you can try more pizzas =)
author: Andrea G.

description: One of the best pizzas Ive had! I was visiting SF and came across this place on yelp. Decided to give it a try and was surprised! The pizza can feed about 1-2 ppl depends how hungry you are. I tried the bbq beef and farm egg with chorizo one both are amazing! Small place but great food!! The service was great as well! Highly recommend coming here :)
author: Sara K.

description:
Cute little pizza shop, with quite a few staff members working for a monday night.  My dad and i had a couple pizzas and the on special gnocchi appetizer.  The gnocchi appetizer was the best thing I've eaten in recent memory (see pic).  I'm a sucker for wild mushrooms and a hoitey-toitey mushroom snob so I was sold at black trumpet, the texture of the gnocchi was great as well.
  For pizzas we had their margherita and the rosemary-fiore sardo cheese-pine nuts.  I dig the crust on both pizzas, very light and crisp.  The margherita lacked enough cheese for my taste, had a good fresh basil flavor though.  The fiore-sardo was interesting, as the cheese was not melted over the top of the pizza just grated on after it had come out of the oven.  I'd give both pizzas 3.5 star, and that gnocchi appetizer 6 stars, cos damn that was amazing.
author: Spencer W.

description: Unbelievable. How could there be even better authentic Italian pizza in this city of incredible pizza places? It's so worth the trek to Richmond and the wait.
author: Be F.

description:
Cute little place in the middle of an area in the city where I never go (because, let's face it, it's too far). 

the little place has 4 tables in side, and I think two more outside. Thin crusted pizzas full of flavor and desserts that truly look homemade await for you here. They also have wine, but I had just finished a 3 hour hike, so what I needed was water. Next time I'll try the wine!
author: Ezekiel G.

description:
First off, I cannot stress how great the service was. 

This place is small. We came on a Saturday night, less than an hour before closing, with a group of 7 that slowly trickled in. Our whole group wasn't there until 8:55pm, and they still sat us and served us, with a smile. If they had turned us away, I would have totally understood, but they were super gracious and we were there until 10pm (they close at 9pm). 

They didn't rush us, in fact, they told us to relax and enjoy, because that's clearly what they were doing as well. 

We ordered:
Farm Egg, Tunisian Pepper Sauce, Spanish Chorizo (on half), Ricotta Salata , Cilantro. 
-- really good. the runny yolk + pepper sauce played off each other super well. 
Quattro Formaggi, Slow Roasted Tomatoes, Garlic, Oregano
-- also delicious. The slow roasted tomatoes resembled softer version of sun dried tomatoes and added a wonderful flavor and texture. 

The pies are definitely meant for a single hungry adult. The crust is super thin and super crispy. 
The toppings are somewhat light, but also very considered. 
 
And, as if they hadn't already been super sweet to us, they brought us a couple of desserts for the table, on the house. It was a fig / date / raisin brea, with homemade whipped cream and a splattering of a caramel chocolate sauce (super yummy and also clearly their own creation). 

Overall, had a great experience and (despite being far from our usual stomping ground) wouldn't mind heading back.
author: Dimple B.

description:
Seriously the greatest thin crust style pizza to grace San Francisco.  

Rotating toppings (seasonal) with a couple permanent performers on the menu.

PROTIP:  Come now.  Get the pizza with egg.
author: David C.

description: Writing this update just having had a great NYC pizza. With all due respect to the pizza restaurants in NY, Pizzetta 211 is still my preference.
author: Al S.

description:
The top three reasons that will bring me to Outer Richmond:

1) Ocean Beach
2) Dim Sum
3) Pizza

No need to get explain ocean beach because you perverts know I'm obviously not out collecting seashells by the seashore.

And it's a given that the Richmond has the best dim sum in SF but pizza?

Oh yes, but not just any pizza... I'm talking about the BEST damn pizza in SF: Pizzetta 211's. Consistency is key and my most recent visit in April was just as good as I remembered it 7 years ago during my pre-yelp era. They definitely trump Delfina, Flour + Water, Zero Zero, and even the 11 time world pizza champion Tony Gemignani of Tony's Pizza Napoletana (lacks consistency). 

The size of celebrity walk-in closet, Pizzetta 211 seats just 12-14 people. However, what they lack in size they make up in flavor. Not only do they have your standard margherita pizza, they have creative flavor combinations that will tantalize your taste buds. With a small, seasonal menu that changes weekly, there's a salad, a cheese salad, 6-7 pizzas thin crust pizzas, a calzone and 2 desserts on the menu. CASH ONLY. 

Unless you like waiting and circling tiredly for parking, come when Pizzetta 211 opens so you can be seated immediately. If not, be prepared to wait as they don't take reservations.

We started out with the Soup of the Day: White Bean & Kale Soup ($6) which was chockfull of tender beans and topped with shaving of cheese; very hearty and comforting: http://bit.ly/10A1FOm. The Cheese Board Salad ($8) had a duo of a hard and soft cheese served alongside toast points: http://bit.ly/11yD5yN. It was nothing special so I wouldn't waste stomach space on this next time.

For the grand premiere, came the two pizzas we ordered: Rosemary & Pine Nut Pizza ($12.25) and Sausage, Red Potatoes & Farm Egg Pizza ($15.75). Surprisingly, 7x7 didn't lead us astray this time. A must order, the Rosemary & Pine Nut Pizza was uniquely delicious: http://bit.ly/13YMjUl. The aromatic rosemary, salty cheese and sweet richness of the pine nuts on a flavorful crunchy crust was insanely good. If you're a sucker for gluttony, then you'll love the Sausage, Red Potatoes & Farm Egg Pizza: http://bit.ly/146zp3l. This pizza was generously topped with rich sausage crumbles, thin slices of potatoes and TWO eggs for your poking pleasure. Take a slice and poke into one of the eggs and use the yolk as a dipping sauce. Pure artery-clogging bliss!

Service could be friendlier though. I did sense a bit of a Marina-Mission Yipster attitude from the staff so I don't doubt all the negative reviews. However, I easily overlooked it since the pizzas were phenomenal, food service was prompt, and dinner left me with enough money for a happy ending nearby.

"Happy ending" in the form of a footgasmic massage at Wonderfoot nearby, you pervs...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Very nice. Never been here before and have been around it for so long! We were coming with six, and had to wait not that long, knowing that it was dinner time. The waiter was really kind and nice and offered to move two tables to accommodate for our seating. 
Started off with 2 drinks, which came bottled. The Mexican Coke and a Root Beer. Not bad, but a bit steep for the price; but also affordable. 
Ordered 4 pizzas and the daily special salad. The salad came at 10 and the pizzas came all together at the 30 minute mark. The wait time was slightly lengthy, but makes sense because they gotta bake it at the time. 
The pizzas were AMAZING!!! The crust was crispy and crunchy. The toppings were really flavorful. And you could tell that it was all fresh. Appropriate sauce:cheese ratio, which is important for pizza. The dough was a little thin, but I think that it was their style. Everything was light and flavorful and perfect!!
Everything came down to the bill. All together, the price was...
~drumroll~
$83! (Before tax and tips)
So about 14 dollars per person, which is not too bad!
It's really gourmet and really "American" (if you can call it that [^+^'] ) 
Service 5/5
Food 5/5
Price 5/5 
Would most definitely come here again!!!
author: PokeMoshimon Y.

description:
If I could I would give this place 4.5 stars.  The pizzas are amazing and it's a quaint neighborhood gem.  If you like thin crust style pizzas, this venue is highly recommended.

You can't go wrong with a pizza with an added egg.  I would avoid the clam pizza however.  Ours came with the clams still in their shells.  They were not drained very well so the pizza crust came out soggy.  All other pizzas however rocked.

One issue is the space.  It's a bit cozy and may not be good for big parties.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
I had the mascarpone, arugula, San Marazano sauce pizza. Gwow. The spice factor in the sauce danced with my taste buds, the mascarpone melted all up in my mauf, the arugula made me feel like I got a serving of veggies in. Win, win, win.

The field greens salad was boring. Skip it.

The pizza? Be all about it.
author: Gabriela W.

description:
When I first discovered Pizzetta 211, it was a few years ago, when I was dating a girl that lived in the area.  Since it looked like a pretty cool spot, I suggested we check them out one night...and was quickly denied ("they suck" she said).  Long story short - we stopped dating soon after that.  Now, I'm not saying the two are related, but clearly she was wrong (in multiple ways) because Pizzetta 211 is GREAT!

After failing on my first few attempts to come here, I finally got the chance when my friend and I found a parking space nearby, and a very short wait outside.  It's was like fate was telling us to go!  Given their physical limitations, almost everything about the place is small - from the dining room (seats about 20 total, inside and out), to the menu, to the pizzas (hence "pizzetta").  What's not small though, are all of the delicious flavors!

- Cheese Board - Bleu di Lazio and Humboldt Fog Goat Cheese...A.Q.
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pizzetta-211-san-francisco?select=Ie9E1R3d4Dma5sp4ws0CJA#_jbudhXH8DWimik0uE7Riw)
Listed on their daily specials board, both were good...though neither really blew my mind.  While I'm not a huge fan of goat cheeses, the Humboldt Fog stood out more than the Bleu di Lazio (the latter tasted almost like any other bleu cheese).

- Farm Egg, Fennel Salame, Roasted Tomato Sauce, Parsley-Caper Oil, and Caciocavallo Pizzetta...$15.50
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pizzetta-211-san-francisco?select=Ie9E1R3d4Dma5sp4ws0CJA#l7ADUdynofh9hjLQqXS9KA)
Without the egg, the pizza was pretty good.  It's fairly simple, but I really liked the fennel salame and the caciocavallo (so different than just mozzarella).  With the farm egg though?  BONKERS.  Who knew an egg could make a pizza go from good, to awesome!

- Chard, French Fingerling Potato, Garlic Confit, and Gruyere Pizzetta...$14.50
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pizzetta-211-san-francisco?select=Ie9E1R3d4Dma5sp4ws0CJA#H6T8Qj48ae6D8hvcPZQ57g)
If not for the Farm Egg Pizza, I would have said this is the one to get.  Sure, there wasn't any meat, and the chard was a little different, but it was great!  The chard and potatoes gave it a nice, earthy taste, and you can never go wrong with garlic and gruyere! 

Although I enjoyed the food quite a bit, I wasn't 100% on rounding up from FOUR AND A HALF STARS.  However, they're definitely better than a four, and the service got them the rest (very friendly, and they offered us drinks while we waited).  Despite how scarce parking can be, I'll most definitely be back for more...and to further prove how wrong that girl was.  Ha!
author: Mike L.

description: I love this place. My favorite pizza destination in SF. It's cozy, so best for groups of 2 to 4. Best to get there by 5:30/6 pm if you want to eat before 7:30. Line is long after 6 because this place is so popular and seating is limited. Get 1 pizzeta per person, 1 isn't enough for 2 people to split. Delicious, can't recommend this place enough.
author: Patrick C.

description: A hole in the wall home-style pizza joint. Wait times are long since they have very limited seating. Pizza menu changes every week. Creations are very original, delicious, and worth the wait. The desserts, when available are worth the wait as well. They serve good beer as well.
author: Andy D.

description:
I frequent this establishment more than I let on. I come from an hour and a half away and bring different friends all the time. We enlighten in the pizza, salads, cheese board & bubbly. So many special pies filled with seasonal veggies and artistic flair that keep you looking forward to your next visit. 
 Oh emm gee... desserts are too die for. Fresh fruit tarts, pies, galletted and floorless cake end a perfect meal. 
See you soon Pizetta 211
author: Dora L.

description:
This place and pizza hacker are my fave pizza spots. Sooooo good. 

Pizzetta has overall better, more inventive flavors. However, the crust is almost cracker thin (whereas pizza hacker has a traditional Neapolitan wood fired crust that's bubbly, yet thin with a little spring). We had a Brussel sprout pizza that was divine and another pizza that had spicy sausage and a sort of chimichurri sauce.  We almost considered getting a third pizza, we loved everything so much. 

For dessert, we got an olive oil cake with huckleberries and whipped cream. The portions were generous - even the huckleberries (which aren't cheap at all). 

The place is super cute, but tiny.  I loved the atmosphere. We came late, relatively close to closing time. I was somewhat worried they wouldn't take us, but they did so gracefully. They were full upon our arrival, but we found a spot at the bar. 

Lastly, this place is cooperatively owned. The servers all have a stake, so they care about the product and the service. 

Can't wait to come back!
author: Alison H.

description: The pizzettas are okay, but they are costly. The wine was quite good - but it's best to buy a bottle rather than a glass because the price by the class is costly also.
author: Amy S.

description: Have walked by this place dozen times before deciding to try it. Ordered for pick up as seating is limited and was short on time. Ingredients are definitely fresh. Mix of ingredients and the dough is pretty good but for all the hype I expected something more.
author: Jc B.

description:
I love the atmosphere here. Such a tiny, homely place. You can sit outside where there are heatlamps and these lovely homemade quilts to keep you warm.

~~COST~~
2 pizzas, 1 dessert (1 free), a couple beers
= light dinner for two
$24.50 each (including tax/tip)

~~THE SERVICE~~
The service is chill and laid back:
- We came in around 8:30pm on a Tuesday (no wait! Score!). We started off sitting outside saying we'd move in once a table opened up, and when it did the server stuck his head out and beckoned us inside. 
- We stayed well past their 9pm closing, but the staff were sitting down together to their own dinner and let us hang out for quite a while. They still got up so we could order dessert, to get our bill, etc.
- Speaking of dessert, when we couldn't decide between the butterscotch and the rhubarb tart and were leaning towards the latter, he said he'd give us the tart for free if we ordered the butterscotch.
- You feel like you're just hanging out at a good friend's house. May be different when there's a crazy wait, but there were just a few customers left and it was the end of the dinner shift.

~~MUST-HAVES~~
Anchovy pizza, butterscotch pudding.

~~THE PIZZA~~
Overall a great thin crust, done really well. If I'm being extra picky, I think there could be more chewiness in the crust, though it has a good crisp to it.

~~THE TOPPINGS~~
* Braised pork, broccoli rabe, kasseri, horseradish ($14.75) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pizzetta-211-san-francisco?select=xAOOYFwpS7yRMM3VeB246w#xAOOYFwpS7yRMM3VeB246w
Love love love the horseradish! It didn't make the pizza spicy all over but you get pockets with just enough of a hint of that intensity. The pork was delicious and you get this big hearty chunks. The broccoli was very fresh and slightly bitter. My only slight complain is that there was a hint of something sweet which I didn't think went very well with this pizza - the server said it was from the pork seasoning.

* Tomato, mozzarella, Basil, with White Anchovies ($12.75) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pizzetta-211-san-francisco?select=xAOOYFwpS7yRMM3VeB246w#XkPIQMnuTCSHU9H5xmCCfg
Great - the tomato sauce was incredibly fresh and strong!

~~DESSERTS~~
* Butterscotch pudding - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pizzetta-211-san-francisco?select=xAOOYFwpS7yRMM3VeB246w#wARcXCxNRks_FfDnGrI81A
This was very sweet but absolutely delicious. I don't normally even like butterscotch pudding but our server was pretty adamant and I really loved this. The cookies were amazing as well, have that buttery dry texture of an Italian cookie but still somehow retained a slight chewiness.

* Rhubarb tart - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pizzetta-211-san-francisco?select=xAOOYFwpS7yRMM3VeB246w#MoycuTjEvWqjlayEFRCeZA
Flavor-wise, it was a little too much just tart rhubarb. There was a little bit of cream, but they could've used a lot more of this to offset the tartness. The crust was buttery and nice!
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Rosemary, Fiore Sardo, and Pine Nut Pizza- #50 on the 2013 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list.

Pizzetta 211 is a tiny pizzeria located in the Outer Richmond, but they do take-out, so you can skip the long lines here. However, the pizza isn't going to taste quite as good, but that was partly because I wasn't able to eat it right away. I just ordered the Rosemary, Fiore Sardo Cheese, Pine Nuts Pizzetta ($12.25, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/pizzetta-211-san-francisco?select=J8cZRCZlPK-thLmHrnOaJg#J8cZRCZlPK-thLmHrnOaJg), and I loved the thin crust. However, I thought the quantity of rosemary was a little overpowering. although I enjoyed the taste of the pine nuts. Overall, I would come back to Pizzetta 211 if I was in the mood for thin crust pizza, but would still opt for take-out versus waiting for a seat. Parking in this area is super difficult to find as well.
author: Amy D.

description:
5 years since my last review here, and the place is as good as ever.

I came here tonight with my wife and sat at the bar - the staff, customers, and food were all a perfect blend.

Kept it simple with the cheese salad (Humboldt Fog and a Sheep Milk tonight) a margharita, and the mascarpone with arugula pies and it was the perfect choice.

Olive Oil Cake with fresh whipped cream and strawberries could not be any better.

It had been way to long since my last visit, and this was a quick reminder that it's worth making the time for.

Thanks guys!
author: David K.

description: I had one of their specialty pizzas with egg, arugula, and a couple other ingredients which I can't recall. The pizza just want all that interesting tasting. For a gourmet pie with good sounding ingredients it just didn't have enough seasoning or unique flavor to leave a lasting impression. I would go back to try the margherita but probably would shy away from something more exotic.
author: Michael S.

description: Pizzetta is tiny. With only 4 tables inside and 3 tables on the outside. We had to wait for 10 min to get a table inside. It was totally worth it! Delicious food and cozy ambience. Thin Italian-style crust. Ambient music is playing in the background and you feel the warmth coming from the pizza oven.
author: Jay Z.

description: Expensive pies (~$20), but very very tasty. Cool ambience also if there is any open seating. It's cramped inside, but I like that homey vibe :)
author: Nick S.

description:
Service was friendly but the place was really small and so was was the pizza.   We have been spoiled in the east bay with artisian cheeseboard pizza and sliver and this doesn't compare.   Yes it's New York thin crust but this is personal size pizza that seemed a lot to pay

Ps it's tiny but sweet.
author: margaret c.

description: My favorite pizza place! It's cozy (the perfect restaurant for a date night) and the food is always good. It does get busy so going on a weekday is best, but they do offer drinks when waiting for a table.
author: Kelsey F.

description: Phenomenal artisan pizza. Incredibly friendly staff. Trust their recommendations, they won't steer you wrong. Small place, but great vibe. Didn't get a chance to try the baked goods, but they looked amazing. Can't go wrong with the pizzas, the cheese salad and the mushroom soup that was the special appetizer the day we went. Solid choice for a bite to eat in Outer Richmond!
author: Suzanne P.

description: Really small place, around 12 seats but extremely charming. Shared a green salad and a potato pizza for two and finished with a great, very light, flourless chocolate cake. The pizza was great, crust was crispy and tasty and just enough thyme and pepper to season everything.
author: Nicolas B.

description: Loved this small restaurant. Two tables plus several stools at the bar. The pizzettas were delicious! Salads were fresh and savory. Pear tort was a dessert lover's dream. Espresso was dark and strong. Service friendly. It is pricey. $100 (included tip) for three of us. But, this is San Francisco, CA.
author: S C.

description:
Worst ever pizza, don't let its high stars fool you,
Pizza is so tiny, has nothing in it and too expensive, It's worth less than $3 and they sell it for $16!!!!, most ridiculous ingredients I have ever seen in a pizza 
Do you think people are stupid? No
author: Alireza K.

description: Hands down the best pizza place ever! This was my second time here and my first time was with my sister. I came here last night around 5:45pm and we had to wait till our whole party was here. Unfortunately our friend didn't come till 6:45pm so my other friend and I just waited outside talking on the bench. We told the waiter our name and how many people is in our table. He was super nice and kept checking up on us to see if we were ready to be seated but unfortunately not. I wish we got to sit down but I understand that the place is small and cramped so it would be inconvenient for us to hold the table for another hour till our friend came. After our friend came, we ordered right away. We ordered 3 different pizzas. We ordered the farm egg pizza, fingerling potato pizza, and the roasted cauliflower pizza. All three were delicious and honestly, if you're hella hungry you can probably eat the whole piece of pizza by yourself. I highly recommend the farm egg pizza though. It's like heaven inside your mouth. My stomach was moaning from the inside lol. Like literally, this farm egg pizza was probably the best pizza I ever tasted in my whole life. Service was great too. The waiter kept checking up on us and asking if we were good. We also ordered a chocolate cake at the end. I'm usually not a big fan of chocolate cake but my friends wanted to order it and it was actually pretty good. It wasn't too sweet which was perfect. Our overall experience was awesome and I definitely will be back for some more! :)
author: Monica W.

description:
This place is so small I blinked and almost missed it! Inside is smaller yet with a very farm to table feel. I can imagine there may be an extra long wait during the dinner rush, but I came here around 3:30pm and missed out on that experience :-) I tried two out of the maybe five pizza choices they had and both were amazing. 
Parking is hit or miss, depending on if you're lucky enough to find something on the street. I'm bringing my out-of-town friends here...I can't wait to to back!
author: Lucia D.

description:
It's a small, cute little pizza spot that doesn't only serve pizza. When I first parked I was afraid I was in the wrong area because it just looked like a street of homes, but don't be intimidated it's a really small spot. 

A little on the expensive side ($16-$17). We only purchased two pizzas. The total came out to $42 including tips.

I thought it was cute that they put their water in a glass bottle. The wait took a while, as expected, but worth the wait. It was so delicious! Glad I took the time to come here. Associates made sure our experience was perfect. I would definitely come here again.
author: Cindy Z.

description:
According to my boyfriend (who lives a couple blocks away), this place is usually packed with a line forming along the street. And (after having visit) with good reason!

My taste buds were indulged as I ate my tomato, mozzarella, basil, and white anchovies pizzetta. The flavors were incredible, as they had just the proportionate amount of cheese and sauce. The crust was also properly made, without it being a deterrent to the overall taste.

However, I would suggest that, if at all possible, perhaps it would be wiser to have larger anchovies. That way one would be able to have more bites of them, which would only positively impact both the flavor composition and texture. 

In addition to the pizzetta, my partner and I shared a flourless chocolate cake. After having eaten a pizzetta each, one was enough to adequately fill the both of us! The cake was wonderfully rich. I am grateful that they decided to pair the cake with cream, for the cake alone may have been too rich and dense; the cream added more of a neutral, airy balance.

All in all, a great experience! I will come back, not just for the excellent food, but also for the fabulous service and ambiance

EDIT: While it is normally very busy, we went on a Saturday at 2:30 P.M. There wasn't a line, and we were promptly seated and served. So if you're: 1) in the Outer Richmond looking for a late lunch and 2) want quality food, service, and cozy ambiance - then this is your place!
author: Angelica R.

description: Cozy little spot with only 4 small tables inside and a few more outside. Come dressed for the possibility of Karl the Fog joining your meal. Luckily, I didn't experience the snooty service many seem to have come across judging from the other reviews.  I just enjoyed two pizzas. One was the menu staple tomato, mozz and added pepperoni. Simple and delicious! They also update the menu weekly. Knowing that, we ordered a bolognese sauce based pizza with a farm egg and capers. I normally despise capers! Everything blended so well together i hadn't even noticed they were on there. The pizza did not disappoint. I would personally order a pizza per person though. If you want more bang for your buck i would head down Geary St.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Days after eating here and I'm still daydreaming about this place--it's that good!

This pizzeria has a small menu which means their food is very fresh. They have 5-6 types of pizza, with the first two options on the menu changing periodically.

I started with their fennel cream soup (I think that was what it was) and omg was it heaven. Nice creamy soup topped with crispy crouton crumbs and a drizzle of olive oil. The group that I came with ordered one order of each pizza so we could share it amongst ourselves. 

The hen of the woods mushroom and leek pizza I ordered was the best. Crispy thin crust, delicious cheese and amazing toppings. Honestly, you can't go wrong with any of the pizzas on the menu. 

The show stopper of the night was the apple crisp, which was warmed to perfection, topped with whipped cream. My god.

This hidden gem in Inner Richmond is on a low key street and is not neighbor to any other food joints. It's small and can only seat 20-25 people at a time. So be prepared for a wait if coming on a busy weekend night. Coming in a group of five or more will be a struggle as well. Their tables seat groups of 2-4. 

They have daily starters and desserts (it changes daily), so I can't promise that the soup and apple crisp will be on the menu.
author: Justina L.

description: This place is the best! Great food, super nice staff and cute little location. Be prepared to wait, but know that they have blankets and some seating and are willing to bring you wine until your name is called. I really love the variety of thin crust pizza they have and they're always changing it up - salads are good too. Great wine and beer selection.
author: Molly W.

description:
Just went here for the first time for lunch and was really disappointed. With the high reviews and so many, I was excited to come here and have a nice pizza. I've lived in NYC, LA and St. Louis. I know good pizza.
I went with my friend and split a pizza. We had no idea how small the pizza would be...around 9 inches and expensive--$16. I thought it would've been bigger for the price.
We got the one with the homemade sausage. Where was the sausage? I would've had to get out a magnifying glass to find it. There was hardly any on there! A couple tiny crumbles on each slice. I felt cheated.
The description was a bit off...I didn't realize it wasn't going to be tomato based. Perhaps the menu should be organized differently. The entire pizza was covered with the white cheese, which once it cooled slightly (the pizza didn't even come out piping hot...I usually burn my mouth) became stiff. It overwhelmed the crust. The chili oil wasn't spicy at all. The lemon over the broccolini stood out a lot. The lack of sausage just made it taste...meh...


I should have said something to the waiter about how I thought this was unacceptable. It's really disappointing to go out to eat and have a lackluster, expensive meal and then come home and eat some more food and write a bad yelp review.
author: Stella H.

description:
tiny place, few rotating pizza choices, thin crust and not bubbly.  almost personal size but still shareable
Farm Egg, Prosciutto Cotto, Bechamel, Dijon Mustard, Gruyere, Chives
very nice delicate fresh ingredient oven pizza (steel oven).  the béchamel with the gruyere was extra nice.
parking can be painful.
author: Rob C.

description: Nyc pizza in San Francisco. Great, everyone likes pizza! Legendary pizza. Nice surroundings and decor
author: Bertha S.

description:
Pizza with the egg was good. Thin but not to the point where the sauces were melting the crust. Looks like they properly bake the pizza at the correct high temp unlike a lot of traditional style Italian pizzerias.

i would give it another star, but the waitress just gave us some attitude and gave us blank stares while we spoke to her. we also ordered 2 beers. one beer she just gave us the bottle, the other, she gave us a glass but only filled it 25% of the way... yea.
author: Jason C.

description:
Those who know me well will tell you that I could probably eat pizza days on end. With that said, I am also critical of the kinds of pizza I eat. For me, a top notch pizza has to be thin crust- this place fulfills that requirement. 

I also make a note of their hand picked toppings- it's really important that they pair well together. My friend and I ordered two separate pizzas: a margarita pizza with white anchovies and egg, along with a homemade sausage with broccoli pizza. I would have loved the sausage and broccoli pizza a lot more if it didn't have this orange lemony sauce on it. For me, it was too overpowering, which made the pizza taste really sour. I love adding lemon juice to meals for that extra zing, but this sauce was over the top. As for the margarita pizza, it was an "eh" for me. I didn't care much for the egg, but I did like the anchovy add on. It made the pizza less bland in my opinion with that nice bit of saltiness. 

The pizzeria is also VERY small. The table next to us had to move over a bit, so that we could squeeze into this tiny table in the corner. I am not saying that I wouldn't come back, but as far as pizza goes, I've had better. I believe their pizza menu changes too, so maybe the next pizza I try here will be out of this world!
author: Zandra T.

description: Super friendly neighborhood pizza joint in the Outer Richmond. The place has limited seating so take out is a good option.
author: Michelle R.

description: This place was absolutely amazing. Food was delicious and the sparkling wine was great!! We ended our night with the flour less chocolate cake and panna cotta and it was yummo!  Oliver was our waiter and he was very friendly and very welcoming. In my eyes he should get a raise! We need more waiters like Oliver.  If he is your waiter tip him good.  We'll be coming back and hopefully Oliver will be our waiter!
author: Joanna H.

description:
Store: a small place in a residential neighborhood.   We were looking for the restaurant and only found it because some customers were waiting outside on the street.   There were 3-4 small tables in side and 2-3 on the street.  It's warmly decorated with a full view of the open kitchen.  I really like the place. 

Service:  simple.  Quick.   

Food:   Simple food that is amazing.  We had a starter salad for sharing, and two pizzas. All were excellent.  The small salad was so good that my kids ate it all.  Nothing was fancy but all were just wonderful.  

Highly recommended.   It's a good restaurant for just relaxing with family or friends to enjoy an easy meal.
author: Mike Y.

description:
Update #2 - I've been here 5x since my last review, and it's just as excellent as when I first came here. I'm obsessed with their San Marzano pizza, it's melt in your mouth delish. Since the 5x I've been here, I've taken as many different friends with me and they too, say it's excellent. Don't forget to try the cheese plate salad thingie. It's just as excellent as their pizza's. 

Wow. This is a teeny tiny pizza place but, they can definitely give Delifina a run for its money. Seriously. Blown away with their thin crust pizza. But be prepared to be wind swept away with their homemade desserts. The lovely woman behind the counter is a pastry chef. And she does an absolutely fine job with the desserts. Especially the lemon verbena panna cotta. It was PERFECT. And I've had ALOT of desserts from high priced restaurants that doesn't hold a candle to this. I will def be coming back with a slew of my entourage and then some. This neighborhood is lucky to have Pizzetta 211 here.
author: Ny H.

description: This is a tiny, cute place in the Richmond neighborhood. Very understated. They have specials for starters and the Farro salad was delicious. The corn, onion and crescenza pizza is absolutely delicious and fresh. The macchiato is strong and flavorful. The ricotta and strawberries dessert was also on specials and delicious. Loved the place !
author: Where A.

description:
Great thin crust pizza. The Roasted Corn, Pancetta, Truffled Pecorino, Garlic surprised me. The sweetness of the corn and the truffled pecorino made for a pleasing yet interesting combination. This was my favorite of the two we ordered that night. . 

These pizzas are pretty much in their own category as far as I'm concerned. With a crispier and thinner crust, they're not as soggy or puffy blister crusted as the Neapolitans and (obv) not floppy NY style either. They aren't really cracker thin either so I can't really compare their pizzas with any other pizzas I know of. 

Note it is pretty cozy inside and got crowded quickly so we were glad to have arrived when we did. There were about 4 tables inside, some bar seating with two tables outside tables below heat lamps. You cannot wait inside when the tables are filled as there is nowhere to stand without blocking the way. 

I found the staff friendly and pleasant. Pizzetta 211 is another SF pizza establishment that shouldn't be missed.
author: Esther A.

description:
We have been going here for a long time because we live in the neighborhood... but the past 3 times the guy who hosts and seats folks has been incredibly unfriendly, condescending, and it just really rubs me the wrong way for being a neighborhood spot that is meant to be warm and friendly.  

I understand. It's frustrating. You have a tiny restaurant. You have a limited number of tables. You need to manage your pizzas. But it goes with the territory, no? If you run a restaurant, you can be hospitable and welcoming. 

For example, this past time we had 3 kids with us and he told us "this is not a family restaurant, this is a date restaurant." Ummm... reality check: There were no less than 5 tables (out of a restaurant that has maybe 7 tables) that had children under the age of 7 at them. Let's be more aware and less curt. I'm not blind. And then he told us "I can't seat you inside, I can't have children running around." Then he stared awkwardly at us waiting for us to respond to his non-option of seating us outside. 

At that point we were just hungry and didn't want to walk the kids somewhere else, so we stayed. Pizza still good. Just tastes a little bitter when the guy is a totally obtuse.
author: Subie C.

description: This place was great. It's a quaint whole in the wall pizza joint with friendly staff. We had the cheese board with a creamy brie and sharp cheddar which came with olives and bread as a starter. It's clear that their offerings on the cheese platter rotate, but they have that day's selection marked on a chalk board on the wall. We had a very unique Dijon mustard, pork sausage and cheese pizza. The crust is thin and the size is about what a medium is for national pizza chains. With the cheese board, one pie was more than enough for two people. It was delicious and the crust was crispy and light. Service was quick and friendly!
author: Brandon S.

description: What a wonderful hidden gem. The service was amazing, and all the servers were so sweet. The pizza is so rich in flavor. One pizza is a perfect size for 2. Best pizza in SF!
author: Carolyn M.

description:
We came here for this first time a couple weeks ago.  We were starving, craving pizza, and chose this place based on it's astronomical yelp status.  A couple things of note: yes, as mentioned in almost every other review, this place is teeny tiny.  We were lucky to get there when we did and snag a table.  Still though, the tables are small and you're so close to the table next to you, it makes getting up awkward.  

Ok, now the reason for my 3-star rating: they brought our food to the wrong table. Ok, let me explain, normally this wouldn't upset me so much, but this restaurant is a TINY room with only 4 or 5 tables- how do you mix up the tables?? Worse, they gave our order to a couple who came in, sat down, and ordered probably 15 minutes after us.  Again, the restaurant is super small, so we were keen on the fact that a table who had come in much later than us was eating before us, which is annoying in it's own right, and that they were eating what we had ordered.  Then the waiter came up to us and said, "Sorry, there's been a mixup, we brought your food to the wrong table. We're starting your pizzas now." Ugh.  So we wait another 15 minutes, starving (see above), watching a couple graze the pizzas we ordered.

Ok so the pizzas themselves get 5/5 stars.  Yes, amazing, delicious, mouth watering, unique pizza comparable to those in Italy.  They are small though, and I would say, over-priced.

Take away: Amazing pizza, though small portioned and over-priced. Sub-standard service. We will probably be back, but not dying to anytime soon.  And we definitely wouldn't come during prime-time dining hours when it's sure to be busy.
author: Cierra B.

description: If you're fan of pizza this place are for you. Huge selection of delicious pizza. High quality and fast service. Very kind and friendly staff. Highly recommend.
author: Paula S.

description:
Pizzetta is the most poetic little restaurant in San Francisco.  I love everything about it.  I love the location, for one.  Located on 23rd Avenue off of California St., Pizzetta is nestled in a cozy little space with a tree shading it's single door entrance and 2 front windows.  The vibe is residential, laid back, local, easy going.  As for the space itself, the square footprint and modest dimensions would certainly qualify it for a "hole in the wall" eatery.  If this is true, then what is also true is that little restaurants can offer expansively sublime experiences.  Perfect simplicity is the secret.

Poetic it is, with everything proportional to the allotted space.  Four table in all, plus a small counter space.  My guess is 15 persons total inside.  There are small tables on the sidewalk for an additional 8 individuals.  You will get to know your fellow diners, if you wish.  You'll definitely see their faces and hear their conversations.  Note that babies are allowed at Pizzetta.  I saw a couple eating with their kid inside, and liked it.  One must keep in mind the family oriented Richmond district.

Everything seems in its place at Pizzetta.  Order and cleanliness is essential for obvious reasons.  In such close quarters, clutter would quickly be noticed.  No one enjoys dining amid chaos.  Appearance does influence appetite, I believe.  And to me, there is something both beautiful and fine about Pizzetta's visual appeal.   Pizzetta can be seen in it's fullness in one 3 second gaze when you first step through the door.  Maybe the subconscious appeal of small eateries lies is this fact.  Nothing is hidden, the space is not intimidating but down to earth.  You feel you can easily handle it and feel at home there.  That's the beauty of Pizzetta's first impression - you have the feeling of walking into a good friend's kitchen for an unhurried dinner.  

This feeling carries over into the care applied to food preparation here.  Since only a handful of people can eat at Pizzetta, plates are just about made to order.  I saw only one cook behind the counter, and one server.  That's really all that is needed.  The menu is simple and concentrated, with several thin crust pizzas, an appetizer of the day, a choice of 2 or 3 salads, cheese board, olives, a handful of desserts.  I asked for the appetizer and a sausage/egg/kale/garlic confit pizza.  

The appetizer blew my mind!  Cauliflower puree, roasted brussel sprouts, shiitake mushrooms, crushed almonds, brown butter croutons.  It was so delicious, the best thing I've put in my mouth in some time.  I'm still thinking about how lush that dish was, and crave a return trip to have it again.  The pizza was also delicious, with sharply flavored sausage, nicely fried eggs, kale.  Very rich, and the crust nicely crisped and thin. I am excited to try their salad and dessert next time, yes indeed, perhaps in the evening so that wine can be enjoyed.  Try Pizzetta.  Perhaps you too will fall in love!
author: Roland C.

description: I am a native NY/NJ girl and have been on the hunt for decent SF pizza for FOUR years! This place has pizza done right. Thin crust, great sauce and cheese ratio, balanced flavors. A bit pricey, sure. But that's what you gotta pay to get awesome pizza in this town. A+. I am so happy!
author: Marisa D.

description: My family discovered this place on one of our trips to Baker Beach. We stick to what we know as far as good/clean places to eat, but seeing as Pizzetta 211 had great reviews we thought why not. The first time we went here it was a bit disappointing that they only served one size, because who eats a small pizza? So we ordered two smalls for $30, A tad expensive we thought. I like my pizza thick and unhealthy, but this pizza was the complete opposite. Which to my surprise it did not disappoint, As soon as we got to Beach we devoured every slice!
author: Juanita R.

description: Pizza can be exquisite; I know this now after my experience at Pizzetta this evening. The crust was perfectly crisp, yet giving. The flavor profiles were far more complex than other gourmet pizza joints I've frequented. I ordered the summer squash pizza, and was delighted to find the flavors enhanced by lemon zest. The wait is worth it--I grabbed a glass of wine while outside and enjoyed watching the server/host call people in, mostly from memory. After about twenty minutes, he called me in. Service is brisk, run by a single server accompanied by support from the kitchen. He was particularly perceptive, and I was not found wanting for anything. The flourless chocolate cake was unbelievable. It was particularly light, fluffy, and mild: a perfect cake. Can't wait to go back.
author: Jen H.

description:
Second time here and damn you just can't beat their pizzettas! I personally prefer thick crust (even though I know this isn't a pizza) BUT THESE ARE SOOO GOOODDD. The rosemary&pine nuts pizzetta was delicious. You could really taste the rosemary and the cheese since there wasn't any meats to overpower it. The brussel sprouts&bacon one was also delicious. Both pizzettas had me wanting more and more! If you want something in a small, cutesy atmosphere with delicious and I mean DELICIOUS artisan food, then try Pizzetta 211!

I'm not going to minus any stars because I actually thought it was kinda funny and laughed at it, but one of the waitresses was rude in like the nicest way hahaha
author: Holly P.

description:
My bf and I headed over to 211 last night to address a pizza and salad craving. It's true it was Mother's Day and we weren't thinking about that factor when we arrived and saw the ginormous line. Good news: we brought a bottle of Williams Selyem with us and the staff happily cracked it while we waited. It's a small spot and people don't leave quickly but it was a nice night, the wine was flowing and the folks who run the place couldn't have been nicer.

When two seats at the bar opened up, we decided to sit. It was cozy and we had front row seats to the action in the small, well oiled kitchen.

We started with the cheese plate and salad with strawberries and pecorino and hazelnuts. Mmm. We followed up with two pizzas--pepperoni and a prosciutto and pea with a white sauce. Both were outrageously good. The crust is even better than I remembered it--and we devoured everything. 

For dessert we managed to squeeze in a slice of ricotta cake with fresh berries. Good god was it good.

Bonus: this place used to only accept cash and part of our visit always hinged on how much paper we had on us. Now that they take credit cards, we are so there, so much more of the time!
author: Carrie S.

description:
On Bay to Breakers. My husband and I got to the door at 11:50am to wait for the doors to open. There is a party of six ahead of us that has been waiting since 11:15am. After us, three more parties of two wait behind us. 

Doors open, the party of six ahead of us get seated, and the hostess asks if everyone in our party is here. I tell her we are waiting for my sister but we will just go ahead and order so there is no hold up. She shakes her head no and says that we have to wait for everyone in our party and moves on to seat the people behind us. No apology, just abrupt brushing us to the side. I've worked in restaurants before, and I understand that it is helpful to move the seating along by making sure everyone in the party is there, but there were plenty of tables available even after every party was seated. 

I tried to explain to her that we live in the neighborhood, and that we would go ahead and order and my sister was merely ten minutes away. But she ignored me and turned her back on me. I could have just said there were two of us, ordered, and then my sister could have joined us but I wanted to tell the truth. 

It was especially frustrating because after she seated everyone we just stood there in shock at how we've been treated and noticed that there were two tables outside and one table inside that was empty. And she briskly ignored us and walked back inside. There were OPEN tables, THREE of them. 

My neighbors have all praised the food at Pizzetta 211. We will never come back and we will tell our neighbors not to go here anymore. The rude behavior is inexcusable. I guess you don't want our business?
author: Clover S.

description: Oh god, this pizza is amazing. I'm surprised it's taken me 5 years of living in the neighborhood to finally eat here. We ordered take out because, it was Sunday, a holy day for game of thrones, and it was not to be missed. Ordered two pies and paid a cheerful staff at the register. The atmosphere is super casual but classy at the same time. The pizzas took about the standard time it takes to bake, 30-40 min and it was just delicious. Simple, flavorful, balanced and light. Don't skip 5 years like I did.
author: Elton F.

description:
I really hate Pizzetta 211.  

They always have some really interesting and delicious starter and salad that you can't say no to.  
They serve interesting cheeses that are unique and flavorful.  
The special pizza of the day makes my taste buds water.
The pizza dough is spun and rolled to order, no pre-made crusts here.
When they are busy, the stop taking to-go orders so that the existing customers don't get too backed up.
The beer and wine selection is a nice small variety that has something for each persons tastes.
The staff is friendly and engaging.

So why do I hate them?  Because every time I go there I eat too much and I finish my pie.  So later I am too full and I have no leftovers for my midnight snack.

Obviously you can tell I don't really hate them (if you didn't catch that, well ...).  The clientele there is always fun and interesting - actually that's not quite true since there seems to be at least one bozo there when I am there.  But most of them are fun and interesting.  On a nice evening it is enjoyable to sit outside at a table.  When it is cooler you can sit inside and watch the crowd out front.

The place is rather small.  So sometimes the wait is pretty long.  They try to do a good job at managing the flow and keeping people moving.  And they have 4 seats at the counter that aren't as comfortable, so those turn over a little more quickly.

It was at one of those seats where I dined alone the other day.  I had spent the day on the Presidio at the wine bunkers and then taking some shots along the coast.  Being by myself made it easier to grab a spot at the counter where I was soon joined by a couple that seemed to be on a date.  BTW, If you want privacy, don't sit at the counter - the other people there hear every word, the staff is right in front of you, and all the people coming in to order and pick up come right up behind you.  I was perfectly fine, but the male in the couple that sat next to me seemed to have an issue with it.

Then again he had a lot of issues.  He dropped out of school because he didn't think the education was worth the effort. I liked one of his comments in particular "you know I went to Berkeley for 2 years.  I was accepted into Stanford too but just couldn't see spending that kind of money.  And when they raised my fees at Cal, I just didn't see the ROI of staying there." Huh?  This was followed up shortly with "An MBA is just not worth it.  All that time and money, for what?  I have more important things to do with my time."  You do?  Like what?  Maybe finish your first college degree at one of the best universities in the country?  She was eating it up.  Oh well, young love.

Anyway, Pizzetta - it's a love hate relationship.  I love just about everything about you, but hate how you make me want more.
author: Jeff H.

description: My favorite spot for pizza in the City.  The pizza is delicious!  We shared a salad (the special for the night) and a tomato, mozzarella, and basil pizza.  The thin cornmeal pizza crust is what draws me back to Pizzetta 211 again and again.  Sometimes I'm adventurous and will try other pizzas on the menu - but, in my humble opinion, I think the margarita pizza is the best!
author: L. M.

description:
I usually find pizza boring but pizzette 211 is the exception. They come up with these really odd but incredibly tasting recipes. Ingredients are always very fresh, the crust is done just right but thin so it doesn't get in the way.

The store itself is cutely nestled into the neighborhood and has the feel of a pop up. Yet the place is cozy and worth the wait on a sunny day. Grab a table outside or in the window.
author: Alex H.

description:
There are rare occasions that I prefer a thin pizza and this is one of them!
List of things that bring me here over and over: 
1) Have you been to Barcelona? This place is a perfect little hole in the wall example.
2) Who ever selects the wine for here, knows what he is doing! I have tried it from Rhone to Cab Franc, they never disappointed me.
3) Don't forget the cheese plate!
4) pizza time! my favorite is the one with lamb.
ps. sit at the bar and enjoy watching your pizza being prepared ;)
5) Lemon tart is a must have desert here! I also love the Pana cotta..
author: T M.

description:
Really good thin crust pizza. Fresh ingredients. Went last night and sat at the bar. The guys that work there are hilarious and fun to talk with. 
I had the sausage and broccoli pizza with lemon/chili oil. Super good. 
Also the cheese and walnut salad. 
Great beer selection. There is almost always a long wait so be prepared to hangout in front for awhile.
author: Sam A.

description:
What beautiful pizza from this tiny place! The anchovy pizza and arugula pizza are a must, forever. 

Got take out just now and couldn't enjoy these more.

The pizzas are small, so order up!
author: Carleen W.

description:
One of the direct routes to my heart is pizza and beer. When that pizza happens to be artisan, the beer is Allagash, and there's delectable chocolate cake for dessert as a bonus, you've won me over. #SWOON 

I went here last night with my parents for an early birthday celebration, and it was absolutely perfect. I had the arugula and mascarpone (to myself, obvs) and it was the type of pizza I dream about--thin crust, uber high quality ingredients, and fresh out of the oven for me. My mom had the pine-nut rosemary pizza and my dad had the classic margherita--all three were delicious, although mine was the best because MASCARPONE. It's like, the trump card of cheese. 

The service was truly wonderful--everyone was so welcoming, friendly, and attentive in this tiny wooden pizza box. It was terribly quaint and charming. I will definitely be taking loved ones there in the future.
author: Meredith C.

description:
Came on a weekday for lunch so there was no wait, but this place is very tiny, so plan accordingly (avoid rush times, prepare for parking etc)

Overall, great place for pizza if you love the thin, crispy cracker-like crust. I prefer a traditional Neapolitan pizza with the chewy, fluffy crust, and this was definitely not that style.
