That said, it's still enjoyable and I think there's some neat experimentation with flavors (they rotate bi-monthly I think?) though they may not always come together (see OK below).

Loved: 
- Mascarpone on their san marzano + cheese pizza: the tomato sauce was fantastic, lots of flavor and the spots of creaminess from the mascarpone were delightful. In fact, I would recommend all pizza places to try adding a mascarpone topping
- asparagus + mustard greens seasonal starter: loved the grinded bread-crumb crunchy topping, nice mix of salad flavors and perfectly cooked giant white beans. I'm not sure if they always offer this style of starter, but it was delicious.

OK:
- farm egg with braised beef and kale: I love each of these ingredients on their own, but they just didn't come quite together for me on a pizza. It also felt like it was missing something (salt? pepper?) to make it interesting. The beef was really tender though...

Skip:
- Flourless chocolate cake: I was expecting something rich, fudgy with deep chocolate flavor, but it was a little dry and kinda flavorless. I'd rather have another pizza.

Tony's pizza still has all my love, but Pizetta 211 makes a nice fling.
author: dana n.

description: We have had great service and pizza at this restaurant before. The night in question our server was very arrogant and rude. As always the restaurant was busy, we were a party of five. The server/materdie was out of line.
author: VG S.

description:
I hate to do this but I think what I think. It seems the quality of the ingredients at least on one of the pizzas was lacking. I had a pine nut/fontana cheese configuration & the cheese didn't have it's usual edge. there was also too much of it and it was like chewing bubble gum, it was hard to break down and digest.

I hope this is a blip here & not a portent of things to come. I've frequented this place from the inception, however after this last outing I'm not sure I wanna come back.
author: Henry K.

description: Great a little neighborhood pizza place with creative menu and good taste food.   It's a tiny place. You can watch them making your pizza if you sit the counter.
author: Thomas N.

description:
We ordered take-out here, and my young son made the mistake of standing in the wrong spot after using the bathroom. For this we were ordered by the obviously angered waiter to stand outside. We never returned. 

It's a small place, kids stand in the wrong place: I get it. But no need to be nasty about it. You're in a family neighborhood - across from an elementary school, no less. You can take your hipster attitude to the Mission.
author: S H.

description: Excellent thin crust pizza and great salad.  Second time here. Always a wait for this small place for good reason.
author: Richard H.

description: Don't want to post this as they are soo good and already always so busy it takes a while to get a table. But that wouldn't be fair considering they deserve the accolades. If you're in the area, totally worth checking out!
author: D R.

description:
Pizzetta, you're restaurant is tiny but who cares because you really know how to make a delicious pizza! One bite and I was sold! This blows Pizzeria Mozza out of the water. 

This was the third stop of my four stop "must eat" food crawl my friends took me on. Prior to this, we had banh mi from Saigon Sandwich and xiao long bao at Shanghai dumpling king. If I had known how good this place was, I would've just saved my appetite for this! I hear this place gets super packed but, luckily, we went at an odd hour so we were seated right away. We got the farm egg pizza and it was to die for! A thin crispy crust topped with bacon, radicchio, gorgonzola and caramelized onions...my mouth is watering just thinking about it. With all these savory ingredients, you'd think it'd be heavy but it was surprisingly super light. The three of us shared one pizza because we went to PPQ right after this but I have to go back and try the other ones! 

If you love pizza, you HAVE to come here! Or don't...we should keep it a secret!
author: Bobbie W.

description: Love the pizza here ! Maybe too small ;) need order two to be happy . Thin crust  and light :)
author: Laura D.

description: This place is nothing if not charming. I couldn't believe we were in the states, let alone the Richmond! Totally European  feel, super tiny and cozy, tucked into a quiet neighborhood street. There are a dozen seats inside and maybe a handful outside. The kitchen and servers are busy busy churning out gorgeous salads, pizzas, and desserts for hungry diners. Everything is simple but fresh and crisp and wonderful. It's so relaxing, just like a vacation to the European countryside (or so I imagine). Daily specials are great. Even though they were busy, we never felt rushed. Definitely worth many repeat visits!
author: Vivian H.

description:
I do the happy food dance just thinking about this place. 

Nom nom nom
author: Gina S.

description: Awesome restaurant. Limited menu. Great pizza. The dad was amazing to finish with. Nice people and cool music. Definitely would come back.
author: Marco G.

description:
The pizza here is good! It's totally got the hipster vibe. Small, quaint, almost a little hidden. 

We tried the Corn, Bacon, Truffle Pecorino, Garlic, Cream, Parsley pizza along with the Rosemary, Fiore Sardo Cheese, Pine Nuts. Their pizzas are about 10inch personal flatbread pizzas. So if you're super hungry, you'll need two. 

The rosemary one was good but the flavor is very subtle. I tried a slice of that one before the corn, bacon and thankfully I did, or I would have thought the rosemary had no flavor. The corn, bacon one was delicious and super flavorful; it packs a punch. 

It's pretty pricey here for pizza, which is why it's not going to be a place I go every time I crave pizza. But it'll be a good treat here and there.
author: Jeannie L.

description: Delicious pizza. Went at an odd hour after a hike on Sunday. No wait, got to sit outside on one of the 3 small tables with my pup and a friend. Friendly service too. What a gem.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
When people said this place was tiny, I had no idea just how tiny this place would be! 4 tables (of 2-4) inside, 4 bar stools, and 2 tables for 2 outside. And it's cramped. Quick tip: they have heaters outside so it's not frigid if you want to try eating al fresco.

This place is so cute, it's something you should try at least once if you are a pizza lover like myself. 

Be warned that even on a Friday afternoon, parking is atrocious! Note: They have a 10 min loading zone for customers just outside. 

PIZZA: so how does pizzetta stack against the other big pizzerias in SF? I loved the ingredients and the size was perfect given the thickness. However, the dough is similar to those rolls/buns they serve chicken sandwiches on (You know the kind for burgers from the grocery store? With the yellow speck-sized crumbs ... err is that cornmeal?... covering the top half of the bun?). It's not the puffy dough style pizza that I like - not chewy at all. And it's not like plain white crusty bread at Beretta because it seemed a lot airier overall, while not falling apart in your hands (Delfina). 

I think the service was great - friendly, efficient - and the pizzas are great quality and creative. I'm just not a fan of this type of thin crust pizza.
author: Jess C.

description:
Pretentious taste and service. Unfortunately, not a lot of love put into the pizza.

Sounded like a good idea. It has a very SF Hipster-lax feel. Seems like it'd be a good place to chill, but don't expect crazy delicious pizza. The menu was fun-looking and seemed like tasty pizza selections - however the actual pizza was lacking deliciousness.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Let me start off by saying, Pizzetta 211 is a small place. Actually, I mean to say a tiny place. Inside only seats 16 people, but really should only seat 14 people. From your seats you can see the chefs and the one server. Two of the tables are in a little nook on each side of the doorway when you walk in. The other two tables seat 4 but should really only seat 3 since they are tight against the place where they store the plates. There is also a counter for 4 people. There is a few outdoor tables too.  

The pizzas are around $15-$17, but can really only feed 1 person. We noticed that even a couple of girls next to us were able to finish 2 pizzas, a starter, and even had a dessert.  The pizzas were great, but honestly were way too small for the price. Since the menu rotates every two weeks, I am not sure what good I'll do by making you drool of over what we ordered. I have to say, the crust was outstanding though.  

The service was lacking terribly though. I am not a needy customer at all, but in a room so small, I can see or even yell to the server. I just felt like we were bothering her and interrupting her socializing. We waited outside for a table to free up. The customers left and then she waited a while to clear the table, not even wipe it. Then another 10 minutes passed. At this point it was starting to rain, so we asked if the table was ready. She looked over at it and said yea, as if we supposed to know. Bringing our menus, bringing drinks and bringing us the check, all seemed to take her a laborious amount of time. Keep in mind, I can almost reach out and touch her from my seat. My gripes were not about her perceptive and attentiveness, but it is about the time it took her to actually act on our requests. Poor chefs were hard and work (right in front of her as well) and she kept talking to them or whomever at the bar. We honestly felt like an inconvenience.  

Food - 4/5
Value -3/5
Service - 1/5
author: Rachelle T.

description:
The wife & I came here with a friend from work & her husband. Parking was atrocious. We asked for the waiter's recommendations and ordered the following:

- Cheese Salad - Organic Greens, Artisanal Cheeses, Spiced Walnuts
One strong French blue cheese and one other mild cheese--I should've paid attention to the names. They were okay I guess, but nothing mind-blowing. The organic greens were extremely boring. There were a couple of okay olives. There were spiced walnuts? Nobody told me.

- Pizza with Tomato, Mozzarella, Basil (we added White Anchovies)
We weren't planning on getting a Margherita, but Christine had heard that the white anchovies were a must-try, and the waiter recommended that we try these on something mild so it wouldn't be overkill. The anchovies themselves were, well, anchovies--quite fishy--not horrible, but not horribly savory either. Not as good as canned oysters or mussels, for example. The pizza itself was okay--crust on the bottom was quite crunchy, the sauce was slightly dry in certain areas--none of the ingredients really stood out to me as delicacies.

- Pizza with San Marzano Tomato Sauce, Mascarpone, Wild Arugula, Olio Verde
In this pizza, the mascarpone was deliciously creamy, however, it was cooked with the pizza rather than added afterward, so some of its magic was lost in the process. I remember thinking that the arugula was a bit wilted looking, but there was a bite or two that carried that potent arugula punch, which is a good thing. This was probably the best pizza of the four.

- Pizza with Sorrel Pesto, Prosciutto, Dry-Farmed Early Girl Tomato, Goat Cheese
I expected the pesto to taste differently as it was made from sorrel, but it actually tasted about the same a basil pesto (perhaps slightly less intense). The goat cheese really didn't have that goat-y flavor, which I was actually disappointed about. The tomatos were soft and artificially sweet  (as if overripe and then canned)--a little sloppy. There was prosciutto? Still, pretty decent pizza.

- Pizza with Rosemary, Fiore Sardo Cheese, Pine Nuts (we added two farm eggs)
Note to self: Rosemary isn't ever really that good, and even pine nuts can't hide its flavor. It's just distracting and annoying. Pine nuts, however, are always welcome in my book. The cheese was an offshoot of pecorino--pleasant but unmemorable. And two eggs, one for each couple--it's hard to argue with all that yolky goodness.

- Buttermilk Panna Cotta, Preserved Fig, Ginger Cookies, Whipped Cream
This was very light actually, slightly less creamy than I had hoped--no noticeable buttermilk flavor (disappointing as I had latched onto that description). In fact the flavor reminded me a lot of Giant brand (east coast grocery chain) vanilla yogurt, in a positive way. The fig sauce (I assume the sauce was connected to the figs) was really light and didn't add anything in my book--I think they should've tried something tart to provide balance. The figs themselves were nice. Ginger cookies were essentially ginger snaps. It was pretty good overall.


- Olive Oil Cake, Macerated Strawberries, Whipped Cream
Our waiter Corey (nice guy) was beating himself up for dropping a slice of our last pizza (his first drop in 15 years or something), so he atoned by offering us this extra dessert. I was really really looking forward to the olive oil cake (still thinking of that heavenly olive oil ice cream from Boulevard), but I found no trace of olive oil--instead it tasted like a dry, slightly lemony pound cake. 'Macerated' must be a fancy word meaning "lacking all fresh and fruity goodness". The cream wasn't really sweet, which was a positive.

- Lemon Tart, Reduced Blackberries, Whipped Cream
Standard lemon pie--nice flavor. The blackberries weren't horribly remarkable (perhaps they'd been 'macerated'?). Pretty good if not a tad traditional.

All in all:

It was an enjoyable evening, and for all the criticism I just leveled, it was a decent place. I guess I just take a little issue with Corey's statement that "This is a pretty well known place--people that work in the restaurant industry come here." It was nice, but certainly no Cafe BaoNecci.
author: Elliott D.

description: I am a big-time fan of this place.  My second meal, an early lunch right when they opened, was awesome.  I consumed their special soup of the day- a corn chowder, and a 4 cheese pizza with roasted tomatoes. Everything was really top-notch, and had the distinct taste of being small-batch produced with very fresh ingredients.  Hard to do much better than this in SF.  I will be back again very soon.
author: Andy S.

description: Best pizza I've had in the 16 years I have been eating in San Francisco. The mascarpone and arugula was just fantastic. Our waiter, Bryan, was good at his job, really nice to talk with, and still seemed to like his job after 9 years. Tells you something right there. I'm really glad we tried this lovely little neighborhood spot. Oh-and the bathroom is a good time. Wierd to say, I know, but trust me!
author: Cassie C.

description:
Listen, if I am going to be paying ungodly amounts of money for a small pizza I could easily devour in one sitting, it's going to be at Pizetta.

The food is always phenomenal (pizza, salads, desserts) and the ambiance of the restaurant is charming.  The restaurant itself is tiny and they offer nice (but limited) out door seating with heat lamps.  

The staff have always been friendly.  The last time we were at Pizetta we arrived and stayed late.  The staff assured us we were welcome to stay as long as we wanted regardless of the fact they had closed.  The entire staff sat down and had dinner together, and they all looked so happy.  It made me really appreciate this small business and their appreciation for their staff.
author: Jen S.

description:
One of my favorite dining experiences in San Francisco!

A small neighborhood spot, my friend and I trekked quite a bit to find it. It's tucked away but its brimming with charm; cute, exposed kitchen...small and simplistic menu...deliciously flavored pizzas. Not too many seats.

Tried:

+Rosemary, Fiore Sardo Cheese, Pine Nuts (+ added a fresh farm egg)
+Tomato, Mozzarella, Basil (+ added a fresh farm egg)

Both were incredible but my personal favorite was the rosemary pizza. The herbs added some amazing flavor to the pizza. Love that it wasn't pricey.
author: Roopa S.

description:
This place should have 6 stars.  I've been here 3 times (although I chose not to wait the 3rd time, I'll get to that in a second) and am just blown away by how good it is.  When I go out in SF, this is exactly the kind of place I hope to find!  

Visit One:  I went for a walk with my girlfriend and about the time we came across 211 (which may or may not have been on-purpose...) I mentioned that I was pretty hungry.  After suggesting we stop in to check it out and getting the nod of approval, we walked in and were immediately seated at the bar.  We ordered a phenomenal salad as an appetizer and watched with amazement as the craftspeople went to work.  Incredible to watch, the employees clearly cared for and loved their product.  The salad was better than a salad should be.  The pizza came out and was absolute perfection.  Everything was just right.  I assumed I was just having an out of body experience as it was pretty Zen like overall, but nope, just the neighborhood pizza joint at its best!  The staff were awesome, food was even better, and I walked into the night giddy with happiness at this newfound marvel.

Visit Two:  Same as above, but got the cheese platter as an appetizer and sat outside.  The cheese is INSANE!  This is not corner store cheese, it is very high quality and expensive imported cheese.  It is not a plate of food, it is literally a plate of experiences.  So, so, so good.  Not skimpy in the portions either.  It may have been true love.  The pizza was somehow better than I remembered.  The service was great and the outside seating (which we waited about 2 minutes for) was somehow perfect for the night.  

Visit Three:  In an attempt to share with one of my close friends, we came to 211 and found a line.  After inquiring about wait time, we hung out for about 20 minutes but no seat opened up.  Here is where you expect me to get upset.  Nope.  It's not their fault that there food is so delicious that people take their time to enjoy it.  Regardless, the waiter (who actually does care, by the way) came over and apologized profusely.  He offered us a drink on the house if we were willing to wait a little longer.  I declined as I was pressed for time and said we'd be back.  Here's the thing though, the guy gave us zero attitude, was genuinely apologetic, and offered an item that did have an expense attached to it in return for us waiting due to a circumstance beyond his control.  That is what customer service should look like.  A waiter that actually cares about the experience even if they are not going to profit from it.  As good as this place is in terms of food, the attitude of the employees makes it even easier to love.
author: Jared J.

description:
I...just...can't.

The food at this place is very good. My first review made that clear. But their customer service/management, as more than hinted at in my follow-up review, needs MAJOR work, and I am now finally done with them.

My husband called before 7:00 during Game 4 of the World Series to pick up a few pizzas. As is pretty much always the case at this restaurant, they were out of the 3 specials on their menu. We were going to order 2 of them. After hesitation from my husband about what to order instead, the guy on the other end of the phone kindly asked if he'd like a few moments to decide and call back. The wait for pick-up was only 20 minutes, anyway. Sounds good, so far.

Fast forward 15 minutes. I called back, ready with a new order. Suddenly, I'm told they are no longer taking orders for pick-up because they have gotten too many calls during the World Series commercials (there could not have been more than 1 break between my husband's call and mine). I patiently lament (assuming the guy would remember he'd just talked to my husband and understand), "Oh no, but my husband just called and was told he could call back with a decision after being told you were out of 3 of the pizzas." His response? A totally unsympathetic, "Yeah, that's where we're at right now."

Okay, Pizzetta 211, this is just super shitty. First, you're out of half of your pizzas - specials or not, it's A LITTLE ridiculous at 7:00 on a Saturday night. Second, you gave us the impression there was no problem calling in an order to pick up, when in fact, it was a major f-ing problem. Third, for all of you reading this and supportively saying, "But it's the World Series, of course it is busy..." EXACTLY. IT IS THE WORLD SERIES SO OF COURSE THEY ARE BUSY. We, as basic, non-restaurant professionals, know this. Why do THEY not know this?? It doesn't take a marketing statistician to guess that they should probably prepare for a higher-than-usual volume of orders during one of the biggest events to capture this city's attention, like, ever. 

Needless to say, we called up our reliable standby, Giorgio's, who quoted us a 1hr 40min delivery that they actually beat by 45 minutes. They may not call their pizzas "pizzettas," but I can actually order and eat them. Thank you for that.
author: Kiesha R.

description: Pizza was great (4 stars) - seasonal and quality ingredients. But my gosh, I have never encountered such a rude waiter before (service - 2 stars. only redeemed bc the people behind the bar were friendly). This guy was incredibly snarky, and I had to bite my tongue on several occasions bc I wanted to tell him off. my blood is boiling just thinking of it. Unless he's the owner or something, he should probably be removed from any service job.
author: Christina Y.

description:
I came here on a whim with my boyfriend and we had the most fantastic meal.
The space is TINY so be sure to call ahead. 
Here is what we ate:

-The prosciutto/egg pizza
-The broccoli lemon herb pizza
-A barley/beet salad
-Strawberry rhubarb galette

Everything was spectacular. The pizzas were some of the best I have ever had: perfect crust with tangy, memorable toppings. 
I don't get to San Fran often but when I do go back, Pizzetta 211 will be a MUST on my list.
author: Kate A.

description:
Pizzetta 211 is one of those little gems that help make a neighborhood. My brother was really surprised when I said, "Drive out to 23rd Avenue." I guess you don't really think of the Outer Richmond when you say, "Let's meet up for lunch in the city."

Pizzetta 211 is definitely worth going out of your way for. It's tiny and can seat probably 10 people inside and 4 people outside. It's charming and rustic like a farm house. It'll transport you all the way to Italy. I really loved it and the service was really friendly. That made a big difference. It was almost like sitting down at a friend's house for lunch. That includes access to the kitchen. The shelves and food are laid out there.

The pizzas only take about 5 minutes to bake. They are thin and small but okay for sharing just as long as you get more than one. We started off with a field greens salad. It was simple, organic, very California (sans avocados!), and tasty with just balsamic vinaigrette and a sprinkle of salt. Then we moved on to two pizzas (Serrano ham, crescenza, oven dried tomato, wild arugula and Tomato mozzarella basil with pepperoni). The pizzas were just perfect. 

I was pressed for time but decided to get dessert to go after quizzing the waitress what was the deal with the biscuits and fresh strawberries on the counter. She whipped up together the best warm strawberry shortcake for me complete with whipped cream. Since they didn't have any plastic utensils for me, she gave me one of their real forks. That was generous.

One of the best gourmet pizza parlors in the Bay. For sure.
author: Rachel A.

description: Stopped by here after Crissy Field and got the margherita! The mozzarella just oozes!! Def Can't go wrong with this classic. So good! I'll def stop by again when in the neighborhood!
author: Tawn B.

description:
Pizzetta 211 is a kind of place that makes you feel special to have "discovered" or tried while traveling. Located in the Outer Richmond, it does not seem like the typical place or neighborhood that a visitor to SF would want to go to or even know of. There are certainly many fantastic eateries in SF, but this was ideal. It's small and removed from the hustle and bustle of the city. This is for sure a place that I'll recommend to people. This is definitely a place that only the locals know, or at least that's the impression I got.  My aunt, a San Francisco local, recommended this place to us and after a week load of solid meals but nothing uber remarkable, I had no idea what to expect, so I went in with no expectations, which is really the best thing to try to do. My expectations were surpassed on all levels; it was remarkable. I let my boyfriend do the ordering since I tend to dwell on items and indecision can take over. The menu is small, simple and thoughtful. The place itself is tiny, as in it can seat like 20 people and that would be pushing it. There are tables outside, but weather isn't always ideal in SF. The menu is comprised of about six pizzette, some of which rotate weekly, one calzone, salad, a cheese board option and desserts. 

We started with an order of the mixed olives. Simply put, the mix of Calevastrano, and two other varieties with oil, chili and fennel seed was perfection. Next, we shared the salad special, which again, was simple yet every bite was complete heaven. What looked like a small, simple and potentially boring baby green salad with baby radishes and two crostini topped with egg salad, turned out to be the best thing I ate all week on this particular trip to San Francisco. Literally, my boyfriend look the first bite out of the crostini and said something he never, ever says: "This is to die for," in a monotone kind of way. I looked up at him before I took my first bite, and replied, "really?" His lack of enthusiasm had me questioning it. Then I took my first bite, and from there on, we ate in silence, savoring every bite. 

We shared the San Marzano pizzetta with mascarpone cheese, wild arugula and olive oil. This one is a regular on the menu and it was an excellent choice. Again simple, but the richness of the mascarpone with the spice of the arugula was "to die for." This pizza was so good that I think even thin-crust haters could be converted to lovers. 
We wrapped things up with dessert: panacotta with blood orange. A complete delight. 
The only thing missing was a glass of wine. Since we were in exploration mode, I stuck to water. One could easily spend the afternoon here drinking wine and eating pizza. 

As many have already pointed out, I will also point it out again because it's important: it's cash only and it is very small! Plan ahead for an early lunch or late dinner. It will get packed and I can see how long waits can upset people. The style of this place is super organic and relaxed. It almost feels like you are eating at home. Keep that in mind when you plan a visit to Pizzetta. This place was 100% worth the forty plus minute ride on the bus and I can't wait to recommend it to people!
author: Isabella J.

description:
Would totally pass on this place. Staff made me and my friend feel totally unwelcome. Hardly a greet or a smile when we first walked in (door was ajar) and asked if they were open and they shut the door after they responded with an aloof "We open in five minutes." Later, they welcomed the other people in (outer Rich locals?) so we just followed and sat ourselves. When I asked what they recommended, she replied "well... it's all good." ... I dunno if she just didn't know what I meant by "recommend." Ordered the farm egg pizza and a mexican coke. 
Just really a meh experience, the place is incredibly tiny. 
I like to support local businesses, but not if the staff carries a "locals only" or arrogant attitude.
author: Christine Y.

description:
Outstanding! Sat at the bar and loved watching the pizza artists. Everyone really works together to provide excellent service and atmosphere, despite the cozy quarters. 

Housemade meatball/fennel pizza was our favorite

Tons of take out orders being placed/picked-up too!
author: Antoinette S.

description: No place like this little gem. True to its roots, it's been around since Tamar Pelz opened it up a long long time ago. You can still get a proper Margherita (she sold the secret recipe to the new owners) and the wine selection remains somewhat true to its brilliant origins. The place has panache, it hangs together, and it has something of the true neighborhood vibe. It takes some time to sit down, but it's fine. It's heated outside, there's a nice tree to sit under, and they'll even bring you wine. Very romantic. Great spot for a date.
author: Lawrence C.

description: It always manages to be a special meal when I eat here. The pizza offerings are always spot-on. Even the more imaginative combinations.
author: David M.

description:
By far, my favorite spot for pizza. It doesn't hurt that it's in my neighborhood, so visits can be frequent! It's a tiny restaurant with 4 tables inside, a handful of bar seating and 4 tables outside with heat lamps. Personally, totally worth the wait.

There are rotating items but they also have menu staples - everything is delicious. All of their pizzas with the farm egg are so tasty, you must try it. Most recently, I had the English Peas, Bacon, Pecorino, Garlic, Cream, Parsley pizza, the Margherita with White Anchovies pizza, the Panna Cotta with Strawberries and the House Made Flourless Chocolate Cake.

The pizzas are thin crust, just the way I prefer pizza and are personal size, 6 slices. It's fun to get a couple and share. The flavors are simple and not overly heavy.
author: Megan L.

description:
I encountered one of the rudest workers I've ever met at an establishment in San Francisco at Pizzetta. It was literally a few minutes ago, on a Saturday night, I saw many people outside waiting to be seated so I knew there would be quite a wait to get in. I walked into the restaurant and asked if I can put my name down on the list (with a smile on my face by the way). The worker immediately asked me, "So you want to be number 14?" I was really confused and asked if it was ok if I put my name down again. He pointed to the list and said, "you are going to behind all these people." Obviously, I knew that by the people waiting outside. And so I responded, "how long will the wait be." He responded in a very rude and condescending tone,"well all these people have to be seated, order, eat, and pay. It's going to be a very long time." To which I responded, "So, do you not want me to eat here?" And he responded, "Unless you want to wait a really long time, you should reconsider."

I immediately turned around and left. I was not going to wait to be seated in a restaurant that would give me such trouble just to add my name on your wait list.
author: Linda N.

description:
Small menu, even smaller restaurant. We're talking, maybe 4 or 5 tables inside, and 2 or 3 tables outside. In a very unassuming location, too. You can smell the delicious aromas floating through the front entrance. YUM.

Pizzas are so delicious! Thin, crisp crust with fresh ingredients on top. I'll take a runny yolk over just about anything, so when I saw they had a pizza topped with a sunny side up egg, I couldn't resist. Really nice variety, even if there are only a handful of items on the menu. They keep it seasonal and fresh, so the menu changes often. I can dig it.

Already looking forward to our next visit, hope it's soon!
author: Kristen S.

description:
My sister's family and I wanted to get dinner before I had to run off to the Peninsula for a meeting.  They'd been wanting to try Pizzetta 211 for the longest time and we lucked out on parking and walked right in.  If it wasn't for the cute, dog-friendly tables outside, we never would have even noticed that they were open.

Prices for entrees typically ranged between $10-15 for a tiny portion.  I decided to try their calzone, my sister the margherita, and my brother in law, pepperoni and basil.  The food itself was delicious and you could taste the freshness of the ingredients.  However, after we finished up, we were all still hungry and could have easily downed a whole other pizza.

For a place with such a high price point, I'm surprised that they only accept cash.  Sure, it's a small shop and all, but it seems pretty popular and I bet they turn a lot of people away as a result of the cash thing.  I expected a whole lot more for our money and certainly didn't feel like I got great value, leaving a less than thrilled taste in my mouth.  For that kind of money, I'd much prefer Basic pizza.  There's a little bit of an elitist, hipster air here as well, but if you want just a taste of good pizza, give Pizzetta a try.

Food: 8/10

Service: 9/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 8/10
author: Joe M.

description: I love to come here with my sister when I am up in the city. It is a neighborhood gem and super cozy.  The arugula pizza is amazing and our staple every time we eat here (so please don't ever take it off the menu) and we also had the squash pizza last night, also just as amazing! It's definitely worth it. All in all I am already craving the pizzas I had last night so I can't wait to get back up there! Oh, their desserts are also heavenly, not what you'd expect from a pizza place so definitely say yes to the dessert!!
author: SP G.

description:
The lamb sausage & eggplant Pizza was one of the best and most unique pizza' I've ever had! Restaurant has an awesome mellow vibe for a date. Its small and busy but not loud.

Service and beer / winelist (no Merlot at a pizza place?) were both good but not excellent which is why I'm holding back a star. Pizza itself was 5-star. EAT HERE!!
author: Colin B.

description:
Tiny little gem of a restaurant with delicious, creative pizzas. We waited for a long time for a seat, even on a Thursday night, but it was definitely worth the wait. There were two of us, so we ordered two pizzas and the cheese salad. The cheese salad was delicious and very generous. The salads were both tasty, crunchy and full of fresh ingredients. We were so full that we had to bring half a pizza home.

Also great beer!
author: Carolyn M.

description:
This cute little (seriously, little) hipster pizza place far out in the Richmond delivered us a memorable experience. 

It was a long wait for the two of us and you probably don't want a party size too much bigger. We waited over 30 minutes from just before 7 on a Friday evening. But our server, who had an amusing, dry sense of humor, genuinely apologized for the wait both before and after our seating. As the only server, he was working his butt off, but overall did a good job. However, because their menu of appetizers, mains, and desserts rotate relatively often, he didn't seem knowledgeable of all the items they were serving. 

I thought the tiny TV in the washroom was really neat, its small size was almost a symbol of the restaurant's size, positioned perfectly if you're a male peeing.

Our appetizer, the mushroom crostini with beretta cheese, was served promptly and was delicious. The stronger taste of the mushroom and garlic balanced well with the side of cheese that almost resembled a poached egg.

Pizzas were thin with a slight crisp and a liberal amount of toppings. There were only chilli flakes on the side. It would've been better if they offered freshly grated parmesan cheese. The pizzas were definitely good, but not amazing.

For the appetizer, two pizzas, two beers, and one dessert, it came to about $62. I was bothered that we never told the prices of the appetizers or desserts; it wasn't on the menu and they didn't reveal its price on the bill. My guess is that they were each just under $10.
author: Andrew D.

description: This place is so cute and so awesome! I came on a Sunday afternoon with a group of four so we got lucky with not having to wait. We were seated at the bar. It was cool watching the chefs make all the pizzas. We ordered the sausage pizza and the farm egg! Both were amazing! The ingredients were so fresh and delicious. I love that the pizzas are individual sized so you can easily order a couple and share with the group. Definitely want to come back and try the other pizzas!
author: Nia R.

description:
Pros: 
- Cozy, romantico atmosphere
- Creative, yet tasteful topping combinations
- Crust is crunchy and delicious
Cons:
- Very limited seating
Depending on your taste:
- Not where you should go if you are looking for orthodox Neapolitan pizza
- Not if you are looking for large variety. While I like short menus, that's not for everyone
author: Carlo P.

description: Their thin crust savory pizzas were absolutely incredible, but this was the worst service I have ever experienced in my life. From the moment my friend requested a table, the server projected an extremely offensive attitude, making our dining experience difficult and unpleasant.
author: Priscilla S.

description: LOVE. tiny place but I came in between lunch and dinner so we were actually able to get a table. Such a great ambiance. I'm scared to come here during normal dining times but with the right company, it's well worth the wait
author: Melissa T.

description:
Phew, finally finally tried this little "hidden treasure" for a date night last night (Wednesday). Called beforehand around 7pm to take a chance and see if there was a wait, luckily there wasn't! But, beware, they seem very serious about not seating people without their full party there. Although understandable, the waiter that night seemed to say it pretty aggressively to everyone that walked through the door. A "hello!" first would have been nice.. 

Cheese salad was yummy - we had one with goat and sheep milk, didn't like how the olives were served in a bowl on the plate tipped over everything (not sure if this is normal?). Pizzas were great. My margarita was literally out of this world yummy. My date had the one with curry, potatoes etc. and we both thought the margarita was way better. Pretty pricey menu but you get what you pay for, this isn't Domino's! 

One star off because I felt that the server was a bit distant and pretentious. Guy with dark black glasses. He barely knew how to correctly explain the cheese to us, and we felt he had a rude-ish air to him. On top of this, keeping the door open on cold SF nights makes it pretty chilly inside, I would have like a more warm and cozy vibe. Lastly, WINE GLASSES. Why why why whyyyyy do you use water glasses for the wine?! Tacky.
author: Alexis T.

description:
It's a super quaint little shop in the richmond.  Only 4 tables inside and a few outside.  Probably a wait normally, but we went at 2:30pm.  Really nice staff and cool decoration.  It's very good personal pizza with some interesting toppings.  The crust is light and crispy and the flavors work very well together.  We got three pizzas and the flourless chocolate cake ($6.50):
Farm Egg, Asparagus, Shallot, Lemon-Chili Ricotta  17.00
Finochio Salame, Fennel, Red Onion, Kumquat Tapenade, Ricotta Salata 16.00
House Made Pork Carnitas, Guacamole, Creme Fraiche, Cotija 16.00

The chocolate cake was rich, but not that special I thought.  I gave it four stars because while very good, I don't think it was worth the pricetag.
author: Phil D.

description: Been back to Pizzetta multiple times and have never been disappointed.  Definitely a joint that I'll always come back to.  The staff is always friendly and the food remains top notch.
author: Shirley T.

description: I love this place!  I had a delicious farro and brussels sprout salad and a cheese pizza for lunch with my toddler.  While in a corner seat, we enjoyed a delicious meal with friendly service. I can't wait to go back!
author: Vanessa L.

description: Pizetta 211 is a bit of a splurge, but when I have a hankering for thin crust gourmet pizza, it's worth it. The roster of pizzas is seasonal and ever changing, but I have never been disappointed. I usually order take out but on the few occasions that I have dined there on warm, Indian summer evenings, it has been a real treat. The restaurant is tiny but there are a few tables out on the sidewalk under a lovely tree. It is a fun spot to enjoy the neighborhood ambiance.
author: Carole B.

description: Small restaurant (really only 26 seats), but its a quick 10-15 minute wait, and definitely worth it. The food is amazing, and I would recommend the artichoke soup: it is the BEST i've ever had. Staff are nice and respectful, and I will definitely come here again!
author: Riley G.

description: Pizza's great!  Sometimes the toppings are kinda funky, but different is good!  We had an awesome fig salad a while ago; I wish they could offer all the time!
author: Michelle K.

description:
God, this was a great decision. 

It was my second of two nights in SF and I wanted pizza. My friend picked out this spot and after a wild adventure finding parking, we finally got there...only to wait outside for about 45 minutes. It was kinda cold, and there was not a place to sit, but we each got a drink and waited patiently. 

There were three tables of two outside and maybe a total of 15 seats inside. What a tiny place! 

We finally got seated (opted for the bar) and had a great view of the chefs making the salads and pizzas, and preparing desserts. 

We got a heirloom tomato salad (their special of the night) and the lamb sausage pizza. Both were incredible. 
The salad was so fresh and light, with just enough parm and croutons garnished on top. The pizza was perfect. It was airy, not too tomato-y, and the crust was just browned enough. 

We were in love. We talked to the waiters and to the woman behind the bar, making pizzas. She described the place as kind of a "co-op," with several of the staff having small shares of ownership. 

Overall, we had a great experience. The place was really cute, with a great ambiance and nice decor. The menu was small but everything tasted and looked delicious. The staff was very helpful and kind. It was worth the wait and worth the price. I love it!
author: Amy R.

description: Super cozy spot with fresh ingredients. Always a different pizza or salad to try. Get there early because seating is really limited (but worth the wait). Prompt and friendly staff, with a relaxed atmosphere -- I Highly recommended this place if you're on that side of town !
author: Dan E.

description:
Mon Petit Bijou!

Anyone who knows me, knows I am a huge fan of pizzerias and I have high standards for the thin-crusted amazingness I crave on a regular basis.

Pizzetta 211 has stolen my heart indefinitely. 

With a very small indoor seating area, it can be hard to grab a spot inside....but Pizzetta has seating outdoors with heating lamps and they even provide blankets on extra chilly nights. If you are able to snag a spot indoors, the large windows and busy kitchen will feel very personal and intimate. 

 The menu is fresh, thoughtful, and changes on a regular basis. All things I look for in local restaurants. French wine pairs nicely with the menu, and I over heard several tables gossiping about the flour-less chocolate cake made fresh in house. I'll have to pace myself...and make myself a regular here. 

Italian is best shared with good friends, so I'll be expecting some of my favorite east bay Yelpers to join me here very soon!
author: Jocelyn B.

description:
4.5stars

Very small little rustic cafe serving up pizza & vino. 

Great service and atmosphere, although you have to be comfortable with tight spaces. 

Have tried three different pizzas and they were all super tasty! 

The crust is thin, so its not overly filling and you can easily eat many slices. The crust is great, it has a flavor to it and is soft but has a bite and doesn't get soggy or floppy. 

All the ingredients they use for sauces, cheeses, and toppings are clearly high quality. 

They had no problem substituting certain things to make the pizzas more vegetarian friendly, but the guy would also tell me when he didn't think something was a good combination and recommended what he thought would taste/pair better. 

The farm eggs added to the pizza were delish! I loved cutting through the yoke and having it run over the pizza. There was only two eggs though, and I definitely thought they could have used a couple more.
author: Angela K.

description:
The pizza is so good. I want some right now and I don't even live in the city anymore. It really doesn't get much better than this.

Its small and it would probably be nice to but a table or two bu the outside seating benches, but other than that.. great great place!
author: L S.

description:
3 words: real artisan pizza

First off, I'm glad I discovered this place in the Richmond. Usually for these types of places I would end up venturing all the way out to the Mission or the Marina but this place is 2 blocks from my house - 1 UP! I can easily walk over and avoid the annoyance of having to find parking in the Richmond which we all know doesn't exist during feeding hours and weekends. I can also walk over on weeknights when it's less crowded so there is little to no wait - 2 UP! Ok less digressing, more talking about food and ambiance.

This place is super small but super quaint. There were probably about 4-5 tables inside to seat 2-4 people each. There are 2 tables outside to seat 2-4 people each. Has a very nice rustic and intimate decor. I would imagine it'd be a relaxing place to have lunch on a sunny day. I feel like I just transported into someone's kitchen somewhere in Europe staring out into a green pasture. It would also be the perfect place for a casual date or to gather your thoughts for your next amazing artsy project - 3 UP!

The pies. Amazing fresh ingredients are used for these little delicious pies. Topping choices are so rustic and they work so well together. We ordered the zucchini, yellow tomato, goat cheese, feta cheese, lemon, and thyme pizza paired with the tomato, basil, mozzarella, sardines, and 2 farm eggs pizza (the farm eggs were add ons).  The dough was perfectly cooked from a brick oven. The crust was crispy, light and thin.  It was so good, we completely finished both even though we were already full 2/3 way through. They're maybe 8 inches in diameter?  Prices were not bad either. Somewhere between $10-$15 - 4 UP!

Best of all, the waiters were a pleasure to talk to and really polite - 5 UP!!

This is a MUST TRY.... I mean this place sucks. Don't come here.... lol.
author: Dorothy W.

description:
My wife and I went here on Super Bowl Sunday -- part of an emerging tradition of going to restaurants when everyone else is not. It is not really in a commercial district, which is nice -- it feels like part of the neighborhood, like a corner store except it is a corner restaurant. We walked right in and sat at the counter, in what appeared to be the last seats in the house (so, probably pretty busy when there isn't a Super Bowl on). 

The pizza was excellent, but what really made it stand out was the people working there. The counter has a view right into the kitchen, so we got to watch the pizzas being made, and at one point the woman who was doing most of the making talked me through her technique -- which was actually super-helpful, I just made some pizzas last night and they were much better for it. The guy behind the counter gave us extra olives for free, and then when we couldn't decide between two desserts, he offered us "half and half" of each of them, which seemed to us more like "two for one" since each half was still quite large. And they were just very friendly and it was fun to watch them work together from the vantage point of the counter. 

Super-excellent experience.
author: Joseph M.

description:
A great addition to the neighborhood, that's warm, welcoming, and ultra cozy both inside (small tables, candles) and out (heat lamps, hanging lights on the trees). In an otherwise very residential area, Pizzetta is the perfect place to stop in and grab a solid bite to eat, when you don't want to stray far from home. However, it's not a destination restaurant.

They serve pizza, salads, and dessert, and only a handful of each, so be prepared for a small but thoughtful menu. The pizzas are impossibly fresh and served to you seconds after coming out of the oven. But, both of ours were very minimalistic, flavor wise. When it says "tomato, arugula, marscapone" it means literally only those things; so I was liberal with the red pepper flakes and salt on the table. 

It's pricey but filled with ambience and a fresh, seasonal menu.
author: Laura J.

description:
My favorite pizza parlor in the bay area!  Too bad its so far away from me...

Its a small restaurant...small bar, few tables, and some tables outside.  Small restroom, and small kitchen.  but its nice to sit at the bar and see the chef make the pizza's.  

I've tried the farm egg, prosciutto, walnut and arugula pizza, salad, the chocolate cake, and the espresso.  The pizza is thin crusted, and the ingredients are very fresh.  Hard to describe how delicious the pizza is...i guess with the crispy crust, farm egg and prosciutto you get a pretty explosive taste.  Each bite full of flavor..and when the yolk drips on the pizza...the bites are even better.  A slice of heaven you could say.  I really wanted to try the ox tail pizza, but it wasn't available when we were here.  for desert the chocolate cake with espresso was a good way to end the meal.  very soft cake...and not too sweet.  

Since i'm a non-san francisoan, parking is pretty difficult to find.  we ended up driving around a few blocks before getting lucky and finding a spot.  If i had a top ten list of favorite restaurants...this place would definitely be on the list!
author: John P.

description:
This is a small, high-quality artisanal pizza place. The bi-weekly pizzas toppings are interesting creations and the desserts are delicious. Especially the apple crumble. 

The space inside is small, and there are also a few tables outside. There may be a wait, but it's worth it.
author: Anna G.

description:
Excellent pies. Kind of a hybrid style, a bit of NY, a bit of New Haven, a bit of Neapolitan. Nice toppings, some unusual combos. The crust is fantastic. Sauce is a touch sweet. The white pie with sheep cheese, rosemary, pine nuts and olive oil is off the hook.

Reviewers who claim eating pizza in NYC as some kind of cred indicator are funny. NYC has tons of crappy pizza joints slinging pepperoni slices. This place is legit.
author: Deacon B.

description:
Meh. Pizza could use a kick of flavor. 

Same result for both eat-in and take-out. The crust was decent, but the sauce and toppings are just ok. For the price, I expected more. It certainly wasn't worth the wait when we dined-in. 

You also see a fair number of the Sea Cliff set which supports the high prices. A couple next to us with their young daughter spent $80 on pizza and drinks.

Oh yeah, parking is pain as well.
author: J. M.

description: This pizza place is very cute and full by the time we stopped by after 1 pm on a Friday. We sat at the bar as it was the only seats left. Staff was friendly. Seems like they have very few ingredients but all of its fresh. I'm guessing it's because their menu is small and they change constantly which is a positive. I ordered their fresh egg, garlic and mushroom pizza and it was good. They literally crack an egg on the pizza so only certain slices had egg on it. I liked the pizza much better without the egg as it tasted like a very gourmet garlic bread. Thin and crispy crust. My friend ordered a pesto pizza with purple potato and fancy ham. That was delicious but wasn't a fan of the potato. We both agreed there should have been more meat on her pizza and more meat options on the menu. Nice if you're a vegetarian. The reason I gave this place just three stars despite the food and service being decent is because the food wasn't so great to justify the cost or a repeat visit.
author: Carol L.

description:
My wife and I came to Pizzetta 211 on a brisk Thursday evening around 6:30pm. As other reviewers note, this place is small, and it was already full but the hostess offered us seats at the bar, which we happily accepted as it gave us a clear view of the pizzaiolos working their magic in the kitchen. It also placed us directly in front of the domed pastry stand that housed the flourless chocolate cake, which my wife eyed hungrily the entire time we were there. This is a tight operation: one hostess and three guys in the kitchen-- one stretching out the dough, assembling pizzas, and managing the oven, one taking phone orders, serving customers at the bar, and replenishing items as they were used, and one finishing pizzas, cleaning, and assembling the other sides/starters they offer. These guys were machines, and we were a little mesmerized by their constant motion. 

We are both vegetarian, and we ordered the Moroccan Roasted Butternut Squash, Brussell sprout, and hazelnut picada pizza (a rotating one) and Rosemary, Fiore Sardo Cheese, Pinenuts pizza and as well as their potato gratin as a starter 

The gratin, with pesto inside and topped with burrata, was rich and wonderful and has inspired us to recreate this dish for Thanksgiving. The pizzas were amazing as well, with a thin crust and bright flavors. Our only regret was that we didn't order a pizza topped with tomato sauce, but after finishing everything we were too full. So full that my wife even passed on the cake she'd been mentally devouring throughout our visit. 

We will definitely be back!
author: T K.

description: This pizza was a bit too expensive for the actual product. They don't do delivery, and the shop itself is super tiny and very hipster-esque (which is fine, just an FYI). The pizzas were small (about 14 inches), and even though I picked them up promptly, they were cold by the time I got home about 15 minutes later. The dough was too thin, and there was too much sauce/liquid on the pie. Overall, I wouldn't recommend.
author: mary g.

description:
My friend raved about how this was the best pizza she ever had, and while I can't say the same, it was still an enjoyable meal. The pizzas are personal sized, so my partner and I got two to share. The first was a sausage and bacon one that we loved. The second came later because they had to remake the pizza after dropping a piece during plating. It was no problem since my partner and I were sharing anyway, but after having the delicious gourmet pizza, the regular pepperoni pizza was a little bit of a let down.

The place is tiny, in someone's former garage. Get there early to get a table inside. They have tables outside as well, and will serve you beverages if you're stuck waiting for a table. Wine is, unfortunately, served in the same glassware as water, so there's that super casual atmosphere going on.
author: Apple P.

description: My daughter and I eat here every time we're in the city. It's a small, hole in the wall place with excellent food and wine. Fresh, delicious ingredients and great service keep this our go-to joint. The short rib pizza is unreal.
author: Erica C.

description:
I want to write a love letter to Pizzetta 211 after the incredible, amazing dinner we had on New Year's Eve. Two days later we're still sure we'll never forget it.  We've been diehard Pizzetta 211 fans for years, their food is ALWAYS amazing and incredible and delicious and every other superlative applied to well-made fresh food.

But last new year's eve, even before dinner was over we were mentally signing up for any future prix fixe menus they would ever offer.

We had this gorgeous menu that obviously had a lot of planning and love put into the preparation. Everything, and I mean every bite of all eight courses, was done perfectly. 

1. Country-style Pork Terrine, pickled vegetables, crostini and cheeses plate.
2. Celery Root Soup with Toasted Hazelnut, Brown Butter, Sage and Creme Fraiche
3. Blood Orange, Fennel and Avocado Salad with Pistachios, Cotija Cheese and Cumin-Lime Vinaigrette (this combination of orange/avo/nuts was incredible together)
4. Mussels Steamed with Anchor Steam and White Wine (this should be on their menu permanently)
5. San Marzano, Mascarpone, Wild Arugula Pizzetta
6. Wild Rice, Shiitake Mushroom and Butternut Squash Risotto (creamiest risotto I've ever had)
7. Roasted Chicken and Pork Sausage with Butterball Potato Puree and Fried Brussels Sprouts
8. Dessert Medley of Flourless Chocolate Cake, Panacotta with raspberry sauce and ginger cookies, and the most delicious Pear Tart I've ever had.

We are going to be back for more Pizzetta soon, but we really want to keep our eyes peeled for another opportunity to dine on their hand-crafted special dinner - that was a night to go down in our dining history book. 

Thanks, Jack & Susan! Thanks Cory for your wonderful service and for every staff member working to make that dream reality. Please do it again!
author: Kira B.

description: There's always a crowd of people outside, but tonight we lucked out and grabbed a seat at the bar. Our server told us the simple menu of pizza and starters changes every few weeks. We tried the kale salad with apples, hazelnuts, and some delicious dressing and shared two pizzas, a classic margherita-ish pizza with mascarpone, and a fingerling potato pizza with garlic and gruyere -- everything was delicious. The service was also great and friendly. I can't wait to go back!
author: Teryll H.

description:
This has the best thin and delicious pizza in SF.
They make interesting topping combinations and really put some thought into their menu. I don't know what time I recommend going in because it is so small! It is a hit or miss with seating, and sitting at the bar is the best. 
We ended up calling in our order as the restaurant is tiny and only has a few tables. Then when we got there, had one person go in and pay and they brought the pizza to our car when it was ready! Such great service. Bomb pizza straight to my car. Then we went on a picnic in the Presidio, very tempted to eat these on the way.
We got the basic tomato, mozzarella, and basil and wow was I impressed! Perfect crust and ratio of ingredients. We also got the special, which had pesto, pine nuts, feta, and potato. Also amazing! 
Love that they rotate several pizzas on their menu every couple of weeks- they really know how to get people to come back! I will have to add this into my diet every 2 weeks.
Such a cute place with so much character and friendly waiters.
author: Alisha K.

description: Great little place.  My friend and I had dinner here, and shared a salad and two pizzas - the perfect amount of food for two people.  The two pizzas were with housemade sausage and broccoli di ciccio, and with peas, pancetta and parm.  Both were excellent - super flavorful and light - as was the salad. Our server made some great wine recommendations, and was very attentive and responsive.  This is a small, cheerful space, with both indoor and outdoor seating.  Highly recommended.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Mostly reiterating what other people have already mentioned: chocolate flourless cake is superb. I don't have much of a sweet tooth and I'm not super fond of chocolate-y things, but this was amazing! It was the perfect balance of sweet and bitter (from the dark chocolate) and freshly whipped cream mmm.

The pizza is also fantastic, my boyfriend and I weren't too hungry so we just shared one for dinner, so they are decently sized. Most people would probably want to order two and have some left over though.
author: Crystal L.

description: This is not your ordinary pizza place. Gourmet, beautiful crust, fresh ingredients, great combinations(but not over complicated). The wine and beer selection was definitely thought out and seemed to be chosen by a true connoisseur. The service was great, didn't take forever to get our food...luckily this hole in the wall didn't have a wait. Mellow neighborhood street, family friendly, a great place to a couple of people but not large groups. I will definitely return!
author: Skye J.

description:
Pizzetta 211 is my favorite place in San Francisco for thin crust pizza.  Tucked away in a residential area of the Richmond District, this place is a hidden gem.  

What makes their pizzas so delicious is their excellent crust and exotic toppings.  Their crust is thin and crispy on the outside with just the right amount of chewiness on the inside.  Each pizza will have only 3 to 4 toppings so that each ingredient shines, marrying together in a burst of flavor when you take your first and last bite.  Simplicity has never tasted so good!  

The menu changes every week, depending on what fresh, local ingredients they have on hand.  You can't go wrong with their tomato, mozzarella, and basil pizza, but I recommend trying the maitake mushroom pizza with farm egg or spicy braised lamb pizza when they're available.  If you have room for dessert, their buttery lemon tart is a must try also.

The restaurant is very cozy, seating 10-12 people at most, so it'd be perfect for a date, but not a large group.  Parking is challenging as well, but spaces are usually available on Lake Street.
author: Anthony H.

description:
By FAR our favorite pizza in the city and perhaps anywhere, including (gulp) Italy.  The crust is sublime--perfectly textured, the right combination of tender, crisp, and chewy.  How do they do that?

The miniscule place can be a challenging table to nab, but the cozy, rustic atmosphere and laid back, friendly staff make you feel at home, no matter how slammed they are.  There are blankets and seating out front to wait on those cold foggy days.

But PIzzette is all about--of course--the pizza.  Every day they have about 8 pies, with no substitutions allowed.  A few items are standard--margherita, one with rosemary and parmigiana etc.--but the rest are daily specials depending on what succulent ingredients and imaginative combinations could be rustled up that day.

The first item on the menu always features a farm egg and these are often the best choices, but the other daily specials are often not to be missed.  There's always a calzone on the list, too.

They usually have a special dessert, which are frequently pretty special, if you pardon the turn of phrase.  I like a cold Peroni in the bottle with my pizza and they've expanded the salad/appetizer choices usually available every day as well.

We have never had a single bad item here, or disappointing pizza and it's a favorite standby when we can't decide on anything else.  

Pizzette 211 is a wonderful wonderful gem in a diamond tiara of a city, and I hope it never really changes.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Pizzetta (little pizzas) --- come here if you want to indulge in small pizzas with huge personalities =)

Had the Coppa, Corno di Toro Pepper and Roasted Corn Pizza (the juicy, sweet charred corn was such a yummy addition to the pizza, balanced out the bitter peppers and the savoriness of the coppa) and the San Marzano Tomato Sauce, Mascarpone, Wild Arugula, Olio Verde Pizza (the tomato sauce was so fresh and tangy, and the bursts of creamy mascarpone were a delicious surprise)

Each pizza is around $12-15 and is around maybe 11'' in diameter. The pizza menu lists several different options and changes weekly, featuring all these unique, bold flavorful combinations on the pies that are torturous to choose between.

The crust here is less puffy, chewy and charred around the edges compared to other wood fired pizza in SF, but it's the right amount of salty and has a nice crunch, bordering a little on chewy. I think the focus is the flavor explosion and gourmetness of the toppings.

I have my eye on the House Made Sausage/Chard/Gruyere/Garlic Confit and the Farm Egg/Bacon/Radicchio/Caramelized Onion/Gorgonzola Dolce...they'll probably be gone by the time I get the chance to come here again but I'm sure whatever replaces them will be just as delish!
author: Jessica C.

description:
stopped by for lunch after doing the lands end trail. there was no wait and we were seated right away. out of the corner of my eye i spotted a beautifully browned caramel colored cake, and immediately thought i would not leave without having it. 
my sister and i shared he field green salad (good to make yourself feel healthy before scarfing a pizza)  and then the tomato, mozzarella, basil pizza. we thought about getting the egg one, but i don't like mustard and that turned out to be the main sauce in it. anyway, the pizza was delicious. the mozzarella was great -- incredibly fresh. the dough and the sauce are great too. 
then for dessert, obviously i had to get that cake I'd been eyeing the whole time. and it did not disappoint. it was apple walnut cake that came with cream on the side and an absolutely divine salted caramel sauce. perfectly cozy for this time of year. couldn't have been more pleased.
author: Rita K.

description: Tiny place with fantastic pizza and a nice little selection of beer and wine.  Only a few tables so best to get there early or be prepared to wait. There was a pizza that had something like a pork chili verde topping....a marriage of Mexico and Italy that somehow created magic. It was new to the menu. Order it and bliss will follow.
author: Timothy S.

description:
Maybe I am not into the fancy pizza scene or willing to pay nearly $20 after tax and tip for a personal size pizza but I believe the 4.5 stars on yelp is a tad overrated. The atmosphere is nice and intimate with candles but kinda cramped. There is about 20 seats with heaters for the outdoor ones.

Got the farm egg pizza with pesto, and prosciutto. The pizza is slightly bigger than your average personal size but smaller than a small. The crust was very thin and crispy and the toppings were nothing extraordinary. 

Overall, the pizza tastes homemade and have different combinations but nothing I would go out of my way to try. I would advise not having a party bigger than 3-4 here as the place is very small.
author: Robert Y.

description: Don't order the èpoisses cheese for the cheese plate unless you know what you're getting yourself into. Nastiest, stankiest cheese ever. The smell was so bad that the little boy next to us was asking his parents if they could leave! The taste was vile. Why even serve it? The waitress didn't disclose the flavor profile of this cheese or tell us if it was comparable to the one they ran out of. Just saying "it's èpoisses, it's a cows milk cheese" isn't going to cut it. We clearly didn't eat any of it and she had no intention of asking us if we were displeased.
author: Liz G.

description: The pizza here is great, but far from being the best I've had. Unfortunately, I cannot say the same about the service. The lady on the phone and the man that greeted me were both curt and lacked any warmness/hospitality. I did not feel welcome at all. I will not be back with so many other great places to eat in sf/ bay area.
author: Emily G.

description: Like a homemade pizza should be. Simple, fresh, and local ingredients. Love this spot has a home town feel. Literary a hole in the wall spot.
author: Brent W.

description: Small pizzeria with excellent food.  Popped in for lunch, got a seat outside (only a handful of seats inside and out) service was good.  Pizza expensive but as good as it gets.  If you are looking for a deal and a large pizza try Pizza Hut or Dominos.
author: Des D.

description:
This business falls right into the "If I owned a business, it would -- hopefully -- look a lot like this." Ever notice that the conversation of the best pizza in San Francisco is a pretty contentious topic, which might be because there isn't that much that's all good and worth the money. Delfina takes the limelight. Una does too. If you know of a classic Brooklyn style pizza, I'd love to see it but clearly the crafty Neapolitans are the norm, and 211 is my choice. The ingredients are fresher. The combinations are a little riskier -- say whole anchovies. 

I have come to the conclusion that the best way to dine out with my girlfriend when she wants to is that I just pick a place, no waffling, confirm they're open & go for it. This was that moment. And in that one shining moment, I shined with the choice -- take that Choice Fatigue of my generation! 

They opened at 5pm, and by 5:25 they were a full house -- granted they have seating for about 16. But still! Vultures, I congratulate you. We waited for about 15-20 minutes for a table to open up, and honestly why wouldn't I want to wait? Bench. Neighborhood street. Positive atmosphere. Once seated, in a window sill. I felt more adorable than I do, normally. 

Maybe we didn't need the cheese board. But maybe we love cheese & olives. The egg & prosciutto pizza was the tops. The anchovies & pepperoni pizza was one of my favorite pizzas I've ever eaten though. Salty. Sweet. Savory. Weird. 

While cramped, every table is charming, including the kitchen bar. Just be prepared to be cramped & you will be A-OK. Combined with the charm & the quality, this is one of my favorite places to dine in the city.
author: Jon A.

description:
PROS
Location
Unique Flavors

CONS
Unfriendly 
Super tiny

The pizza flavors are unique and great for one who enjoys artisan foods.

Three of us shared two pizzas, if you are super hungry you may want to add more. But two will be perfect. We stumbled on this place just by passing by on a light stroll through the neighborhood. It looked cute and so we decided to stay. The space is super tiny easy to miss and fits a few people, I am guessing 10. We were squeezed at a tiny table that didn't accommodate us, at one point I place my cup of water on a ledge, there was simply no room.

Considering the location/neighborhood you would think the service here would be ideal. Sadly it is not. 

We ate our pizzas and left. I don't see myself returning her, nor do I see myself recommending this place to family and friends when they are visiting.
author: R. D.

description:
This place is an unassuming gem in the Outer Richmond.

The interior of the restaurant is small and cozy, with dim lighting and tables that are nested close together. It's a great date spot, though be considerate of the weather conditions when you visit since you will be waiting outside. I came here on Saturday night and was pleasantly surprised by the lack of wait. 

The menu is a curated mix of new creations (rotated every couple of weeks) and then a trio of favorites. At any pizza place I visit for the first time I'll order a margherita as a benchmark, and then one with toppings. For our basic we went with the San Marzano, the purported staff favorite, and for our topping ordered the roasted cauliflower pizza. I was dubious of a cauliflower-topped pizza, but I was bowled over. Both pizzas were phenomenal, and rival any that I've had in the city.
author: John B.

description: This has been on my list for a long time due to the stellar reviews. We tried the mozzarella/tomato and also a chorizo with sunny side egg. The Margerita had a lot of olive oil on it which did enhance the flavor, but the crust and sauce was very lacking. The crust was dry, crackery, charred with no texture. The chorizo was creative and the runny egg added to the flavor but again the crust was very lacking. Il Casaro in North Beach has a better thin crust pie in my opinion.
author: Roland L.

description: Where do I even begin to explain how FANTASTIC of an experience eating at this place was for me. I've lived in the SF Bay Area for all my life and this was one of the top five most memorable pizza eating experiences in my life. Starting with the great service - you will wait a bit but that's okay - the quality of the ingredients and the flavors you will experience - this will be one of the best food experiences of your SF food life!
author: Edwin S.

description: This is a secret spot that tops anything ive seen. Great thin crust that sits so nicely after its gone. Creations that vary from fried eggs to pork belly slaw. Who would have thought such a gourmet ruby was hidden right in outer richmond in the residential area. Great beer and wine selection as well.  Be careful about the lunch and dinner rush. They can only seat around 8 tables. But it is well worth it. And what a treat, the bathroom has a small television that adds some great pizzaz for all the men out there. Definitely have to check this place.
author: Izaak W.

description:
Currently chugging a bottle of the ever so fancy Trader Joe's wine, feeling pumped up to write this semi-sober review. How do I chug and type at the same time? Well, it takes a lot of skill, wit, and a dash of genius, but basically I'm just really talented.

A chef friend of mine recommended this restaurant for me, but warned me about the super small space and wait ahead of time. I was mentally prepared for this, but the wait was excruciatingly long (1.5 hours), and my blood sugar levels were running dangerously close to diva levels and I felt extremely delirious by the time we were seated. Even so, in the name of Food, I marched onward. 

We ordered 
- The mixed greens salad with spiced candied walnuts and a balsamic dressing
- The special, which was a proscuitto cantaloupe burrata arugula dish that was deelish
- Pine nut and rosemary pizza
- Farmer's egg pizza
- Margherita pizza 
- Squash pizza
- Flourless chocolate cake w/ chantilly cream

The pizzas are packed with flavor, but they're extremely thin and are fun-sized, so I would suggest ordering one per person. The only problem I had with these pizzas was the actual construction of it; they were smaller than average and so thin that they lost heat extremely quickly. By the time you were onto your second or third helpings, the slices would already be lukewarm. 

The most memorable part of my meal there was--surprisingly--the dessert. This cake calmed down my fat kid soul and put it in a state of absolute bliss and serenity.
author: Kandice K.

description:
Wow one of the best pizzas I have ever had!  This place ranks #2 in my books, right behind pizzeria Mozza in LA.  The crust is really thin and crispy and they pile on fresh local ingredients.  My favorite part, plenty of melting oozing cheesey goodness on top of this amazing pizza.  Now if only they had more pizza flavors to choose from.  

I tried both the pizzetta special and the prosciutto pizza.  The pizzetta pizza was topped with green chilies and chorizo, and two sunny side up eggs.  Super delicious and not heavy.  The prosciutto had a garlic base with a 4 cheese blend and sun dried tomatoes.  I enjoyed both pizzas and continued to eat ever after I was stuffed, because you cant let good pizza go to waste.  The bar seating is the best spot because you get to watch the chefs hand toss your pizza and put your pizza together.  I would have preferred an even thinner crust, which is why Pizza Mozza in LA is still my top spot...but the crust here is very thin and crispy to my liking.  

Be prepared to wait..this shop is tiny and maybe holds 20ppl max.  I see a lot of take out orders for those who don't want to wait for a seat.  The menu is pretty limited, there are about 5 pizzas to choose from, a few salads, and desserts.  For dessert I wanted the poached pears because they looked delicious sitting on the countertop.  The waiter was nice enough to give us only poached pears with whipped cream, and I got to say those were very tasty poached pears. 

There are a lot of pizza shops all over town, but what made Pizzetta stand out is their fresh local ingredients piled on top of a super thin and crispy crust.  I really enjoyed the generous amount of fresh cheese on top, because I love extra cheese on my pizza.  The staff are super nice and don't rush you out the door, even though there is a long wait outside.   The only thing they can do to make this place even more amazing is to add a few more pizza choices to their menu.
author: Terence N.

description: I really liked the pizza here! It's a tiny little restaurant with only 5 tables inside cramped up against each other. Gives it character I suppose. We weren't up for sitting elbow to elbow in a tiny table since our party had 5 ppl so we opted for outdoor seating. Food was yummy! We had 3 pizzas, my fav was the simple Margherita pizza with pepperoni and my least fav was the one with pine nuts. I read fellow yelp reviews and said it was a must have! I think you ought to skip out on it. It's different but made it taste like a cheese or gourmet flat bread instead of a pizza. Parking is hard since it's a residential area. I'd come back still if I were in the neighborhood.
author: Lynn V.

description: My friend and I walking in here after they had already closed but they served us anyways - and we are so lucky they did! The pizza was delicious! (Although a tad on the small side). The staff were awesome and let us stay and finish our meal while they were enjoying an end of the shift drink. The place is really small and really busy but well worth the wait.
author: Amy Y.

description: Great food.  We tried two of their pizzas and a sampler type appetizer.  Everything was so flavorful.  My understanding is that they change their menu every couple of weeks but considering how excellent their flavor profiles were I would pretty much trust anything new that they create.
author: Kirsten F.

description:
Definitely a hole in the wall place but not necessarily in a bad way. The waitress was very friendly and they manage to fit a bunch of comfortable seats in such a tiny spot. 

We ordered the Hen of the Woods pizza which comes with butter braised leeks, garlic, cream, truffled, pecorino and the House Made Sausage pizza with the standard roasted tomato sauce, red onions, caper oil and Parmesan (both at $16 each). 

The crust is nice and thin, a little soft and a little chewy. In other words, just right. The flavors are very unique and distinct. It had a little too much oil for my liking, but to each and their own. 

A bit pricey and one person can definitely finish one pizza (so a little on the small side), but you probably won't have room for dessert. 

Next time I'm in the area, I'd like to try the egg pizza (Farm Egg, arugula pesto, fingerling potato, hot coppa, and goat cheese for $17). The egg comes sunny side up. I love runny yolk. 

We showed up at 3pm on Sunday, so it wasn't too busy. There were four other parties there, so I would imagine during peak hours this place would be insane. Park on the street, of course.
author: Maria T.

description:
Delicious pizza; great seasonal toppings.  

However, I have issue with some elements of their customer service.  This place is slightly snobby.  The know their pizza is great, and they are resistant to make any modifications to the toppings to suit customer preference.  They offer no options for you to choose your own combination of toppings (there only offer a handful of specific combinations of toppings you can choose from, rather than allowing the customer to choose their own), and generally act offended if you order a pizza without one of the toppings (i.e. the farm egg pizza without the braised pork).
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Many people talk about other places in the city being the best pizza in the city.  I don't wan to name names here, but we've tried the ones in the Mission, Glen Park, the one on 18th.  This is is the best place in the city for thin crust, done by people who care about great food.
