We usually would pick one pizza on the menu, follow by a salad or a small place the staff has done special for that day and follow by whatever dessert is on the menu. Because the desserts runs out so quickly, ask them what's on the menu and reserve it ahead of time.

For the perfect evening, romantic meal, this is the place.
author: Tony T.

description: Waited 40 minutes. Asked for a wait time and I was given a number in line. I asked for take out and they said they stopped offering, and then they continued to give people takeout five minutes after. Waiters are pretentious. I'm sure the pizza is great.. If you wait over an hour for it. Went to pizza place next door and was greeted with a smile and an actual wait time. Now that isn't so hard is it?
author: Fred K.

description:
Pizzetta is so cute, the perfect place to take someone on a date. Yes, it's a little off the beaten track in the Richmond District, which may not be as chic as some other places. BUT. If you have a car, this is highly recommended!

There are a handful of seats indoors, in a very rustic-looking space (Think wooden tables and benches, with bottles decorating the walls and cushions on the seats.) Two tables outside, very nice for a warm day. 

I was on a major food tour so my friend and I shared a pizza. Typically, they say one pizza per hungry adult. The pizza was 6 pieces, perfect for a light lunch or a snack. The pizza menu changes every week, although certain items remain the same.

_Bacon, chive, corn, egg pizza with chipotle creme fraiche: Wow, I just got hungry typing that item... it tasted amazing, just like it sounds. Thin crust, fresh toppings, yummy runny egg on top (which we agreed seems to elevate just about everything!) Quite good, although part of me wishes I tried a more traditional pizza. At $14, it was kind of pricey, but okay for a splurge/date.

I don't think I've tried enough at Pizzetta to give it 5 stars, but hopefully I will get a chance in the future!

For more information and some photos, check out my blog post on Pizzetta...

http://spoonfuloflemons.blogspot.com/2011/07/san-francisco-food-destinations.html
author: Cathy S.

description:
Love love love! I have no idea how I didn't know this place existed for so many years!

I recently saw a FB friend's post of her meal here. Yes, I normally am against the excessive posting of photos of people's food, but it looked SO delicious! So when A (so very nicely) picked me up from work on a Friday afternoon, I suggested we go here for dinner.

We found parking easily about a block away around 5:30pm at a metered spot, so we had to pay about 30 minutes on the meter.

I wasn't sure exactly where it's located, but we ambled along in the general direction and found it without any problems. 

All the tables in the suuuuper tiny restaurant were already occupied, so we were offered a table outside, a seat at the bar, or the first spot on the coveted waiting list. We chose the bar to be close to the pizza-making action!

So the photos I'd seen all had a farm egg pizza, but the one on the menu combined it with tuna, which didn't sound appealing to me. We, instead, ordered a salad and the pie with Lacitano Kale, Oven Dried Romas, Parmesan, Lemon, and Garlic. 

Oh. My. Stars. 

Let me tell you. That was, most likely, the best pizza I've ever had. Aaaand, it was the perfect portion size.

We normally don't order desserts at pizza "joints", but sitting at the bar, we got to see all the desserts sitting right in front of us.

So, yes, we ordered dessert. Do yourself a flavor (yeah, I said flavor!) and order the Peach & Apricot Cobbler with freshly made whipped cream on top. Wow!

Total, no drinks, including tax & tip - around $35.

We're definitely coming back (and you should too!).

(Please pardon any spelling & grammatical errors. This is my first review typed solely on my phone! Thanks for the update, Yelp!)
author: Kris L.

description:
Outstanding food and service. The 'special' weekly pizza with egg was better than expected...and their Margherita with anchovies was great.  Definitely worth checking out.

The place is small so unless you get there early...you'll be waiting for a table.
author: Zoran L.

description: This is definitely in contention for best pizza I've had in SF. We split the tomato mozz basil pie, and the spicy pork sausage (and other stuff) pie. The crust was perfectly thin and the cheese used on each slice was delicious. The crust/bread is probably what stood out the most (second to the cheese), and all the other toppings were very delicious. We came on a Sunday afternoon and only had to wait a few minutes.
author: Rohan S.

description: Delicious thin crust pizza made with quality ingredients in an adorable space, with personable service. Parking is kind of a pain, so leave yourself a little bit extra time.
author: Emily Z.

description:
Came here in early spring and loved this place. Would have waited outside for 45 minutes back then. Came back this fall and sorely disappointed.

It was no big deal to start outside under the heater to wait for a table inside, but this became uncool when the waitstaff merely waved customers to come in instead of coming out to invite them in and carry in their glasses of wine and silverware. Instead customers carried their own stuff in.

Additionally, the waitress who took my order never asked how my meal was and then later left the payment iPad upside down on the table in front of me while she turned toward her own dinner. She also left the door open while taking out the trash as the fog rolled in.

I give 2 stars instead of one because the cab franc was very good and worked perfectly with the tomato, mascarpone, and arugula pizza, though the pizza was over-salted and unevenly crispy. (Prefer a little soggy actually.) It was so salty 
that it interfered with the flavor of the tomatoes. Fortunately, the pizza maker missed salting the last few bites I ate, and I had a good taste of what would have been a very good pie.

Okay, now I'm adding a star, because the other waitperson came by with a box announcing it's a fig dessert that they are sharing since it's closing time. That was cool.

Still, guys, careful with the salt and put the "serve" in service!
author: Kiai K.

description:
Such a great place.  I'm from Southern California and I cant think of a pizza place down here that compares...well Pizzeria Mozza is awesome, but different.  This is the kind of place that is one of those finds that you don't want to tell too many people about because then it will get too crowded but then again you want to tell everyone about it.  I think everyone knows about it though, looks like there always is a good wait.  

Our server was really friendly, gave great recommendations.  The people in there are also friendly, feels like a small town restaurant.  One guy actually gave me a slice of his pizza because I said it looked really good.

So if you want amazing food, go here.  Don't complain about the wait.  The best things in life......
author: Joe L.

description:
Don't under estimate the size of the pizza! My friend and I stopped by for lunch around 2pm. We were ravishing so obviously we weren't thinking straight. We ordered two pizzas to share, the Tomato, Mozzarella with pepperoni and the one with zucchini (weekly special). We were full after 4 slices each. We could have easily shared one pizza and would have been full until to until dinner, but the stomach was talking when we were ordering. 

I would definitely come back. 
And if you were wondering, yes, we had to wait for a table at 2pm.
author: Jess W.

description: Great and unique pizzas and salads, good short wine and beer list that will please the discerning palate. Massive wait, and if you can't deal with it, don't go there.
author: Jeff W.

description: Cute place.  Awesome staff.  Unreal pizzas - nothing like you ever had. Possibly the best pizza in SF.  Worth the ride out to the Rich.
author: Phillip S.

description:
I do love me some egg on my pizza.  The menu rotates so the offered ingredients change every couple weeks, the selection is limited, and the space is tiny, but the pizzas are definitely delicious.  

We lucked out grabbing lunch for four here on a Thursday afternoon around 1pm.  We got a table inside (a tad cozy for four people, four pizzas, and drinks, but we were the only patrons on our side of the restaurant so we had a little wiggle room.  Two of us got the pizza with the fresh farm egg, pulled pork, chile verde, and queso fresco.  It was cooked perfectly and had a great balance of flavors to it.  The other two ordered a standard margarita pizza and one with butternut squash, sage, and brown butter.  Both said theirs were great too.  

For dessert we all shared a slice of the chocolate torte and the lemon tart with pomegranate seeds.  The chocolate was a little lackluster for me, but we devoured that lemon tart like it was the only thing we'd eaten all day.  It was good.  

So obviously you should come try a pizza here.  They do a great job with the crust and have interesting toppings and flavor combinations.  I was able to finish my entire pizza, though I started feeling full about half way through.  Two of us were smart and got half their pizzas boxed for later, but I didn't think fresh egg would taste so good reheated so I powered through and finished that pie.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
Worst service ever. Yesterday I went in around 3 pm and 5 employees just starred at us. No one greeted us with a "welcome in" or anything. They looked annoyed that people were even in there. 

Then finally some girl with red and black hair said something. But I had to be the one to initiate it. I live in the neighborhood and come here all the time but it's not even worth it to go in because the service is so shi**y! Tipping then a $1 was even to much!
author: Prosperity H.

description: Love this place. Every time I've been here, it's well worth the price. The staff is pretty friendly. I just wish this place wasn't as secluded but I guess it's a good thing when it's unknown.
author: Anthony N.

description:
This place has officially been added to my "Must-Visit-When-I'm-in-San-Francisco" Food list. 

Why you ask? Let me tell you: 

Thin, Crispy, Crunchy, Melt in your Mouth Pizza. 

Topped with Fresh off the farm ingredients. Made to order. 

Quaint, Warm decor. Perfect for a lunch or brunch setting. 

One bite and you'll be in love with it too. 
Damn, now I want Pizzetta for lunch. Too bad it's so far. (I'm in LA)
author: Kathy C.

description:
I really enjoyed our meal here tonight. Believe the hype- they do a damn good job here. 

Have you ever noticed how the best restaurants have the smallest menus? The secret to food success seems to be focus rather than catering to the masses, and Pizzetta does this well. We had the pulled pork, farm egg, and quest fresco along with the Margarhita with Pepperoni. Topped off with a Toasted Porter and finished with their  flourless chocolate cake, it was the perfect dinner.

Unpretentious, approachable service too.
author: Mark C.

description: Wow. Yes. Let's. Everything about this place is perfect. Please don't come here and make it impossible to get in.
author: John Mark J.

description: Such an adorable little pizza place hidden in the inner Richmond. Customer service is so nice, feels like a little restaurant in Italy. Delicious pizza and even more delicious wine. I don't want to write this review, because I don't want the wait to be even longer, but too good not to share!
author: Kelsey M.

description:
My pizza included house-made sausage, thyme, potatoes, cheese, garlic and it was absolutely fantastic.  I think what really makes an incredible pizza is one that tastes amazing despite the simplicity and that's what this place offers.  There aren't really any fancy tricks to their pizza as far as toppings, but using the freshest ingredients and using the perfect amount of spices really makes these pizzas incredible.

I really did enjoy my meal here and will definitely go back...too bad it's so far away...

No reservations and cash only!
author: Ken G.

description:
At some point, when you've gorged your way through a weeks plus worth of San Francisco's Michelin starred luminaries,  you just want uncomplicated, earthy food. Pizza always does the trick. It's a humble food, even in its fanciest incarnations still a simple plate. 

Pizzetta 211 is off the beaten path in Outer Richmond. There's a surprising variety of tremendously good, small inexpensive restaurants in the area, it's worth a drive to search them out. Pizzetta 211 is even further off, down a residential street and sandwiched in a very small space. It was late afternoon when we came so it was empty, but I wouldn't want to fight for a seat during lunch or dinner. If there were thirteen patrons, it would be like playing musical chairs since there are probably no more than a dozen seats at best.

The pizzas, lovely thin crusted creations, are very, very good. Among the best pies I've had the pleasure of disposing of. No, they're not better than Mozza, though the comparison isn't really relevant. 

Margarita is the house special, with excellent reason. Its about as good a version as you'll find. Here, there or anywhere. Housemade sausage with Manila Clams was my favorite. The Farm Egg pizza sounds delightful but we had no room to put it. Pizza size is petite, but wonderfully crafted in the wood fire grill and well worth the $12-15 or so price. 

There's much conversation regarding the service (or lack thereof), I didn't notice anything off, but my wife mentioned rolled eyes and other things when they thought we weren't watching. Lost a star for sure for that no matter how good your pizza is. 

We closed the show with a sublime cobbler.

Can't compare to the pizzas at popular bay restaurants like Beretta and Delfina because we haven't tried them, but this slaps the snot out of any LA pizza I've had, except the incomparable Mozza. 

Best Plates: Margarita pizza, Sausage and Manila Clam pizza, Cobbler

Palate: quirky but mainstream

Food - A+
Ambience - B+
Service - B
Value - A-
author: Forrest D.

description:
Please note: I don't like pizza very much. I'm lactose intolerant, and my stomach doesn't handle them very well. However, when my boyfriend was craving pizza, we went took out here and I was impressed. 

My favorite pizza topping was the finger-link potatoes. So delicious, whoever thought of potatoes on a pizza must have been god. Also, I loved the fried egg (on a separate pizza). Very unique, and nice gourmet spin on it. Thin-crust pizza lovers will also love this place. 

Only things I wasn't too fond about was the $15 corkage!  Good thing we ordered to go. Seemed a little ridiculous since the place was casual and laid back.  Restaurant is also tiny, so if you have a table of 4, come on the early side. 

Would definitely come back :) and I'm not even a pizza lover!  Also, staff is very friendly and made us feel at home!! Another plus.
author: Jocelyn L.

description: The size of the pizza was very small. It is a small place, we were 5 people and we sat in a table for 2 . The pizza is tasty and the service is okay. But it was very very expensive. 3 pizzas and the smallest salad ever for 62$.
author: Tali R.

description: Stumbled upon this place randomly when visiting SF. WOW! I'm from Philly and my boyfriend is from Brooklyn, so we know good pizza. We were both blown away. We had the salad special with goat cheese dressing and then split the pizza with eggplant and basil (I forget the name). Our only regret is not ordering more.  I will definitely make a special trip to this spot next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Sam R.

description:
Been to this place twice. The pizzas are amazing!!

The first time we ordered a pizza, the cheese salad, and the chocolate cake. Everything was amazing. Based on that experience alone, the restaurant deserves 5 stars.

HOWEVER, the second time, we also order take-out. The food was amazing as usual. But the next day, ALL 5 OF US GOT FOOD POISONING. Not something too serious, but bad enough to not want to order from here again.

I must say tho, the food is good. And hopefully the food poisoning was just a one-time thing. But be warned...
author: Ngan B.

description: Fantastic flavors, great service,  and nice quaint ambience.  Get the pizza with the egg and bacon. Amazing!
author: Kyle K.

description: I am in love with this tiny restaurant in my neighborhood! Pizzetta 211 has the best pizza in SF in my opinion. Totally worth the wait for an amazing farm to table food experience. Also, their team are made of really wonderful people, adding to the casual and cool vibe there. I highly recommend it!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
This is tough. I'm going to struggle through this, but, here goes:

Pizzetta, when it's open and serving food, is precious. The smells, flavors, ambiance are truly unique. 

But the catch is- they never seem to be OPEN. 

I traveled across the city after many days of planning and anticipation, only to find that they were closed for "maintenance". No sign, no change to hours on website. 

I guess I should have called, but I didn't think that was necessary based on the HOURS LISTED ON THE WEBSITE AND DOOR AND EVERYWHERE ELSE. 

and it's not like this place is close to lots of other options. 

Customers are counting on you to be open. Keep me them in the loop. Don't crush their pizza dreams
author: Jessica K.

description:
Do not expect a bright sign attracting you in, but who needs that when you got a delicious thin-crusted pizza. The Farm Egg pizza had a great sauce to it with sausages that really surprised me with great flavor. 

Personally, for a young male adult, one of their pizzas was enough to leave me satisfied and not overly full. The service is kind and they get out the food fairly quick without losing quality.
author: Danny P.

description:
My new favorite thin-crust pizza place in the city! 

I was completely blown away by how AMAZING the pizzas tasted! 

What we ordered (party of TWO):

Field Green Salad ($5.50)- It's literally just a mix of greens. Nothing else. I was definitely disappointed by how boring and sad the salad looked. I'd skip this for sure and go for one of their other appetizers which can change from day-to-day. Ask for the special starter- it's probably (hopefully) a better bet! 

Mozzarella, tomato, + basil ($10.50)- SOOOOOOO tasty. Perfect amount of cheesy-goodness and freshly grinded basil. :O i couldn't believe how good it was for such a small and simple pizza.

Farm egg + prosciutto + crescenza, walnut, wild arugula ($15.50)- again, blew my mind how perfect the combination was altogether. Perfect amount of prosciutto and the farm eggs were somehow the perfect size and readyness! It was amazing! i've had other pizzas before that had the infamous "farm egg" on top- most of the time, it'd make that area of the pizza super soggy and... interesting BUT Pizzetta 211 got it done perfectly. BRAVO. [NOTE: This doesn't have any tomato sauce so just an FYi if you're looking for something with a tomato base.]

Pizzas are 10 inches big- super thin- so definitely don't come too hungry unless you want to order TWO for yourself and take home leftovers (.... OR you could do it intentionally so you CAN have two pizzas to yourself aka like me for my next visit :D). 
I'd recommend one pizza/person and share an appetizer if you come moderately hungry and want to leave satisfied. 


REMEMBER TO BRING CASH! IT'S A CASH-ONLY RESTAURANT!!!!!! (I think that's another reason why I docked it 1-star bc I rarely carry cash- nonetheless enough for a $$ dinner.)
author: Patricia K.

description:
I ordered from PIzzetta 211 a few weeks ago with a friend, in our effort to try more restaurants in our neighborhood.  I think after only one visit, this has become my favorite pizza place in the city.   My pick-up order was ready pretty quickly even though they were busy, and the staff seemed really friendly.  I did not dine in, but the restaurant was so cute and cozy.  

We tried two of the weekly pizza specials... I cannot recall the exact combination, but the egg-topped pizza was fantastic.  It was just "really good" until I got to the egg, with the egg yoke... amazing.  The other (sausage) pizza was good too, the salad was satisfying, and the dressed olives were pretty tasty too.   

The only complaint I have is that there is no allergy labeling on their menu.  When I ordered, I asked for no nuts in the salad due to an allergy.  When I arrived to pick up my order, I was informed that there are nuts mixed in with the sausage (on the pizza I'd ordered).   I would have never guessed there would be nuts in it, so while I'm glad they warned me, that information should have been given before I ordered it.
author: Heidi M.

description: 2 stars for the attitude of the people working here . The food was good . First the lady at the counter takes our order and we order the pizza salad and one drink and she tells us it is small. Then she throws in some attitude when we ask for dessert. Next they hand us a bill without a breakup with just a dollar amount . And then they tell us they missed billing and another hand another dollar amount .Ok so you are famous and people are waiting to eat here . That does not mean you are rude to your customers
author: Naina T.

description: Great pizza!  Very tasty but I've only been once because it's always crowded... Oh, San Francisco.
author: Diana G.

description:
Best thin crust pizza in the Bay Area. I would like to apologize to Pizzetta for waiting to write this review after I moved out of the city. This place isn't very big and I was always afraid it was going to blow up.
They use fresh ingredients and show off their creativity by always changing their menu depending on what ingredients they source. The staff is always friendly and helpful.
author: Mark J.

description:
After passing by countless times, I finally was able to try Pizzetta!!! They are tucked away in the depths known as the Outer Richmond. It is very easy to pass as it is very small and not surrounded by any other restros or stores. I came  here for lunch with two co-workers because my favorite lunch buddy Jane was leaving for a new job. I am going to miss u lunch buddy!!! :(.  My other co-worker Kate is a fellow foodie and heard great things about Pizzetta, so you can bet we were super excited to finally try it.

All of the Pizzetta's sounded really yummy and it was a hard decision to pick only two between the three of us. We finally decided on: 

Farm Egg, Kasseri Cheese, Braised Oxtail, Tomato, and Onion: http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/BJR_mdN0hkcLL2X_kA0DnA/l

and

House Cured Pancetta, Radicchio, Gorgonzola Dulce, Balsamic Reduction: http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/WYifpvyhLcsQI-_T6b1yVQ/l

Both Pizza's were very delicious but the farm egg pizza was my favorite. A simple Tomato and Onion pizza in itself but when Kasseri Cheese is added as well as the tender Braised Oxtail and then toss on two sunny side up eggs. OMG it was marvelous, the combination of different flavors made it really spectacular. This was the first time i had egg on my pizza/pizzetta and for sure it will not be the last time. The house Cured Pancetta pizza was also yummy but In my opinion Balsamic vinegar shouldn't be on a pizza. The atmosphere is very warm and cozy, the people that work there are very kind. 

The Pizzetta's range in price from 11-14 bucks, a bit steep but for unique delicious pizzettas it is worth it. They make a lot of their pizzeta ingredients in store and they also make fresh desserts everyday. The hardest part is finding the right timing to come into Pizzetta because I guarantee it will be busy. We lucked out on going on a Wednesday around noon. I will be back to try some more different pizzetta infusions!

Note: In Italy according to my coworker Kate (Who is Italian) Egg is a common ingredient on pizza! Yum!! As some of you may have noticed I have been putting a sum up of definitions at the bottom of my reviews! I just want to share what i have found out with everyone! Hope you guys enjoy the lil tidbits of info i give ya! Here's This wks!

*Kasseri- is a cheese made from unpasteurized sheep milk that is mixed in Turkey and Greece.
author: Jonathan W.

description: wait for your table and it pays off.  Some of the best pizza Ive ever had.  taste and crust is exactly on point, and I like the friendly staff- they seem like a family.  I love the vibe; you think you're going to feel cramped, but instead its warm and cozy inside.
author: Danielle B.

description:
I have lived in the neighborhood for almost 10 years.  We eat out quite a bit....all over SF, but also attempt to dine here in our neighborhood.  

We first started eating at Pizetta 211 at least 6 years ago, but honestly can't recall.  In any event, my experience has been universally the same.  

Dine-in:  the tables are extremely limited, and don't bring the kids.  Expect a wait and unfriendly attitude.  

Take out:  historically, this has been an issue for the restaurant.  In my experience 1-2 pizzas were OK for takeout, but 4 or more created an issue and a lot of unnecessary attitude.  In the past, they were cash only, but somewhere along the way they converted to credit cards.  Although it's been awhile since I last ordered take out, I encountered the same general attitude tonight.  If you come with low service expectations and don't mind waiting....you will do well, the pizza is great.  The owners/staff, on the other hand, need a lesson or two in the service industry.

PS  I've waited tables in several restaurants during high school, college and graduate school
author: Stephen H.

description:
What a sweet neighborhood spot. It's small and fills up (understandably) quickly. We arrived at 5:30 on a Sunday and the tables were already occupied. Luckily there are three tables outside under heat lamps and they also have blankets patrons can use to keep warm. 

The menu is well edited and to the point. Salads, pizzas, one calzone option and a handful of desserts. 

The special salad of artichokes, beans and ricotta was a nice start and both of the pizzas we ordered were beautiful. The farm egg, prosciutto, walnuts and wild arugula was a nice mix of creamy egg, tangy cheese and peppery arugula. The crust was thin and perfectly crispy - not one piece was soggy. 

The tomato, mozzarella and basil was a good test of a basic pizza and Pizzetta 211 passed the test. Sweet tomatoes, creamy mozzarella with that crispy crust was perfect. 

It's amazing to taste what the folks at Pizzetta 211 can turn out in such a tiny space.
author: Lee H.

description:
My ex-boyfriend was anti-yuppies.  Even though he lived 4 doors down from Pizzetta, we never went.

FINALLY I got my chance to go, and I've gotta say that this is now one of my favorite neighborhood gems: excellent food, service, and ambiance.

Pizzetta is one of the tiniest, coziest restaurants I've seen.  The ideal number of people in a party is 3 (2 is even better), and they definitely wouldn't be able to take a large party.  We had 5, and even though they were able to accommodate us within a reasonable amount of time - they don't seat you until everyone is present - it was very, very squished.  There are only a few tables outside for couples, and four wooden tables inside for parties of 3 or 4.

Since there were 5 of us, we decided to order one of each of the pizzas featured for the week: eggplant, fig & prosciutto, tomato basil pepperoni, egg and bacon, and a goat cheese pine nut one.  The pizzas barely fit on our table, so we did the switcheroo and gave each person one slice of the pizza sitting in front of us so we could try every single flavor.  Each pizza was a delicious thin crust (if you've been to Local, it's just like that).

My favorite was the tomato basil pepperoni one; it was super fresh and flavorful.  The egg and bacon one came a close second, although I didn't like how only one slice has the fried egg yolk on top - I got a slice with just the egg white, and I can imagine how much yummier it would've been with the whole egg.  Everyone else liked the fig & prosciutto one, but since I'm not a fan of the sweet vinaigrette, I didn't really like how everything came together.  The eggplant one was heavily eggplant-flavored, and if you're a fan of aubergines, you'd love this one.  The least memorable one was the pine nut one, because it was basically just a cheese pizza (to me, at least), with a few pine nuts on top.

$75 pre-tip for the dinner, as the pizzas ranged from $11 to $15.  The menu changes based on the local ingredients that they get.  And, surprisingly, cash only.

Pizzetta 211 is on the top of my list now for a perfect romantic dinner, and the drive out to the Outer Richmond (aka easy parking) is so, so worth it, especially on a gorgeous, clear, warm San Francisco evening.
author: Tori S.

description: The pizza was amazing, it was the best I had ever tasted. Also the food comes very fast and the atmosphere is very cozy.I think it was definitely a five star pizza. If your looking for the BEST pizza Pizzeta is the place to go.
author: Ortal O.

description: A friend had recommended this place to me so we went to order pizzas. The place was super tiny, so we ordered ours to go. It took a bit of time to get our order and parking is not good in the area, so we kept driving around the block until it was ready. It was worth the wait, the pizza was delicious.
author: Rebecca J.

description:
Heard of this place from Sunset Magazine and it's been on my bookmark list for ages.  

We finally came here.

Ordered the tasty thin crust pizza with basic ingredients.  We got the TUNA RESERVA (capers, mustard green, squirt of lemon juice, dash of pepper and salt).  

$14/shared between 2 people.  


Mixed Olives $3.

STREET PARKING ONLY
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Though the place is kinda small and you will have to wait a bit, the food is worth it. We came here on a Sunday night at around 6:30PM and still had to wait about 30 minutes for a spot at the bar. 

We started off with the Organic Greens, Artisanal Cheeses, Spiced Walnuts salad, which was simple but tasty. They gave us two types of cheese (we don't remember what they were, but they were pretty yummy), olives, apples, bread, and a salad with a vinaigrette dressing. There were spiced walnuts in the salad that were crunchy and addicting.

For our pizza, we got the Farm Egg, Braised Beef, Kale, Crescenza, Gremolata pizza. The crust was extremely thin and crunchy, and the toppings worked well together. They finished the pizza off with a gremolata that added a nice tartness and zing to the pizza.

To finish off the meal, we got their House Made Flourless Chocolate Cake, which had a nice sizable dollop of fresh whipped cream. The cake tasted and felt like a fluffy brownie and was super good. Definitely try this out. On a side note, for coffee lovers, you can also finish off your meal with a Blue Bottle espresso.

Overall, we really liked this place. It was a little pricey, but worth it. Only downside is that the place is really small and parking around the area can be a pain in the butt. They do have take-out, which is something we may end up doing next time.
author: NoonNarin N.

description: I'm appalled at the three-star rating I previously gave Pizzetta 211, as this clearly does not reflect the glowing praises I actually sing for this place.  It is everything that Cheeseboard (Berkeley), Diavola (Geyserville), and Tony's is, and more.  Additionally, it's quaint, in my neighborhood, and you should definitely save room for dessert.
author: Jenn C.

description:
LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this place! There's a longer than usual wait for a table, it's a tiny and cramped space and parking is eh depending on the night. BUT, this has absolutely nothing to do with the food or service. And at the end of the day...that's what we're judging here right?

I read the reviews and opted to pick up my order. As described by others, the place was packed (about 7sih) with people waiting outside for a table (see, it's that good). I was a few minutes late so I double parked in hopes of running it and out. Pizza wasn't ready yet, but they delivered it to me curbside since I was double parked. So you see...no doubt that they're RAD at Pizzetta 211.
author: Penny T.

description:
Tiny restaurant, fills up fast.  Neighborhood pizza place with friendly service. Tasty and cute, but would I go back?  hmm maybe?

It would be better if the pizza's were bigger with more generous toppings.

My friend and I shared a pizza with the egg on top [15 bucks] and the field green salad which was overly dressed, should have asked for the dressing on the side.
author: Tashie P.

description:
Love love love this place. Hubby and I ate here tonight for the first time since moving to SF a year ago. We've passed by the restaurant a few times when out to dinner. I don't know why we never ate here sooner. A year is way too long. 
I have to say, I was very impressed and blown away.. Great food.. Fresh ingredients.. By far the best pizza I have ever eaten. I also love how the restaurant is nestled in a corner in a quiet residential neighborhood. It's quaint and intimate. The wait can be long since the restaurant is a bit tiny but it's definitely worth the wait. 
If you enjoy thin crust pizzas, Pizzetta 211 is a must.. A definite GEM in the city.
author: Rachelle L.

description:
Finally got the chance to wander in here for a late lunch, perfect because the place is tiny so we were able to grab a table without a wait and we weren't too hungry so we could share a few things for pretty cheap. 
Farm egg pizza and flourless cake are worth the hype. We also got the starter salad of the day and it was fantastic. 
Fresh ingredients, creative combinations, and a cute local atmosphere. I live close so I think this will definitely be a regular spot.
author: Brittany F.

description: This is a tiny restaurant with the of charm of a Wes Anderson movie. Be prepared to wait, if not show up early. It's friendly, caring and dedicated staff work together to create something special every time. This is unlike any pizza found in the city. The pizza's are thin, light and medium sized. The San marzano is a must. San Marzano sauce with fresh mozzarella and ricotta topped with arugula, olive oil and sea salt. This is a fantastic restaurant and will visit frequently.
author: Jeff F.

description:
I hesitated writing a review for Pizzetta 211. I don't want word to get out just how good it is. Selfish I know but it's just that good and just around the corner from me! Damn I'm lucky.

It's tucked away on a residential street so hopefully you won't be able to find it. :P

The food and service are great. The restaurant itself has such a cute, homey feel and I can't possibly say enough about the food. You surely won't be disappointed. They have daily specials along with a few items that remain on the menu. Lots of choices and great selection of beer as well.
author: Leanne S.

description:
Adorable spot with delightful pizza, perfect for romantic dates!

I've tried 4 of their pizza specials and have only been unimpressed by 1, as their ingredients are consistently fresh and innovative (such as: brussels sprouts, homemade pesto, local eggs) and each pizza is made right in front of you with care and expertise.

The cakes are also delectable and the specials change regularly so you could return every week and try something new.
author: Eljo L.

description: Yum yum yum. I know we have a ton of good pizza in SF, but this place is on my Top 5 list. Only been there once but have been craving it ever since - I think we just firmed up plans to go back tomorrow :) The San Marzano Tomato Sauce, Mascarpone, Wild Arugula, Olio Verde is the way to go if you have never been before. Such a unique blend of flavors. I love a restaurant that does one thing, and does it really well. This is that kind of place.
author: Malarie J.

description:
Walked in around 12:30pm on a Thursday and luckily there was a table open for the two of us.  I don't quite remember what was on the pizza I ordered, but it had Farm Egg, Brussels Sprouts and Prosciutto.  My friend ordered the Tomato, Mozzarella, Basil with Pepperoni.  We waited agonizingly for 20-30 minutes with just ice water before our pizzas arrived hot out of the oven and cut into six uneven slices.  It was worth the wait though!  A nice layer of cheese with savory prosciutto, crunchy sprouts and a delightful even crunchier crust.  The farm egg on top gave me a brunch feeling as I sopped up the yolk with the pizza with every bite.  My friend's classic pizza had a nice tomato sauce with just the right amount of cheese.  Perfect proportions!  Our leftovers tasted even more delicious after a night in the fridge.   

Other thoughts: I noticed the waitress had a bunch of black underneath her fingernails.  At first I was put off by this, but then I thought maybe it was probably from the burns on the bottom of the pizzas..or at least I hope so!  Also, this place really is tiny! But if you've been reading the other reviews, you'd probably know that already.  And street parking is tough in this area so plan ahead plus more for the wait.
author: Renee L.

description: Excellent. I've been in the neighborhood for over a year and kept missing this place since it's so tiny, but I finally rectified that last night and had the most flavorful pizza I've come across in the city. They seem to rotate pizzas, so it seems like the taste will stay fresh. Very SF palette friendly in their toppings. They had a row of basil plants in the kitchen! The flourless chocolate cake was rather fantastic, to top it off. There's not much seating, so I'd plan for a wait if you go around 7. But, they do take out! There are some bar stools if you're chill with that. Bring a coat l because they have a few outside tables if you want less of a wait.
author: Tim W.

description: Maybe I'm bias, but I really doubt it. Loved the place since years ago, but the food is just solid. And everything is fresh everyday! U can taste it too. I'll be coming in a lot the next few weeks. Bringing friends and fam.
author: mel l.

description: This place is, and always has been, amazing.  Intimate and lovely.  Don't miss the video in the bathroom!
author: Jeff W.

description:
Used to live in the Bay Area, moved away, moved back. Found quite a few of the restaurants I used to frequent have gone down in quality/taste. Pizzetta 211 is a lovely exception. 

Regular order: one pizza w anchovies, one pizza w baked eggs (what gets served w the baked eggs changes regularly). Delicious, thin crust that has chewiness to it and not cracker crisp/thin. Fresh ingredients. Order is usually one pizza per person then share slices. 

Non-food comments:
Prompt service (we went right when it opened - first time i sat at a table and not the counter), intimate (read: small) space, and quirky bathroom that makes you feel like you're part of an art installation. Oh, and remember: cash only. Not cheap, but a solidly good eat.
author: Jay K.

description: Ordered the farm egg pizza becuase I never had pizza with eggs before, but it's no doubt that eggs goes well with anything! I'm a big fan of eggs so the farm egg pizza caught my eye and it's vegetarian friendly. The portion was small, I would say it's a good personal size if you're really hungry or you can share it with one other person if neither person is hungry. It was a delectable pizza that was palatable and scrumptious; a pizza like no others. The place is small but is definitely worth coming.
author: Tiramisu W.

description: The owner stayed open past hours of operation just to serve us his delicious pizza and salad! Great lunch. Definitely recommend to everyone.
author: Melanie Z.

description:
Excellent pizza for the lovers of the experiment and "new" recepies. We have tried 4 different pizzas and calzone. All pizzas were good. Crispy nice dough. Toppings well balanced, not too little, and not too much of the stuff. With the calzone - you have to be exactly in the mood for this kind of variation of stuffed piece.

The place is very tiny, consider ordering to-go.
author: Dmitry D.

description:
Cute little (and I mean that literally) neighborhood spot that serves up pizza just how I like! Thin and crisp, they've got their pizzetas down to a science. We ordered the Margherita (add pepperoni) and the Proscuitto with Asparagus and Fontina Cheese. Hands down, loved their Margherita. Not only a perfect crust but the tomato sauce (had to have been San Marzano tomatoes) was tangy and sweet, and they had the right amount of basil and cheese. I love a good margherita and don't usually add pep, but it was at the request of my dining companion. It definitely added another element to the pizzetta with a lot of flavor and it's crispy textured edges. The Flourless Chocolate Cake came highly yelp recommended, but it was a little dry for my liking.

Service is attentive with one waiter tending to everyone. And they've got three awesome ladies working it out in that kitchen - one for pizzetas, one for salads and apps, and one for desserts.

This place is amazing in the amount of business they do considering the size of the place. Expect a wait,  though they even offer blankets outside for patrons. If you don't live too far, takeout is an excellent option as well as it was evident by the number of customers coming by to pick up their orders.
author: Anna R.

description: The food here is amazing, their menu has only a few items which completely makes sense since their kitchen is so tiny. But boy do they do a great job at doing every single item to perfection. We had heirloom tomato & roasted corn salad to start, the corn and tomatoes where sweet and delicious, it has been two weeks since then and I Still think about lol. Yes it was that good :)
author: Eric G.

description:
Had takeout of their Farm Egg, Hot Coppa, Arugula Pesto, Goat Cheese pizzetta
Awesome pie and full of intricate flavor
Place is tucked around corner from California St
author: R C.

description:
Went here yesterday since a friend was RAVING about this place, and wow-o-wow was he right.

Pizzetta has totally NAILED the perfect thin crust pizza. The toppings are fresh, the pizza is delicious and the menu changes regularly.  I had the rosemary pinenut pizza and it was awesome--my friend had the arugula + marscapone which legit melted in your mouth... I could have eaten a bucket of their marscapone!

Overall it was a great place, but TINY so make sure you plan accordingly. Also, this place is not for picky eaters; they have only what they have on the menu, i.e. no add-on toppings to your pizza... but it doesn't matter since what they make is SOO SOO good :D
author: Alyssa S.

description:
My friend is originally from Marin and a huge foodie. When she took me here, I was really dubious as to how great the pizza would be, why she loved it as much as she did, and if it can compare to a few of my favorite pizza places in NY. I didn't get swayed until I had the rosemary, pine nut, and cheese pie. 

To start, the service was great, even though we waited around 25 minutes and sat outside at first; I did not mind because you could order wine/drinks as you wait - this made the time go by rather easily. Once we were seated, I realized our seats can be dismissed as most of the action is inside the restaurant, but our waiter was attentive and easy to talk to!

We split an appetizer of simple mixed greens and decided to skip the special of the day as we wanted to save room for the entrees we came for. The salad was a good balance to the meal, but definitely true in how it was a bit overpriced. I still enjoyed it though; the dressing was what made the salad for me. Then, our pizzas came out quickly! We got the corn, braised pork, and roasted pepper pizza as well as the rosemary, pine nut, and cheese. I enjoyed the braised pork as it was super juicy, flavorful, and had a nice kick that I did not expect. The crust on both were nice and crisp, I loved how it did not get soggy as we took our time savoring each bite. When I dug into the rosemary pizza, I was blown away. The mixture of cheese, carbs, creamy pine nut, and rosemary aroma was a perfect combination! 

I think about Pizzetta 211 often and have recommended this place to so many of my friends and coworkers already. I'm pining for my next trip already, and know that I'll definitely be reordering that rosemary pizza. The best part is that there are always rotating pizza selections, so I'll be sure to try a new dish - possibly the farmer's egg next!
author: Serena S.

description: Great meal. Terrible wait. Nice staff. Innovative specials. Small place.
author: Anjolie C.

description: Very good if you're looking for authentic style pizza. Honestly I prefer more cheese. The sauce is fantastic; tangy with great herbs and spices. The atmosphere is wonderful too - cozy and rustic. Our service was very friendly if not terribly attentive.
author: Tavia B.

description:
I tried Pizzatta last night and was extremely satisfied with my meal. My kind of pizza - Thin but not too thin. Crispy but not too crispy! I got to try my first pizza with an egg on top. I heard this is how the italians normally eat (with an egg on their pizza) and i'm a converter. Delicious.  

Small place (four tables, seats maybe 3-4 people each) and fits up to 3-4 people at the bar. That is it! Yes i said small and i meant it. So i would recommend going early to wait for a table or not going if you are absolutely starving. There will be a wait! I got there around 630 sunday night and waited about 20 minutes. 

Pizzas about $10-14 each (cheaper than Flour+Water which I recently tried and didnt like as much) and calzone was $10. 

Parking around the area is a 'female dog'. It sucks big time. Pizzetta will NOT seat you until your entire party is there. CASH ONLY place so leave your plastic at home.
author: Cicely T.

description: Okay, this place could not be cuter, more quaint (in a good way) and intimate. The pizza was DELICIOUS. You can watch them make your pizza while also watching people traffic out the window. Oh, and they were playing Barry white, which was just the icing on the cake. Who doesn't have a soft spot for Barry white?
author: Marla L.

description:
Our friend used to live around the corner and that is how we discovered this place. We've been going here for...probably around 6 years now? Not once was anything less than rave-worthy. 

Of course, we don't live in SF and we are only in the city 1X or 2X a year (sorry, could never get used to the gloomy fog, the numerous pedestrians AND traffic, the lack of parking). But when we are in the city, we ALWAYS fit in at least one meal at Pizetta.

How could I let the chance pass me by if I'm only in SF a few time a year?!? It is THAT GOOD. (For context, my boyfriend and I are usually the kind of people who always want to try new things but we just can't pass this place up!)

If you like thick chewy crusts or deep dish - ok maybe you won't like it. These pizzas are thin crust - like a flatbread- designed to let the toppings shine.
If you like quick and fast...ok maybe you won't like it either. They are tiny...including the kitchen area.
If you like no wait... ok maybe not again... there's always a wait for a table (at least on weekends). This is a neighborhood favorite. You can call your order in ahead of time for take out though.
And (I think) at least they accept credit cards now :D

So despite the caveats, Pizetta is so awesome that I bring all my out of town visitors to try it.

You have to try the farm egg pizza at least once - they never disappoint. However, I wouldn't pass up the weekly specials.

My absolute favorite thus far was a asparagus pizza with preserved lemons and toasted hazelnuts with the farm egg pizza a close second (exact one changes every now and then but what can I say, I love runny eggs). They once did an oxtail pizza that was excellent too... and another time sorrel pesto ... and once the house-made sausage - YUMM! (I'm not nuts- I swear :) - but I can probably name each time we ate at Pizetta and what we ordered .... it was that good)

Anyways, you get the idea. Really unusual, fresh ingredients. Really good pizza. (also try the desert P: ) They also have more familiar pizzas too if you aren't' feeling that adventurous. 

(And why did I wait to write this review? partly laziness...partly cus I didn't want to give away my "secret" but..this place is not realy a secret anymore)
author: H W.

description:
What a fabulous establishment! For a Sunday afternoon, this little joint was just the spot we needed. First off all, I think that every pizza should have egg on it, after consuming (or should I say shoveling) the Farm Egg, Ham, Braised Endive, Gruyere, Mustard pizza into my mouth. Does mustard seem weird on a pizza? Absolutely! But it came so highly recommended that I had no choice but to order. I followed the pizza up with a spiced pear cake with a salted caramel drizzle on top and warm pear. We also split the fig salad, and while that was delicious, the pizza and the dessert were the winning combination. 

Tip: Listen to their daily specials and ORDER THEM. I felt like I was eating off a secret menu. I've also heard this place gets packed, I mean there are only about 5 tables. I went on a Sunday afternoon (like 3:30ish) and were able to sit almost right away.
author: Megan T.

description:
From a perspective of pure, high quality best pizza in the city, Pizzetta 211 is my standard.  Their crust is naturally risen over 24 hours (when they run out, they close, be warned), their topping combinations span the traditional and the creative, and are always delicious and well-balanced.  I've worked hard to recreat some of their pizzas at home (such as the pecorino sardo with rosemary).

Do be aware that they ONLY do pizza.  They have some salads and sweet things (and a very short, but carefully selected wine list), but that's it.  Oh, and the waits.
author: Josh B.

description: Love their thin crust pizzas - farm egg with goat cheese and olives was delicious, but you can't really go wrong with any of them. The menu changes and I always try their specials - yesterday's roasted cauliflower and farro salad with Parmesan dressing was amazing! Not a combo I would expect to be so great but it was. I also love their desserts - had the best cake there one time (was a ginger spice flavor with whipped cream on the side), wish I could order it every time! For a pizza joint, I always leave here feeling full but not stuffed, and like I actually had a relatively healthy/balanced meal, thanks to the thin crusts and creative salads/starters. I wish it was closer so I could eat here more often!
author: Yangchen C.

description: Great chocolate cake!!! Best in the city! The pizza is also amazing, very fresh and the flavor is delish!!!! A little gem in Richmond.
author: Z W.

description: A friend of ours told us about this place and has bugged us about when we were going to go here. We order it for pick up. Although it wasn't ready at the time frame they gave us, it's OK though, because it was understandable it was a Saturday night. And, it was one of the best thin crusted pizzas I have ever eaten! They were friendly.
author: Brittany H.

description: All I can say is everything is just AMAZING! If you're pizza lover, you MUST come here! SUPER friendly workers and  GREAT food! Even their non flour chocolate cake is wonderful!
author: Arisa H.

description:
I really wanted to love Pizzetta 211, but they are just too overpriced.  The restaurant itself is adorable and the staff was very welcoming and laid back.  The pizza smelled amazing and I didn't mind having to wait a bit longer than what they told me.  The host told me I could wait in my car and he would bring it out for me.  When the food came he placed it through the window and I was on my way.  Great!

However, I opened up the salad to grab a nibble as I was on my way to my friend's but was shocked to find the smallest handful of lettuce masquerading as my salad! This can't be right; they must have forgotten something, right?  So I went back.  They opened it up and told me that nothing was forgotten and that it looked so small because of the box.  So silly.  I asked them to put some more in, and they begrudgingly complied.  Of all things to over charge on - mixed greens?

Overall the pizza was tasty (but small), and the mixed greens salad was nothing special.  I will go back and dine in just to get more of the atmosphere, but I will avoid the salads!
author: Christine N.

description: I really love this place.  Everything always good, pizza with egg on it so good, desserts are housemade, not fancy just really good. (Had amazing olive oil cake) Thin crispy pizza, friendly staff with minimal attitude. Sidewalk dining, I could eat here weekly. It is tiny, really tiny.
author: Art-Suzanne R.

description: Tiny place, BIG flavor! Unique combinations using really awesome fresh ingredients. What a great little find!
author: Christen R.

description:
Pizzetta = a hole in the wall? I think not!

I came here on a brisk night with 2 of my friends to catch up on our lives and stories. My boyfriend and I were walking the puppy and walked up to the door of the restaurant. There were elevated benches around the trunk of a tree with warm, fuzzy blankets enticing its guests to use on a blustery night.

Conversations started as we all came together and out comes the waiter with a bowl of water just for the puppy (she's really spoiled and i really mean REALLY). She got her fix and now it was time for the humans to grub!

The restaurant may be small but this place has got a lot to offer. We were seated outside; heaters kept us warm and gleeful. We conversed, we ate and we were stuffed! The pizza is like a personal sized pizza but wonderful; the crust is crispy, thin and the toppings are fresh & organic. Each bite I took made me want to continue and when I took a glance at my plate my pizza was all gone. 

It's worth the bang for your buck. No more delivery for me! Pizzetta, you're my new pizza love. :)
author: Carol L.

description:
After having tried and failed to go to Pizzetta 211, I jumped at the chance to go when I knew everyone was watching the Giants in the World Series. My hunch was right - there was no wait! Although the tiny restaurant was still packed.

The pizzas were amazing - the bread/crust was crispy, thin, and chew, all at once (at least 1 pizza / person recommended!). The cheese salad was delicious. We also got free dessert since we were the last ones at the restaurant - a generous helping of Apple cake and a huge piece of chocolate cake. YUM! 

I love this place. Can't wait till the Giants are in the World Series again! :)
author: Nami S.

description:
In a corner shielded by yuppies lays Pizetta 211.

In their miniscule kitchen they whip out a surprising amount of food.

Sit near the bar area! Its worth it and you can converse with the staff. (if they're not too busy) 

The pizza margherita with san marzano tomatoes was deliciously balanced, the cheese and olive oil mixed with the tartness of the sauce all layered on a crispy crust.

(Egg pizza w/ bacon was decent but get the magherita!)

Buttermilk panna cotta was a pillowy creme with a delicate strawberry jelly on top.

We also got a small piece of the flourless chocolate cake which was quite good but not the star.

best pizza I've had in my life
author: Daniel K.

description:
The pizza was so good we had ended up ordering a second (no joke). Nice wine, cute  (small) venue, great waitstaff. 

We had these two:
San Marzano Tomato Sauce, Mascarpone, Wild Arugula, Olio Verde
Rosemary, Fiore Sardo Cheese, Pine Nuts

The rosemary pizza is a white pizza. I typically love tomato sauce, but this won me over. The pine nuts on the flavorfull sardo cheese, with rosemary underneath the surface was fantastic. 

The San Marzano pizza had a beautiful array of peppery arugula, sweet (ish) mascarpone, and very saucy and mildly spicy tomato sauce. Amazing.
author: Abraham B.

description:
A recent find, way out in the Outer Richmond.

VERY small restaurant  - like sits maybe 6 people small - that produces delicious, fresh pizza.  Great ingredients, interesting topping (I'm a big fan of the farm-egg topped variety), and excellent service.
Very reasonable prices to boot.

if you're in the mood for pizza a la Delfina, and don't want to deal the hassle of parking near Fillmore Street, give this place a try.
author: Tobin S.

description: Had the pizza with two eggs, prosciutto, braised endive, whole grain mustard, and gruyere cheese... SO GOOD. Also had an equally excellent beet salad. One of the best meals I've ever had in the City!
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I like this place a lot. It is very, very small so go at an off time.

Pizzas with egg are the way to go. I've tried 4 pizzas and all were great except  their standard pepperoni pie, which is fine unless you're expecting a more traditional pepperoni pizza flavor.
author: Artur G.

description:
My husband and I made a last-minute decision to try this tiny neighborhood pizzeria on a Saturday night. We had a wonderful experience all around. Luckily, we had only a 20 minute wait, and we made it in before 9 p.m. closing and before they ran out of pizzas.

For starters, we had their daily specials: a kale white bean soup and a cauliflower farro salad. Both were excellent. The pizzas were also fantastic, perhaps the best I've had in several years. My husband got the sausage pizza, and I had the tomato with white anchovies. He enjoyed mine so much that he ordered one to go, snagging the last pizza crust left! For dessert, we shared a refreshing lemon lime tart.

The service is down-to-earth, attentive, and friendly. I appreciated them accommodating my request for less cheese and even coming back to ask exactly how much I preferred. (Our server suggested 4 cubes instead of their usual 12, which was perfect.)

The place is very cozy with only a few tables inside and another few outside. We were seated at the bar, and it was fun to watch the team at work.

We both highly recommend this neighborhood gem; we'll definitely return!
author: Amanda M. C.

description: Pizzetta 211 is simply the BEST, and I do mean best, pizza in the city. If you appreciate pizza that isn't simply thick bread dough, globs of cheese, and toppings dumped on it drown in tomato sauce, then this is the place. Crusts are delicately formed, thin and crispy, toppings are selected and mixed together based on their blended tastes and harmony. Nothing is over done or under cooked. The style is chic and elegant. Paired with a glass of a big red wine, you enter the zone of food ecstasy and afternoon nap coma.
author: Shannon M.

description:
Got the margherita pizza and one of their rotational ones (housemade sausage, roasted broccoli shoots, parmigiano reggiano, lemon-chili oil). Got them to go this time and even though they were a little (just a little) cold, both pizzas hit the spot!  Love this place and will really miss neighborhood gems like Pizzetta if we ever move out of the city. Dude on the phone who took my order was really nice and reminded me that it's cash only.  That was a bonus because this is one of the few places in SF that's cash only. 

Even the bad pizza place down the street from my aparent accepts credit card.

Not hatin'.  Just sayin'.
author: Sherielyn G.

description:
I walk by Pizzetta 211 almost everyday on the way to work. And being a Big Pizza fan, how can I not pop in and give it a try.

They salad, appetizer and cake was ALRIGHT.

Their pizza on the other hand was great!!

They have Special Pizzas that come and go weekly, but they also have permanent pizzas.

I want to try to their pizza again some day.

Only 4-Stars, because I think their prices are a tad pricey. 

btw...it isn't a big restaurant, they have (4) mini tables inside and (2) mini tables on the outside. Not good for groups.

Field Green Salad - Organic Greens, Balsamic Vinaigrette
http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/EGUmToKJWsAlqdThXCXTEw/l

Asparagus Appetizer
http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/hUZbhzNq_byvvRQwnUdLew/l

Tomato, Mozzarella, Basil w/ Pepperoni
http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/FR_8eaIeOCvh9Gqfc7e_0A/l

Scharffenberger Flourless Chocolate Cake
http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/HO7OWllAkFLbOmS2VyzcdA/l

(Friday, May 7, 2010)
author: Kenny C.

description:
Pizzetta reinforced my long held belief that everything is better with an egg on it.  That being said, try their farm egg pizza - its absolutely out of this world.  They have perfected pizza from the simplest pies to unique combinations of ingredients that create a balanced flavorful bite.  Their anchovy pizza is perfect.  

The wait can be pretty long, especially to eat indoors, but they provide blankets and heaters for their outdoor seating, and you can enjoy a beverage while you wait.  

Nice small bites - marinated olives, salads, etc.  Delicious desserts.  

Cash only, so come prepared, or walk to the Chase ATM just down the street.
author: Virginia B.

description: One comment on the kitchen hygiene would be that some of the staff place their laundry on the bar top. Not very hygienic
author: Benito L.

description:
Pizza is a bit on the expensive side, and one can potentially finish an entire pizza. But it's so delicious! Especially the pizzas that have the egg on top! The yolk inside is so warm and creamy. The farm egg pizzas does not taste too heavy nor too greasy. I also highly recommend the flourless chocolate cake (I think that's what it's called). Simple on the outside, but very tasty on the inside. It's not too sweet.

Some of their pizzas stay on the  menu all the time; some of the pizzas they change weekly. Since I live so close to this place, I usually call in and pick up my pizza in 25 minutes, since there is not a lot of room to sit inside the restaurant.
author: Selina T.

description:
I had such a great experience here! I Love this place! I definitely aim to go back! 

This cute little place really has a big punch in flavor! 

The flavors of their pizza is just...lets just say my friend and I were speechless...and quiet...it was delicious. I for one am really hard to please in the tasting department. I can't help it i want to eat the best that is made with the best ingredients.

We had the cheese salad...I definitely remember the smoked buffalo mozzarella, and the goat cheese...so good, how it was matched well with the candied pecans, greens, bread, olives, and strawberries. We got to sit at the bar so we got a chance to learn a lot! They were so informative, truly shows their passion in all aspects from the selected cheeses to the well paired wines to the pizzas. I love their precision and their dedication in making the pizzas as well as the salads. My friend had the margarita pizza and I had a white pizza with potatoes, arugula, perfect runny eggs, pancetta...it was so good...The crust was thin and crispy with a little chew to it...loved it...

It was just so F***** delicious...words really can not describe it...So glad i've had the chance to eat there! Keep it up!
author: Tiff L.

description:
Pizza was fine, very limited selection of wines, and if you come around dinner you can expect to wait for 30+ minutes (especially if you want to sit inside--the dining room only seats 20 or so). Particularly frustrating was the fact that the waiter held tables for folks who left the line, making the wait even longer. Definitely wasn't worth the wait. 

That said, the (comped) "pluot" upside down cake was a pleasant surprise after a less than worthwhile dining experience.
author: Catherine T.

description: Come for the fresh made mini pizzas with tasty ingredients, stay for the fresh made tasty desserts! Rosemary & pine nut pizzeta, peach crisp dessert, glass of red wine. Perfect!
author: Chris S.

description:
Been back a couple more times and each and every time, is a five star experience, whether it be with service, the food, or the ambiance. 

Every time i've been back, i've gotten the farm egg pizza and every time, it's been different variation of it! What culinery creativity. You can really tell they put love and passion into everything they make. 

The flourless choc cake tastes like a lighter version of a brownie.. i thought it was good but not for me.  

i love bringing my girlfriends to this place for a cute night out!
author: Lily S.

description: The best pizza I had in my life. Small place, waited for about an hour or so, but totally worth it! Pizzas change bi-weekly so can't wait to try what's next
author: Yosuke M.

description:
If you are willing to look, the best things can often be found in the most unlikely places.  Like a random residential block on the outer fringes of the Outer Richmond neighborhood in way-outer S.F where the graceful geniuses of gourmet who preside over Pizzetta 211 ply their trade.  This is one of the legendary Alice Waters' favorite San Francisco spots, and the place evokes all the creative locavorian glory that Waters patented so many years ago.  

The restaurant is very small, the tables tiny (including a few outside), and the mood strikingly intimate.  Everything is close together and comfortable.  Many of the fresh ingredients that inspire the menu, which changes weekly, are displayed in plates and bowls along a counter within easy view of the pint-sized dining room.  The picture-perfect daily desserts sit suggestively between the tables and the small kitchen, presiding over the room, daring you to leave room for indulgence (which I, alas, didn't).

Every item on the menu, and virtually every ingredient therein, spoke to us.  The two starters that were offered as daily specials were the most hard to resist.  A masterfully presented and thoroughly delicious salad of shaved asparagus, fennel, arugula, oranges and hazelnuts, tossed unobtrusively in a light creme fraiche dressing.  Then a bundle of perfectly crisp broccolini, kissed with a subtle dash of chili, garlic and olive oil and served alongside a warm bowl of fresh ricotta.  At that point, it was time to do the "pinch yourself, am I real?" test.   Then came the pizzetta, atop a nicely blistered crust covered in pancetta, fontina, arugula, a tease of freshly shaved orange zest, and two sunny-side up eggs (a pizza topping that we believe must have been invented by one of the world's foremost prodigies).  

As we savored each bite, I closed my eyes and joyfully envisioned the chef's deft, meticulous selection of just-peaking fruit and vegetables from local farms.  A true celebration of nature's bounty.
author: Derek W.

description: I put this review up, not because I want to... but because I have to. Out of all the pizza places in SF, perhaps the world, this little gem of a shop might possibly be the best. I will not go into detail because I don't want this place to be overrun. In fact, the Richmond District is a cold, shadowy and foggy place. You'd be happy to have your subpar pizza in a much cool and fun part of the city. However, if you do end up in the way out and find yourself with a rumbly in your tumbly there are worse choice on could make.
author: Sean D.

description:
Freaking great.

We had a really simple appetizer of braised romano beans (not on the menu, but recommended by our server) in a marinara that was really exceptional, well-balanced and fresh.

The pizza is by far the best you'll get in the Outer Richmond. 

I saw a girl on a bike pick up her order for take out, wrap the box in plastic-wrap, put it in a hot-cold bag, and bungie it all together into her messenger bag so it would not tip over or fall out before riding away. I totally sympathize with her efforts to get good pizza.

While the inside was filled to capacity with 3 tables ahead of us in line, we immediately took a seat outside and ate under heated tables. This was topped by a knowledgeable and very friendly waiter.

Great night, great food.
author: Joshua O.

description:
My friend and I just went to Pizzetta 211 for the first time tonight. It was a random decision and we found it on yelp and saw the great reviews. The only thing was that for college students a 34$ meal between two is a little bit pricey, but on occasion we decided its okay :) especially when the food was this good!!!!

It is a really cute little restaraunt. There was four tables inside, a bar seating area with four stools and three outdoor tables set for two people. The place would not be accomodating for large groups but for groups of about 2-4 it is perfect. 

The staff was really nice. We ordered the special starter which was a tomato salad with green beans, burrata, grilled croutons, and peppers. It was such a good starter! We were blown away with how good it was actually. Then we got a pizza to share. It had prossciuto, pesto, mozzerella, goat cheese, and tomato. The pizza was also AMAZING!!!!! And it was thin crusted , which is my favorite type. 

To finish we were offered espresso or dessert. We were tempted between the special dessert of the night which was a buttermilk panna cotta with a rasperry puree sauce and ginger snap cookies or the usual dessert they served which was a flourless chocolate cake. We were so conflicted but the server was so kind and offered to give us the panna cotta with an additional sliver of chocolate cake so that we could try both of them. I thought this was such a nice gesture by her and we were so grateful! 

The overall experience here was awesome. We were both so satisfied by the end of the meal and we decided that we are definitely going back and with others too!
author: Hannah B.

description: Really good, really thin crust pizza. Not "the best pizza"... But best in neighborhood by far. Best within many neighborhoods. Worth a 30 minute wait, although we only waited minutes. Very fresh ingredients, very friendly staff, very good prices.
author: Joshua G.

description:
I was excited to try this place so I suggested it to my boyfriends mom for her birthday lunch. We showed up and the place looked really quaint and the food looked great. Luckily there was some space for five of us, which is saying something because the interior of pizetta211 is tiny. No problem, I'll suffer for a good pizza. My boyfriends mom asked me to move my chair to make room. And here, oddly enough, is where the trouble starts:

Out of nowhere this waitress (miserable looking thing with a curly-frizzy abomination you might call hair) takes us by surprise and starts barking at me to move my chair  telling me I'll get in the way of the servers. She kept ranting on about it, speaking to me like I'm mentally challenged even though I understood perfectly what she was saying (I'm not the type to take barking orders from just anyone, let alone someone who should be serving me). 

My bfs mom politely asks her where the rest of our party would go and she rudely answers (again in the "you're an idiot" tone) "You have both tables" and flashes her the most bitchy "fuck you" smile I think I have ever seen! It was all pretty unnecessary and we were all pretty confused by this woman.

We told her we were leaving because of her attitude. You would think if she didn't mean to be rude she would apologize, offer us a complimentary something or other, or even just tell us she was having a bad day and it wasn't anything personal. But she really didn't seem to care if she lost our business. (I think her exact words were " I didn't think I was being rude. But its your choice!")  

Of course we left, doesn't matter how nice the food is if a total wench is serving it.
author: Lady G.

description:
This pie is great. Im from NY and had a Sicilian grandmother e.g im an expert.
Love the thin crust. My favorite is the sardo rosemary pine nut. Jack one of the co-owners is a stand up guy. Met him at a bar and we made a bet about where some guy was from based on his accent. Jack lost and the next time I went into the shop, maybe a week later, as I was going to pay he told me, "nope, I never welsh on a bet". 
 Support this neighborhood gem. You're palate will be rewarded. 
 I can also testify that the person that does their shopping at the farmers market on Saturday mornings, is very thorough and takes pride in the selection of ingredients he's purchasing. Just saying, tis good to know right??
author: Conlon D.

description: The space is small but very homey feeling. We got take out and the pizza is nice thin crust.
author: Aki J.

description:
All I can say is wow.  We were on our way to another Pizza spot when this showed up in path. We decided to drive by and check it out. We couldn't see it on our first pass and Luckily found a parking spot down the road. 
When we arrived we were greeted with a smile and told to sit anywhere. Having looked at the weather in Columbus,  25 and snowing, we decided to eat outside even though it was in the upper 50s. To our surprise they had over head heaters that were perfect for my wife! 
We both ordered the side salad and when it can wish we ordered just one, because it was so big! Very simple, a lot of greens and vinaigrette perfect for a pre meal snack.
I don't normally like ricotta cheese, but with it being paired with asparagus and egg we couldn't resist. I'm glad we didn't because it might have been a top 5 woodfired pizza.  The tastes blended together perfectly and the toppings spread so each bite had a better taste. I make a point to save the best bite for last, but i didn't have to save anything because each bite wad better than the last. 
This was not easy to find and didn't seem like a tourist spot, but we are sure glad we ended up here!
author: Aaron L.

description: Delicious gourmet pizza! I love this place although the significant other unfortunately isn't as big a fan as his pizza tastes are more on the carnivorous/mainstream side (did someone say Supreme?). I love the pizzas here though. Can get crowded as the place is tiny so get here early, especially on a Friday night. Otherwise it's a wait in the cold and not much immediately around here either, so you'll be standing awkwardly in a residential area or hanging by your car.
author: Lisette P.

description:
went here about two weeks ago. Pizza was simply amazing. Some of the best I've had. Quarters were kinda cramped, but had a nice, homey feel. 

Cash only...lose a star. sorry. I don't even have a business and I can take credit cards. costs less than 3%. Build it in to your pricing. Give cash folks a discount if it means that much to you. 

I was OK with the cash thing because fortunately, I actually had cash in my wallet. It was the extremely snotty 'ITS ON THE MENU' condescension from one of the folks behind the counter that really kind of ruined my mood. Like I read all the fine print on menus...minus another star for their extreme rudeness. 

There are a bunch of other amazing pizza places in town, so it will probably be a while, if ever, before I go back.
author: pedro w.

description: Yay! They use square now, so they get the full 5 stars. Great pizza, nice, informed staff, and a very cozy dining experience. One of our neighborhood favorites.
author: C. K.

description: Perfect service, pizza, atmosphere  Been here 4x and love it more each time.  It will be the most miniscule restaurant you've ever been to: either prepare to wait or bring warm clothes for adorable outside dining.  We were self aware of the crowd gathering and made an effort to accommodate, but the restaurant would have left us alone for much longer.  No sense of rush.  Attentive service.  Easy to quickly eat as the pizza is divine.  Suggest staggering pizzas so they don't go cold.  1 pizza/person easy to accomplish and shared chocolate cake  a noble finish.
author: C R.

description:
The place is super cute. It's a tiny cottage house transformed into a restaurant. No other businesses around, just houses.  They don't take reservations and there's usually a looong wait.  I guess that just adds to the charm of the place.

As for the food, it's pretty good.  They offer a couple of different pizza, wine, and dessert choices which gets changed up every night.  Simple no brainer menu.  

Both times I've been my waiters have been charming and witty.  Def. a fun spot to check out if you're looking for a different dining experience in SF.
author: Shree R.

description:
So cozy and romantic and delicious.  I love me a pizza with a runny egg built in (it's like the ultimate Benny!) and they do this well. 

It's tempting not to spread the news since this is such a tiny place, but I believe in sharing :)
author: Oni X.

description:
What a gorgeous, cozy pizza shop!  Serves passionately inspired, carefully sourced & artfully crafted seasonal pizzas, along with one of the most glorious chocolate cakes I have ever had.  Which was accompanied by an *incomparable* chantilly cream.  The ingredients here?  Are seriously exquisite.
It's a remarkably teensy space, only accommodating four small parties (2-4 per table) indoors, with a couple/three weather-permitting outdoor tables.  The ambiance is intimate, with upper-class, rural-rustic overtones... it made me feel like I was living the first world white collar dream, for sure.  I would gladly return for a dine-in experience in a heartbeat with treasured friends or family, and gladly order take-out for a highbrow night on the couch.
author: Rachel S.

description:
Honestly? Overrated. We had the Farm Egg pizza, Bacon/Brussel Sprouts pizza, and the Margherita Pizza. The pizzas were good, but the pizzas at Arizmendi are just as good. We arrived 10 mins before they opened, and there was already a long line..on a Monday. Naturally we had high expectations. The verdict? Not worth the wait (or the money). The venue is small. The service is mediocre (they served TWO tables that arrived after us..screwed up our Farm Egg pizza and had to redo it...and oh yeah screwed up our Bacon/Brussel Sprouts pizza too.) The only mildly exceptional pizza was the Margherita. They do make a good margherita. But the service ruined it for us. They did apologize and give us a complimentary apple cobbler, BUT their sorry was not genuine, the waiter came off as completely unapologetic, and bottom line it was too little too late. 

Won't be returning. SORRY I'M NOT SORRY.
author: Diane G.

description: One of the most delicious pizza I've had in a very long time.  My friend and I went on March 24, 2014 so since then the menu has changed.  But here's what we had:  1) Farm egg, maitake mushroom, truffled pecorino, garlic, herbs, & cream. 2) Spicy braised lamb, mint yogurt, & charred spring onion.  OMG!!!  It was amazing...both!!  But I might even like the spicy braised lamb more.  The combination was just amazing and the crust was well cooked.  Definitely coming back to try other toppings.  I love that they change the menu every 2 weeks.  Though I hope to have the spicy braised lamb again.  I'm salivating thinking about it.  And I also love that the place is small and intimate.
author: M. T.

description:
The crust here is delicious! The pizza combinations change based on the season so for the time being... The eggplant and creme fraiche pizza has good flavor, and is my favorite. If you order the egg pizza I recommend having them add a second egg. The field green salad isn't worth the moola.
