The non-alcoholic drink selection is very limited. No iced tea, no soda, but they do have red and white wines. I think it is overly pretentious that they call the tap water Hetch Hetchy. Really? REALLY?!?

My rating is 4 stars.
author: urban r.

description: All the pizzas and salads are good. The chicory salad was way way overdressed with pillows of mayo . The white pizza and brussel sprout pizza was very salty. The margarita pizza was very nice. They are not getting a fifth star because their server was unwelcoming, unhelpful, off putting and unfriendly. She was a b___h. I would go back but feel uncomfortable because of the server's surly attitude and face making. She's every reason why this restaurant needs to evaluate whether she's going to eventually erode business. I hope the owner is listening. I saw other comments similar to mine about service only after I wrote this review. This place has s great product but it's eroded by your servers maligned attitude.
author: Tertiary D.

description: Tiny place with tiny pizzas, but not too tiny prices.  Taste was good but I had to order 2 of there "pies" to fill up me and my girlfriend, and we are not big eaters by any means.  They do use very good, fresh ingredients and a nice thin crust...... but I have had comparable quality with much more quantity at the same price.  Two small pies ran us $31 plus drinks, tip and tax.  They need to work on either price or quantity,, then I would go back....
author: Patrick C.

description: I was in the city for the day and I was looking for a good, authentic pizza place. I tried to get reservations at A 16 and Flour + Water, but was unable to get a reservation. I found this place on Yelp and saw that it had a lot of good reviews, so I decided to try it out. It is a hole-in-the-wall (literally!) kind of place with maybe 4 tables inside and a few outside. Luckily my friend and I were able to get a table without waiting. I ordered a pizza with San Marzano tomato sauce, Mascarpone, wild arugula and olio verde. It was absolutely delicious! The tangy tomato sauce with the creamy, cheesy mascarpone, and the fresh, peppery arugula was divine! The pizza was made in a wood brick oven and arrived at our table with the cheese still bubbling. After I ordered the dessert du jour, which was a strawberry shortcake with a homemade whipped cream; it was a nice and light way to end the evening. I would highly recommend this place. The waiters are attentive and friendly, and it is a nice, casual alternative to some of its better-known counterparts.
author: Krystal D.

description: This is my FAVORITE restaurant in the city, hands down. The pana cotta that I had there 2 years ago still drifts into my thoughts from time to time and causes some serious salivation. The place is small and cozy and the food is fresh and flavorful. They have a salad with artisanal cheeses, every time I eat it I savor every single bite.... They have good lattes too. I suppose they're known for their pizzas but in reality ALL of it is AMAZING. It's the type of place I go to and I over order yet proceed to eat every damn thing in front of me and end up having to unbutton my pants so I can breath on the way home.
author: Sandy P.

description:
Ordered two pizzas here with a friend... I can't remember the first one, but it was pretty good. 

As for the second one... rosemary, fiore sardo cheese, and pine nut pizzetta (we also added sausage to it) was so amazingly delicious, I couldn't put it down! 

In fact, I'm still having dreams about this pizza...
author: Lucinda W.

description:
Small gem hidden in the outer Richmond. Definitely not exaggerating when I say small, seats about 6 - 8 people at most, with additional seating outside.

We were lucky enough to get there before the evening rush, right before a line formed.

The menu changes on a weekly/bi-weekly basis, with a few staples. We ordered:

-The beet salad (tangy, fresh, great starter),

-Farm Egg, Pork Confit, Chive, Potato, Gruyere $15.50 (seemed pretty popular, didn't disappoint, loved the eggs) 

-Rosemary, Fiore Sardo Cheese, Pine Nuts  $12.00 (sweet aroma, pine nuts really made the dish for me)

-Flourless Chocolate Cake (pretty good)

The pizzas are thin crust and has a nice crunch to it. Definitely not what I would consider "heavy" for those calorie counters out there. I'd recommend a pizza for each person, any less might leave you hungry.

The service was pretty good, staff was attentive.

Like many have mentioned before, it's a small establishment, which has its charms but can also lead to long waits, so be prepared. It's also cash only, so plastics wont do you any good here!
author: Albert T.

description: This place makes the Richmond seem charming. Pizza with egg and very salty ham was sublime. The sausage pizza with nuts was overwhelmed by sweet mushrooms. Service was kooky and scattered, but generally sweet. We sat outside, in low 60s, and were comfortable for dinner under the space heaters.
author: Morris R.

description:
I miss living in the neighborhood so we could go on a Tuesday when it wasn't packed, and also going during the Pre-Sunset magazine review days....

Still, they deserve all the accolades- the pizzas are amazing, the service was good, and salads/appetizers are fresh and inventive-especially specials. 

Hmmm- we have people visiting soon.....SF neighborhood tour may need to include a snack stop!
author: Keri B.

description: This is my first time here and coincedntly my first review. I have to say I am thuroughly satisfied. The food was awesome and the service was good the gentalmen taking our order was very sweet. I really like how small of a place it is to unlike some larger restaurants who've lost their soul focusing on covers this place seems to take thief time. Instead focusing on quality and it shows. I Will definitely come back here.
author: Phillip B.

description:
Despite the long wait, this place is definitely worth it.

My girlfriend and I were served with drinks as we were waiting to be seated, which is a nice touch.  The waiting staff and kitchen were very friendly and the ambiance was very casual and intimate.  The place is a little small, but I think its good because more people would take away the intimacy and increase the noise level.

The food was superb.  We ordered a heirloom tomato salad with rigotte cheese? (it was not on the menu for the appetizers), the Farm Egg, Coppa, Corno Di Toro Pepper, Parley-Caper Oil Pizza, and the House Made Flourless Chocolate Cake.  All three items were DELICIOUS.  The balance of the appetizer with the different flavors and textures was intricate.  The pizza was awesome.  Thin crust, but very tasty and very filling even though it looks small.  And the chocolate cake basically tasted like a brownie in cake form and felt very fresh.

Overall, I would highly recommend this place.  Had a great experience and will definitely come back!
author: Lawrence E.

description: What a special place!  Some of the best and most unique pizza in San Francisco, all served up in a tiny (but comfortable) kitchen/dining space.  Not to be missed.
author: John S.

description:
Perfect little restaurant. 

Romantic, cozy, beautiful. Delicious food. Great service.
author: Joyce G.

description:
I'm updating my review, since I've been back to Pizzetta 211 more than I'd like to admit, especially considering I live 45 minutes away.

This is my favorite thin-crust pizzeria, in any area. The rotating menu is a great idea, but my recommended go-to that's always on the menu is the Rosemary, Fiore Sardo Cheese, and Pine Nut pizzetta. That is, if the butternut squash one isn't in season. Always fresh and made to order.

The pizzettas are 6 slices, which is ample enough to share, but I'd recommend getting your own and trading slices. I mean, nobody dislikes leftover pizza. The appetizers change frequently, and the field greens salad never fails to make me happy.

Yes, there is usually a wait, but I've been lucky enough on occasion to just walk in and be seated, and there are almost always seats at the counter, too. I'm going to repeat from my old review that even if there is a wait outside, the employees will never rush you to leave, and will continue to give you 5-star service during your visit.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
3.23.2011
6:30 PM

Egg and Pancetta pizza
Arugula Pizza

White bean salad

Mmmmhmmm.

I would give it 5 stars but it took too long to get my grumpy ass seated.  Great food, though.  The ingredients definitely shine through and the cooking staff is not a lazy bunch; they freshly make EVERYTHING on the reg.

Good work.
author: William R.

description:
with over 600 yelp reviews and a solid 4 starts there's plenty of reasons to go to Pizetta 211. 

I'd like to give you one reason not to go: chances are you wont be able to enjoy most pizza (after this point) without thinking about how awesome it could've been if it came from Pizetta 211.

On the serious note - everything was great. Starting with the special salad (which still makes me wonder - weeks later - "how do you make plants taste like that?!?!?") and ending with the chocolate cake.
author: Oleg H.

description: This is our favorite pizza place! Yummy thin crust pizzas. Especially love the seasonal one with a farm egg.
author: Heather R.

description: Delicious pizzas, great wines and a cozy ambience. The service: calm, warm, caring. A rare spot with food that could elate the most insatiable pizza aficionados, and gracious service. A little home of charm.
author: Ethan H.

description:
Delicious, uber fresh pizza. I could eat endless amounts of it! 

My boyfriend and I got seats at the bar which was fun- we got to watch our food being made and salivate over the desserts that were laid out right in front of us. We also got to witness a minor hissy fit and other staff happenings. ;) 

I got pepperoni pizza and he got the Coppa pizza. They were both amazing and really light. If I didn't live so far away I'd be a regular here. We also split a piece of their Plum Almond turn over cake which was lovely. I'll be back! The only downfall is, as others have said, it's a very tiny restaurant.
author: M P.

description:
Small, but delicious.

NOTE - be prepared to wait a bit if you go during a peak time. I like to call ahead and ask them how busy they are before heading over.

Perfect for a date, but maybe not a first date (a little too intimate).

Delicious pizza - especially if you like eggs.
author: Brian S.

description: My favorite spot in the Outer Richmond - hands down. The space is small and cozy and inviting. And most importantly, the food is to-die-for! Always order the seasonal starter, their vegetables are fresh and delicious. My personal favorite is the pine nut rosemary pizzetta! A wonderful place for an intimate (and romantic) weeknight dinner. I love you Pizzetta!
author: Claire D.

description:
Just moved to Richmond from Potrero/Dog Patch....was missing Piccino and stumbled upon Pizetta - as it turns out the folks at Piccino got their start here.....not sure but seems the breakup might have been sour - but the pizza here is SWEET - we think THE BEST in the city - bar none - with all of the lovely charm a small place offers - great service - incredible daily specials (last week a white bean and kale soup that was achingly delicious) and house made desserts.  Did I mention blue bottle coffee?

Almost hate to write a rave and have others "discover" it - but had to, as is that good.

We have been back again and again - the pizzas change every so often with the seasons - right now the artichoke and olive with goat cheese is to die for and my staple is the San Marzano with arugula and mascarpone cheese.  A true gem in a city of amazing restaurants - but be prepared to wait or wear a sweater and plan to sit outside as only 4 tables and a small bar inside.
author: Mylea C.

description:
Okay this place is delicious with fresh ingredients and an amazingly cute atmosphere.  If you are lucky enough to stumble upon Pizzetta when it is not crowded you have to go. 

That said, I never even try and go here because I don't like to waste my time staring at other people eating beautiful food while I starve.  Life is too short. 

...but seriously yum.
author: Cork C.

description: Mmm, this place is better than Delfina in my opinion. Far less overhyped. It's cute and intimate, the ingredients are fresh, the crust is thin and satisfyingly crispy, and the combination of pine nuts, bok choy, and shiitake mushrooms was unique and texturally perfect.
author: Carol C.

description:
Fantastic, delicately prepared gourmet pizza and to die for desserts and coffee.  They use only the very best ingredients.

PS, we were there on a Sunday where some reviewer disparaged their service and attitude.  We sure didn't find a problem and found their service and attitude to be wonderful.

Will go back!
author: V L.

description: This place has been on my bookmarked list for years and I finally went. I really enjoyed my pizza and the rest of my dinner. It was a nice night out and the place was really fun and cozy. I'll definitely be going back soon and I'm still kicking myself for not going sooner.
author: El T.

description:
Oh my gosh, this place is amazing!  If I could go back to all of my other pizza place reviews and take a star off of them and give it to Pizetta I would!  

I guess I didn't really know good pizza until here... I've been awakened!

Pros:
Perfect light and crisp crust 
super friendly staff
amazingly delicious pizza combinations
I love the quaint warm decor of this place - very rustic.

Note:
Their menu changes weekly, so if you read about a pizza on Yelp it won't necessarily be there on your visit. 

Plan of Action:
Make the hour drive to eat here over and over again!
author: K. R.

description: This place is the best. I have tried several of their pizzas by now and they are all delicious. It's a super tiny place so I usually do takeout. The pizzas are so. good.
author: nichole g.

description: My go to place for pizza craving or need for friends dropping by.  Very good service, excellent salads, adventuresome wines, and if crowded as it can be order to go!
author: Donald H.

description:
Ate: farm egg with pancetta, and margherita with white anchovies. 
Amazing pizza! Small place. Four tables. A couple outside with heaters. A must for pizza enthusiasts.
author: Tracy R.

description:
Sausage pizza
Bacon pizza

Simple salad with mixed greens 

This place is fabulous. Little hole-in-the-wall. Reminds me of tiny mom n pop bistros in France. Comes with a WC.

And the service can't be beat. I love these people.
author: Ta G.

description:
We almost missed it driving by for lunch because it was such a tiny place, tucked between Clement and California next to a laundromat. It looked adorably cozy - I doubt that twenty people can squeeze into this place comfortably - and I was excited. The smaller the place, the more attention given to the customers and the orders, I hoped.

When we got there, one other table was taken, and we were seated by the window on a long, cushioned bench.The server was very nice and friendly, a UCSD alumni who checked in on us several times to make sure that things were A-OK. He kindly advised my friend and I not to spend all our time at college studying, which had been my initial plan. No idea what to do with my college life now, but I do know that when I get back to SF on the occasional weekend, I will be returning here sometime.

Between three people we shared three pizzettas, each ten inches in diameter and very thin, yet boasting a nice crust. The amount of ingredients was just right for the amount of dough, which was slightly toasted on the bottom yet still soft underneath the cheese and tomato sauce. The Rosemary and Pine Nuts pizzetta was my favorite; it definitely had plenty of the herb for a rich, delicious flavor and the pine nuts, which is not the usual fare for pizza, added a lovely crunchy texture, though it was not overwhelming in the least. And that cheese! It just melted in the mouth. 

The Basil, Mozzarella, and Tomato pizzetta sounded simple but tasted fantastic, and the basil was sprinkled generously, complementing the cheese and sauce nicely. It was very yummy. The same pizzetta with anchovies, was not my favorite, but my fellow diners loved it. I'm usually not fond of fish, and especially not on pizza, but I had a bite and it was rich with unique flavor. A nice addition, though not for me.

If I did not fit into the typical broke-college-student mold, I would love to frequent this place more often, but alas, the bill came to about fourteen dollars a person after tip. A nice lunch, and definitely the best pizza I've had in a long while, but the amount was not quite satisfying. I liked the style of pizza with a very thin crust, but I couldn't see it filling up any starving customers. Anyone who is seeking a light-medium lunch and doesn't mind forking over the cash should definitely stop by.
author: Tina Y.

description:
Blinded by the awe of another great thin pizza, I may have overlooked the slight bit of chaos whirling through Pizzetta on the last visit.

Quick Tips:
*Arrive early. When the dough is sold out, so is your dinner. The other night I watched diners being turned away at 9:00 pm.
*If you are a 2-top, bring a jacket. The tables inside are mostly for groups of 3 or 4 (unless you get lucky). The tables for 2 are all outside (under heaters) plus some seats at the bar. The bar was a little cramped, nowhere to put your jacket/purse etc and you're right in front of the open door so it's going to get cool.
*BRING CASH

*Sausage-potato-sage pizza was insanely flavorful but felt greasy.
*Daily antipasto/small plates. Try one.
*Flour-less chocolate cake - FTW.
author: Alissa A.

description: Such a tiny place filled with so much charm! Their menu is inventive and fresh, and everything we tried was delicious. The handmade pizza was incredible, but the loss of one star is for the pizza maker that kept checking her cell phone every 3 minutes. Call me a germaphobe, but handling your cell phone between bare handed pizza dough pressing struck me as icky. Wish I hadn't seen that, but we were seated at the bar facing her, so if was impossible to ignore. It didn't freak me enough to swear off the place or anything. I'd definitely go back and try more menu items. The bathroom had some trippy entertainment. Check it out, even if you don't have to pee. :-)
author: A T.

description:
I think I've found my perfect thin-crust pizza!  Pizzetta's a cute pocket pizza joint, but it delivers big taste. They have a few pies that are always on the menu, and have other seasonal pies that drift in and out.  (I am in love with the butternut squash/sage one.)  Like everything else at Pizzetta, the wine list is small but carefully chosen.  

Oh!  And save room for dessert.  If they have the goat cheese cheesecake with candied kumquats, get it!  I hear really good things about the flourless chocolate cake as well.

Regulars will tell you to go in the afternoon.  I'll just tell you to go there.  Period, end of story.
author: Andi T.

description: I am going to make this quick: If you haven't eaten at Pizzetta, you haven't experienced life.
author: Penny S.

description:
"I'm still thinking about Pizzetta," says my girlfriend with a sigh. "I could eat more pizza but it wouldn't be the same."

That means a lot coming from a New Yorker.

Outdoor seating. A weekly updated menu. Delectable desserts. And more charm than a Tiffany's bracelet. Every time I've eaten at Pizzetta, I've walked home stuffed and satisfied.

The pizza has an excellent crunch to the crust and the variety of traditional and untraditional ingredients are super fresh, everything from cheese, to greens, and even my favorite--a whole egg baked right into the cheese. Superb.

One pizza is definitely a good size for a hungry person. Two pizzas on a date, and you may or may not have a slice or two to take home. If I have one complaint, it's the tiny kitchen area. But in a friendly neighborhood that lacks the glitz of trendier spots in the city and where parking can be a nightmare, I've never had to wait too long for a table.
author: Tony L.

description:
We had the Farm Egg Pizza and Sausage & Shitaki Mushroom Pizza, as well as the Calzone. Calzone was not worth it. We liked the Farm Egg Pizza the best. The pizzas are pretty pricey at $14-15/ea. Also the pizzas are pretty small so you should order 2 if you want to make a dent on your hunger and it takes them awhile to make it. 

I liked the tiny little shop selling 'gourmet pizza' feel to the place, but too bad the pizza didn't make the bar for me. The husband loved it though!

Didn't get to try the flour less chocolate cake :sad face:
author: Jessica H.

description: I am seriously impressed with the pizza here. The tomato sauce had just the right amount of kick to it and the mascarpone cheese was decadent but not overly heavy. I can't wait to eat here again. We got pizza to go because I was afraid of the wait. The quality of the pizza held up over the 10 or so minutes it took to pick it up and drive home.
author: Denise G.

description:
First off I want to say parking is difficult, the place seats 20 at the max, its small, yet the décor is industrial trendy.  The waiting area is outside. As for the pizza, I don't think it's worth the bus ride or taxi to go there.  The pizza was tasteless, the tomato sauce was tomato paste from Contandina (well it tasted like that to me, since I make pizza at home)...
The staff was attentive but not smiling. 

Ok I ordered the 

1)egg pizza (it tasted like breakfast pizza, hmmm nothing special to me--just egg on cheese and bread--eh whatevs)

2)Margherita (they say you can judge a pizza place by the taste of its margherita--well it was oily and tasted like it had fake cheese, canned tomato paste and  no hint of basil flavor), it basically tasted like a thin crust domino cheese pizza)

3)I tried the Eggplant pizza with baby arugula (it was also blah, and nothing that makes my mouth water, again BLAND!--my goodness)

They however do not have soggy krust so that's good. When the pizza comes out, it looks very appetizing, then once you bite into it, first it's OK, then it gets bland as you keep biting...maybe this place is good for people around the neighborhood because it's the only thin crust gourmet  restaurant in outer richmond.

Oh well, it was worth the try, At least I can say I hunted down the top gourmet thin crust pizzeria's in SF.
author: Q A.

description:
Love Love LOVE this place. The people that work there are awesome (nice but not annoying) and the food is FABULOUS! We split a salad and the egg and oxtail pizza and even tried their cake. Everything was good. =) Next time we have to try a different pizza...

I took away one star because they're cash only....which sucks if you would like to run up the tab (sucks for them too!)
author: Zoeboe D.

description: Great tiny place. Great service. Creative, well done food. Only 4 small tables inside plus a few tiny tables on the street "patio". Worth the wait for fresh thin crust pizza. Probably the best pizza we've had in CA.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Love the feel of this place! Feels like you're in someone's homey kitchen dining room.
Wasn't very busy this afternoon (possibly because it was street cleaning day).

pizzettas:
+ Farm egg: comes with 2 eggs(!), huge chunks of sausage, a little salty, but sooooo good
++ Bacon, meyer lemon, brussel sprouts: FAVORITE, all the flavors worked well together
+/-  Savory Spinach: ok, glad they didn't skimp on the veggies :)

dessert:
++ Flourless choco cake: I need to learn out to make this! Fluffy, rich, delish
++ Apple "pie?": I usually don't like apple pies, but this was PERFECT. Fresh apple pieces, not mush; sweet light crisp pie crust. DONE.

Probably helped the experience that we didn't have to wait, no rush, and it was a sunny day enjoying lunch with friends. :)
author: Angel L.

description:
I came here by myself the first time and had a delightful time. "Delightful" is exactly the sort of adjective for this place. It's quaint and tiny and has this very neighborhood cafe sort of atmosphere to it. I don't remember which pizza I had, but I remember it being pretty damn tasty.

The second time around, I brought a group of friends with me. Everyone loved it. Again, I don't remember exactly which pizza I got--but I remember it being pretty damn tasty. If you want a recommendation for which pizza to get: get the one that sounds pretty damn tasty. It probably is.

Also, the bathroom is a total trip.
author: Greg P.

description: Great food. Small quaint little place. Recommended by a local restaurant worker. Highly recommend
author: Leigh F.

description:
the fiance and i stumbled across this very quaint neighborhood place. we had just scored a parking space about 2 blocks south of clement st and noticed the large groups of people gathered outside this tiny restaurant. we figured it MUST be good for that many people to wait outdoors in the cold.

well, our original choice for dinner (PPQ dungeness crab) had a 35 min wait. i couldn't wait that long so we walked back to pizzetta and was told it would be a 15-20 min wait. still a wait but bearable. although we were seated outdoors, there were heated lamps and blankets which helped.

as for the pizza, i really enjoyed the rapini with homemade sausage and agrumato cheese. we also tried the rosemary with pine nuts pizza but the cheese was way too strong (some sort of blue cheese). and for dessert, we both loved the scharffen berger flourless chocolate cake (think rich and dense chocolate brownie) with fresh whipped cream.

i would def come back if i was craving for thin crust pizza in this area. the fiance would probably think twice as he didn't think the food was worth the "dough". yes, pun intended.
author: Helen Y.

description: We went on a Saturday afternoon and I was pleased to get a table for two after just a quick five minute wait. I wouldn't want to go with more than two people total as there just isn't much space. I was blown away by the pizza itself, enjoyed the olive appetizer selection, and appreciated their reasonable $15 corkage fee. It really didn't seem like you could go wrong with the pizzas. We had one combination that I wasn't as sure I would like but I still loved it - they really know what they're doing.
author: Lisa K.

description:
We found parking RIGHT outside the entrance. LUUUUUUCKY! :)

This place has an amazing pizza...AMAZING. And the service is super duper nice too. 

Since I read so many good reviews talking about the farm egg pizza, I had to get it... Halfway  through our pizza, I realized that they put different things on the pizza every week; and I wish I had remembered the rest of the ingredients on our pizza that particular week because it was SAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAALTY!!!!!!!! I was really good and all; but oh my god the saltiness was just very very very very very very overpowering- not to be repetitive....

The crust was so good and the egg on the pizza was very unique, so I'm definitely up to try this place again, and maybe I can bump this review up to five stars!
author: Erica A.

description: It has a really cool vibe, the place is small and cozy, the food is delicious and the service is great. They got us waiting a bit for the pizza, and then gave us the desert we ordered for free. The home made flour free chocolate cake was so good! We didn't had wine but it looked to me like the had a good selection and the even let you taste before choosing. It's a bit far from where we live, but if I have the chance I would totally come back. Lovely pizza place.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
I hesitated to go back to Pizzetta for a few years because of the awful wait times.  But, a random rainy Saturday afternoon had me craving pizza, and we figured at 3pm it shouldn't be too hard to get a seat. So happy I went back! Not that the food was bad the first time I went, far from it, but it was better the second time around. 
The farm egg pizza is incredible... the runny egg, greens... perfectly done crust... I want more. Now.
Their house made sausage is amazing as well. It has fennel seeds in it, and I don't even like fennel that much! But, I scarfed it down and wanted seconds. 
We finished with a great blood orange tart. 
I left full and happy and I definitely won't wait another year or two before I go back.
author: Jordan R.

description: You have to wait but it's worth it.  When I moved into Inner Richmond awhile back, this was one of my first meals in my furniture-less apartment.  I love eggs...everything tastes better with eggs. Why shouldn't it always be on pizza?  With prosciutto, no less! The thin crust is amazing, too.
author: Erika C.

description: Great pizza, inexpensive wine- all around nice place
author: Lisa B.

description: So rude, that when they finally opened the door at 12:15pm this afternoon, we decided not to eat here. One of the most uninviting places in the City.
author: David R.

description:
Went here for a date night with one of my girlfriends. It's pretty close to my house so it was a nice walk. We sat outside (the place is veryyyy small) but it was a fairly nice night and there are heaters outside. We split a field green salad withe balsamic vinegar and a pizza with pinenuts and goat cheese (i wish i remember the name) and had a good time overall.

The pizza was delicious and the crust was deliciously thin with a great texture. Their pizzas are seasonal and change week to week (which is why i can't remember the name of the one we got!) so all their ingredients are really fresh and so flavorful!

The mixed green salad with balsamic vinegar was literally just that--i mean i should've expected that as that's what it said on their menu but I would've enjoyed some tomatoes or crisper mixed green leaves--just something to make the salad special since their pizzas are so stellar.
author: An-Nhien L.

description: You don't often think of heading to the Outer Richmond for food. For both Aziza and Pizzetta 211 it's worth the trip. Their pizzas change often with fresh and in season ingredients. The crust is perfectly baked. The food is fairly simple in the best kind of way-- no molecular gastronomy, just good old fashioned really high quality ingredients prepared in a way that showcases them. I live in the Mission so don't get out here as often as I'd like to, but highly recommend it to anyone who hasn't been.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
Jan and I just had lunch here and our pizzas were super delish.  Jan had the egg and pepper sauce and I had the pesto, bacon and tomato.  

I've eaten here several times and always experienced excellent food and at least decent service (although nothing remarkable).  I've never experienced any attitude but I can see how that is possible here.  Server 'tude really bothers me and would turn me away even if the food was really good.  

Minus one star for the prices - they could be justified (being organic,local etc) but it's rough to pay nearly $20 for a pizza and water lunch.
author: Julienne G.

description: Great thin-style craft pizzas with great texture and taste.  I liked the white sardine pizza.
author: Ruthie K.

description:
Delicious! We had the farm egg, bacon, roasted corn, chive, chipotle creme fraiche pizza and the tomato, mozzarella and basil pizza with anchovies. Both were excellent.

It got pretty crowded but you really can't beat the atmosphere. There are 4 tables inside, 3 tables outside and a little waiting area outside where you can sit and have a drink or two during your wait. 

Our server was also very good. He was very friendly, attentive and easy to talk to. Even though he was quite busy, he did not act rushed while answering our questions- amazing customer service.

We'll be back!
author: Kristy R.

description: Great neighborhood spot! Tiny restaurant, you'll definitely have to wait to get a table. Though it's worth it. They always have starters they make for the day, always combinations I would never think to cook or order and every time they are outstanding. The pizza crust is super thin and really tasty. We usually get one app and one pie. You will need more if you're starving.
author: Lori F.

description:
We went around 3 o'clock on a foggy Sunday (who are we kidding, every Sunday is foggy out there!) We got a table by the window (no wait) and a margerita pizza to share.

Staff was friendly, pizza was super tasty.
author: Miriam W.

description: A small neighborhoody place that reminds me of a back alley trattoria in Italy. Wonderful, plate-sized pizzas with a nice simple sauce and cheese. Just a very pleasant place to visit. I was there early and got a seat inside. Within 15 minutes there was a wait.  Sitting outside would have worked as long as I was under a heat lamp.
author: Nico F.

description: I just found out about this place and it was absolutely amazing, I cannot wait to go back. From the inviting staff to the warm ambiance to the delicious food that just kept getting better and better with every course. It was a little bit of a wait, but totally worth it. Simply one of the best places the Richmond District has to offer.
author: Lindsay C.

description:
Pizetta 211 gets its name from the symbolic beauty of simple math.

2 = 1 + 1, where "1" is flavor and the other "1" is ambience. 

It also is a sly reference to how nice this place is for a date, as two individuals in love equal something greater.

Then again, 211 might just be the address of the place on 23rd Ave, much like when you say "meet me Crab House At Pier 39" or "just swing by 126 Tenderloin Housing Clinic." 

Pizetta is a tiny restaurant, just a handful of cramped tables inside next to the kitchen and a few tables on the sidewalk. But this shortage of space creates a friendly and intimate atmosphere.

I prefer sitting outside, as the neighborhood is really quiet and I feel like there's more breathing room. 

There are benches and blankets under a tree for those waiting on a table.

The daily limited menu is based on availability of ingredients. The thin crust pizzas are tasty and unique, with a variety of different and playful toppings and subtle flavor. They are pretty small though, so if your just ordering pizza think one per person. Everything else on the menu is fantastic too: great salads (especially the cheese plate) and dessert.

I've been here multiple times and have yet to be disappointed in any way. The wait staff has also been genuinely friendly and attentive, though it might be due to the blinking "serviceborg" implants visible on the back of their necks.

Cash only.
author: Nik D.

description:
Great place for date night.

I love Pizza! This place totally delivered and awesome pie as well as an awesome atmosphere. It's super small and intimate, so don't expect a tons of elbow room. However the small space makes it totally boutique and cozy. 

Oh! Please try any dessert they have on the menu for that night. You will NOT regret it.
author: Leslie D.

description:
I love this little pizzetta shop.  If I lived here, in this neighborhood, I would go to Pizzetta 211 several times a week.

My husband and I had the pizza with anchovies and a cheese salad.  I was pleasantly surprised and very happy with the salad.  It was almost a cheese plate with greens that were tossed in light balsamic dressing.  A good amount of olives and some nuts also garnished the plate.  It was everything you could ask for in a salad.  In one word, it was a fancy salad and great with a glass of wine.
author: YM K.

description:
CASH ONLY!!! grrrrrr

i dont exactly remember which pizza i had except that it was alright. still looking for pizza better than cheeseboard in berkeley!!!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
One word..PERFECTION!  Okay..here are more words!  Usually my friends and I don't go out for pizza.  It's usually Thai, Burmese, Mexican, Ethiopian, Chinese (dumplings!), Peruvian, Middle Eastern, Korean..well..you get the point!!  When going out I usually spend hours researching 7X7 100 Things 2 Eat Before You Die, their mini restaurant guide and all my bookmarked restaurants here!  Oye!

My friend said Italian was one of her favorites..so I had to research!  It was down to this place and Berretta..and she chose this one!  I'm SO GLAD!!!!

Such a nice young man (I sounds older than I am!) :)  greeted us and said it would be 20 min. for two people; it was probably 7:30 (found a spot a block and a half away).  One minute later...he asked if we wanted to sit at the counter...we said YES!  If you do sit at the counter..there really isn't any place for a jacket..but they have hooks for purses under the counter....feeeeel your way!  The guy who waited on us was nice and helpful..never rushed us...even though their restaurant is tinier than this other dive I love...really!   

House Made Lamb Sausage, Harissa, Spring Onion, Mint!  That's what I had! Outstanding flavor on a thin, crispy crust!  The best pizza I have ever had...yeah, better than Delfina....like..WAY!  Actually..just writing this is getting me hungry!  Where is my pizza?!!  I really want to try the...Hot Coppa, Braised Artichoke, Crescenza, Caper-Herb Oil pizza!!!!  My friend had the pizza with..Rosemary, Fiore Sardo Cheese, Pine Nuts ..which is one of the 101 things to eat before you die..according to 7X7..with a farm egg.  My pizza was better!  We also had the Cheese Salad...Organic Greens, Artisanal Cheeses, Spiced Walnuts ...that also had the sweetest tiny tangerines and olives too!  All through our meal..we watched our server slice thick slices of their super rich chocolate torte..as he got down to the last slice we wanted to cry.  That was until he whipped out a new one for the cake stand with a sly smile.  Our eyes were too big..as we were too full to have any! 

Every element was perfection..and sitting at the counter you can get super close to all the pizza action!  Wonderful, knowledgeable people, perfectly crafted succulent pizza, amazing cheese..tangerines..spiced walnuts..everything!  What are you waiting for?  Go!
author: Delicious B.

description: Loved it! Some of the best thin crust pizza I have ever had, and really great toppings. When I went, I had the braised lamb which was delicious. My friend claims the pork belly confit one was even better. The farm egg one was good, but not as good as the others. Will definitely be coming back here.
author: Jason B.

description: Pizzetta is one of my favorite places in SF. I like their Margarita pizza, although it is very small and thin and is not enough food if you want to share it, which makes it a little pricy. Their soups were good too (they rotate them and make everything seasonal). Last time I was there they had a lemon souffle cake - it was one of the best desserts I've ever had, very well done! This lemon dessert deserves 5 stars alone. I think some good pastry chef much be dropping off some of his the desserts there.  I wonder if they really make them in-house. The place is tiny, very cramped, but cozy and the personnel is nice. I definitely recommend it.
author: Elena S.

description:
I know it seems crazy to drive from the Oakland Hills all the way out to the Avenues for lunch, but believe me it's worth it. 

Cozy, warm, welcoming, unassuming - this restaurant is all of that and then some. 

The then some is the pizza. If you love thin crust you will be begging for the recipe - don't worry they published it in Sunset Magazine and I got ya covered. It is absolute perfection - thin, crisp, but not too crisp and so savory it doesn't really need all those delicious toppings although they are a great addition. 

All the food is great - all the way down to the smoothest Blue Bottle Coffee cappuccino. 

R.O.A.D.T.R.I.P!
author: Michelle S.

description:
Awesome ambiance and solid California-style pizza.  We came in at 8:59PM, a minute before they stop seating and were happily given our choice of tables.  Window seat it is!  

We loved the ambiance and the service.  Everyone was incredibly friendly and we were served by what seems like the entire staff instead of just 1 waiter.  The place had a very friendly feel and we were not at all rushed, even though we weaseled our way in right before close.  

We ordered the pizza margherita and the special with asparagus and feta  (I think?).  We also ordered the cheese salad.

The cheese salad was fantastic.  It's less of a salad and more of a cheese plate with mixed greens thrown in.  I think we had a sharp cheddar and a softer sheep's milk cheese.  Both were quite good!  Also, they gave us 2 large wedges of both cheese, so there this little cheese hog didn't have to share!

Our favorite pizza was the special.  The shaved feta perfectly complimented the asparagus.  The margherita was decent as well, but it was far more subtle.  We both agreed that there was a little something missing in both of the pizzas that made them just good rather than excellent (salt?  garlic?), especially the margherita.  The sauce on the margherita wasn't as tangy and flavorful as I like.  

That said, we still enjoyed our experience here and would love to come back!
author: Julie S.

description:
My wife and I are in love with this place, we both think it's some of the best pizza in the city (Sorry Paxti's and Little Star).  Best part is, it's totally walking distance from our place ... always a bonus.

The food is always amazing.   Not a huge menu but it changes all the time and all the offerings are fantastic!   Pizzas are an amazing thin crust with great combinations and super farm-fresh ingredients.   Super huge fan of their deserts like the flour-less chocolate cake of almond tart!

Only problem is that's it's so tiny (only 4-6 tables depending on setup), but this is also part of the appeal of the place.   There's also usually a bit of a wait because it's so small, but grab a beer or a fine glass of wine and shoot the breeze with your fellow Pizzetta fans while you wait!

Funny how I'm writing a review about a place I want so badly to stay a secret!
author: Hunter H.

description:
Ok - I seriously just had the best Choc-Eclair that I've ever had...seriuosly. 

To be clear, the Pie is great, and P-211 is my goto coffee shop for my hit of Blue Bottle drip (please no haters of BB, it really is good stuff) in the morning, but their homemade baked goods are really off the hook. 

So - Andrew really took it to a new level yesterday; he might make more next Tues too, so I'll race yall there.
author: Michael S.

description:
Finally got to pop in here to try it out. At first walking through the doors, I thought "WOW this place IS small" ... small but cute and service was excellent. 

We were seated right away and we were so busy chatting that the waiter stopped by a few times to see if we needed help ordering. After a few wine tastings, we were on our way. 

Ordered: 

-Cheese plate 
- pesto pizza 
-farm egg pizza 
- flourless chocolate cake 
-shortbread cake 

OMFG! Great thin crust pizza. Both are definitely recommended, however I did prefer the pesto a little over the farm egg. Who knew you could put egg on a pizza? The crust was thin and crunchy just the way i liked it. 

Cheese plate was delicious - came with a small green salad, 2 types of cheeses, dried fruit and olives. A great starter btw. 

Finally desserts (in between a few more glasses of wine), choc cake was delicious! Next up shortbread cake with strawberries and raspberries. Now that was definitely the winner in my book! Love this place, will be back. 

Tip: Cash only!
author: Julie F.

description:
Charming, fun, quiet and delicious - it doesn't get much better or neighborhood-ier than this.  

We each ordered a salad -  the mixed greens on the menu (perfectly dressed, not too much) and the special, roasted beets, toast with goat cheese and a bit of arugula.  Absolutely fantastic.

We shared a pepperoni pizzetta (not too adventurous... this time) and it was perfect.  The dough was delicious, the basil was ground with olive oil, but very flavorful, and the pepperoni .... oh the pepperoni... slightly crispy, all yummy.  

Possibly even better than the meal was watching it being made while enjoying our Peronis.  The pizza maker is seriously skilled, and a chick, which is awesome.
author: Corinna K.

description: We absolutely loved this restaurant!  The place is very small and cozy, and the staff is so nice and friendly!  I ordered the butternut squash and bacon pizza, and it was delicious.  Hands down one of the best pizzas i've had in San Francisco.  The pizza is just big enough for one person.  My boyfriend ordered one with egg and ham on it, and it was so delicious!  We are definitely going to come back to try the rest of their biweekly pizzas
author: Alicia Q.

description:
One of the best meals I've had in the City... While heading toward another restaurant on Clement, I drove by and noticed that the restaurant was practically empty - a sight I've never seen in the 5 years I've lived in the Richmond! So a change of plans was called for.

On to the food...my girl and I started with the cheese salad and moved on to a fennel with kumquat pizza and another with potatoe and egg. Yeah, the ingredients sound bizarre but the combos were seriously other-worldy. The thin crust was also perfect. Throw in some solid wine and finish with a 3-ginger cake and you have THE perfect meal for a rainy day or any other day for that matter.
author: Art O.

description:
This is the only place in town to go to for Italian style pizza - thin crispy crust with gourmet toppings. Fantastic combination of flavors for toppings.  My favorite was the bacon, broccoli rabe, and egg.  I love any pizza with egg.  A classic.  Great mouthfeel.  Also good was the artichoke and rictotta insalata.  As well the classic margherita but with mascarpone (I know!  but fantastically creamy and rich) and rocket.

Yes, the place is small.  If you are not prepared to wait or willing to come at odd hours like 3 PM, then I advise you to get it to go.

Yes, the pizza can take a while to come out because the place is small, only 3 people work there, and it's always packed.

However, I think it's totally worth it.  Worth the 30 minute bike ride, the 10 minute wait for a table (at 3 PM), and the 30 minute wait for food.  

Servers were super sweet.  There was a pizza accident and since our pizzas thus came out late, we got drinks and dessert comped.

Pizzas are individually sized and are $10-14 each.  Comparable to what you would pay in Italy for the same thing.  Pizza ain't some cheap food, it's an art form that Pizzetta has perfected.
author: Jean K.

description:
This place is so good that I almost don't want to review it, but I guess the cat is out of the bag.

They specialize in delicious thin crust, Italian style personal size pizzas, with interesting flavor combinations. My favorite is definitely the wild mushroom with some kind of minty oregano type herb on top. The one with the egg on top is interesting, I love the one with pine nuts, and they make a mean Margherita.

I've been there twice with a group of friends and even though the place is small they seem to be able to pack us all into a table. 

I recommend ordering a bottle of wine and getting there early. The wait can be long if you get there later in the evening. 

The place is a little quirky, but in the best tiny European cafe type way. You have to get your own plates (and I have no idea where they keep them) and my friends and I sat at the bar and then got kicked out into the street for a while, but we had our wine in tow so it was no stress, and we just drank away happily on the sidewalk.
author: Julia H.

description:
I'd been meaning to eat here for a year and a half and I finally tried it for my birthday dinner this year. I'm not into waiting so we arrived at 5:30 on a Monday and got the last available table. 
A salad, a pizza and a desert, split between 2 people is a perfect amount of food. 
We had 
organic greens and cheese salad
mushroom and green garlic and some cheese I'd never heard of pizza 
flourless chocolate cake.
Hot damn. Everything was amazing. Just schlep over to the Richmond as early as you can and eat here!
author: Lauren T.

description:
As everyone says, they have very good pizza. Maybe I didn't read enough reviews, but I had no idea how small the place is. It shouldn't hurt the review, but it should be mentioned. I'm talking tiny. So are the pizzas. I guess you "smaller people" could share one, but since its very thin crust, I'd recommend one per person. 
We had to squeeze 5 people around a tiny table, but we did it and had a good time. I'd prefer a bigger setting for 5 people to be honest, but I'm happy I tried the place and the pizzas are good and so was the service. One more thing, don't sit near the door when its cold outside. Come to think of it, its hard NOT to sit by the door. Did I mention the place is tiny?
author: Rich M.

description:
BEST PIZZA IN TOWN
DON'T SKIP DESSERT

If I was unscrupulous, I'd give a 1-star review only to keep this best secret to myself...but I'm not, so I won't, and I'll enjoy sharing a beer on the sidewalk waiting for my chair/table for the best neighborhood pizza experience in town.

Go here knowing there are verrrry few tables, slow down a bit, and enjoy.
author: Jess W.

description:
Pizzetta 211 is the Outer Richmond's response to cute, cozy, and romantic pizzerias in SF. A straight 4 stars, but I bet it'll convince me to give it 4.5 the next time I visit because it's so damn charming.

Ambiance: 
-Please, someone take me on a date here! 
-When I say cozy, believe me, there's so little room in this tiny restaurant that you'll be quite intimate with whoever you're eating with.
-Big windows, warm light, cushions, and wooden chairs. It's like you're eating in someone's kitchen - in the countryside. On the other hand, there's also something about Pizzetta that makes me think it could also belong in Brooklyn. I love it all.
-Lastly, my favorite are the trees outside with Christmas lights. Truly magical :)

Food:
-Frankly, not the best pizza I've had in SF, but still very good oven baked thin-crust.
-I highly enjoyed the housemade sausage, with roma tomatoes. It had the perfect amount of spice and was super satisfying.
-The Farm Egg pizza was nice to try, but a bit too sour for me. Still, it offers a very interesting texture and is worth ordering.
-They serve wine in the same glasses as water - i.e., not wine glasses. There's something about this that makes me feel like I've paid too much for my alcohol. Oh well.

Service:
-Ok, the service here is excellent! The wait staff is cheery and super helpful :) 
-My friend poured water into my wine glass by mistake (again, a reference to the lack of differentiation between wine and water glasses here), and my wine glass was replaced and refilled immediately free of charge.
-To top it off, we received a slice of their special Pluot cake on the house - the crust was fabulous!

Tips:
-CASH ONLY!! 
-Cozy + popular = a long wait. Come on an off night. Monday is perfect.
-Start off the meal with the cheeseboard.

Warm, balmy nights in SF are few and far between. Visit Pizzetta 211 before the fog rolls back in.
author: Gina L.

description: Fantastic. Love the rustic decor. Love the kind staff. Love the tasty hand tossed thin crust pizza. Margherita all the way, that mozzarella melted in my mouth and washed down nicely with the Copain syrah. Yum.
author: Cec D.

description: Went in with three friends after the USWNT world cup final with three friends. It's a small place with limited seating so we did have to wait for 10min or so for a table. We decided to order one pizza each to share, which was the perfect amount. Went with the Quattro Formaggi, farm egg, lamb sausage, and mascarpone. Lamb sausage was my personal favorite!
author: Carlos A.

description: Pizzetta 211 is hands down the best Pizza in town. Its small so be prepared to wait or go in off peak hours. Menu changes regularly with imaginative combinations you are not likely to see elsewhere. Prices are reasonable and cheaper than other similar restaurants. Its not your pizza hut so be prepared to pay for quality.
author: L W.

description: Pizza Nazis!  Excellent pies whatever they are making that day but when you live close by and want one to go...they tell you to go away!  As they need to SAVE their gifts for staying customers.  This is beyond annoying and frankly strange so not going back...I understand you need yo take care of sitting customers first but the 'rude tude' is just toooooo much for a pizza place.
author: Gregory C.

description:
The pizzas were delicious. My boyfriend and I stuck with the permanent selection (they change some of their pizzas every week due to the seasonal ingredients they can get from locals) and we were not disappointed. The rosemary, cheese, & pine-nut pizza was absolutely delicious. We loved the simplicity of that pizza as well as the simplicity of the tomato, basil and mozzarella. 

Lauren, our server, was knowledgeable about the pizza and the wine. She was sweet, checked up on us just enough and overall gave very great service! We sat outside (the heaters are amazing) and it really wasn't bad. I enjoyed the atmosphere and the neighborhood feel, as well as the intimacy that Pizzetta 211 provided.

I can see this place being great for a first date or for even just a quick bite to eat. They seemed to do tons of to-go orders as well. I will definitely be coming back, especially since I am only two blocks away.
author: Briana C.

description:
Visiting this blink-and-you'll-miss-it restaurant during odd hours is key to being able to obtain a seat and be provided with timely service (it's tiny and leanly staffed).

I've ordered the appetizer special during two visits and each time, it has been phenomenal--with a flavor profile that is spot on.

As for the pizzas, I've had the farm egg and savoy spinach varieties.  The former was a bit bland and so required the addition of pepper flakes.  The latter, however, was flavorful with a refreshing zing that was imparted by the lemon zest.

3.5 stars.
author: Momo R.

description:
It doesn't have an avg of 4 stars for nothin! Seriously, get any pizza and it'll be  amazing. All fresh ingredients, amazingly thin but not too thin crust, menu that changes so you can try everything! 
Recommendations: 
-get there right when it opens or count on waiting for a table for a while
-one pizza per person unless you're a hungry boy or girl, then get two per person :)
author: S K.

description:
A friend brought me here because she loves their pizza. She wanted my take on it so we headed out on a weekend night, around the peak dinner hour which was perfect, since we snagged the last table!

The three of us were starving so we ordered 3 pies

- Rosie's farm egg, sliced heirloom tomatoes, pancetta & ricotta salata ($13.75): I liked the raw egg on top (yummie when you mix it in with the pie), but thought it was salty with the pancetta
- Savory spinach, red onion, nicoise olives & feta ($13.75): my fav outta the 3...the taste of each ingredient complemented the other and was not too overpowering.
- Roasted eggplant, arugula-walnut pesto & ricotta ($13.75): bland

Service was friendly and attentive. You can tell that this is a great place when the employees know people who walk by the restaurant and ask how long the wait is. By the time we left, there were three parties waiting for a table and that's not counting several other parties who wanted Pizzetta 211, but didn't want to wait. Oh...they should have waited!!
author: Janel Y.

description: I've eaten here 3 times and each meal is less satisfying as the one before it.  Perhaps that first experience just set the bar too high.  Speaking of bars, my first time here I sat at the bar with my friend.  We were able to talk with the cooks and see all the preparation which made the for some free entertainment.  I'd go with the cheese salad.  Having ordered the pizza with the over easy egg twice now, I'll definitely move on to other selections.  The dough is excellent.  For my money , I think the sauce is what makes a killer pizza.  It's there that the pizzas here seem to be lacking.  The fresh ingredients are great but the sauce is wear my taste buds soak up the most enjoyment.  The place is small so you have to come at the right time or risk waiting outside for a good while.  For the neighborhood, you're probably not going to find a better pizza.
author: John M.

description: Best pizza ever. Better than Delfina. Better than Gjelina in Venice. Better than Pizzeria Mozza in LA. I love it because the staff is always so friendly and nice!
author: Ms. S.

description: LOVE this place. My husband and I visited on a weeknight when they were not too busy and we were able to nestle into a corner and have an intimate evening. The menu changes, but order whatever pizza they have that has farm fresh eggs- DELISH!
author: Laura R.

description:
Very very very small cozy lil neighborhood joint. If you have a large large group, you will not all fit. Trust me. There's maybe about... 4 tables? 
This litte spot is awesome though. They have BLUE BOTTLE COFFEE! The staff is warm, welcoming and extremely nice. They aren't pushy at all either. I really appreciate that. 
They do thin crust pizza with fresh ingredients (organic too!) which is just about my favorite. I don't even LIKE pizza, as a matter of fact I hate pizza. But when I have to eat it, this is the type of pizza I prefer. I've actually been CRAVING pizza and Pizzetta 211 has turned me into a pizza lover.
Last night I had 2 pizzas: housemade lamb sausage, garlic confit & ricottta cheese and the other pizza was some sort of curried cauliflower.
The lamb sausage pizza had so much flavor. The ricotta cheese cut right through the gamey taste of lamb but complimented it very very well on my palette. 
Be aware that their menu changes every week! I'm going to have to make many trips back here to try all the various pizzas they offer.
author: Susy C.

description:
H'ok. So. Someone needs to set the record straight.

I am a Pizzetta regular (yeah? can I claim that? I think so). Pizzetta is small. Like, super small. As in- there is a closet behind the ovens where they wash the dishes, and other than that what you see when you walk in is what you get. So there is no massive conspiracy being perpetuated by a gang of rowdy hipsters plotting to bum you out.

Pizzetta is in a residential neighborhood, with zoning. Zoning that says that if you are on an numbered avenue, you must close at 9. Rumblefish, around the corner, closes at 10 because it is on California. If Pizzetta tried to keep its doors open on busy nights, it would be a shitty neighbor and then the people who live on that block would be the ones writing bitchy reviews. Places have hours of operation. Get over it.

This place has the best pizza because one of like two people makes their dough in small batches every day. Like a microbrew. If you want an endless supply of food, go to Pizza Hut. I don't know, it's not a sweat shop, it's a tasty restaurant. Sometimes they run out. Move on.

OK, sometimes they say they're out of dough but they can do a to-go. What does that mean, you ask? Every night, they save a couple rounds of dough so the staff can eat dinner before they go home. Pizza is all they serve- if they sell every last crumb of dough there's nothing to eat at the end of the night. Sometimes, a staffer isn't that hungry, and she'll give you her dough. So if there's a little confusion at the end of the night about the dough situation, that's why.

A couple of the waiters can be a little formal for such a small joint. There's one dude in particular who is so polite it's a little weird. I think his manner makes people think he is pretentious, or ironic, or some other current SF buzz word.. He's just being nice, dude, fer real. Be polite back- you could probably use the practice.

I like being able to help myself to my own water and napkin. It makes me feel like a guest asked sincerely to make herself at home.

The only thing I sometimes don't like about Pizzetta is the bad parenting I'm forced to observe on occasion. Seriously, people- pay attention to your kids. Talk to them, converse with them while you share dinner- don't just ignore them and spend the meal whining at your spouse.

And now, as I finish writing this, I realize I should be happy that annoying bitchy people don't like eating here. More tasty food for me. Just don't go bad-mouthing my pizza-fairies, OK? This staff makes my life more mouth-watering.
author: Caitlin E.

description:
I love this place! What initially drew me to it were the aesthetics of the restaurant. The ambiance is awesome! The place is very small and cozy and has a very cool neighborhood feel. 

The menu. I have been here about 3 or 4 times and I have only gotten one thing, but I can tell you that it was awesome. Simple yet delicious, which is what I am generally looking for as my girlfriend can attest. I get the Mozarella, Basil, Tomato with Pepperoni. They combination of good spices and fresh ingredients makes the pizza here amazing. 

Definitely recommend it for anyone going on a first date as its got a very unique feel.
author: Bernard D.

description:
Note: Takeout only

This place rocks! 

My sis wanted to get lunch and since the baby was sick and fuzzy, we figured that eating at a restaurant wouldn't be ideal. We left her house and she said that she saw a pizza place around the corner and that she wanted to try it out... OMG...was I thankful she found this place!

We got there and it seemed packed (considering it's a very tiny place...intimate would be the ideal word.)

The bf got the menu and we ordered for takeout. I had the pancetta with goat cheese, sis and the bf had that marinara with pepperoni as well as the calzone. 

We waited outside for our food (gorgeous day, just hella windy!)

Got the food and went home to discover the good stuff!

First bite...we were all "WOW!" Everyone seemed to declare...this is really good pizza...it's our new favorite place...and so forth. It was funny but of course, all true. My pizza had two eggs in it and that was a surprised. The taste was just right, crispy everywhere.

Will definitely be going back here for more... Really rocks!

PS: my sis also likes this place even more b/c they serve Blue Bottle!
author: Cath M.

description:
At Pizzetta 211, the pizzettas are delicious, all are served on satisfyingly crisp thin crusts, with your choice of traditional toppings, such as the staple Margherita, or unique seasonal combinations.  Our group of four decided to share four different pizzettas, especially since the waiter informed us that with a weekly menu, it may be awhile before we get to try certain items again.  Nearly all of the ingredients are made with organic and local produce.

1.The Margherita pizza, however, is a permanent dish on the menu.  The tomato sauce and basil were flavorful and tangy, though I prefer much more mozzarella cheese. 

2. Outside of Paris, Pizzetta 211 is the only place that I know of that serves an egg topping; this is the place to try it out!  The farm egg pizza was light and zesty; I loved the flavor of the mint and roasted tendril.  One of my favorites.

3. The arugula-hazelnut pesto pizzetta was packed with flavor and crunch, along with the salty and savory sausage.  These ingredients would also make an amazing pasta dish.

4. My first time trying Bresaola, air dried beef, on a pizza.  The meat paired with the horseradish-creme fraiche, French style sour cream, gave the dish an interesting gourmet feel.  The flavors were unique, though not my top choice for a pizza topping.

Arrive 15 minutes before noon to score a table on a Saturday at this cozy neighborhood pizza place.  Pizzetta 211, named appropriately because it is located on 211 23rd Avenue, is proof that big taste can come in tiny packages.  The restaurant has only four tables and a seated counter area, so we got close and comfortable with fellow patrons.  Pizzetta 211, recently started serving Bluebottle Coffee, one of my favorite brands based in the Bay Area.  One Bluebottle latte with a lump of brown sugar after a satisfying meal and I'm a happy gal.
author: Pauline L.

description: Loved this place. Everything was fresh and VERY good. I'll come back next trip to the city.
author: David H.

description:
There is TLC in the pizza served at Pizzetta 211.  The setting has a rustic overtone and the attitude is half French, half barista.  It's cozy.  Don't come in a hurry, but the food is something you should savor anyway.  You'll find yourself wanting to order "one of each" of the pizzas they've put on the menu for the day.  High quality, farm fresh ingredients cooked on thin crust and wood fired.

If they are serving beet salad, whether or not you are a fan of beets, you must order that while you wait for your pizza.
author: Mark F.

description:
I came here yesterday for dinner and was so pleasantly surprised.  The food was tasty and the service was fast and friendly.

We sampled 3 of the pizzas offered and they were all divine.  The ingredients were really fresh and the crust was savory and crisp.

I also had a Blue Bottle Coffee latte to end my meal...also lovely.

I will definitely come back.

I recommend you either come at an off peak time or willing to wait because the place is pretty small.

oh yeah, bring cash.  You can't use a card here.
author: Lu E.

description:
Pizzetta is terrible, please don't bother going all the way out to the Richmond for it.
Ok, that's a lie.  It's the best pizza in the city.  It's just tiny, and it's a few blocks from our apartment, and I'm sorry, I don't want to share.
author: Lulu L.

description: After 90 minute wait and only two check ins from the waitress, I can officially say it isn't worth the aggregation. This place is small, the food is good, but there are many places in the city with better pizza, for less, that don't include the hassle. I can't say I'll be back.
author: Bob R.

description: This is a small hole in the wall restaurant.  It has good artisan pizza.  If you are looking for traditional pizza or spacious seating, then I would look elsewhere.
author: Jeff N.

description:
I went at lunch as I know it's a small restaurant that can get crowded fast.  Only 4 tables inside and 2 outside.  

It was a tiny bit tough to park as it's near Clement St.  But I thought the pizza was excellent thin crust, Napolitano style.  Great ingredients and care.  Simple, ok glass of red wine.  Just the perfect kind of neighborhood place.  Lucky neighborhood people!  The inside space is filled with light (similar in look to Zuni)--pure, simple, flour dust caught in rays of light... a temple to food.

I talked to the elderly locals next to me, and they wanted to close the door as it was a bit cold.  The cute teachers from the school across the street looked cold too as they were wrapped tightly in their coats.  The senior couple anguished for a bit if they should ask the fellow working the kitchen if they could?  They said he could have an "attitude" sometimes.  So cute.  The guy with the attitude, although not Mr. Chapeau level friendly, is probably just a purist who is fairly straight forward.  

I had the pizza with egg, pancetta (not much, but remained balanced), and greens (rapini?).  Pretty darn good.  Crust was properly seasoned and not over-proteined (meaning, it was delicate and perfectly textured).  Presentation was simple and excellent.  Did not have dessert (which was beautiful fruit torte) or blue bottle coffee (people should use ritual roasters too!).  But had I wanted to complete my meal, I think that would have been a very satisfying ending.  

I prefer this to Paulines, which is a slightly different style and less delicate crust.  Overall, it's more similar to Pizzeria Delfina.  A bit more rustic and neighborhoody, and less glossy/chrome than Delfina.  I thought it was a tiny bit better value (than Delfina) and hope to go back again if I happen to be out there.  Also, in case you're wondering, I think Gialina's is okay, but their combinations can be sort of untasty.  Pizetta is the best in SF in my opinion, of this thin crust style.  I respected that there was a lot of care not only in the ingredients, but in expert preparation.
author: Philip L.

description: I just love this place. Local, in my neighborhood, small. Plus, the dogs can hang
author: Rob D.

description:
Favorite restaurant in San Francisco, hands down. I didn't want to tell you, but it looks like the cat's out of the bag already. 
What more is there to say? Incredible food, staff, atmosphere. 
However, be warned that this place is best for small parties - it's a tight squeeze!
author: Sarah H.

description: My all time favorite pizza place. The food is fabulous the people are wonderful and the setting is great. I have yet to not have a delicious meal at this tiny local spot. One of a kind!
author: Allison F.

description: Honestly, I don't get how this place gets so many good reviews. I can only assume that the clientele is used to dumpy places. I was referred here by a friend and I now wonder if she is really my friend at all!! What a dump this was!! We chose to sit outside as my bedroom closet is larger than the interior of this place. We sat outside at a crumbling bistro table with very uncomfortable chairs. I wanted to leave. Really, just hightail it outta there before anything negative happened. However my friend wanted to try it. Fine whatever! We were brought a carafe of water and 2 glasses, one of them dirty. I asked for ice and was told they didn't have ice. No ice??? Shoulda known what was coming!! No ice, no Wifi, and they don't take credit cards and this is in San Francisco??? I thought I was in Hooterville!!! The menu was limited but we each tried a pizza and it was  expensive and not very good. No coke or diet coke either! I had the pine nut pizza and my friend had the Marguerita style. I would give them each a D-. Really! What keeps this place in business?? Driving by, I thought it was a laundromat! It's a NEVER for anyone with taste who would rather eat lunch at place that's not a dump. Rude service too which was the icing on the cake. I peeled wheels leaving this hole in my rearview mirror FOR GOOD!!!
author: Sandra P.

description:
Quick Tip: Egg on pizza. Yum.

I'm always looking for a pizza place that makes pizza without tomatoes. I'm allergic to tomatoes, so you can see why this is a big thing for me, and this place makes really good pizza. 

It's a hole in the wall. My boyfriend use to live a few blocks away from this place, but never really ate there until a few years later. The place is in a residential neighborhood, and parking can be a b*tch to find, so patience is definitely required in that department. Oh yah, and patience is also required in the waiting-for-your-order department as well.

This is a small place, so it can be a little difficult to find, especially if you aren't familiar with the Richmond district. There are a couple of tables outside, and you think..."oh, this is cute. There's an outdoor area." And for good reason...the maximum number of people that fit in the place itself is about...15? Maybe less. it's a small space, but in my opinion (as well as our friends), it's worth it.

We usually get the cheeseboard which is pretty damn awesome, especially if you decide to eat it with wine. The menu tends to change on the types of cheeses, but from the times I've been there...it's always been really good. 

The menu isn't as fluffy with other types of pizzas. it's straight to the point, and I make sure to get the pizza with egg. When I first tried pizza with an egg, it was because all the other pizzas had tomatoes and this one didn't. It was delicious. So delicious that I hope they never take it off their menu!

The wait for the pizza can be a little long, especially if you're going there on a super empty stomach. It's because they make it fresh. You can see their oven in the store, and the little bar area they have. It's a cute place and I go there whenever I get a craving for a thin crust pizza with egg.

it's worth the try. As the saying goes, "don't knock it 'til you try it."
author: J D.

description:
We dropped by Pizzetta 211 at 8:30 PM on a Saturday night. Okay, it was late, they close at 9:00, maybe they're out of pizza dough. I can understand that, but the hostess said, verbatim, "We are not seating any customers as we are running out of pizza dough, but we can take a to go order."

Either she's a liar or borderline retarded. In either case, not good. The first, and only other time we dropped by it was earlier in the evening and we stood at the door for 3-4 minutes, the hostess practically pushed us out of the way to get outside but never even managed so much as a 'Hi, I'll be with you in a moment.'

As everyone knows the place is tiny but one or two people should be able to handle some basic customer service. I've never been treated with so much contempt at a place I've not even been able to eat at. Compared to this I got treated like a king everywhere I've ever been in Los Angeles.

I won't be giving this place a third chance. I honestly don't know why it's so difficult to provide some basic service in this town. It's endemic.
author: Matt J.

description:
Great little restaurant with interesting pizzas on the menu. I don't think this place has my favorite pizzas but for sure the most original ones: they are different and delightful. 
They take no reservations and they don't sit incomplete parties. Bring your jacket! You might need it while you wait.
author: Ricardo L.

description:
Seriously, I don't know why I have yet to write a review for this place.  I found it on yelp about 3 years ago and have been a regular visitor ever since.  It's a bit out of the way, but well worth the trek.  Every time we come, we've been happy.

Yes there is usually a wait, but it goes by pretty fast.  There are pretty lights, a few heat lamps, blankets and a bench.  They'll also serve you coffee outside while you wait if you'd like.

Pizza menu changes weekly.  Top 3 pizzas are the specials for the week.  The others are standard ones.  Fresh, local ingredients, crispy thin crust, and not super heavy.  They have introduced me to the egg on the pizza (I used to only have that for breakfast pizzas), random mushrooms, chimichurri sauce....

Blue bottle coffee - love the latte!

Save room for dessert because TASTY is an understatement.  Flipping fantastic.  i.e. last night we had a nectarine, pluot, blackberry, strawberry tart with fresh whip cream!  If I could have eaten the cheesecake in a cup too, I would have.

If you get a chance, sit at the bar and watch the magic happen.  Haven't seen a team of restaurant folks work so seamlessly in a tiny kitchen in a long time.  The service is laid back, friendly, and good times!
author: Denice L.

description: Probably one of the most romantic pizza places you will ever stumble upon. It's the atmosphere above all that startled me: it's as if you were invited into a chef's home for a dimly lit, artistically crafted pizza dinner. Can't complain about the price, though definitely expect more than your standard "Round Table." Be willing to explore the possibility of cozying up close to another couple, because the atmosphere certainly requires it. Though it may feel uncomfortable at first, by the time you see your pizza being made and tossed in the oven, you'll find unique comfort in the communal yet privately intimate environment. Definitely planning to return.
author: Austin V.

description: Adorable little place. The pizza is the best I have had since moving to the avenues.  The cheese board was insanely delicious and their wine selection was on point.
author: Angie P.

description:
Yep.  I'm doin' it: I'm reviewing a restaurant that Gwyneth Paltro blogged about.  And apparently I'm admitting to reading Gwyneth's blog.  For the record, I heard about this place from a yoga-friend who knows her pizza... not from GP.  
Ok, back to my point: this place is amazing.  Their menu changes weekly, but whatever it is, it's mouthwatering, creative, and local!  The crust is that perfect, wood-fired, crisp on the outside, slightly dough-y on the inside... and the combinations are ones you'd never put together yourself, but they'll nock your socks off.  The place is TEEEEEEEENIE: 4 tables total, I think inside, but it's cute, hidden, and just amazing.  

Try it.  You won't be sorry... and who knows, maybe you'll see Mrs. Coldplay, herself!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I have been coming here maybe three times a month  since the original owner had it.  That's  quite a while--seven years?  On the one hand, I LOVE Pizzetta for many things.The food is awesome, done with hands down mastery.
The music they play is totally eclectic tasteful and ultra cool
all over the map good stuff.  I like the care and  simplicity and lack of decadence and waste. Cash only is smart, keeps down the overhead, etc.

Now...on the other hand....the place is crawling with spoiled
obnoxious affluent yuppies and soccer mom types.
 Because they always find out what's good and
descend like a plague of clueless locusts. It's annoying
to me, but probably not to most yelp people, because, uh, well, that 
pretty much describes most yelp people. 

The staff is quirky and temperamental, like people in general.
They have their good days and bad days, so what?  They are a
bit aloof-hipster-like, but not off the scale. Personally I think they are
quietish because the space is small and it's prudent to keep it chill.

The food's been slipping a bit recently, and I speak as one who knows.

Just sayin'.
author: harmonia b.

description:
what a wonderful place. (4.5 stars)

so glad my friend suggested this place for the dinner tonight as it had been on my list for a very long time.

it's a very tiny, cash-only pizza place. it has about 6 tables and 4 bar chairs. i can see how busy and crowded this place could get, but luckily, we got a table as we walked in.

the atmosphere, service, and food were fantastic.

can't go wrong with any of the dishes on the menu.. it has everything you're looking for in a cozy little great place!

(san marzano pizza was superb)
author: Sung C.

description:
Very small but cozy and warm. The food was delicious. The deserts looked awesome too bad we didnt have any room left for them. Very friendly atmosphere and great service.

3 pizzetas, 1 calzone, 1 appetizer and 3 drinks = $70 +
Very Pricey
author: A. T.

description:
Oh my goodness. I can't help but rave about Pizzetta 211. I also can't take credit for finding them. They came highly recommended by a couple of friends and their close proximity to baker beach (my home away from home when the sun is shining on sf) makes them a natural choice for tasty, local grub.

The pizzas were magnificent. The blue ribbon of the evening definitely went to the roasted zucchini squash and chived ricotta pizza. The tomato, mozzarella and pepperoni was delicious but didn't compare to our squash dream. The crust was light, crispy but soft on the inside. I was impressed with the simplicity and beauty of the pizzas. We finished off the meal with their cherry tart and whipped cream. So good.

The space is proper: small but appropriate for a seasonal, rotating menu featuring locally grown ingredients. You can watch them work the dough from your table or mosey up to the bar.
