We didn't wait that long (party of 2) on a Sunday evening around 6pm. Ride your bike because parking is rough and if you've got an outter layer, jump on one of the outside tables. They have heat lamps. 

Cash only at Pizzetta 211 but it's worth it.
author: Corey F.

description:
Unbelievably delicious pizza (Margherita), salad of buffalo mozzarella, beets, beet greens, hazelnut dressing was just fucking fabulous, coffee delicious.  I got there at 12:30 on a Saturday and was easily seated. It filled up quickly, though.

Service was extraordinary. I'll keep going back and back and back.
author: Pat P.

description:
If you are going to Pizzetta and want to have a good Pizza that is your place. But, do not expect same quality for the service you'll rececive.

After waiting over 40 minutes we get to our table and we get a big attitude from the waiter for no particular reason. I guess that is what you need to expect when you are a regular.

Pizzetta with an attitude is back!
author: Michele M.

description:
This is the closest i came to really feeling like I was in Italy since I was in Italy. The food is inexpensive, ingredients fresh and organic, recipes simple and tasty and service is personal. I get fed up with dealing with 4-5 different people in one sitting.

Highly reccomended.
author: Chris H.

description:
I don't recommend that you go to Pizzetta 211 to eat in at prime lunch hours. It is *tiny*. Thankfully we didn't have a problem getting a table, but I can't imagine eating outside on a blustery day.

The pizza has a super thin crust with loads of street cred. There's always a margherita and then some specialty pizzas all with yuppie ingredients. They also make their own fancy salads. Sometimes fancy yuppie is good.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
So I'm sure this is a local hangout being its location hidden away in the Richmond. But thanx to yelpers and some deep searching we had a really amazing lunch today. My husband and I had a "date" to see the Chihuly @ the DeYoung Museum (which I think the last time I was there was like when I was in 4th grade? shit eons ago) Anyhoo after visiting the museum and being inspired by all the amazing glass work we wanted something good for lunch. I had already scoped out this place on yelp yesterday and read all the reviews and it sounded quaint and the food sounded fresh and unique.
I liked the feel of the neighborhood, and the size of the restaurant being very intimate and cozy (though I could see it being crazy at dinner time). We arrived around 1:30 on a Thursday and it was pretty full, but were able to get a seat inside for two. They also have a few tables for outside seating, and on a nice day like yesterday was perfect(but they were taken).
We ordered two of the pizzas of the day a summer squash with tomatoes and ricotta cheese and another with pine nuts, rosemary and a very pungent cheese  I can't remember the name but had quite a "kick" with every bite. The crust was thin and crunchy and the cheese perfect and chewy!
Each pie is made to order and fresh, fresh, fresh!
Like someone said its cash only (we were prepared) and with a couple of beers and a fabulous piece of flour less chocolate cake (I don't know how they make it so light and fluffy?) it was $42. Worth every penny! 
We brought one piece of pizza home with us.
The the salads of the day also looked wonderful too.
Parking is challenging but we found some metered parking out on Clement with an easy walk. I know we aren't "locals" but it made our day out in SF. I love the flavor of the city and I prefer finding those out of way "gems" to have a really great meal.
I added my two pizza's to the pics.
author: Susan D.

description:
I found out about this place when I was listening to a junior person at my company talk about the places to eat in SF during a new hire orientation. Apparently there is still something to be said for listening to those below you because I was able to find a gem of a pizza place from him.

Nestled far away in the Richmond is this tiny random pizza place, unfortunately by now, popular with many so you'll have to compete for parking and a place to sit. But don't worry, this place is worth the wait. If you're forced to wait on a chilly night (no indoor space to wait, sorry), you can ask for blankets, or huddle by the heat lamp at some of the unoccupied outdoor tables. If you really can't wait, you can always get a pizza to go (phone in your order) but where's the fun in that?

Obviously the cream of the crop here is their thin crust pizzas. The menu rotates every couple weeks or so, but there is always one pizza that features farm eggs on it, an interesting, but tasty addition to a pizza (why have we not gotten on this in other pizza chains!) While your specific pizza will depend on the menu when you go, let me tell you that every pizza I've had here has been fantastic. They're cooked with the freshest ingredients and don't leave you with that sense of regret that you ate far too much.

They also have a relatively large calzone if you're feeling really hungry, but I honestly think you should just save space for the pizzas.

A minor hit for a random visit I had where the pizza took inexplicably long to come out (the place wasn't super busy) but for the most part, I'll make the drive out here anytime.
author: Roland C.

description:
The best farm egg pizza I've eaten! 
Thin crust and not soggy.
Mixed green salad was okay, but tastes even better when you top it on your pizza!
Excellent service.  They even packed us a dessert on the house cuz we were too full to eat it there :)
author: Melissa F.

description: Yeah, this place is great... the eggplant starter that we shared tonight was delicious and the pizzas were unique and full of flavor
author: Erik A.

description: Small, service is slow.  But the food is incredible.  Worth the wait.  Carve 2-2.5 hours for dinner or lunch during busy times.  Everything is amazingly fresh.  LOVE this place!
author: Aki L.

description: PIZZA MONSTER APPROVED Get there fast and order the housemade sausage pizza before it's gone, every bite is amazing.
author: Chris D.

description:
I'm serious about my Italian, and it's funny to me what passes for Italian in San Francisco and beyond. It's not authentic, it's some silly mix of American Italian crap, but that's fine. Just be honest about it, don't tell me it's going to be authentic if it isn't.

Trust me, I know authentic Italian. I may be born and raised in SF, and proud to represent, but I lived in Italy, and have traveled all over the country, being lucky enough to explore the culinary delights of the region.

But where do you go when you don't want to wait in line for two hours at Delfina, and you don't want (gasp!) Domino's Pizza. Of course we don't want Domino's, it's not even food. Yuck, at the least.

Well we've been lucky enough to live down the street from Pizzetta 211, a tiny little homestyle neighborhood joint that just rocks. Set with heaters outside (cause you know it's cold in the city even in the summer) with cute little cozy blankets is the heater isn't good enough. Animal friendly if you sit outside (we had four dogs with us last time we ate there), it's a true locals joint for the Richmond Hood.

Serving up tasty pizzas, salads, and calzone, with a great but small wine list, I was happy. Dripping with gooey quality tasty cheese, my calzone was done right, with perfect crust. Sometimes you just want to eat the insides of calzones, or leave the crust of your half done pizza, but not here. We licked our plates. 

Their special pizzas are rotated every two weeks ( I think he told me Wednesday but I may be wrong) and everytime we go, there is something new and intriguing on the menu, but still classic and hits the spot. 

The staff was quick and attentive but unobtrusive, and they were knowledgeable, telling me where certain cheese they used came from and the greens. I love food education. I'm all about knowing where my food came from, it's important these days more than ever.

Plus we're pretty broke, like most of you out there (even though we don't want to always admit) so this place gets you great food, in a wonderful comfortable atmosphere and won't break the bank.

That way you can sneak those few extra bucks in later, and get yourself some new kicks for New Years.
author: Danielle S.

description:
Great neighborhood gem for farm-fresh California style pizza.  Side salads just as delicious. 

rosemary with egg lamb sausage mint pizza
Try the butternut squash sage pizza
author: around town e.

description:
Okay, went back with my sister and actually ate in the restaurant this time.

Service was super friendly and the pizza, as always, was good. My sis and I had to wait for about 15 minutes or so for a table to free up, but we didn't mind. 

They took our orders, brought us our appetizer, brought us our pizzas, and gave us dessert (it was closing time and we were the last ones there).

Pizzas: Margherita and the Farm Egg pizza. Both good.

Appetizer: Eggplant with pine nuts and something else (cous cous, I think?) Very good if you like eggplant. 

Service: Super friendly without being fake. 

Love this place.
author: Evelyn C.

description: YUUUUMMMMY! A must visit every time I visit San Francisco! The ingredients are so fresh and delicious. Excellent sausages and desserts as well! I leave felling full but not disgusting like most pizzas make me feel.  Some of the pizzas ordered I didn't expect to enjoy but ended up being my favorites.  A refreshing and unique pizza experience!
author: Zack S.

description: Great gourmet pizza, appetizers and wine with an intimate neighborhood atmosphere.
author: Drew S.

description: Delicious, fresh food and great ambiance. This is a very small restaurant with a small(ish) menu so we were impressed by the chef's positive attitude when someone asked for a pizza with no red sauce and no cheese. The cheese plate was incredible, definitely will go back just for that!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
This place totally caught me off guard.  I guess my expectations for places in the outer Richmond are quite low, especially for things like pizza. 

 This pizzeria is one of the quaint, charming, and serves up some of the most inspired pizza in the city.  All the buzz you here is about places like Berrata, Deflina, Gialina, etc.  This places serves similar style pizzas (i.e.  they are thin crust pizzas of the highest quality), with modern california ingredients (not not CPK, but organic farm eggs, pancetta, guanciale, nettles, raddichio, house made lamb sausage, and other such 'unusual' ingredients), but it is actually BETTER than all three of these places!  Why this place gets so little press is beyond me.  I almost think this place tops Pizzeria Mozza in LA, but alas, no pizza can top that.  

I haven't been to Zero Zero, or the other new kids on the block, but this place is a true gem and a destination pizzeria.
author: Jeremy R.

description: I love this place. We go back time and time again. The food is always fresh, the pizza crust is crisp and blistered and the specials are always a treat. The desserts are fantastic too! I have been searching for a pizza in the Monterey Bay area as good as Pizzetta 211's but to no avail...
author: Lori D.

description: Recommended by a friend to go here and I must say it lived up to all the hype.  Some of the best gourmet pizza I have ever had.  Small place, but actually had no wait when i got there.  Sat at the bar and ordered the daily specials.  Oxtail and farm egg pizza and the piadine with bacon, cabbage, olive oil, vinaigrette, and nice slices of reggiano cheese.
author: Jeff F.

description:
I am a big fan of anchovies on pizza. Please don't judge me. 

Pizzetta does a wonderful job of combining simple fresh ingredients  (and anchovies!) on top of a thin crunchy crust. With prices around $10 - 15 per pizza, its hard not to like this place. 

I tried the one with the farm egg on top and didnt like it too much.I found the runny yolk a bit too overpowering. Overall, this is a great date place and I'll be coming back for more.
author: Stacy L.

description:
I was leafing through an old issue of SF Magazine and read a review and wondered why in the world I had never heard of this place.  Thankfully I have experienced Pizzetta 211 aka pizza heaven.  Incredible thin crust pizza with fresh, seasonal ingredients.  The ultimate comfort food.  I've had a lot and this is the best.  Cheese salad is excellent.  Desserts are great.  Interesting selection of reds - some French.  Server was helpful on the wines...

For all good things be prepared to wait. The place is small - they even offer blankets to make your wait more endurable.  Cozy close tables by flickering candlelight with a bustling open kitchen as a backdrop.  Cash only, so come with a full wallet and be prepared to leave with a happy stomach.
author: Gail D.

description: Very cute little thin crust pizza shop! We had to wait about 45 minutes during an off time because the restaurant only seats about 10 people, but it was worth it! The staff was so nice, offering drinks while we waiting and then getting our food out quickly once we were seated. We got a Margarita pizza ($11 I think) and two beers. Very nice cheap and light lunch. I would highly recommend!
author: Emily S.

description: This place is so awesome. Tiny, a little off the grid, and super delicious. The menu is really small, but I still had trouble deciding what to order. My friend ordered the arugula, tomato sauce, and mascarpone pizza and it might have been the best pizza either of us has ever had. Finished up with the flourless chocolate cake, which was divine. Overall an excellent spiritual food journey. Pretty casual, staff is friendly, and at ~$25 per person I'd say it was definitely a treat I will be having again!
author: Margaret O.

description:
Pizzetta 211 is always a fantastic place to eat. The staff couldn't be more amazing, they tend to your every need and will fix anything without question if you have a concern, not that we ever do! 

Love Lauren! Super sweet chick and she makes the best pizza. 

Dining in is worth the wait which sometimes can be long but try take out if youre crushed for time. 

Best pizza in the city? Yup Id say so
author: Christina B.

description: i love this place! it's tiny and super intimate so i wouldn't come with more than one other person if i were you. sit at the counter to enjoy some pizza making action to add extra entertainment to your meal. i've been here a few times and haven't had an undesirable pizza. my favorite was a curried cauliflower with almonds and some sort of cheese but that's long gone from their menu. i assume ingredients change with the seasons which is always a plus. oh, and whatever dessert they've got for the day, go with it! they're pretty awesome and homey too.
author: Regina C.

description: Great place to end a long weekend walk with the pup on a sunny day.
author: Todd H.

description:
Cool tiny little pizza place. Did I say it's small. Yeah it's small but the pizza's are big in flavor and the the staff are good peeps. 

We were another one of the people who saw the article in Sunset magazine and trekked to SF just to try some crafty artisan za. 

We ordered two:
the mozzarella, tomato, and basil 
and the potato, prosciutto and egg

We were torn on which one was better since I thought the potato and egg one was other worldly and Tin thought the Margherita was the cat's meow. Both were delicious either way. 

Small spot but big on heart and caring about their craft.
author: Johnny J.

description:
Been wanting to try this place for a while.  

The place is tiny, so waiting for a table is almost guaranteed.  The blankets they provide outside is a nice touch to keep you warm while waiting outside.  I love the cozy atmosphere and think it's worth the wait. 

I ordered the Farm Egg, Prosciutto, Walnut and Arugula pizza - delicious!  Also tried a slice of the House Made Sausage, Broccoli Raab and Parmesan pizza, which was even better!  The cheese salad was also wonderful.  

The staff were great in general, very friendly.  They made a couple of mistakes, including one on our bill.   I don't blame them though, there seems to be too few of them, given how busy they are between the eat in and take out crowd.
author: Maryam T.

description: Consistently great. This is one of the most under-rated pizza places in the whole San Francisco Bay Area. Tucked away in a quiet neighborhood in the Richmond, make the trip I promise it's worth your while.
author: Nick F.

description: Our favorite pizza in the city -- a real hidden gem if you're willing to make a trek out to the Outer Richmond. All of their pizzas are good, but we always get at least one tomato sauce pizza and the white pizza (with sardo cheese and rosemary, I believe). They also always have a good special vegetable or side of the day, which we have always enjoyed too. The people there are very nice, and it's got such a nice, small, cozy feel to it, so it always feels like a special night when we got there. I just wish we hadn't moved to the other side of town, or else we would be there much more often.
author: Pilan C.

description: Outstanding place. You can't go wrong with their rotating menu. We've tried most of the pizza on their list and haven't been disappointed. So glad to have them in the neighborhood. Also helps that they started taking credit cards via Square.
author: Sean C.

description:
I am kind of obsessed with the pizza here. I went with a friend who works here, which never hurts, but I'd go back again anytime. It's all about the pizza with an amazingly thin, crispy delicious crust. We got the tomato, basil and mozzarella pizza with both the white anchovies and pepperoni. If it weren't for my friend's recommendation I doubt I would have gotten the white anchovies but they made a world of difference. They were plump and tangy and a delicious addition.  My friend also ordered the cheese salad with greens and walnuts.  I'm not a big stinky cheese person but everything looked very fresh.  The hard cheese was good and I imagine if I were a cheese person I would would have been very pleased. 

My only tip is to NOT blot the oil on top of the pizza. After going to Cal and eating hundreds of slices of Blondie's and Fat Slice, it's just what I do.  My friend was appalled.  Apparently, Pizzetta 211 finishes its pizza with quality olive oil which is not meant to be blotted for those of you who have the same tendencies.
author: Tammy L.

description:
Love, love, love!! Wonderful place for a cozy date night. Probably wouldn't want to come here with more than one person, though, or you might wait a while -- there's only a handful of tables in this intimate, neighborhood-y joint.

Nice selection of microbrews (thought not on tap, sadly). A little more pricey than the average (i.e., mediocre) pizza place, but the freshness and interesting flavor combos more than make up for it. We got a pizza with a fried egg on top, all Euro style, and a delicious calzone with goat cheese, among other things. Flourless chocolate cake for dessert, and I was a happy lady.

Friendly service, and the kitchen is right there, which is fun. 

They change their menu all the time, so there's lots of incentive to go back regularly!
author: Megan D.

description:
Pizzetta 211 has got to be a cross between a European and a NY pizza - 

THINK : fresh, thin and ah-may-zingly good! 

First star is for the ambiance - neighborhood pizza place with outdoor and indoor seating.  You can see a lot of people come in around 8:00-8:30pm on a weekday walking from their home to grab a late dinner.  It's small and quaint but that's what gives it the neighborhood feel.

Second star is for the freshness of their food: from the homemade sausages to their menu changing weekly the three times I have been here the consistency of their fresh ingredients always leaves me wanting more.  My hands down favorite is their butternut squash creme fraiche and hazelnut.

Third star is their staff:  the staff works hard and when things don't go right - they're the first to apologize and acknowledge their mistake.  [ Last night - the owner who was serving us and his staff was working really hard to keep things going.  You could tell the owner was a bit frustrated and thought we were upset but told him things were great  and not to worry ]

Fourth star is because I think their pizza is just mouthwatering delicious and this is now my second favorite place in SF - and believe me I've tried a ton...
author: Caroline C.

description: Nice place.  Pizza was really great - (farm eggs with collard greens, bacon, onion.)  Service good.  But... $15.50 for an average size individual thin crust pizza at lunch seems a bit steep.  But, 5/5 for food!
author: Peter G.

description:
This is not a restaurant.
This is not an eatery. 
This is more than the sum of its parts.

Pizetta is a jewel, a gem, a little hole in the wall by which other little holes can be measured. The food is rustic simplicity, the menu doesn't overwhelm you with a million choices and the women who run the shop are pleasant without being saccharin.

If you're in the mood for a hand made pizett with fresh ingredients in a simple atmosphere then this is the place for you. Consequently, the deserts are fantastic and they always have a yummy cheese or two on hand which compliments their salads wonderfully.
author: Len S.

description:
What a little gem in the Outer Richmond district. Came here with an old friend on a Tuesday evening and at 5:54PM this little restaurant was packed. But I guess it wasn't surprising considering the place seats maybe 15 people.. if that.

The menu changes every day with fresh ingredients and innovative toppings. We got the a pizza with bacon and farm eggs on it (is this breakfast pizza? yummm) and a piadini with bacon oil (unhealthy but amazingly delicious), fresh lettuce, and other ingredients that i forgot about (sigh, never leave your review sitting there after drafting it on the iphone...) but I can say confidently that it was absolutely delicious. 

This little joint hits the spot even though I'm not usually a thin crust fan. Will be returning here at 5:30PM sharp next time.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Love, love, love everything about this place! 

My first experience was over a year and half ago. My current boyfriend and I had just started dating and he decided to order pizza and salad to go for our date. We picked it up, drove to his apartment, and sat on his roof watching the sunset over the pacific ocean (doesn't get much better than that!). 

I cannot recall EXACTLY what we ordered, but the pizza had an egg on top of it. He raved about how good it would be and I was a bit hesitant because I've never had an over easy egg on pizza. We can just say...that now I am hooked! I remember biting into the homemade crust with the toppings on top and telling him how delicious it was. His response, "I know. That's why I wanted us to have it." 

Since then him and I will often go back together or with his Mom. Each time we have a wonderful experience and we both love the atmosphere. Yes, it is small and quaint, but it is intimate and warm. I don't mind waiting for a table (it is well worth it). 

Their menu changes, but they always seem to have a pizza with an egg on it (usually at the top of the menu). I highly recommend it to anyone. I love to break and the yolk and swirl its contents over the pizza and taste all the yummy richness in each bite. 

I look forward to our next dinner date when we go back.
author: Holly F.

description:
Love this place but the wait staff is awful.

I was told there was a 'big party' coming in so was sat near the door, where every time it opened (which was over 20 times in 30 minutes!) a huge gust of Outer Rich air blast me and my meal.  Get this, other people came in after me not in that mythic 'big party' and were seated in more comfortable spaces that had been open when I walked in.

Do not whisk away my plate from under my face while I'm still chewing my food and then jump at me with false sincerity to ask how it was so I'll get the check and leave... WHILE I'M STILL EATING.

Seriously.  Can't believe I left this place pissed off.  Hire better people because it leaves a bad taste after such a brilliant meal.
author: Marcy M.

description:
It seems to be a tireless debate between my friends and I whether we prefer Pizetta or Delfina's, two of what I think are the best artisan pizza joints in the city.  Let's just call in a draw because I think I can find the appetite and time for both.  I might give the slight edge to 211 because they consistently have an egg pizza, one of my favorite styles, but this is a matter a personal taste and I can't hold that against Delfina's.

Pizzas here hit it on all marks- locally sourced ingredients of the utmost freshness and quality, everything made from scratch, perfectly cooked in the right ovens, cripsy, flaky, lightly tinged crusts, creative toppings and combinations.  You really can't go wrong with any of their choices.

Plus, they have Blue Bottle coffee and Chimay.  Should I go on or are you convinced yet?

The atmosphere is quaint, if not a little cramped.  Be prepared to wait- there are only a few tables available and no reservations.
author: Mike B.

description:
Pizzetta 211 is truly and absolutely fantastic. It has become my twice a week go-to spot for pizza. Luckily for me, I live nearby. Yippee! 

The crust on the pizza is the best I have had on the west coast, and perhaps, the best ever. The topping choices change up weekly and some of the combinations are outrageously inventive. Nothing too strange and there is always a pepperoni pizza on the menu for the traditionalist. There are daily specials and desserts too. A salad? You got it. 

The crew is wonderful and friendly, the atmosphere is warm and inviting. What else do you want?  

Seriously, l love this place. Bring a bottle of wine (a nice Foxen Cabernet anyone?) and enjoy yourself at Pizzetta 211. I always do.
author: Simon W.

description:
Fresh.  Local. Organic.  Simple.  Elegant.  Tasty.  Friendly.
A unique gem in an otherwise drab neighborhood.
author: Ken B.

description:
Tried two of their pizzas butternut squash w/ hazelnuts and applewood bacon w/ pickled cabbage...interesting toppings but the pie crust was too much crisp not enough chew.

Ordered a cappuccino with their Flowerless chocolate cake.  Cake was a little dense but not overly sweet.  

+++ they serve blue bottle coffee +++

Service was helpful and attentive. Ambiance was nice...the whole layout was cute. crazy small so better get on the list before you are even hungry cause the wait can be long.
author: Diana G.

description:
We have been wanting to try Pizzetta 211 for almost over a year now.  We walk by this place almost every time we're together and always talk about going in, but alway opt out.  Then, the day finally came....

We sat at an outside table under the tree adorned with Christmas lights in September.  (That sounded like a line from a cheesy novel.  Anyway, I digress)...

We shared the Rosemary, Fiore Sardo, and Pine nut pizza and each had a glass of red.  Both were PERFECT.  The flavors of the pizza & the combination with our respective wines were perfect & so were the portions.  

We both made comments that we didn't feel we over-gorged ourselves and felt really good with what we had just put in our bodies.

It's rare to find quality scale food, (that just isn't tossed on your plate), these days.  I feel Pizzetta 211 puts a lot of thought, love and artistry into their food.

If you're ever in the Outer Richmond part of San Francisco, I HIGHLY recommend treating yourself and trying this place.
author: Theresa D.

description:
Awesome thin crust style pizza in this tiny spot in the Richmond. No wood oven, but the 600 degree gas oven delivers piping hot, crispy cornmeal crusted pies. The margherita pizza was awesome, tart tomato sauce, with a nice amount of cheese and brightness from the basil.

The roasted eggplant was perfectly cooked, with a nice combination of flavors from the olives and fresh arugula.

Servers are very friendly and you can end your meal properly with Blue Bottle espresso from a trained Blue Bottle barista.
author: Derrick V.

description:
Must Order:
Everything-- great pizzas.  Fyi, the wait is significant (for a table and food)
author: Tina N.

description: I love this place. Amazing pizza and decent wine way out in the avenues.
author: Julie S.

description: I'd also like to share my complete satisfaction with the New Year's Eve prix fixe meal I had here. It was my first time at Pizetta and I was NOT disappointed. Rich, inventive, flavorful dishes had me dreading the last bite! Fantastic staff, good atmosphere and extraordinary food. Definitely worth checking out!
author: Megan B.

description:
Pizzeta 211 is only 2 blocks away. Yet I didn't come here for the first time until last month! I guess it's because the don't deliver. The also are not open as late in the evening. But if you put out quality thin pizzas like they do, I wouldn't either.

Pizzeta means little pizza. This is true. The pizzas are small enough to be individual servings, but they are big enough to share :)

My favorite is the pizza with the egg on top. Who knew that an egg on the pizza can be so tasty? The pizza has a richness  that only an egg can deliver. The pesto and pancetta pizza is also delicious! It gives a saltiness that you yearn for yet the heirloom tomatoes sweeten the bite. 

The restaurant is tucked away amongst homes and an elementary school across the street. It is not very big, but a great place to check out with a couple of tables outside, which is perfect on a warm Outer Richmond day. There is not that much parking, so walk here if you can. The staff is friendly. The pizzas are a little pricey, but worth it if you are in the area.
author: Jan Z.

description:
Small can some times be better! And Pizzetta 211 is a small place, but does pizza in a big way! 

If thin crusted is something you fancy and you want something fancier, but without the classy feel of what major restaurants give, this is the place for you. Pizzetta has enough choices for the adventurous or the old-fashioned. My fiancee and I went the old-fashioned route and got the Pepperoni. The awesome part of this pizza is the thin crusted dough! There wasn't a lot of toppings, but it was enough to have great balance in flavor. 

We also got their special of the day. It's a salad that has eggplant and toasted bread in it. If they offer it, get it! It's something that I could eat on my own!

Pizzetta 211 doesn't have much seats, but they do have heated outside seats. I would say that they could accommodate about 10 people inside and another 8 outside. Oh, cash only!
author: Jeremy L.

description:
The pizza here is ok.
Perhaps I caught them on an off day.  Perhaps it was a long wait.  Or perhaps it was because my standards for thin crust pizza are abnormally high and SF pizza never can compare to back east.  
The ingredients they use for their pizza are quite top shelf but for some reason when combined they didn't hit all the right flavor notes for me.  
If you come, bring a magazine since it is a small place and you will most likely have to wait a bit until you can eat.
author: Sarah C.

description:
This place rocks. I wouldn't consider myself as a pizza snob, but I am pretty picky about my pizza. 

I like thin-crust pizza with very simple but fresh ingredients. Pizzetta 211 changes their menu quite often based on the in-season ingredients available. They have a very simple but good menu.  I heard their ingredients are all organic. They have been doing a good job altering the menu with good combination of items as well as excellent selection of ingredients. Every time I came here, I was able to have a different good experience. 

You will realize that their pizza is good when you first smell the freshly out-of-the-oven fragrance and take the first bite into the pizza. There's an explosion of flavors of fresh ingredients. Very awesome experience for quality pizza.

Be aware of the line. The restaurant is so tiny but popular, there's always a long line there during rush hours.
author: Kai Y.

description:
pizzetta 211 sounds exclusive, trendy and mythical, right? Well sort of parking around there sucks, on a good day, so you're lucky if it actually is your neighborhood pizza place and you're within walking distance, if your not lucky enough to be a card carrying member of the ORD then go home kook.  Expect to wait for your seats too, but it's worth it. plus, they'll let you start off with drinkies while you wait(actually frenchy style classes of wine, no big-gulp sized beer here). that is, if you're allowed to wait. see, they only have a set number of doughballs pre-made. so if you arrive late, after they've baked up all the pies, you're out of luck. Which is happens a lot. The wifey and I have been shut down there too many times to mention because of this and a book of other hours, rules of engagement, no-no's and other reasons that they deam to turn you away.

But if you do get in, the pizza crust and variety of toppings are excellent. If your feel adventurous try the egg pizza (not a fave of mine but try it). The simple marg's the best.  The staff is quite friendly and it was fun watching them work in concert in the cramped kitchen area. Just take what they make and don't ask for any variation on yer za. I asked for a little Parmesan cheese and they brought the main "chef" out to clarify what the hell i wanted and why, only to shut me down and walk away feeling insulted.  So as you can read this, and other posts, 211 is no Pizza Hut Bubba. expect good, kinda spendy, euro-style fair  and feel lucky if you get in. Welcome to the ORD, take nothing but pictures...leave nothing but big tips. now go home.
author: Lindonesia S.

description: This place has the best thin crust pizza around.    Parking is a bit of problem and the place is kind of a hole in the wall.   Beware, they only take cash.  No credit cards and no freezer.   Everything is fresh.
author: Paul B.

description:
Me and my buddy Ian were hungry on the way home after a social event, so we stopped off at Pizzetta since we were already over by Geary. It's a super cute little restaurant in a quiet neighborhood with a small dining room inside and a couple of tables outside. We couldn't have asked for a more lovely day and chose one of the tables outside. The menu was pretty limited, but had quite a few options for me to choose from. I went with a simple tomato, basil, and mozzarella pizza with white anchovies. The pizza was very flavorful with just the amount of fresh mozzarella and skinny white anchovies that weren't salty like the ones you normally get. The crust was thin and crisp with a slight, smoky charred flavor on the underside. Yum!!!

The service was quick and efficient and the people working behind the counter were super friendly and really seemed enthusiastic about what they were making. I can't wait to come back and bring other people with me!
author: Jason W.

description:
My favorite pizza in all of San Francisco. They make the perfect artisan-style thin crust pie. The pizzas always come out hot and the ingredients always taste garden-fresh. On top of the great food, the atmosphere is welcoming and intimate--the ideal date spot.

Their margherita is fantastic, but they also make very innovative, delicious special pies. I once had a calamari aioli pie here that was out of this world (and I usually am not a fan of fancy or overly creative pizzas).

The space is small, so factor in 30 minutes or so of waiting time if you go for a weekend dinner. If you do end up waiting, they serve drinks to you while you wait out front. I love this place.
author: Bradley T.

description:
I am from NY, so I wasn't expecting memorable pizza during my trip to San Francisco (wheat grass maybe, but not pizza).  But then Pizzetta was great.  Rustic yet new with a rotating menu of pizzas and other dishes.  

Thin crust with fresh ingredients and no charred bits to break your teeth on like some thin crust pizzas I've had elsewhere.  A few kernels of corn and other toppings brightened up my pie.  At lunch on a weekday around 2pm, I got a seat easily.  

I took a slice of the nectarine dessert for the road and ate it sitting on China Beach--thank you Richmond.
author: Sydney B.

description:
1st off, this place is really small.  It's a neighborhood joint that packs up quickly so you need to arrive early.  The service is good and attentive.

The pizza...it's ok.  The toppings are fresh and well selected.  However, the crust is not there.  It's a bit too doughly and on the hard side.  If it can be made thinner, lighter, and chewier, it would be better. 

The salads, cheese plate, dessert were very good.
author: MTBer I.

description: Still my favorite restaurant in the city.  Service is always great (seems like very little staff turnover).  Food is great.  If they offer the sausage and orzo appetizer - it's fantastic.
author: Josh L.

description:
Their entire menu is fantastic. This restaurant is under a house in a somewhat, quiet neighborhood across an elementary school. Everything is homemade and so very quaint. 

I loved their thin-crusted pizza, salad and desserts. Sometimes when I go there with my family, we order their homemade desserts. I'm not a big fan of whip cream, but their homemade whip cream alongside their famous chocolate cake was so nice and creamy. 

The owners, cooks and employees were all so kind, lively and considerate to every customer that goes there.
author: Chau T.

description:
I really like cute little unassuming restaurants like this.  Tucked away on a side street you may not notice it unless walking directly passed.  Apparently they're known for their pizza w/ egg on top.  I was a little hesitant as ive never had this before.  But, i admit, it was good.  Ok ok, it was really good.  I would definitely order it again.  

Know what was even better - scharffenberger flourless chocolate cake.   It was better than good and not too sweet.  It was like sex on a plate with delicious whipped cream on the side.  Whipped cream so good it makes you want to smear it all over . . . . more chocolate cake of course.  I believe i may have blushed while placing forkfuls atop my tongue - my cheeks, down my neck, down my chest, to my legs, felt flushed.  I may have also let out a quiet mmmm to myself.  Oh yeah, it was good stuff baby.  

I suppose i'll also mention that their prices are decent.  And that yes, their pizza is worth every bite.  And i'll also mention that the staff is very friendly and personable.  And that the place is tiny but really charming - use the bathroom, its pretty freakin cool.  Oh and that they offer blue bottle coffee.  But lets be real, after reading my review, these arent the things that will make you want to experience Pizzetta 211.
author: Juv C.

description:
Each year for my wife's birthday we do a culinary tour.  One year it was chocolate.  The next pizza, then ice cream.  The year we did pizza we hit five pizza places in one day, and without a doubt, Pizzetta 211 was the best.  

Two years later we did a "best of" culinary tour -- hitting the best chocolate (XOX Truffles in North Beach), the best pizza (Pizzetta 211) and best ice cream (Mr. and Mrs. Miscellaneous).  After two years away, it was still phenomenal.  Six of us came back and got great service (Jack was awesome).  Beware, there is very little seating, so time your visit right.

We gorged ourselves (six pizzas, two sides, three desserts for six people?!?) but it was all worth it.  Yes, the pizzas are great, but their salads are also a must.  And the flourless chocolate cake was light and delicious.  

It's a long trek from Oakland, but that's probably a good thing.  Otherwise we'd be there regularly and be significantly larger and poorer.
author: Jamie A.

description: Food is fine, but woman who does the service is terrible...sarcastic and rude.  Makes you feel like a schmuck for asking questions.  Too bad.
author: Jamie D.

description: Excellent, fresh pizza. Friendly service.  Excellent beer and wine selection.  Reasonable prices.  Happy ambiance.
author: Chris R.

description: This is probably the best pizza I've had since my trip to Croatia a couple of years ago. Don't come to this place if you are only interested in pizza toppings. Toppings here are good, but this isn't the pizza place that loads the up with toppings and gives you soggy dough. Here, you'll get the crispy, light and thin, probably the best pizza dough you can get in the city. Absolutely delicious!
author: Alton Y.

description: Exceptional service and Italian pizza. If I could doodle hearts into this review, I would. Had the margherita and pizza bianca - super, super yummy. And we tried their pluton (hybrid fruit: plum + apricot) cake!!! Loved it - not too sweet but tarte, yummy crust.
author: Jan S.

description:
After eating here, I have a tasty dilemma....do I declare Pizzetta 211 my new favorite pizza place and throw Little Star to the curb?  Or do I stay true to my Chicago roots and the gooey awesomeness of a spinach and garlic pies?  I guess I'll just have to eat more and more of each until I can figure it out.  

Anyways, this place is great for my veggie friends  - I went with the family and we managed to find three different and equally-but-differently delicious veggie pizzas: 1) basil/tomato/mozzella, 2) Rosemary, Fiore Sardo Cheese, Pine Nuts, and 3) Summer Squash, Oven Dried Roma Tomato, Gruyere, Thyme.  #2 was probably to rich for me an I wouldn't order it again, but #1 was excellent.  Also, highly recommend the olive sampler for appetizer - I have no idea what those green ones were but they were delicious!
author: Rosers M.

description:
I am extremely disappointed in writing a bad review of Pizzetta, as their pizza is excellent if rather expensive, but the service today was completely unacceptable.

If a customer walks in the door, there are not open tables inside, offers to sit outside until a space opens up inside and then move, and you agree, then a few minutes later when other people walk in you come out to tell the first customers that you will not be able to sit them inside, even though the came in first, specifically told you and you agreed that they would sit outside only until something opened inside, have not yet ordered, and offered to wait rather than sit so they could get an inside table first, do not expect happy customers, specially in a cold day like today.

At the very least be forward about what you mean, rather than dancing around the subject.

We should have walked away after having to have this discussion with our waitress for four minutes, but we were too hungry.  This is not how you treat customers.
author: E L.

description: Fresh ingredients and simply prepared. Really small, cash only, neighborhood pizza place with decent salads too. Try to sit outside if possible. I'm a fan of anything thin crust except when it's in my eyes, ears, between my toes, and other cravasses that shall remain nameless.
author: Jen Y.

description:
I HATED this place. In fact, it gets two stars only because I like the wines and they use fresh ingredients, but that's it. The worst/most disgusting toppings to exist on a pizza are here. The pizza has very thin sauce, and while baking, they crack an egg on it. It's not in a good way like a breakfast pizza. It's not even really sunny-side up. It's nearly raw! Are you kidding me? Then you are going to charge a crapload for this nasty shit? I ate one slice out of politeness (I was with my brother and sister in law) but I couldn't eat it without wanting to puke. Maybe if something else was ordered, it would be better, but this place is awful. The people who wait in line or those already seated glare at everyone too. Rude clientele, horrible food. Way too tiny of a place. Thanks, but no thanks, I will stick to "mainstream" pizza joints if I want pizza from somewhere.

I know a lot of people get so offended about everything, especially the "food" in this city, but I have been around the country and this is by far one of the worst pizza places I have experienced. Maybe it was a bad day or the cook sucked or something, but it was really bad.

No, I don't need to go home and eat a dick because of the disgusting pizza that was served to me. I will just spend my money elsewhere and not support a place that serves gross pizza.
author: Tiffany P.

description:
This is a very tiny restaurant with space at an absolute premium. Definitely not good for groups or for bringing children. I was seated at the bar, which was a bit uncomfortable (no leg room, and no hooks for hanging bags or coats) but the window seats looked cozy and the outdoor seating looked nice too although was a bit chilly for that on my visit. 

But anyway, most importantly, the food. I had the basic tomato, mozzarella, and basil and it was absolute perfection: nice thin crust with the perfect crunch, yummy little dollops of pesto, and just the right amount of cheese. It only took about 10 minutes to cook too, so did not have to wait long. The pizza was the perfect size for one person, so if you are really hungry I recommend getting your own pizza, but if you're just looking for a snack then they are a good size for sharing. Definitely going back.
author: Kathleen R.

description:
Steer away from the pizza with two eggs if you prefer tomato sauce on your pizza.

Overall, cute space, nice service, quality ingredients - I esp liked the sausage appetizer served on M/T. It's a little on the pricey side, and a 3-course dinner goes by a little too fast.  But a good option for the neighborhood.
author: c t.

description:
I wanted to like Pizzetta 211, but I can't say I did.  It was always so crowded every time I went by and I randomly met the owner once (which is how I found out about the restaurant), so I sauntered in one day to test the waters.

No owner in sight, and of course you're always going to be crowded when you only have enough seating for 6 people...

Why anybody would pay so much for crackers with melted cheese is beyond me.  I don't consider this pizza.
author: Jin D.

description: Amazing use of local ingredients. Super efficient and friendly staff.
author: Paul C.

description:
By far the best thin crust pizza i have had.  This place is amazing on multiple levels.  1) it was totally adorable.  2) it was really tiny.  3) it wasnt that busy at all.  3) the pizza is amazing.

I odered a Margarita Pizza with Pepperoni.  When i saw it come out of the ovent, it was kind of a mystery because i couldnt really see what the toppings looked like as she moved the pizza from oven to countertop.  But when she took the slicer and began cutting out the slices, i could hear the crip of the crust breaking and i knew i was in for it.

When the pizza arrived, i needed a few moments to myself.  Such good flavors that were fresh and simple.  Not much else to say.

The pizza is a bit expensive.  It is $11 for their cheapest pizza (mine) and its not terribly large.  Enough for one person.  I even contemplated getting a second but the place is cash only and i only had a $20 on me.  Oh well.  Next time.

Definately worth the small trek for any pizza enthusiest.
author: Reuben D.

description: I can not believe this awesome place is my neighborhood! What a gem. I love real Italian pizza, so I rarely ever eat pizza in the states but this stuff was excellent. thin crust, fresh ingredients, simple, delicious. Tried the mascarpone and pine nuts and the margheritta. I cant wait to try more of the menu!
author: Chelsey G.

description: Best pizza ever! Fresh ingredients, friendly, chill staff, and delicious food. Pizzetta offers simple, feel good food and an unpretentious atmosphere. I would suggest trying a vegetable side with a pizza and holding out for a desert. The flour-less chocolate cake is the best I've ever had. The only draw back is the restaurant is tiny! If there is a wait more than 15 minutes, it's better to come back another day.
author: Nicole S.

description: So good! we randomly came across this place and were blown away. Such good food, quick service and great staff. Enjoy whenever you can!
author: Dave B.

description:
The best thin crust pizza in the Richmond district. Small and cozy. Fresh, organic ingredients - only the best!

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: Quaint place with great food.  Tiny, but worth the experience.  Sit outside on a warm day if you can.  Or sip some wine outside while you wait for a table.  They change the pizza selections frequently and the quality behind each one, will make you smile. This place opened up my taste buds to how tasty fresh farm eggs can be on a pizza. Who would have thought?  Cons are parking, price and they only take cash.  It's the perfect date place, but can add up pretty quick.  If you're not in a hurry and looking for cozy ambiance, check it out.
author: Lindy C.

description: Yum yum yum! Great staff, delicious pizza, unreal strawberry shortcake and flourless chocolate cake. Cannot say anything bad about this place. I even love that, most nights, you have to earn a seat here.
author: Cameron V.

description:
One of the best pizza places in the city. Their pizzettas are experimental, interesting and just amazing. Can you think of a pizza that tastes like pine nuts and is still good? I cannot either, but they just do it.

The place is super-small, and you may need to wait for a table, and they don't accept credit card. It is also quite far away in the Richmond/Sea Cliff. Despite all of this, it is definitely worth the trip.
author: Janne K.

description:
As European, I've never liked "American style pizza" meaning those pizzas with too much fake cheese and a large soggy crust.
Since I moved 2 blocks away from Pizzetta, I pass it by quit often and was always curious about this place. When my roommate told me about the good reviews she read about Pizzetta, we decided to try it.
Man, this pizza is amazing! It's by far the best pizza I've had since I moved to the United States (and as a student, I eat pizza quit often!). 

We ordered the following:
Farm Egg, Pea Tendril, Feta, Mint, Lemon Zest; YUMMY. Never had egg on a pizza, but MAN this is delicious! 
Rosemary, Fiore Sardo Cheese, Pine Nuts; My favorite!! This one is super delicious!
Tomato, Mozzarella, Basil; standard, but ow so yummy.

It's a little more expensive than most other pizza places, but knowing you will have a satisfying meal, rather than just a quick bite, it's definitely worth it.

Pizzetta, I'll be back! :)
author: Helen D.

description:
I'm torn between a 3 and a 4.

First, some background. I love pizza, and have a high standard. For something to be a 5* pizza place, it has to simply be awesome. Pizzetta's pizza was quite good; but not awesome.

The most basic pizza one can get is the Margherita: cheese + basil on a tomato sauce. The purist in me was disappointed to find a pesto-like pureed olive oil + basil blend on the cheese. It's a nice variation on the theme, but it ain't no Margherita, I'm sorry. Would I come back? Yes.

The flour-less chocolate cake was very good.

Other things to note: this is a _really_ small place. It's the size of a living room, basically. I counted, and at most 16 people can squeeze in here without someone sitting on a stranger's lap. There are a couple of tables set up outside (and heaters too); on a warm evening (if we ever have one in SF), it would be a great place to slowly enjoy a pizza or two over beer. They also provide blankets if you feel cold outside (only in San Francisco would you find such a touch).

Overall: it's a cozy, neighborhood place. I wish my neighborhood had one like this. I will go back.
author: A J.

description: If you like airy thin crust pizza, then you would love this place!  The menu is not big, but they execute everything extremely well.  There's about half a dozen different pizzas to choose from, 3 of which are new options introduced each week.  The pizzas here are simply perfect:  fresh gourmet toppings, airy thin crust, and slightly chewy dough.  Beyond pizzas, salads and desserts are equally amazing.  To end the meal, we had a panna cotta with fresh figs and soft gingerbread cookies.  Plus, the staff here are super friendly, and the vibe is laid-back.   This place totally exceeded our expectations.  I can't wait to come back already!
author: Judy H.

description:
I am never disappointed by pizzetta, ever. 

I've made many visits here, but I recently visited two days in a row, once after an epic 18 mile hike, and the next day for an out of town guest. Both visits were everything I could have hoped for: the food simple and perfect, the service casual but attentive. 

On my first visit:
I drank: imported italian mineral water - lots of it. Also, blue bottle latte.
I ate: grilled asparagus with preserved lemon and fresh goat cheese crostini. 1/2 baby artichoke, fingerling potato & spicy aoli pizza. 1 saffron biscotti.

On my second visit:
I drank: 1 glass spanish white, 1 blue bottle latte
I ate 1/2 butter lettuce, avocado, jicama, grapefruit salad & 1/2 mozzerella basil white anchovy pizza, 1 slice goat cheese tart with preserved kumquat.
author: H G.

description:
This is THE quintessential neighborhood joint. I just wish I lived closer so I could walk here nightly! 

It's tiny, and has no more than maybe 10 tables. Tables are close together and it's cramped by comfy. The kitchen is open in the restaurant so you can see all that is going on. The appetizers change daily and are fresh made, so when they are out, they are out! The pizzas are super thin crust, and on the smaller side, more on the gourmet front than the Domino's pizza style, if you get what I mean. (small, thin crust, fancier toppings!). There were 4 of us and I think we polished off at least 5 pizzas..........the farm one with the fried egg, the sausage one, the one with the mozzarella and tomatoes, and then also the butternut squash one which was AMAZING. The almond cake is to die for also, so light and just the perfect way to end the meal. 

Things to know: self service, you can go to the table against the wall and get your own utensils and water and napkins. On nights where it is super busy they allow for to go pizzas but this is not every night. Even so, if you get there and wait, it is so worth the wait. The can by the door is not for trash, it is for wet umbrellas.
author: Denise B.

description:
Very good thin crusted pizza.

The farmer cheese pizza topped with an egg was very good.
author: S.K. Y.

description:
As good as it gets, for real. Amazing dough, great and fresh ingredients, very tasty flavorful pizza and wonderful people.
The only problem is the limited seating area, which leads to very long wait at times.
Hands down my favorite pizza place.
author: Carl T.

description:
A drizzly Sunday is a great time to be holed away in this little Outer-Richmond gem.  Lucky for us that intermittent showers drove the crowds away, so we were seated within 10 minutes of arrival.

The field greens salad is just a pile of lightly dressed greens.  I was a little surprised that it was so unadorned, but you can't fault them because it came just as described on the menu!

We shared the farm egg / prosciutto and roasted fennel / currant pizzas.  Both had a pleasantly thin, crispy crust and were served fresh and hot from the Baker's Pride oven.  One thing to note is that it takes a long time for your food to arrive, so make sure not to be famished upon arrival.  Of the two pies we ordered, I favored the farm egg and prosciutto pizza.  I'm a sucker for runny egg yolks because the richness from the golden orb perfectly complemented the slight saltiness from the proscuitto and cheese.  The fennel was nicely roasted, but I thought it would have been better had it been a white pizza instead of a red tomato base.

We ended our meal with blue bottle coffees and a slice of room temperature flourless chocolate cake accompanied by a dollop of freshly whipped cream.  I would have loved it more had it been slightly warm, but that's a personal preference!
author: Janet L.

description: Small place and limited seating but delicious! We had all the pizzas in one stop.  My favorite was arugula!  Beer for $5
author: Sheila P.

description: Pizzeta 211 over in the Richmond is soooo worth the long trek to get there.  Expect cozy dining, friendly service, and delicious thin crust pizza with top quality ingredients.  I came here a couple weeks ago on a rainy weekend afternoon  with a friend and got a table by the window.  I love the atmosphere.  Plus, the guy cooking the pizzas truly seeks perfection.  After a bit of time had passed since we ordered, he came over and said my pizza had cooked about 30 seconds longer than he wanted so he was refiring them.  The pizzas cook fast so it was not a time issue and upon arrival at our table my pizza really did look and taste amazing.  I had the Rosemary, Fiore Sardo, and Pinenuts and while my friend enjoyed the classic Margherita Pizza.  I can't wait to go back!!!"
author: Laura B.

description:
A thin crusty pizza is a good thing, especially right out of the oven with  fresh, quality ingredients and good sauce. I liked the pizzetta at 211. My friend ordered. She had taken me there at least 5 years ago, saying it was a top secret place. I'm happy to see it's popular now and looks like it's retained its quality. 

I have to say when they brought out the one with the egg on it I gagged a little - not an egg fan here - but I was also very impressed. It truly is lovely looking. The presentation here is wonderful.
author: Roxmarie M.

description: Workers handling money AND food without washing hands.  One worker cleaning and handling mop and dustpan alternating with handling food. Same worker adds trimmings to cooked pizza with same unwashed hands.  Same worker tosses some salad in his mouth while prepping.  Workers making salads with bare hands unwashed after handling money.  Dirty rags hanging on workers' belts for convenience I suppose.  Not coming back here.  I hope we don't get food poisoning tonight.  We should have left without eating the food.  Same process for to-go orders.  Noticed Health Inspection score from October is 86.  Should be way lower based on today's observations.  If you don't want to witness this don't sit at the counter.
author: Chris D.

description: The best pizzettas you will ever have made with fresh ingredients and love. This is a small neighborhood place with limited seating so you may have a wait. Great find.
author: Michael C.

description:
If it weren't for Yelp, I would never know the existence of Pizzetta 211, hidden between Clement and California, away from all the busy restaurants.  The place is tiny and there is nothing else commercial on 23rd Ave, so it's very easy to overlook it.

Pizzetta is tiny, fits about 4 tables (unless you want to sit outside in the fog.)  The menu is simple and changes frequently.  

I had the simple tomato and mozzarella pizza, which came in a very thin crust. It was so thin I ate the whole pizza, which I normally would not do.  Flavors were good.  

My husband had the egg and pancetta pizza.  He looooved it!  The combination does sound a bit unconventional: sunny side up egg, pancetta, green tomatoes.  But somehow it works wonder for him.  He, too, ate the whole pizza. 

Prices are very reasonable: we spent about $30 for two pizzas including tips and taxes.  They only take cash though.  Service is pretty fast, and each table gets a whole carafe of water (such a simple and nice gesture and yet not many restaurants implement the practice.)

My husband wanted to give it 5 stars, but guess who is writing this review?  I give it four because my pizza was good, but not mind blowing good.  But apparently the egg and pancetta pizza is that good.
author: Candice B.

description:
This is my absolute favorite pizza.  The only reason it doesn't get 5 stars is the variability of the wait staff, who lately have been great.  I'll revisit again and probably upgrade to 5 stars if I enjoy the service one more time (plenty of previous bad experiences prohibit me from doing so today).

Try to arrive early as seating is very limited.   

All of the pizzas are mouth-watering delish. You have to try this pizza.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Shut UP!  By far, hands down, nothing compares to the BEST PIZZA EVER!  My hubby and I went there on a Saturday afternoon for a late lunch before a stroll along the Coastal Trail....we hadn't eaten breakfast in anticipation of the pizza.  We ordered the starter which were a roasted beans w/a fab cheese I can't remember the name of with some perfectly toasted crostinis....then on to the main event.

We ordered the Farm Egg, Pancetta, oven dried roma tomato, garlic confit pizza and a Roasted squash, cherry tomato, ricotta and chive pizza.  Perfect crust, egg was awesome flavors were outstanding.  

Ridiculously delicious...highly recommend - oh my goodness, cannot wait until I can go again.
author: Mrs. S.

description:
Claire and I adore Pizzetta. The best part, according to Claire, is that she can hang  with her canine gal pals outside sniffing  humans while I sip wine and nosh on delicious pine nut and rosemary thin crust pizza inside. The staff is friendly and helpful, and gets things done efficently and seamlessly. Claire gets all the attention and love. I just get a nice red wine buzz and some tasty vitels.

Slightly pricy, delicious fresh ingredients,  and an interesting and friendly gathering make it all worthwhile. Two paws up for Pizzetta!
author: david l.

description:
The food is great, the atmosphere is terrific for a date with a significant other and the owner and help staff are terrific.

A trusted friend recommended that I come my first time, and I keep coming back because I love the food and experience.
author: Brandon C.

description: Fantastic pizzas.   Seriously, seriously good.  Thin crust.  Gorgeous.  Made in front of you. Sit down, relax, eat pizza.  Nice desserts too.
author: Jon M.

description:
Pizzetta 211 is DELICIOUS! Their menu changes every week and they strive to use the freshest local ingredients they can find. Being from NY I have pretty tough standards for pizza. This spot is unlike any I have ever tasted and the fact that the menu is always different makes it all the more awesome for me since I'm only in town a few times a year. 

I've eaten here twice with a couple friends and have eaten 6 different pizzas total. Every single one had me wishing for more. 

Let's start with the basic, the tomato and basil pie, it's fantastic. You know that when a place can deliver such delicious flavors on such a fundamental pie that they really have some skill. 

I've gotten 2 different farm egg pizzas here too that were both to die for. The 1st time it had oxtail, the second pancetta, both were so AMAZING! 

I've eaten the manila claim and homemade sausage, again, delicious! 

The calzone, delicious! 

So yeah, everything this place cooks up is worth a taste. Check them out! 

I'll definitely be coming back here every time I make it up to the bay. 

-Reverend ToneZone
author: Tone Z.

description:
Someone compared this place to Pizzeria Picco is Larkspur, and I must say I'm personally offended. There is NO comparison. To begin with, the margherita pizza was oily. This seemed to be intentional - they had drizzled some olive oil over top, but they seemed to have gotten a little over excited. Also, the tomato sauce was a little high on the tartness and the oregano. Our second pizza was very good - rocket onion, goat cheese and egg - but I truly measure a place by the quality of their margherita. 
Would have been nice to have a local pizza place I liked as much as Picco, but I guess it's back to Marin for me.
author: Purnima M.

description:
Ambiance: 5 indoor 2 outdoor self set tables and few counter stools. Small bathroom with cute TV. 

Food: Perfect for any pizza portfolio. Unique, fresh, and well paired, simple ingredients. Lovely salad, well dressed. Ever changing fruit, nut, & cheese combos that make a perfect salad with tender greens. 

Service: Always friendly and efficient. Feels like a close group. Offer blankets if it's cold outside with a wait.
author: Miss M.

description:
Why can't all restaurants in the city be like Pizzetta 211?

Cozy doesn't begin to describe this thumbelina-sized bistro that serves up the CRISPEST, TASTIEST, most DELICIOUSEST thin crust pies. 

The best pizza is something transcending humble flavors of its parts when joined together in a piping hot oven. Pizzetta works the same way matching a hearth-like atmosphere, a talented group of four friends, a tightly focused but interesting menu, and a pizza chef that dazzles with deft easygoing speed. 

I loved the way each pie was checked for perfect crispness, rotated if needed and moved about the oven for even temperature management. No part of my savory basil, tomato pepperoni pizza was burned or limp.

There's nothing better than enjoying something created with pride, experience and heart.
author: Brady K.

description:
Super cute everything!  Cute space, cute baby pizza pies, cute people working the oven!

My kind of neighborhood restaurant.

A must is the Cheese Salad with organic greens, artisanal cheeses, walnuts, dehydrated figs, and olives.  Combined, they go so well together... the salty cheese goes perfect with the sweet fig... loved the textures together.  Since they were both soft it was like eating one item with ever changing flavors.  

The pizzetta with the egg, pancetta, potato and garlic is quite hearty.  You can grow full from this real easily.  I felt it needed a sauce too.. not sure why they didn't put marinara on this pizza.  The tang would have really cut the richness of the yolk and mellow out the garlic cloves.  

Also got the margherita w/ pepperoni.  Solid.  You've all had pepporini pizza... they just do it right here.  They also do crust right... thin, almost to cracker consistency, but still able to pull off chewiness.

Service was mediocre.  Very casual here.  They swing by when you make eye contact, but they're not really out to check up on you and generically ask you if everything was to your liking.  If you want them, just get their attention... the place is small so they really don't want to keep squeezing in and out when not necessary.  They're still friendly folks here!

Blue Bottle coffee was awesome too by the way.  I'll need to revisit for their weekly cheese specials and desserts.
author: Chris T.

description:
So cute, I just want to stick it in my pocket and carry it around with me.
We got a table right away at 6:30p on a Thursday night, and split one of the special pizzas, and an amazing beet-beet greens, fresh-ricotta-shmeared-on-toasted-levain appetizer. Awesome. All of it. Plus, the service was friendly and easy-going, and every bit of it feels like a charming neighborhood place. We'll be back!
author: Emmy M.

description:
Better than the pizza in Rome. No joke. Their pies are thin-crust, dough fired to perfection, and not at all a perfectly round pizza. Looks and tastes gourmet and handmade. Their restaurant is super tiny but very charming, and if you wait for a table you can order a bottle of wine and sip your glass on the curb until your table's up. If you're in more of a hurry, I'd recommend calling ahead for takeout. Luckily my gf lives down the street, so were able to grab our food and stroll home.

They only do about 5 pies per night, and they regularly switch them up. One constant on the menu is the tomato and mozzarella, which any good pizza place should master (hint: they have, and you should order it). When I went, they had very interesting combinations of ingredients including egg and fine Italian sausage -- absolutely delicious. They were also serving one with calamari that night.

One pie is enough for only 1 person, so plan on getting a variety of pizzas and sharing them. It makes it more fun that way!
author: Andrew K.

description: I love that their menu is constantly changing but is consistently delicious. The cool thing about this place too is the people serving you. It's family run and the guys who work there are beyond friendly and cool. I was hesitant to writing this review because I adore my neighborhood pizzetta
author: Carlos S.

description:
Full disclosure; I'm a neighbor.

Absolutely fantastic service; one of the best.

The pizza is superb; thin crust; excellent flavor.

The atmosphere is totally romantic; small, only 4 tables inside; 2 on the outside with heaters.

5 stars for sure.
author: Stuart L.

description: Sometimes those tiny, off the beaten path places seem like they wouldn't be that great, and then you find those ones that are. And Pizzeta 221 is the latter. They are serving up wonderful pizza and apps with great ingredients in a tiny store front right in the Outer Richmond. This is a great date night place to go when you wouldn't mind sitting outside enjoying a couple glasses of wine with good company. You'll wait a while for a table, but in the end it's definitely worth the long wait. Enjoy some great pizza and Italian wines while sitting among the fog just off Lake Street.
author: Rebecca D.

description: I got the simple margarita pizza so maybe I didn't get to experience the 'amazingness' of this place. Cheese pizza is cheese pizza... I would not hold your breath guys.
author: Lena T.

description: Great authentic Italian pizza that you can see being made, environmental friendly atmosphere, and pleasant employees. What more could you ask for?
author: Shannon H.

description:
We went into Pizzetta 211 for dinner recently.  This place is quietly tucked away in the Richmond district and serves really good thin crust pizzas.

We ordered the tomato, mozzarella & basil pizza w/ pepperoni and the Fiori Sardo Sheep Cheese Pizza w/ pinenuts and rosemary.  The sheep cheese pizza had a sharp white cheddar taste to it and is served without tomato sauce.  The pinenuts were toasted for a nice crunch and the rosemary made it fragrant and very tasty.  Highly recommended!  I was able to sneak a bite of the pepperoni pizza and it was pretty good too.  I am in love with their version of the thin crust pizza.

I was highly anticipating dessert & coffee here.  For dessert we had the flourless chocolate cake.  It was delicious - they use Scharffenberger in their chocolate!  It is served with fresh whipping cream.  We also order a single espresso and an Americano made using Blue Bottle Coffee.  A great way to end the dinner!

Can't wait to go back to Pizzetta 211!  Funny, as I post this review they will be open in 5 minutes (Wed 5PM).  Hmm . . .
author: Janet H.

description: Ate here twice. Nice place with great pizza's and salads for a reasonable price. The short menu changes frequently so always something new to try!
author: C S.

description:
Hands down one of my favorite restaurants in san francisco. Love the cheese salad, all of the pizzas, housemade sausage on monday and tuesday, and best of all- the flourless chocolate cake with fresh whipped cream.

Owner operated, great service, delicious food prepared with love. A fantastic local gem.
author: Anna H.

description: FANTASTIC pizza.  We had the wild mushroom, spinach, and ricotta cheese pizza.  It was sublime.  Highly recommended!
author: Nathan W.

description:
After having seen folks waiting for one of the six tiny tables for many a moon, I was very happy to see space available at Pizzetta during an early evening walk through the neighborhood.

The place is tiny, but charming.  The pizzas reminded me of the real deal from Italy -- personal-size, thin-crust pizzas with fresh ingredients that complement each other in creative ways. Both the farm egg/pancetta and the pine nut/cheese pizza that my wife ordered were delicious.  The generous pour of vino is served in a real table glass, not stemware (hooray).

Although you are served at your table, the cutlery and napkins were left on a "self-serve" station on a table inside -- ?  Not sure why this is.  After dinner, we shared a slice of chocolate cake that was a wee bit dry, but the espresso was made very well. 

The wait staff said that summer evenings have been slow -- now's the time to enjoy this neighborhood gem.  Mille grazie, Pizzetta.
author: kristoffe R.

description:
I took the advice of other reviewers and called a head to make sure they still had dough before heading over on a rainy evening. we had the olives to start and then shared the egg, fennel, and tomato pizza and the tomato, basil, and cheese pizza. 

the egg pizza wasn't thrilling. an interesting concept but the other flavors of the fennel and onion weren't really present.

the basil, cheese and tomato pizza was a very strong choice and would be a safe pizza to order if you don't want to take any chances. I am also sad that i passed up on the cauliflower salsa verde pizza.

ambiance is warm and cozy. i don't think i would like to go there with a party larger than 3 and 4 would be really pushing it. we were lucky that there was an open table when we got there because i don' t think the place sits more than 15 comfortably. staff were friendly enough and not imposing. i am glad i got to try this place and the quality does a good job of matching the prices.
author: Leuwam T.

description: I give Pizzetta 5 stars for the experience, not on the proverbial 5 stars for that which is "5 star pizza" or "5 stars for little pizza" for that matter. Although, with an egg on top, who could complain? Think: foggy evening, warm blanket, good friends, a half-bottle of wine, and little pizzas served up with care.
author: Eloy T.

description:
I've never really been a pizza gal. I know, that's kind of weird, but it's just never been my thing. Maybe it's the fact that you typically eat it with your hands, and I like food that requires a fork and knife. Maybe it's the fact that sometimes pizza's bad, and you really don't know until you take a bite. And then you become depressed because your expectations were high and the pizza let you down.

People say that bad pizza is like bad sex--Overall disappointing. I say that bad pizza is worse than bad sex. At least with bad sex you can change up at least your side of it, and occasionally end up with mediocre sex. There's nothing you can do to make bad pizza mediocre. It's just bad pizza. And completely wasted calories.

Pizzetta 211 has made me a convert. I am a pizza gal now (well, at least a Pizzetta gal). When Joe C. and I sat down at one of the little tables outside underneath the heat lamp, I looked at the menu and said, "I can't possibly eat an entire pizza." 

Along with some of his egg/chorizo/guacamole, I ate the entire Margherita pizza. I preferred mine, but his was tasty too. 

They run out of things often, like last night they had no more calzones, and Joe told me once that they ran out of dough on a night he went, but doesn't that just show their authenticity and freshness? 

If you get there and all of their 7 or so tables are occupied, they have plush blankets to wrap you in so you don't shiver while you wait. 

Although to this Potrero Hill gal, California and 23rd Ave. might as well be Egypt, I will be back. And often. Maybe I should move.
author: Rachel F.

description: This place rocks. Pizza is tasty and toppings depends on what's in season. No set menu. A pizza is good for one person. Good selection of local cheeses for appetizers. Not much seating so get there early or can wait. But could be waiting a long time if you go during peak hours. There is outdoor seating with heaters. Can order wine/beer with pizza. Very swanky place. All the cool people go here.
author: SF R.

description:
First, Michael Bauer is a skinny little bitch for not even placing Pizzetta on his "Top 10 Pizzas in the Bay Area" list, because Pizzetta is NUMBER ONE! (Don't argue with me.  Yes I've been to [insert name of your favorite pizzeria here].  I've tried them all.  Pizzetta is better.  Get over it.)

Second, last night they offered an egg/chorizo/guacamole pie that, while not traditionally Italian, may be the single most delicious pizza I've ever tasted in my entire life.  And that says a lot, because I am old.
author: Joe C.

description:
Ask 20 people to name their favorite pizza place in the city and you'll probably get 20 answers. Of course 10 of those people will probably say "There's no good pizza in this city!" Well I beg to differ. 

Tommaso...Pizzeria Delfina...A 16...Nob Hill Cafe...Little Star...hell, you can even get a great breakfast pizza at Rose's or Ottimista. And now I have discovered a pizza that may be at the top of my list - Pizzetta 211.

The place is tiny and in the middle of nowhere (yes, I consider the Richmond the middle of nowhere...hell, dating someone in the sunset would be a long distance relationship for me) but they make some of the best pizza I've had in the city. Fresh ingredients and interesting toppings make for a great pie but what I love most is the crust - thin and slightly blistering and oh so good.

If you're in the mood for some fantastic pizza do yourself a favor and make a road trip out to the Richmond...you won't be sorry. Come hungry, bring cash (no credit cards accepted) and be prepared for a wait but trust me, it'll be worth it.
author: phil h.

description:
I've recently made an executive life decision that if I am going to eat out, it will only be in places with attractive lighting and food that is amazing. Pizzetta 211 meets both of those requirements. It was the perfect spot to go with my very attractive housemate (who also happens to be an excellent cook herself, but you can't come over, so this info is useless to you) and drink a spicy bottle of wine on a cold night. 

The place is tiny and adorable; the food was fantastic (who knew putting an egg on pizza was so good?) & the service was a little bitchy, but you knew how I am into that kind of thing.
author: Maria D.

description:
Great pizza, with an equally great experience.

Such a great little shop, run by such great people.  They make some amazing pizza, no doubt, but Jack and the staff are tip top.  Really friendly, even when in the middle of a crazy lunch rush.

THE PIZZA
Small, thin crust fired in a gas oven.
Inventive combinations of toppings using very fresh ingredients.
Made with care.

PIZZA CRUST
Great crust is seasoned well, but my one little gripe is that the edges of the crust are a little to crackery for my liking (but the rest makes up for it)

DESSERTS
The flourless chocolate cake is pretty good.  The fresh tart they had when we were last there looked amazing (though we didn't try it)

COFFEE
Blue Bottle.  Only serve drip coffee in the mornings.  Espresso drinks only for the rest of the day/night.


THE WAIT
Can be 15 - 30 minutes these days.  They are a lot more popular since Sunset Magazine wrote them up. 

THE TABLES
They're packed pretty tight but not too unreasonable for a small place.  Try grabbing one of the four bar seats and watch them make their tasty little pies.
author: michael l.

description:
"Anyone can fry something. This is an art."
-overheard employee at Pizzetta 211.

Pizzetta 211 has eluded me since I moved to the 'hood. One time we showed up at 8, and they weren't taking any more customers because they close at 9. Another time, we showed up on their off day (Tuesday).
