It's much better than Pizzeria Delfina, the best analogue I can think of right now. That said, though it is similar in style to PD, it comes with less sauce, less headaches and less waiting. It's very small and cozy in here, but the indoor-outdoor seating can fit less than 20 people comfortably.

The goods: tomato, basil and pepperoni pizza was better than most, with a perfectly crispy thin crust. J's pancetta, feta and fennel creation was the best pizza I've had in ages; almost no sauce and minimal cheese. Salad with walnuts and feta is always good. Flourless chocolate cake was delicious. Red wine (a malbec and Sicilian something) complimented the food well.

I'm coming back again and again, no question.
author: Tara R.

description:
Pizzetta is to thin crust what Little Star is to deep dish.  In my opinion, the only two pizza places worthy of 5 stars in the Bay Area.

The wait can be long, as many reviewers mention - no street has seemed colder or more windy on some nights.  It's what has sadly kept me away for a couple of years, because it greatly pains me to watch others eat while my stomach grumbles and complains.  

Problem solved:  we went late on a Saturday afternoon (after 3pm) and were able to snag two seats at the counter.  It's one of the best places to sit, since the staff is almost always present and you get to watch the artistry of the pies being created.

If you have not been there, know that there is some protocol to follow:
- Order at the counter
- Get your own silverware, napkins and glasses of water at the table inside
- Pay cash

I suggest that you order a starter or two as pizzas are made to order and can take some time.  We shared the Artisinal Cheese Salad which is wonderful and generous, and the Roasted Beets Salad, which was a plate full of sunshine-yellow beets with cheese toasts and greens.  

I love the Margherita pizza, but on this day I tried the cheese, rosemary and pine nuts one - to which we added a fried egg on top - terrific!!  What lovely flavors together on the most perfect, perfect crust.  It was heavenly.

For dessert, we splurged and split a piece of the fruit galette of the day, made with raspberries and nectarines.  It's a dessert you can have even if you are full, because the crust is fairly light.  They serve it with a generous dollop of whipped cream, too.  A dessert as homespun and charming as the place itself.  They serve Blue Bottle Coffee, which is an added bonus (although not for the people who are waiting for your table!)

It's all about seasonal ingredients and simplicity here, which I love.  And knowing when to go, which I do (now).
author: Liz S.

description: We stopped over here for lunch before heading out to the Outside Lands Festival and glad we did! We found two bar seats and had one of the best thin crust pizzas in the City! We had the pepperoni pizza with white sardines and a cheese plate to boot. We both had two bottles of scrimshaw beer and it was perfect. We met the staff and they were so personable and friendly. We made friends with the other diners and chopped it up until we had to leave. We also tried their warm peach cobbler and flourless chocolate cake which were sitting right under our noses! I love this place...looking forward to coming back for another foodie adventure!
author: Mika D.

description: Incredible pizza. Thin crust and flavorful, and reasonably priced. Little hole in the wall but great atmosphere, the way a place should be.
author: Ben G.

description:
I like it.
A lovely little place for good pizza.
It is very small place but that is the point .
The size matters.
Not big.
Small.
Small is good.
Small, nice service and a bit romantic.
I do recomend for a couple.
This place, I don't mind to wait.
author: Nobu K.

description:
I remember my very first pizza just like I remember my first kiss, it was completely different from what I expected it to be,  but a few things were for certain--it made me feel good inside and unveiled everything mystical about it.  In essence I give credit to the pizza for opening my world in appreciating Italian food, cheese and that indelible dough done to such crispiness!   The first kiss did not fare as well-- it was the last day of middle school, he was off to go back home to Ireland, leaving me with the solace of his limericks  and the comfort of  Shepherd's Pie.   

So finding a good pizza must bring out that happy sensation and must have the care and effort in making the delicious sauce and crust!  To start off, the ingredients must be fresh, and at Pizzetta's- even Alice Waters would approve of the just picked-out-of-the-backyard freshness in the arugula, tomatoes and yes even the quail eggs!  Dollops of fresh mozzarella cheese- of the buffala kind layered on top of the radiant Roma tomato sauce. The dough was kneaded, hand tossed then flattened to their Neapolitan thinness- to produce those  treasured pockets of crispiness and its unbroken golden brown edges  attesting to its baked ripeness.  

The place is small yet cozy with a rustic countryside feel to it.  I found that the best place to sit is by the kitchen- giving you a bird's eye view of the pizza preparation and access to the cheese and Italian books on the ledge. Pizza menu changes according to the season's offerings-  Pizza w/ arugula, caramelized onions and quail egg; or the Prosciutto and arugula were my favorites.  Their chocolate cake was rich with just enough creme anglaise to balance that decadent cocoa taste. The pizzetta experience delivers with 4.5 shining yelp stars enough to curl anyone's toes.
 
PS-  It's no wonder why Italians express their approval for something extraordinary--by kissing the tips of their gathered fingers (as if the lips of of another )- and  in a grand gesture, throw it up in the air and say,  "Molto Bene!"  Sooo- when I find these two things together- how sublime can that be... ;-)
author: Arissa C.

description: Great neighborhood spot. It's tiny but the food is delicious and the staff was great.  Really enjoyed the pizzas and the environment.
author: Dilly M.

description:
Pizzetta is a really tiny restaurant -- we're talking no more than 6-7 tables. There's a wait, and for good reason: it's small and exciting.

We ordered the anchovy pizza and egg/sausage pizza, preceded by a fresh green salad.The salad came first. It was organic greens mixed with olive oil and nothing else. It was pretty plain.

When the pizza finally arrived, we were happy. The anchovy pizza tasted like very fresh thin crust pizza with a delicious salty anchovy bite in each slice. The egg/sausage pizza tasted like this: Pretend you ate a sausage/hash brown/sunny side up egg breakfast, and you ate it messy. The juices left over are what you soak up with a slice of buttered toast. You get the picture because it tastes just like that.

All in all, it's hard to rate this place w/o going numerous times are the menu changes. The pizza was pretty good, the atmosphere was really cozy, and service was excellent. 

I'll definitely be back.
author: Jason C.

description:
Ugh. I guess that's why they call these "opinions".... We wondered what all the HYPE was about this place and tried it about a month ago. After a tired day of work, we called in our order and picked it up. ONLY to realise that we totally got 2 wrong pizzas (completely wrong, not even close- we ordered meaty pizzas but got vegetarian) but we were so tired and feeling pretty lazy, and we had a movie on demand, we just ate them anyway. 

Well, about 30 minutes later, one of us gets reaaaaly sick and ends up in the ER- allergy to Pine Nuts, which clearly we did NOT order but we had eaten anyway. $220 and a $25 copay on the epi-pen later, i guess we learned that he is allergic to pine nuts.. we'll NEVER be going there again!!! 

Stay away from the hype, stick with the better pizzas in the neighborhood- Gaspare's and Georgio's.
author: M'ia K.

description: Great establishment tucked right into the neighborhood.  A real gem with the ability to invoke thoughts of Europe as one approaches at night.  Service as just as you would want it to be for such a small space.  The food is outstanding and the wine list very good.  Overall a real treat for the Richmond District.
author: jd h.

description:
FIRST TIME I EVER GOT A TABLE HERE!! Normally, this tiny place is packed and the wait for a table is insane, so I don't even bother.  But, I guess we finally came at the right time.  We waited only about 15 minutes before we were seated.

The food here is awesome.  We ordered pizza with curried cauliflower and grapes.  Sounds weird, but they totally pulled it off.   We also split a calzone, which was very tasty.  

This place is worth the wait.
author: Starla D.

description: I ate here a couple years ago while visiting SF and loved it. I couldn't resist coming back again this trip. I regret nothing. Probably my favorite pizza in the world.
author: Ethan F.

description:
Whenever my friends try to introduce me to a new pizza place, I am always a little skeptical. I know it's not a good attitude to begin with. You can call me a pizza snob. 

Another reason why I was unsure about this place is because we were a party of 5. Please believe yelpers when they say this place is T-I-N-Y. However, you could probably fit 100 of me in there. :) I suggest visiting with a max of 4 people. 

The pizza was delicious and innovative. I must have tried everyone's pizza. Maybe that's rude but I don't care. I'm a monster when it comes to pizza. The topping that stood out to me was the one with the egg on top. Not my favorite but definitely confused my taste buds in a good way. 

A unique factor that I liked about this place is that when you are inside you feel like you are in the kitchen. Kind of like when it's Thanksgiving/Christmas/Hannukah/etc. and everyone is hanging around the kitchen waiting for the fresh food to come off the stove/out of the oven. 

There is outdoor seating. If you get cold, there are heating lamps overhead, as well as blankets. All in all, a very pleasing experience.
author: Ileana H.

description:
I braced myself for the snobby service we'd receive, but it was all for nothing.  Granted, the service in general wasn't overly friendly (not to mention, they were skimpy with the bread after having to request it)--they're more straight and to the point, but it's the typical grunge you'd expect from a good pizza parlor.  

The field greens salad was very simple, a small bed of greens that was barely enough for two.  I highly enjoyed the squash pizza; it was light, yet still filling.  The rosemary and pine nuts had a nice roasted taste, but was too cheesy for my liking.  Do leave room for dessert; I doubt you can go wrong with any of them.  The flourless cake was a hit.  

I had read how tiny this place was, but didn't realize just how much it was until I got there.  Only a half hour after they had opened, and all the seats inside were already taken.  Luckily, there wasn't much of a wait for a table, but I can't imagine trying to eat there at 7 p.m. on a Friday night.  Note their hours and try to get their as early as possible.  The menu is small, but rotates weekly.  Also, don't miss the funky lil monitor in the W.C., possibly the most random item I've seen to decorate a restaurant bathroom.

It's undoubtedly a neighborhood joint--certainly not worth the cross-town trip, but an excellent choice for those in the area, and a worthy rival to Gialina's.
author: Marsha Z.

description: Super cute, neighborhood pizza joint.  Very creative and gourmet personal pizzas - menu is constantly changing.  I really enjoyed the butternut squash pizza - it was actually a sweet pizza with sugar and cinnamon.  So unique and made the perfect desert!  Their classic margarita is delicious as well!
author: Anna V.

description:
Who knew sunny side up eggs on pizza would be so tasty?

This place is super tiny and the wait is about 20 minutes.  But you can order a glass of wine and sit outside near the tree.  Sit at the bar and entertain yourself by their pizza making skills.  Have your mouth water with the homemade fresh desserts displayed on the bar.  If you're low on cash, this is a cuuuuute place to take your date (make sure it's not a first date).
author: Nezza F.

description:
I have a public confession: I have fallen in love with someone else, someone other than my girlfriend.

Her name is Pizzetta 211, and she's amazing. Let me tell you about her, so you'll see why.

I love simplicity, and the operations at this tiny neighborhood pizzeria are threadbare. The menu has four pizzas, one calzone, two salads, and three desserts. A couple of the pizzas have the option of various meats or cheeses.

The flipside of the menu had a drink list. Something like four whites, one rosé, and three reds.

Tara went traditional, and I went out on a limb. We did this sort of on purpose, to test the place. They passed with flying colors. Their tomato, mozzarella, and basil (we added pepperoni) was solid, and the basil came in near-pesto form (wet).

My pizzetta had red onion, olive, goat cheese, Tuscan salami, and fennel. The fennel part is what scared me, but to my astonishment, it was quite delicious.

Service is bare-bones, too, and I like that. A lot.

The place is charming for a small group of friends, and romantic for a couple.

What more could you ask for?
author: Jeff H.

description:
My experience with Pizza: 1) I'm from New York 2) I've eaten the "world's best pizza" by default; a pizzeria in Fondi, Italy that has won best Pizza in Italy's nat'l competitions many times in the past several years.

On a trip to Italy I found out that restaurants don't open until 8pm? Apparently it's because most people work until 7pm & between that one hour of work & eating, they go home, get changed, get drinks, have some appertivo. As an American, it was quite shocking for me to be told that I was not able to have dinner at 6pm. I mention this because... some people just do it differently.

You are most likely trying to figure out whether or not you should try Pizzetta 211. It's so unclear!  The reviews are on both sides of the spectrum. Ask yourself, "What do I want?"

Types of Pizza: Neapolitan Pizza: the "world's best pizza" is Neapolitan. It is considered traditional Italian pizza made from local ingredients & with a thin crust that poofs up when baked. Most Americans have never had authentic Neapolitan pizza. New York pizza is like an oversized Neapolitan fit for our oversized American appetites. Most Americans associate "pizza" with this style.

Thin crust pizza: typical to Northern Italy. Having thinner dough, the pizza supports less ingredients than some other types; smaller, usually serving 1 per pie.

Lazio/Roman style: Thin crust pizzas but the crust is harder & made/served in large cut squares. I haven't seen this type of Pizza served in SF.

Sicilian Style: Also large squares. An authentic Sicilian pizza is not served with cheese. The crust is more like bread with sauce & toppings. It's pretty much saucy bread.

Chicago Deep Dish Style: You all know what this is.  Point being, there are many types of pizzas!

WHAT YOU WANT & NEED TO KNOW.

FOOD:
Pizzetta 211 serves thin crust pizzas. Don't make the mistake of expecting New York or American style pizza. They use local & organic ingredients which is reflected in their menu. While there are a few staple pizzas on the menu (margherita (see pictures), white cheese & pine nuts, one with an egg on it), the rest of the pizzas (about 2! read: small menu) and their starters changes almost weekly depending on what ingredients they can get.

211 has great N.Italian styled Pizza. Fresh ingredients come through in their dishes.  The sizes of dishes are "European." If you are a hungry-man capable of ungodly damage at the local buffet, you may leave severely disappointed. Furthermore, if you're disappointed, the prices will just make you madder. $10-15 for just a pizza. $30 for a pizza, starter, & dessert (also great). $40-50 for a pizza, starter, wine, dessert, espresso. Know what you're getting into & be ok with spending that much.

SERVICE
Nothing special.  In the six times I have been to 211, I have not had any issues with service nor have I been witness to any service issues. 211 has a sitting policy. If your entire party is not present, they will not seat you. The location is cramp & they realize that there are sometimes long waits.  As such, they need to get bodies in & out as fast as they can. One reviewer sourly noted that she was unable to join some friends at a table. I would rebut that single addition would hold the table up for an additional 30 minutes if they were already eating. If you go during peak hours, expect to wait. If there is a line MAKE SURE YOU ARE ON THE WAIT LIST. Again, if your entire party is not present when called, you will not be seated & your turn will be skipped.  211 is indeed cramp & such policies are out of necessity. If you want to argue with them, I guarantee you, you're just causing trouble for everyone.

When you are seated, know that you have to ORDER AT THE COUNTER. Water, utensils, napkins are all SELF SERVICED. They are located on a small table to the left of the counter/bar. If you are immensely bothered by these things, don't go. They aren't paid to put up with you. Just tip accordingly. Again, they just do it differently.

Judge for yourself; this might not be for you.

DON'T GO IF
. you are tight one money.
. you can't adapt to different situations: mmaybe don't go. Their policies may drive you bonkers.
. you "don't understand" "fancy food" you might consider the meal "ok" & feel swindled.

If you have an enormous & voracious appetite: don't go unless you are both rich & willing to spend.

GO IF
. you like healthy eating
. you'd like to try a different type of pizza
. you don't mind spending extra money for a decent meal

I recommend going on a weekend in the afternoon. If you go for lunch or dinner, you're likely to run into lines. If you go at night, they may be out of pizza dough (only 120 made per day).

I don't recommend ordering to-go/delivery (unavailable on weekends).
author: Nat L.

description:
In my never ending quest of good thin crust pizza, this place has been hit so many times, I just had to try it.

I met a friend or dinner and both of us made the trek across town for some good pizza.  This place is SMALL ... as in only four tables inside, four outside, and a few counter seats.  I didn't know just how small it was until I got there.  The menu rotates on what I think is a weekly basis.  I decided on the Rosemary, Cheese and Pine Nut pizza.  My friend had the Summer Squash, (I think that was it.)  A Margherita was available, and since my friend assumed I would order that, I ordered the Cheese and Pine Nut pizza.  :-)

We had a mixed green salad, and it was plain, and average.  It needed a little boost.  Small enough for one.

My pizza was OK.  A bit dry, but a lot of cheese.  I love pine nuts and the nuts give the pizza a nice toasted flavor.  But like I said, a bit dry.  My friend's pizza was even better than mine, with squash, chives maybe, and dollops of ricotta.  Very good.  Don't get attached to the some of the pizza's, because in a week, they could be gone.  They change toppings as the become available or by season.

The Scharffen Berger Flourless Cake was very good, served with some whipped cream.  The espresso was said to be Blue Bottle, but I'm not sure.  I had a latte and it was quite good ... just as good as Cafe Bello.

Service is marginal, and you have to get your own napkins and utensils.  Getting bread was a bit of challenge.  Hours are kind of funky ... closed on Tuesday, and opens around "noonish" on the rest of the week.  Open only for dinner on Monday.  I was expecting to wait a while, even though we got there at 5:30, but it wasn't too bad.

We did have the LAST full bottle of a pretty good bottle of a red called Bellesio Cannonau.  You won't be able to get it again, because we got the last bottle, and they opened the remaining bottle for a few glasses.  Once that's gone, that's it!  Just had to rub that last part in.

While not a destination for me, I don't see myself going back.  It's one of those things where I don't get the hype.  I'll stick with Gialina for thin crust and Little Star when I want a hearty slice.
author: Michael M.

description: I've been wanting to try this place for a while, since I live close by, and we're always looking for a good pizza place to replace Organismica because I refuse to go there, but that's another review. We had the farm egg and san marzano pizza. Good flavors, but the dough on the farm egg would fall apart on me. My boyfriend was able to fold his in half. Personally I like eating pizza that I can hold. I almost wanted to grab a knife and fork! That's just bonkers! Overall, I'd eat the farm egg for breakfast. It just wasn't appealing to my dinner palate, and the the san marzano had tomato paste overload, though, the arugula was very fresh and tasty. In fact, all the ingredients were. Pizzas were expensive, $32 big ones for 2 personal pizzas that left us feeling hungry...Maybe I'll be back but not anytime soon...
author: Lotus L.

description:
It's simple: THE best pizza in town. Period.

What about Little Star, you ask? Two words: little star. Yes, compared to this place, I give LS ONE LITTLE star. 

(As if having utterly delicious pizza with the bestest most perfectest crust wasn't enough, the atmosphere at Pizzetta 211 couldn't be cozier. If it weren't for the foggy Richmond, I'd swear I was tucked away in some warm, delicious nook in the Tuscan countryside.)
author: Shannon R.

description:
I went back to Pizzetta 211 last night to give it a second chance. I had been so underwhelmed the last time I went that I decided to try it again (plus, the 40 minute wait at Delfina was just too much for us to deal with on  a week night). 

We called to see what the wait time was like or if there were tables available and the woman on the phone was really not pleasant. 

When I arrived I asked if there was a waiting list and was told yes and I asked to be put next on the waiting list. The host was gracious and gave me a menu too look at while I waited in case I wanted to order  a drink. At no point did he say that they only seated complete parties or give me an estimate of how long he thought it would before a table became available. Also, at no point during my over 10 minute wait outside in the not-so-warm foggy night did the host peak his head out the door to ask if I had decided on a drink while I was waiting. 

As parking is always miserable in that neighborhood, my bf was looking for parking and right as he pulled up to an available spot right outside of the restaurant the spot was snagged by two clueless hippies in a blue vanagon. Of course, they immediately strolled into the restaurant saying "Oh hey, look, how lucky, there's a table available!" and the host proceeded to seat them. As I'd been standing outside in the freezing cold for the past ten minutes, I walked back into the restaurant and politely asked the host why the available table was being given to a party ahead of us if we'd put our name on the waiting list first. He proceeded to politely, with a hint of annoyance and condescension, explain that they didn't seat incomplete parties due to the small size of their locale. Yeah thanks. 

Mind you, at that very moment a party was leaving their table and all he had to do was say "a party has just left their table and when I bus it shortly it will be available." No. He was not accommodating at all. 

Past that, while browsing the menu and the wine list as I sat outside in the freezing cold waiting for a table, the menu and wine list still underwhelmed me. The service last night, however, sealed the coffin.
author: Dee I.

description:
I regret giving Pizzetta a positive review for fear that the wait will get even longer.  Pizzetta is a cozy restaurant tucked away in Outer Richmond of all places and offers some of SF's best pizza (certainly rivals Delfina for top nod).  The menu changes every week, but you can always count on some inventive creations.  Last night I had a pizza with fontina, speck, asparagus and two over-easy eggs.  Yes, it's fancy-pants pizza - not a place to just grab a slice - but fortunately not too pretentious, in part thanks to its Richmond location.  The salads are good, as are the desserts.  Last night they offered a flourless chocolate cake and a light olive oil cake with blood orange compote and whipped cream.

The only bummer is that I've had to wait a while outside each time I've been.  The wait is easier with the blankets they provide and wine you can order.  I often bond with the other waiting customers but end up feeling like an orphan in Cider House Rules when they get a table first: I'm happy they've found a home, but mostly just jealous and hoping this means my chances of being selected increase with their absence.
author: Jamie Y.

description:
the paunchy rude guy that 'welcomed' us as we entered should have been a sign to turn right around and leave.  And, he was a double a**hole cuz he was rude when we paid the bill too!

the pizza was OK.  I'm not sure what the hype is about.  The pizza's, yes, are paper thin.  Sure, OK.  Whatever.  The first bite of the pizza as it came out of the oven was *almost* enough to make me forget the 40 minute wait time from ordering to delivery.  The pizza cooled so fast that by the time I got to a second piece the pizza was now more like cheese and crackers. 

Oh, this was awesome too.  It took 40 minutes to get our crackers, and it took 10 minutes for the guy who ordered after us to get his. 

Definitely definitely not worth $33 for two meatless pizzas and one glass of wine.
author: Jackie D.

description:
After a curious episode wherein I experienced piercing, stabbing pains in my stomach bad enough to double me up (no - not my heart - that measures up perfectly), called Kaiser, booked an appointment and went there early, waited for an hour, only to have the inexplicable 9-out-of-10 pain points pain suddenly subside just 10 minutes before meeting with the very sympathetic and understanding doctor, I found my self feeling like I had dodged a bullet and craving.... pizza.... and beer.

The Missus remembered this place "Pizzetta 911" or some such out in the land of the fog-that-turns-people-inside-out. A quick search on the wonderful mobile.yelp.com, and we had located and mapped the pizzeria just 25 blocks to the left through the fog-that-turns-people-inside-out. Undeterred, and after only three or four turns around the block, we found parking and found our restaurant.

This is a very casual, teenie-tiny,down-to-earth quality pizza dive. After a short wait, we were taken to our table, informed of  the specials and that we should come to the end of the bar to order - but after ordering, the rest of the service was at the table and very good.

The asparagus special and the green salad were only mediocre, and I would skip them next time, but the stuff you come here for is the pizza. We had Margarita with arugula and marscarpone which was quite excellent  and worth the return visit - especially if you find yourself in the fog-that-turns-people-inside-out. 

But the other reason to risk the fog-that-turns-people-inside-out is the cake - the flourless chocolate cake which looked so good (the couple next to us order a piece to share and then ordered another!) and the olive-oil-cake-with-blood-orange-and whipped-cream which was just fantastic. You should skip the starters and try all the deserts you can handle!

Wash it all down with a bottle of Chimay and surprisingly good espresso and it's just what the doctor ordered. Ha!
author: Kingpin X.

description: Loved the farm egg pizza and an interesting beer selection. Just what we were looking for.
author: Marit C.

description:
I love this place for the neighborhood feel and the ever changing menu incorporating fresh and seasonal ingredients.  They've got to be the king of thin crust pizza.  It's not just thin, it's paper thin!

The prices for a pizza are fair, but it's hard to fill up on just one pizza.  Great place for a snack or light meal, not if you're starvin' like marvin. 
I've been wanting to try some of their more daring offerings like the pie with served with a raw egg, but I always end up ordering something ordinary like the margherita.  

I'm a creature of habit!
author: Eric W.

description:
The staff is rude.  The pizza is overpriced.  
I can't wait for this place to close down and get the stink outta my 'hood.
author: Mike M.

description:
Pizzetta by the numbers!

This is the number one place I've found in San Francisco for thin crust pizza outside of Roy H.'s house [http://roy.yelp.com/]! One pizzetta per person is usually enough, but if you want to sample more, stagger your order. You'll probably hear groans from the people waiting outside for your table, but that way your second pizza won't get cold by the time you get to it.

There are two tables outside. I avoid them unless it's an absolutely beautiful and warm evening. Cold wind and thin pizzas don't mix. Even if you are OK with the heat lamps and a little wine in you, the pizzette won't be. Unless you eat really fast, but why should you feed like that? If you won't do it for yourself, do it for the pizzette!

Three is the right number of diners for pizzetta. Three people you can fit at any of the four tables inside and in a pinch, at the counter. You could squeeze four people into the two window tables, but you'd be, ahem, squeezed. Three people can also share easily as the pizzette are cut into six slices, which is the lowest common denominator for two or three diners. It gets dicey when you have four people eyeing six slices, if you know what I mean.

Four is the radius of blocks you'll need to extend you parking search. Expect to spend at least half an hour or more looking for street parking, unless you are really lucky (I'm too cheap to pay for lots! I'd rather walk three blocks, work up an appetite and spend the money on dessert.).

Five o'clock is when I usually start craving pizzetta and we start to make our way down Geary Blvd.. It takes a long time to park (see number four) and we usually don't get there for the first seating, so that means we get to eat around seven.

Six is the number of white anchovies you can get on my favorite item on the menu, the margherita. I like normal anchovies, the salty ones, but these aren't like that. They are marinated and slightly larger and add a tang to the pizza rather than saltiness. You might like them even if you don't like anchovies.

Seven is the number of things I'll squeeze into this line before I get back to work: 1) They usually have three or four wine bottles open, 2) it's mostly self serve (you get your own water and silverware, easy on the napkins, you pay at the cashier after your meal), 3) it is on the pricey side, but the ingredients are top notch, 4) service is fine, maybe not friendly, but definitely not rude, 5) sit at the counter at least once to check out how they work, 6) the desserts don't really inspire, and 7) people, please, when you come in to check how long the wait is, close the door behind you, it's freezing out there, think of the pizzette, they are getting cold...
author: Mister X.

description:
I read all the reviews and basically showed up thinking I'd have to wait a trillion minutes for a table but no. . .

It all started with the sunset.  See review below.  Perfection.  Then the parking a half block away from the restaurant.   Okay yes, a couple laps were done around the block but it was nothing.  Then walk up to the restaurant which, by the way is packed, and look here, two seats right at the bar.  Voila!  

The host guy with the cool glasses was really nice, and chatted with us.  The server/prep girl gave us cute smiles too.  

So far I'm loving this place.

Then came the menu!  Leker!  I'm a fan of thin crust crispy pizza and this place does it well.  Ordered the fancy cheese salad, and then a pizza with pancetta, figs, and gorgonzola!  Flourless chocolate cake with fresh creme and two espresso's via Blue Bottle Coffee.   

Wait a minute. . .I didn't even mention the bathroom!  The bathroom was like stepping into a very cool lounge in Budapest that plays groovy drum and bass.  Random but it works.

While we're eating, Stanlee Gatti walks in to order food.  Hilarious.   

This is my kind of place.  Cozy and great food.  This place is very gazellig.  

Yum yum yum yum yum yum yum.  Seven yums for Pizzetta 221.   I'll be back and soon, I've got to try a pizza with egg on top.  Crazy Yum!
author: James M.

description:
FABULOUS pizza.  And yeah, it's the fancy-schmancy kind.  So if you're a Round Table purist or *gasp* Dominos or similar, then maybe you won't like the pizza here.  Don't get me wrong, I grew up with Round Table and it has a special place in my heart.  But this is another category all together.  They usually have two or three daily specials, which depend on what local, fresh ingredients they can get that day.  Every pizza I've had here was just so good.  And their farmers salad, with fresh greens, a couple of rustic cheeses, some olives, dates, and walnuts...this is my fav pizza in the city.  Outstanding!

...plus, I think the Pizzetta lady lives in my neighborhood, and every time I see her I want to tell her how awesome the pizza is.  Would that seem too stalker-ish?  I can't decide.
author: Leslie R.

description:
I've been dying to try this quaint, neighborhood restaurant and the last time I attempted they were closed for "Indian Summer Vacation".  A couple of girlfriends & I went last night, it was their 1st night returning from their vacation.  We waited about 15 min at 6:30pm to sit indoors at a table.  Each of us ordered our own pizzas, and the best was the Margherita - which my friend always orders because it's staple on their menu and she can never go wrong w/ this choice.  I love the thin crust (although I'm a crush person), the sauce was delicious, and I liked that there was not a lot of cheese, plus I love how they drizzle basil atop.  I had the butternut squash pizza which was pretty good, no sauce with crumbles of ricotta cheese.  We all shared the flourless chocolate cake - it was ok, probably could've passed since I was already full.   

They're closed Monday & Tuesdays.  And don't forget to hit the ATM before - cash only*
author: Meredith K.

description: Not for everyone. But I like high quality pizza with an emphasis on fresh ingredients of the season and generally with only a few key items on the pizza so I can taste all of the flavorings. This place does it for me. The price is in line with pizza restaurants of this category. The Farm Egg on any of their pizzas are golden for my taste. I highly recommend Pizzetta 211 for a change to your local commercial pizza joint. These guys are top notch at what they produce inside a small restaurant.
author: Dinah Y.

description:
Almost don't want to add another review as this place is great but so tiny. I used to go when I lived out by the Cliff House. 

Its super duper tiny, and as noted by others they can/do run out of items. 

These people care about what they make, and I have never had anything out of their kitchens that wasn't awesome.
author: William A.

description:
Went back the other day for another delicious pizza, this time with sorrel pesto, heirloom tomatoes, and ricotta. I've never had ricotta on a pizza (much less sorrel), and oh my god is it good. Plus, my friend ordered a calzone (it turns out that they don't make them if they don't think their dough is behaving properly), which, though simple, was also incredibly tasty.

Oh, and don't forget: it's cash only.
author: Katie I.

description: it was my first time here .afriend recomended it ...i never had a fresh pizza as the one here for sure its a 5 stars pizza ..grate job
author: Marwan I.

description:
This is like the soup nazi of pizza places. The food is tremendous. The atmosphere it intimate. This is my favorites pizza in the city.

But you gotta remember to prep before entering:
- Remember to bring cash
- You can't usually put your name on the list without everyone in the party being there 
- It's not always open and sometimes closes early
- You can't always get take out
- You have to get your own silverware (yeah you fatty)

These are little details that most people will be able to see past. Otherwise, no pizza for you!

One other tip, order the flourless chocolate cake for desert. You will not be disappointed.
author: Nick M.

description:
I have walked past this place for six months and each time I thought "that looks cool, we should try it sometime." Last night my roommate and I finally took the plunge and I am hating myself for wasting 6 months of life without the most amazing pizza ever. 

No seriously-- it's to die for-- like, I'd kill you for a free pie. 

It's one of the smallest restaurants in the city, sandwiched between an apartment and store on each side. There is a tree directly in front of Pizzetta with lights dangling from the branches. Under the tree are some benches, chairs and a box full of blankets. You'll probably have to wait for a table so they provide you with warmth as you sit outside during a typical chilly Outer Richmond evening. 

The inside and outside each have four tables (and the outside ones have heat lamps directly above them). The inside also has one of the coolest bathrooms in town... if you're a guy, enjoy the video on the tv above the toilet as you use the loo. The entire interior is no larger than a loft apartment. It has a few ovens for a pizza, a counter to make the food, a small bar, a table where the water and silverware are kept (you get them yourself), and 4 tables against the walls and windows. 

Now decor will only get you so far in my book; you need the food to back it up. And man, this place delivers. They have 5 pizzas each week- 3 that are different depending on the week, 2 that are always available. We each got the same one that had arugula, cheese, baby tomatoes and summer squash. The pizzas are about $13 and individual-sized. Before you take your first bite, appreciate what's been placed in front of you. This isn't just a mass produced pizza that has toppings thrown on it sporadically; it's a work of art. Each vegetable has been placed carefully on the dough in such a way that resembles a beautiful combination of strategy and creativity. The crust is thin and perfectly crunchy. If you're like me and need some kick, hot pepper flakes are readily available.  

We went to a friend's party afterward and couldn't stop telling people about how great our dinner was. This place is perfect for small moments in your life: first or second dates, parents visiting from out-of-town, relaxing with a friend after a hectic day of work, or just when you're in the mood for some of the best pizza this city has to offer.
author: Jared S.

description:
Why is the best pizza I've found in the city also the farthest from my house?  (I guess the bigger question is, why can't I afford a car to get me there? Don't work in advertising if you want the big bucks, people).

I have this thing against taking the bus on the weekend.  I will make two exceptions: the 12 to the Ferry Building farmer's market and the 1 out to Pizzetta 211.  But only on a Saturday/Sunday super early evening or late afternoon cause otherwise long wait + long bus ride = death.

This is great pizza.  Well, if you like ultra thin-crusted, delicately topped, ultra-seasonal Chez Panisse-style pizza.   If you like a sloppy grease-soaked hangover-killer go to Golden Boy or something.  

My most memorable pizza here had a little pesto and ricotta and was topped with a sunny side up egg.  The very farmers-markety ingredients were top notch.  Other standout from that meal was a definitive apricot tart: perfectly buttery crust, perfect apricots, perfect creme fraiche on the side.  And they have Blue Bottle coffee - how can you beat that?

Basically the menu is tiny - only 6 or 7 pizzas that change frequently, plus a few salads, a cheese plate, one non-bread/cheese starter (last it was some type of fritatta), and maybe two desserts.  But because every choice is delicious, there needn't be more.
author: Melissa B.

description:
oooh pizzetta.....crispity organicy orgasmolicious pizzetta...ok, i gotta say I'm a bit biased, but this place is ridiculously cute (please see my prior review from la med ...small=cute). 

The pizza here is southern italian style- crispy but tasty crust, and crazy topping you've (or at least i've) never heard of. For instance- last night i had a pizza with Mache'- WTF is Mache' you asked? well, so did i. its some crazy kind lettuce, but more whacky. Kinda like that hippy aunt you have on your crazy mom's side of the family. Don't question it, just go with me on this one.

Their cheese salad is insanely tasty, and the tables they have on the sidewalk are great for a chill sunday afternoon beer. mmm....beer and pizzetta...its tasty, and a lot cheaper than a plane ride to Cinque Terre.
author: Tim V.

description:
Best pizza in SF hands down.  The menu changes often and incorporates seasonal veggies.  This restaurant gives people a reason to live in the Richmond.  The only drawback is the long wait to get a table.  

No take away on Sundays.
author: Rob U.

description:
Very delicious house made foods. But the portions are rather small - which is cruel considering how mouth-watering their pizzas, salads, apps, desserts and coffees are.
They really get into the *artisanal* approach to cuisine. One of the best things I had there was a pluot tart that was outah this world.
Either bring a stuffed wallet or a stuffed belly before visiting Pizzetta, 'cause the food goes quickly off these tables!
author: Nigel F.

description:
Pizzetta wins for me everytime. I think it is hands down the best in it's class.  Ingredients are often fresh from the farmer's market, and there is always something interesting on the menu.  Some of my favorite pizza toppings have been things such as chorizo and egg, fiorelli, garlic scapes, herbed ricotta.  The Poussin on monday nights is out of this world, laid on top of bread which sops up all the delicious juice, and accompanied by the most beautiful and perfectly dressed salad.  The Blue Bottle Cappucinos are the best i've had at a restaurant, and i love love love the saffron biscotti.  Last time i was there i had a goat cheese and fig tart for dessert which was excellent.
And finally, the godsend for me since i have to sit outside if it is available, the heat lamps.
author: sarah C.

description:
Yum, Yum, YUMMMMMMMMMMMY!!!!!!  What a delectable little spot this is!  I had read all of the great reviews on this place and was really excited to try it.  I drove by a few times and it was always packed and there was never parking, but I was not discouraged....it called to me....... I just kept trying and it finally worked out.  

I must say I was impressed and that it was worth the wait.  We sat at the bar and got to watch the pizza girl make and bake all of the pizzas from scratch.  Fresh, seasonal ingredients with very thin crust made for unique flavor combinations that were delicate yet impressive.  I loved it because it was different than any other pizza place I'm used to going to.  It wasn't a grease puddle pie.  Some thought, some love, some passion goes into the food here and you just can't ask for anything more than that in my book.

The pizzas are meant to order individually.  They are pretty light so a salad or another appetizer might help to better fill your tummy.  But then again, it might leave you room for one of their seriously alluring desserts.  I admit I didn't try one but I had dreams about the cake w/berries that I stared at all night.  I can't wait to go back and if you haven't tried it I think you should.  Just not when I'm going.  :)
author: J L.

description:
Very thin crust, excellent eclectic fresh toppings.
Expensive, but keep in mind that it's all local/organic, etc and then you realize it's probably worth it.
Tiny seating area and an even tinier kitchen - so expect a delay. It's the nature of the place, so take it in stride or don't eat there.
I found the service to be adequate. 
I really enjoyed the tiny video screen and cool music playing in the bathroom.
author: Miles T.

description:
I love this place!
Food is great!!
But...service could be better. My waitress literally did not wait 2 seconds to take my plate away and never asked me if I needed something or if my food was ok...poor service. My boyfriend and I love going there, we had great service before.
Servers need to understand that when people go out, they want to be served, that is why we go out, otherwise we cook at home...
author: Maria Loreto R.

description:
Delicious pizza, charming little space (emphasis on little) and zero hospitality. Rude rude rude rude. Not just to me, but to my friend's mother. - "Sorry you're cold, we have to leave to door open or the chef gets hot."
- "Sorry, but you can't put a chair there or you'll block those people. Never mind if those people don't care."
- "Sorry, we can't put your pizza back in the oven and cook it a little more."
- "You can get water for yourself over there."

One of the pizzas was delicious - the potato one. The others were tasty but not worth the ignominity we were forced to endure.
author: sarah l.

description:
This is one of the most unexpected, special places that just makes me smile and thank god I live in this fine city.

Thin crust pizza, which I was raised on, charm and warmth, which I grew up on, and friendly service - which I highly value.

The other reviews get into it, the place is small, expect to wait - the seasonal varieties are great but so is the margarita. I am a big pizza fan, and I probably go for plain margarita 9/10 times but this pace does have some delightful choice. Great informal date spot, romantico.
author: Mick M.

description: Intimate Atmosphere, Delicious, High Quality Hand-crafted pizzettas.  Casually knowledgeable, and personable staff.  Wine while you wait for one of the 6 or so tables or bar stools, outdoor heated seating.  Amazing.  Menu changes weekly, so there's always an excuse to go back. Yum.
author: Stuart H.

description:
What's with all the sass bud? And where's my food?

This pizza might actually be pretty good, but I seriously doubt it. 
Unfortunately I will never get the chance to find out as I will never eat here. The guy making the pizza here is a real A-hole, and whoever is answering the phones has no idea what it is they actually do. I could have called Krave Hair & Beauty down the block and placed my pizza order and ended up with the same thing I got from these people, but probably with a little less attitude... and maybe with a few hair products thrown in. I digress, as far as I'm concerned this place is dead to me. 

This place needs to fade away, we could use the space for a Starbucks.
author: matt l.

description:
When you just feel like getting the hell out of Hipsterville....this seemingly nowhere-in-particular place is an intimate 10+/-person micro-restaurant, serving great thin crust pizzas (as close to authentic italian pizza as I've had in SF, though, incidentally, not run by italians).  The menu is simple, but offers a fresh and inviting selection of greens, artisan cheeses and wines/beer.  The portions are personal sized, but big enough if you just want a nosh with a friend. The wines are slightly overpriced for what they are, but good. The prices are very reasonable at about $7-11 a pizza. The service can be a little wanting and slightly gruff (i.e. soup nazi's kinder and gentler younger brother) but the food is worth the wait (ordered one of each pizza, wasn't a fan of the egg pizza, but others at the table liked it). 

However, the best kept secret....is all about the restroom. If you hadn't already excused yourself from the table or stood in line, you begin to wonder..."Was it something they ate?" What's inside this tiny gloss-red toilet nook is wholly unexpected and charming. You can't seem to take your eyes off it and end up being in there for longer than seems socially comfortable: a miniature theatre video installation ala janet cardiff  with small stage, velvet curtains, and 7ish min. video loop with soundtrack.
author: rebecca z.

description:
Look. The place is small. TEENY tiny. You might not even find if if you go out lookin' for it. It's like a micro-restaurant or something.

But because it's little, they have no freezer. Everything on your plate came in *that* day and was maybe in the ground still that morning's how fresh. No joke. 

The food's GOOD. Little obscure cheeses on a board with olives an' stuff.  Total foodie geek-out for about $30 after pizza, drinks and an appetizer.. They buy almost all organic and usually local, which means different pizzas on different days depending on what's good that day or if it rained last night in Cupertino or not... 

We went this past Monday, and didn't wait longer than twenty minutes.. There's seating outside under a tree with little windchimes way overhead.. Besides, if you can't handle the wait, go to the bathroom and watch a movie! (Seriously. It's that cute.)

Oh! Also, the staff was really down to earth and helpful and friendly.. And really into what they were serving, too.. which is always fun. I'm going again for sure.
author: Missy B.

description:
Recently enjoyed take-out from this apparently charming and cozy (I didn't actually make it inside the door) pizza place in the Outer Richmond.  The pizzas feature innovative and unusual combinations of ingredients - we had the poached egg pizza (sounds weird, but actually it's scrumptious - sort of an Italian version of a Croque Madame), a special featuring cauliflower and bread crumbs, and another with rosemary and pine nuts (the great thing about the thin crusts and light cheese is that you get to eat a lot of pieces!).  More like what you get in Rome than what you get at Little Star - don't go here looking for oozing cheese or pounds of meaty toppings.

Totally delicious, can't wait to go back.  Five stars based on food since I haven't actually been there, but I hear the ambience is nice too!
author: Katy M.

description:
Yeah!! This place is terrible. Don't even think about going here!! And their Pizza??...I'm sure you'd be better off going to North Beach (Brazilian) Pizza. This place is WAY out in the Richmond "Fog Bank Bring a Parka" District. Yeah...you don't want to go here at all. And the terrible parking situation.... ...there just isn't ANY-Not even for your teeny-weeny hybrid!  Why bother?? Still not discouraged? CASH ONLY!!!! TINY SPACE!!

Ok, now that I've thinned the herd, this is perhaps the quaintest place in the city. Nice pizza. Great menu. Good first date place.  Lovely experience. Neighborhoody! Very friendly people servin' up the pies. A little bit-o-Italy in SF. 

5 duckets of wonderful!
author: Johnny C.

description:
I declare this place... delectable" 

Food-- phenomenal pizza
Ambiance-- very small space-- you may have to wait
Service-- good

This is the kind of place you actually crave on a regular basis.  It is tiny, and that can mean you'll have to wait for a table if it's busy, but it's worth the wait.  

I personally prefer the simpler pizzas they serve, but others rave about the more daring pies.  

The space really only has about 6 or 8 tables, plus a few outside if it's a nice day/night.  Not super cute or totally quaint, but nicely decorated.
author: Tahd F.

description:
I love me some pizza.  When I compare Pizzetta 211 to Pizzeria Pico in Larkspur, A16, Delfina Pizzeria, Little Star, and Patxis.  Pizzetta comes out on top.

Sure it's a bit of a pizza Nazi place.  Take out only some days, they run out of dough.  But you know I'll take some abuse when the food is worth it.

If artichokes are offered get it ....it's out of this world and don't miss their Cheese salad.  Trust me.  

As you would guess their pizzas are dynomite.  The sauce and the blistery crust combine to make a heavenly pizza.
author: Lulu M.

description:
Take one: 
Last Saturday night - a friend and I walked in, sat at the four person bar and were served a good pizzetta experience.  In fact, it was the best pizza I've had in San Francisco. 

This is a quaint pizza place with an air of cool sophistication, not stuffy. And everything I had Saturday night is something I would normally never order.  I've never liked pepperoni or thin crust pizzas, or chocolate cake much - but this pizzetta did them all well.  With all of the aforementioned foods consumed in less than an hour's time, I didn't get the feeling that I ate too much.  Why? Because they use good portions, wonderful NATURAL ingredients and serious care in their pizza architecture.

Their standard pepperoni pizza was delicious.  Instead of that overly greasy taste you get with most pepperoni pies, this one had a surprise olive oil flavoring that was refreshing and oh so natural. 

The slowly cooked broccoli, prosciutto and specialty cheese pizza was also delicious. 

One of them had corm meal crust that crunched just perfectly. 

And the flourless chocolate cake with whipped cream (and this was REAL, delicious cream) is good. 

They rotate their menu weekly, which means variety.  And creativity.  According to Johnny Carson, that's a double whammy. 

The place is small and quaint, and the service is decent.  The workers were younger nice-without-being-too-nice ladies and gentlemen.  

We need to keep this is place around for a while - what a good find.
____________
Take two: 
I had dinner there tonight, almost six months after my first pizzetta 211 experience, and I'm almost positive that there is not superior pizza dinner in San Francisco.  
The "waiter" was great - not too imposing and knew just when to swing by (I'm sure the "hole in the wall" size of the pizzetta helps with that). The appetizer tonight was a melted goat cheese that we had to spread over a perfectly toasted and flavored thin slice of bread, with savory and soft beans that melded with the cheese wonderfully.  The greens were great, and the two pizza's just hit the spot.  I still maintain that thin crust pizza here is one of the only thin crust pizzas i will eat - in fact, the variety, flavors, great staff and atmposhere here seem to be gradually persuading me that thin crust is the best crust.
author: Andrew D.

description: Amazing pizzas! Great friendly service! Don't miss out on the tomato sauce pizza. It's delicious!
author: Philipp S.

description:
Pizzetta 211 ranks up there with the best places offering an authentic slice of Italy. The crust is very thin, crisp, and is a perfect vehicle for the simple, delicious, and seasonal toppings. Seeing as I am addicted to tomato sauce, I go for the semplice Margherita pizza, but will order any special pizza with goat cheese or basically anything the staff loves - can't go wrong there!

Yes - it is hard to get in and find a table. Late lunch is my solution and the place is always a bit more mellow then anyway. Well priced and so delicious!
author: Mariangela S.

description: Fantastic semi-hidden pizza place; tiny inside, only a few tables. One waiter handles all the tables, and you can sip a drink outside if you need to wait a bit for a table. Great, short menu, decent wine list. Even the restroom is interesting, with a tiny video screen playing old films.
author: Timothy V.

description:
I almost want to pull the same stunt Darren R. did with Sushi Zone and give this 1-star, in hopes of keeping it off the radar.  I could also refrain from writing a review altogether.  But it really deserves one....!

Unlike Jeanty at Jack's, (which I just reviewed) this is a place my parents (or any  non-local) would NEVER have found on their own.  I always feel good about bringing out-of-towners to restaurants that are waaaay off the beaten path.  SF has plenty of high-profile restaurants, but as a food-lover my favorite part of living here is the myriad small, wonderful, places run by talented local chefs who rely on the amazing, local meat and produce available in the bay area.  Pizzetta 211 fits this description perfectly. 

There is seating for MAYBE 15 people.  4 TINY tables and a bar.  This is a really, really small operation.  They make 100 doughs in the morning, and are open "until 9, or we run out of dough."  Read Nick M's review for other idiosyncracies of this odd little place.  Like the run-out-of-mom's kitchen feel, everything on the menu is carefully and artfully thought out, and prepared with lots of love.  

The crusts are SO thin, they're almost 2-dimensional.  But somehow, they're crispy, doughy, and flavorful.  Physics don't really apply here.  The margherita is so simple, and so delicious - the sauce is both delicate and light, while being robust and intense.  Sounds impossible.  Like the crust.  

My egg and pancetta with dandelion greens pizza was the best breakfast sandwich I've ever had.  The farm-fresh eggs they use have a bright yellow-orange yolk, and bold, delicious eggy flavor.  I added a touch of salt, and it was perfect.

The salads, cheese, olives, and roasted spring vegetable medley were all clean and fresh and wonderful.  

Come here on a weekday, early, and any day I'm not!
author: Jon B.

description:
This used to be my favorite place..
The pizza is incredible and the atmosphere is romantic..
BUT...the new staff is so incredibly rude!!!
So i went there two times on a WEEKEND night at 7 pm and 7 30 pm..BOTH times i was turned away in explanation that they are out of pizza dough...Now what sort of PIZZA rest. runs out of dough in a city on the weekend before 8 pm?!?!? 
One of the times i was told (at 730 pm) that there is only enough dough left for the workers and in case of an error..
h,mmmmmm figure that one out?!?!

-Anyway--pizza delfina is just as good and the staff is accomodating ..you can also be served past 730 pm :):)

-update: decided to give this place another chance and called to ask a simple question and some GUY on the phone was so incredibly rude to me and made me feel like i was an alien for asking basic questions..THE staff at this place need to be fired..RHIA what are you thinking? you used to have such a great establishment..the second that tall blonde girl left your resturaunt went down the tubes, no matter how good your pizza is...the experience SUCKS..
author: CadoBaby P.

description: Hey, I love this place, could be called pantie dropper 211. Bring a first date here and she will become a stalker. Charming, cute, and the food is great.   The service is what it is, it used to be more self-serve but I have noticed that they started bring plates and whatnot to the table for you, perhaps from yelpers who didnt "get it" complaining. Either way I like this places style, one server is a little cold but I cut him some slack, takes all types of people to make the world spin.
author: johnny s.

description: Tiny place, great pizza in the outer Richmond.  Great find by general consensus.  I had the Egg pizza with pepperoni and anchovies.  It tasted great with a nice crust and good flavor.  I also had the nectarine crunch desert which was quite good also.  It was packed by the time I left at 6:30pm.
author: Jim J.

description:
UPDATE!!!! Said Friend proclaims that it was a virus she caught and Pizzetta 211 is INNOCENT! DISREGARD ALL PREVIOUS MENTIONS OF SICKNESS AND FARTING!

Minus one star because I felt very sick that evening and the next day -- angry/rumbly stomach syndrome. I figured it was my newly acquired lactose issue, however my friend who had joined me for the previous evening's dinner also had issues. The next day I was simultaneously passing gas and burping while on the treadmill. Luckily the gym was empty. 

Pizzetta 211 was going to be my new favorite restaurant. It's adorable and authentic -- kinda like you're sitting in someone's home. We sat outside under the heaters (they offered us blankets as well). We ordered olives and wine to much on while we waited. My friend ordered the pizza with pine nuts and some kind of goat cheese. It was insanely good. I ordered some type of pizza with a salad on top, it was surprisingly good. I was bummed when it arrived; I got all excited while reading the menu and seeing "pancetta" and didn't read the rest of the description. In my mind, anything with pancetta would kick ass. And kicked ass, it did. 

So even though we both felt sick afterwards, I will go back. It's worth it.
author: H H.

description:
YAY!!!! finally made it here.....its all that & then some!!!!  tiny,but cozy place.......we sat outside this evening under a heat lamp & was provided with a quilt blanket, not too bad with a glass of red wine.   LOVE the pizza crust!!!! LOVE the tomato sauce on the margherita!!!

shared 3 different pizzas:  
- egg, roasted potatoes, pesto, goat cheese (YUMMMM!!! #1 tonight)
- margherita pizza (YUMMM #2 tonight, great sauce)
- rosemary, sardo cheese, pinenuts 

& ended that w/ a flourless chocolate cake w/side of homemade whipcream.......perfect way to end the evening.........
author: Cindi N.

description:
Eggs on a pizza!?! Runny yolk on a cripsy pizza?!! Are you kidding me?! Not the first place to do that I am sure, but its the first place I've had it. 

I love you Pizzetta 211! You had me at Hello...
author: Jason M.

description:
Every item I have ordered here has been delicious.  Simple menu based on the freshest ingredients.  The pizza crust is incredibly thin, delicate, and flavorful.  The wine selection is simple, but well-chosen, very affordable, and changed frequently.

Accomodations are tight.   Never come with more than four people (2 is ideal). 

The service is a strange mixture of self and full service.  But the food makes me want to tip for full service.  It is an awful dilemma.  I wish they would work out a better service model.
author: Joe R.

description:
This is the best pizza in San Francisco ... so why not 5 stars?  The crust is fabulous, toppings sparse and well chosen, all in all my current favorite pizza.  I love the beautiful salads  and the homey deserts ... the strawberry shortcake is wonderful and the olive oil cake when they make it is as good as any I've had in Italy.  SO WHY NOT 5 STARS?

This place loves pizza and the process of cooking and creating food and it is great if you live close by, (I do not) or you can get there by 5PM, (which is something  I can't  do very much) you're golden.  I've driven out to foggy side of town only to be told they were out of dough ... oh, the disappointment.  It's really not a take out place and it is a tiny  space with room for about ten inside and about six more outside when the weather permits.  I love this place because of its quirks  and its great pizza, but those same quirks have to cost them a star.  

Still the best pizza in San Francisco!
author: Joanne K.

description:
I recently had the chance to attend a lecture by Slovenian academic rock star Slavoj Zizek at Herbst Theater. The leit-motiv of his overwhelming ride into "all-things-ideological" was the set of unwritten rules that we all adhere to in order to get along in society, the social conventions that we take for granted and never question. 

One very common routine is the sort of interaction that happens in a restaurant. The characters involved - waiters, customers, hostess etc. - play their highly scripted roles and recite their lines (this is the right spot to insert a quote from Ervin Goffman, the famous chief at Chez Panisse, but that would be slightly pretentious). They all have different goals and objectives and they all work harmoniously (more or less) to achieve them. 

Now, in a place like Pizzetta, those rules do not apply. Or, better, a different set of rules is enforced and the resulting performance is, at times, peculiar. This is not, by any means, a criticism. You see, Pizzetta is different because it refuses to conform to the standard etiquette: clients are welcome, but they are always kept at arm's length. If they don't follow the rules, they are expelled from the playground. 

The rules are both explicit and implicit. An example of the former is: get your own plate and silverware as you sit on a table, like you would do in a fast-food joint. An example of the latter is: leave the place as soon as you're done, we won't tolerate any waste of time. Which is somehow understandable, because Pizzetta is a very tiny place. It's mini. It's nano. The name of the place says it all: 'pizzetta' means small pizza in Italian. Still, if you go to a restaurant to be pampered and venerated, this is not a good choice. 

To make a long story short: Pizzetta offers a wonderful, artistic culinary experience, but it might appear a bit intimidating to newcomers. The waiters are tres cool, a bit edgy. They all look like characters from a Beastie Boys video. And they have little patience for those who do not play by the rules. This place reminds me a bit of the "Soup Nazi", the fascist soup architect from New York that we all know from Seinfeld (mental note: is it just me or every city has a soup nazi character?). Basically, you need to *deserve* to eat at Pizzetta. It's a bit like Dorcia, although nobody wears Armani here.

Food-wise, Pizzetta rocks. I mean, if you're into thin crust pizzas, this is one of the best spots in San Francisco. Is it over-priced? Hmmm, if you use quantity as a criterion, the answer is definitely yes. A tiny pizza costs 14-15 bucks. However, if you care about quality, then the tariffs are absolutely justified. These guys are creative, dedicated, passionate about pizza. For them, it's like a religion. You'd better believe it because heretics will be banned forever.

Bottom line: if you are willing to embrace a new protocol, learn a new paradigm and obey new rules, Pizzetta is your place. Think of their sublime pizza as a reward for your efforts. After all, we all want to belong. And we all want to believe.

PS. Trivia: check out the restroom. It's very creative, so to speak. Other things to consider/remember: they only accept printed money, that is, cash (I always, always forget it - and according to Pizzetta's rules of engagement, this is a mortal sin. Repent, now!)
author: Matt B.

description:
Traveling out along California avenue two-thirds out to the beach you'll find Pizzetta 211.  It's a great spot to stop with friends whether by foot, car or bike.  
Rather than say the service is a occasionally snotty lets just say they have a certain way of doing things.  If you can ignore the bit of "soup-nazi" anality at the counter then this will become one of your All Time Favs.  
The pizza crusts are as thin as the reasoning used to go to war with Iraq but are an indulgence that is much easier to swallow -- And hey, nobody gets killed!  
Best bets are the Margherita and Rosemary Pizzas.   Both best consumed during a hunger pang.  Supplement that with a drink of wine, beer or even water and you have found the perfect respite.  Great to visit after a bike run out of the Presidio or the 8 block walk from the Legion of Honor
author: Chango M.

description: Best pizza in town. When you want quality and a cozy spot to hang out with a special someone, this is it.
author: SF I.

description:
Pizzetta 211 is a tiny restaurant in the outer Richmond, don't expect a large restaurant, which also means, expect a wait. There are literally 4 tables that hold up to 4 people each (even though it's a squeeze) & 4 bar seats in the entire restaurant. The kitchen takes up more room than the actual eating area. This restaurant has a ton of character, wood slab tables, cushioned benches, cool music, definitely your cute little neighborhood spot (or if you are like me, 2 bus rides away).

Cauliflower soup was very rich & creamy & served w/ a large crouton. Great Success **Borat Accent** The pizza has really thin crust and is very good. My favorite was the tomato, mozzarella & basil pizza.

Overall a very cute spot, with really good food. I could imagine there could be a long wait in the summer when it's nice outside. Oh yeah, I forgot to mention, there are also two tables outside.
author: Elaine S.

description: Yes! Feel very fortunate that Pizzetta is in the neighborhood... we are remodeling the kitchen so when we want to feel like we are having a home cooked meal, we come here... great little spot, probably the best pizza in the City, or at least top 3, not many seats... I wish they could limit the service to the Richmond district!
author: Sarkis S.

description: Excellent pizza. It's think crust with exciting toppings. I have never had a pizza that I did not love. Their menu changes so each week you get new options. The place is small and adorable.
author: Caroline D.

description: The O.G. of small yummy gourmet pizzas. But they keep it real with a local vibe. They do not even advertise the fact they got best pizza in the West by Sunset magazine! Space is limited, but I would say it is kid-friendly.  Definitely worth the wait!
author: Danielle W.

description:
I think key to having an enjoyable experience here is to go at an off-time, that way you won't have to deal with a long wait and cramped eating quarters (though you might have to deal with that anyway if you're taller than 5'2"). Only the two outdoor tables were occupied today when I dropped by early in the afternoon. Score! 

The artisan cheese salad was fresh and a perfect starter before the pizza came out. The Valencia oranges on the fennel pizza was surprisingly delicious. I love thin crust pizzas and Pizzetta's is top-notch. Unfortunately, I was too stuffed for the Scharffen Berger flourless chocolate cake. The other tables were having scones with fresh berries and cream and that looked just as good. 

The place is cash only and you get your own napkins, silverware and water glasses. But you won't mind as soon as you dig into your food!

ETA: The attitude seems to be getting worse. Don't know if I'll keep coming back.
author: Nathalie L.

description:
Don't get me wrong - the food is great.  My date and I split the artisan cheese salad, a tomato pizza, the special pizza (portabello mushrooms, red onion jam, cheese, and oregano), and the olive oil cake - all aces.  

But the thing is...I could take the ridiculously long wait (they said 30-40 minutes; we waited over an hour), or the fact that the wait is so long because it takes them 10-15 minutes to clear a table, or the sub-zero temp in the restaurant, or the rickety tables (I think we call it "rustic"), or the not-quite-surly, but not-quite-warm staff, or the serve yourself style, or the slightly inflated prices...but all together?  As standard operating procedure?  Seems a bit much...
author: Pammy C.

description:
Nothing like being dragged to the Outer Richmond on a typical summer's day in San Francisco....downtown was lovely but as soon as we crossed 19th Avenue, the sun disappeared and clouds overtook.  We arrived at Pizzetta which is in a residential neighborhood...much to my friends surprise there was no wait.  This place is pretty small....max 10-12 people inside comfortably.  We asked for a table of three and there was some confusion by the girl behind the counter.  First she said, you can take the table in the window, then she said oh, but we can't seat you without all of your people here....our friend was parking the car but we still had to wait for him to arrive.  This slightly annoyed me but whatever, it's their policy.

The other confusion is where to order - a waiter comes to your table but then you have to order at the counter...you also have to get your own water.  Not like it's a big deal, but it just seems a bit odd because most places are either self serve or service....this place is somewhere in the middle which confuses things.

The food was excellent though....well, what I had.  We shared the cheese salad and I also had the organic greens salad....dressing was a bit vinegar-y for me, but still good.  The pizza looked good.  Thin crust, toppings all seemed to be organic....not your typical pizza toppings, but tasty looking nonetheless.

While this was pretty good, I don't think I'll come out here again....it's a bit out of the way and I didn't like it enough to go back.  But if you're in the neighborhood it's worth giving it a try!
author: Melanie N.

description:
I didn't expect this place to be so small. It's tiny. And it's also off the beaten path. Quaint and quiet. Something San Francisco is good at.

It was a cold San Francisco night, beginning of what term "winter," and we were invited to sit outside. Under the heat of the lamps, we ordered up a few appetizers and two pizzas. That with a bottle of wine was enough to make a light meal for 3-people.

I really enjoyed the experience. I will be back. My only complaint is that this isn't in my neighborhood.
author: Timothy P.

description:
If your ideal restaurant is all about charm, quaintness, intimacy, or romance...your dream has come true with Pizzetta 211.  This little (and I mean LITTLE) restaurant on 23rd Avenue in the Richmond has romance written all over it (...no, not literally).  Dim lighting, small 2-tops (just 5 of the or  so!) and a quirky fun decor make for an incredible date-night destination.

The pizzas here are just outstanding.  Thin crispy crusts serve as the foundation for innovative and delicious combinations like rosemary with pine nuts or whatever-it-is with the egg on top - wow!  Sounds weird, but trust me...after you try the egg pizza, you'll be hooked.  The egg is added to the top of the pizza and put in the oven just before the pizza is done.  When it comes out, it's like a runny-yolked poached or fried egg - dripping creamy eggy goodness all over the 'za.  Dee-lish!

I took the pizzas to go, but they also offer wine by the glass and bottle and had a mighty-fine lookin' apple tart there.  I'm very much looking forward to making this a date-night destination for a return visit in the near future.

P.S. To those rating Pizzaiolo higher...I think that this is pretty darned comparable and the combinations are a little more experimental (yet still successful) than what you find at Pizzaiolo (which is, no doubt, abfab)
author: Josh M.

description: OVER PRICED fancy yuppie pizza with organic stuff. no thanks.
author: Peter H.

description:
This placy is itsy bitsy.   It seats maybe 15.  We had a group of 5 and so naturally had to wait awhile to get seated.  We were first crammed into a corner until another group left, but the staff was accommodating and apologetic about it. 

I would highly recommend the calzone.... mmm, delicious!  The pizza dough is very nice as well.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
Ambiance is great with a real feel of a cozy West Village joint: wine, water, and beer are all served in the same tumblers, seating is very limited yet not cramped at all, and the clientle was downright friendly the night we were there.  I have a feeling the owner greeted, sat, and took our order, and was a very amicable guy without being too intrusive.

The beets lightly sprinkled with sea salt were a perfect appetizer for the not-too-cripsy, not-too-fatty mozzarella, basil, and pepperoni we shared.  On another night, I'd have no problem with an entire pizza to myself, but thank heavens for missing two functional incisors due to a recent accident!  Insta-diet, however regretful that is when presented with food such as this.

Plus, for dessert, the best double cap I've had this side of Blue Bottle - and I think that's mostly due to Pizzetta 211 using Blue Bottle beans.  After a fruitless weekend-long search of NYC for a cafe that actually poured a proper cap, this was heaven to end a great meal.  The flourless chocolate cake was served with a generous dollop of not-too-sweet whipped cream, and while unremarkable, I much prefer that approach to the overdone sugar bombs so frequently found in other restaurants.
author: K M.

description:
The pizettas here really are THAT yummy. Their ingredients are terrific and I can smell the freshness every morning when I walk out my doorstep. The wait is long, though. And they only serve 100 pizzas each day until they run out, so I can appreciate the freshness but I still want more!!! 

And the wait staff are cool.
author: Jane C.

description: Because it's been 3 days and I'm still thinking about this meal I feel compelled to write a review. Yes, it's tiny and hipster, but in the most lovable way possible. The farm egg pizza got me to like goat cheese for the first time and the zucchini with toasted almonds, tomatoes, and some unfamiliar cheese (waiter could use some tips on cheese descriptions as he descibed it only as "salty", but I was sold) was absolutely amazing. The wax bean special was an amazing combination of ingredients I would have scoffed at putting together.  Now I'm a fan that has to drive to the Richmond for pizza.
author: Maleea M.

description:
Yes, it's small so there might be a short wait. Well worth it. Thin crust pizza with fresh ingredients. The rosemary was aromatic and the margarhita was simple and tasty. The cheese salad consisted of: 2 large slices of fresh country bread, 2 types of insanely good cheeses, candied walnuts and spring mix. All kinds of yum. The flourless chocolate cake was dense but not too rich. I can't remember the name of the Italian beer...but it was quite nice. 
oh yes, our server Carlos was super friendly and attentive. In fact, the whole place had a great laid back atmosphere.
author: Parisa M.

description: Pretty Awesome Pizza, but be ready for of the path toppings. This isn't a oh i just want some pizza tonight pizza, its i want to try a great meal pizza. most of the pizza menu changes so if you liked something last week or month, it may not be there next time you come.
author: Daniel K.

description:
Everything is amazing.  I'll spare revisiting the top ratings, which I agree with.  I always judge in context, and feel strongly about grade inflation.  So why am I giving this place 5 stars?

It's a tiny place (20 seats), and they don't have many staff.  I've read posts complaining about rudeness.  Every time I've visited I've felt well taken care of by people who were excited about their food and my enjoyment of it.  Yeah yeah yeah, they CAN be picky about their rules.  I've found every wankerific exchange (not many, but I remember them) about the ordering system or whatnot turned around by people who were really happy to talk with me about the delicious food they were excited to make.
author: Stefan A.

description:
If I ever found a really special restaurant, this is it. Charming and cozy atmosphere, perfect for a date, a chat with a friend, or time to ponder life away. 

The food is wonderful, pizzas very flavorful, with interesting, yet basic fresh ingredients. 

Space is small, but that is part of the charm it has. I love this place, but call ahead to make sure they are open.

Enjoy! There may be a wait, but it is worth it. Get there early, as they might run out of ingredients. Also, if it's cold, you can bring a blanket, wait outside, and they have a great little bench to sit on.
author: Christopher W.

description: Had a couple of great pizzas last night. Hadn't been back to pizetta in a few years, the last time, the cashier gave someone change and then made a salad.  That person who was the owner's son, is no longer there.  So I think its safe to go back.  The soup was so good. My son gave the pizza 100 thumbs up.
