author: mama s.

description:
Worth an hour wait in the rain!
It was Valentines Day and we arrived right during the busiest time of the evening so I was sure we wouldn't get in but we added our names to the list and huddled under the outdoor heaters and drank wine in the rain for over an hour watching the 4 tiny tables fill up and empty. 
It was worth it. We were tucked into stools at the bar where we got to watch the masters make their magic pizza.
We started with an amazing filet Mignon carpaccio with lemon and olive tapenade. It was so rich and buttery and the flavors were perfectly balanced. 
Then we had two pizzas: Tomato, Mozzarella, Basil with White Anchovies which arrived crispy and bubbly and delicious. The anchovies were not super salty but tangy and firm like pickled herring. Their tartness really balanced out the sweetness of the tomatoes and richness of the cheese. I loved it.
The other was: Fingerling Potato, Chard, Garlic Confit & Gruyere. It was richer, bolder and more complex. The garlic confit was zingy and the Gruyere was nutty, the chard earthy and the potatoes creamy. It was perfect to go back and forth between the two flavors.
For dessert we were planning on the flourless chocolate cake but the chef was chatting with us and started bragging about his panna cotta - which is one of my favorite desserts. He made it with buttermilk so it was a tiny bit tangy and not too much gelatin so it was incredibly soft and smooth and just dissolved the moment it touched my tongue. It was served with a berry coulis and homemade gingersnaps with chewy little nuggets of candied ginger in them. It was the best panna cotta I've ever had; possibly the best dessert I've ever had. Even better, the chef gave us one of them for free!
I felt happier after this meal than I did after my birthday dinner at Fleur di Lis. 
Also, the staff was super friendly and efficient. It is a tightly run, teeny tiny place that turns out amazingly perfect food.
author: Missy F.

description:
I am a pizza snob.  I live in New York, but I'm here for the summer.

This pizza is good, but the crust is not.  It's (1) not flavorful, maybe because it hasn't risen long enough; (2) not cooked in a hot enough oven; (3) over-cornmealed; and (4) doesn't have the chewy, gluteny texture that truly great pizza dough has.  Really, the crust is like something from a college dining hall.  

It's strange, because the toppings are very good and the cheese and sauce were flavorful.  And the ambiance is great, too; I love the neighborhood feel.  But I feel like the people who started this place must have never been to New York, or Italy, or for that matter, Delfina here in San Francisco.  You really can't pretend this is great pizza and have crust like this.  

So I guess your experience may depend on what you're expecting.  If you think this is going to be a good meal in a nice place, you'll be happy.  But if you think it's going to be great pizza, like Lucali in Brooklyn or something, you're going to be really disappointed.
author: Peter A.

description:
FYI

I am choosing not be negative... I will only write reviews on places I dig
author: Mick H.

description: A reason enough to trek it out to the Richmond. Tried this place 6 months ago after a day at the baths and green apple books, and went back the other day on the way home from half moon bay. Probably my favorite pizza place in the bay area, something about it. It's cozy, people have their dogs outside, "kewt", and even the bathroom is like an art installation and not in a gross way. Staff is super nice, young, friendly. Pizza is soooo good! Rosemary Pizza with pine nuts has so much flavor for being so simple. Crust is great. Last time had the Calzone and it's like a bleeding saucy wound of delicious. Prices for fancy style pizza are crazy reasonable, especially to split. Date night gold.
author: Chris V.

description:
I am a Fan, big time! This is simply great food and the atmosphere is what it is...Whatever you make it. 

Pizzetta 211 is on my top 10 list 
fo'sure
author: Sarah B.

description:
it might be the intimacy of the restaurant.
It might be the various walks of life that come here to eat or wait to eat.
It might be their wine selection being perfect for what you want with your meal.
It might be the bathroom with a crazy artistic sense and a mini TV that always has something interesting on.
or
It just might be the concept of the open kitchen and the fact that I feel like I'm at a foodie's house hanging out and having a good time.

It might be a lot of things, but it's always a delicious and a necessary Richmond district munching spot.
author: Mario G.

description:
Ok, it took WEEKS for us to be able to come here because on our first visit they told us they were "out of dough". So next time I called, jokingly, in advance to make sure they had dough. They didn't. After that we would just check on nights we were ready to go out.. hm - can we try it this time!?

Needless to say, the build-up is hard to live up to. Between the anticipation and a couple high reviews on Yelp, I thought this pizza must me amazing... My impression, however, was that it's overrated. The menu came across to me as a bit snobby and the ingredients weren't so special as they sounded. The crust of the pizza was thin and dry. But I do think the pizza seemed a lot healthier than a lot of the over-cheesed versions out there...

One thing I think is great about this restaurant is that you can bring your dog and enjoy one of the tables of outdoor seating. Pretty much every time we've gone by here there's someone with a dog guarding and/or begging under their table!

That said, be fair warned: not only do they apparently run out of dough on all the days with good weather, the restaurant is so small that there's hardly any seating.
author: Kristine K.

description: I love Pizzetta 211. The perfect small quaint restaurant that reminds me of NYC. Cozy, romantic and perfect date spot hidden in Outer Richmond. Great thin crust pizza!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
The best thin crust, gourmet pizza I have ever had! 

The place is very small, so a party of 5 is pushing it. But for 2, it is perfect!
author: Nicole H.

description: If I was on death row and got to have one last meal before I was put to death it would be Pizzetta 211. It is as simple as that. This is my favorite restaurant and pizza in the world, and I am no slouch in testing this. Every time I go to NYC, I do the pizza challenge, I spent 3 weeks in Italy looking for the best pizza in the world. And time and time again I am dissappointed as nothing compares to my Pizzetta 211.
author: D M.

description: Great place.  The wait can be long but you can drink on the sidewalk.   I can't go there anymore, unfortunately, because I saw the manager on his wedding day in Pt. Reyes and said hello but then kept running into him, so he thinks I'm obsessed with him.  I also had a great conversation at the counter with that nice Irish owner and met everyone else but got too excited and said goodbye to everyone by name one by one then told my Dad "oh I know those guys" and he went in asked them and they said "I have no idea who you're talking about, sir."  Overboard on my part.
author: Jack M.

description:
So, so delicious. Fabulous pizza, the best I've had in San Francisco. I normally don't like flourless chocolate cake but I ordered it based on the reviews, and it was just as good as everybody said. Their Blue Bottle coffee is delicious, though I do wish they offered decaf. 

We waited 20 or 30 minutes, but the outdoor heaters, blankets, and drink service while we waited made it an enjoyable wait. 

The only reason they don't get a fifth star is the hours. I just don't see how a restaurant can justify closing at 9pm on a Friday. But funky hours aside, I will definitely be back.
author: Candace D.

description: Great thin crust pizza joint. You'll most likely need to wait for a spot as the restaurant only has 4 tables and a few bar seats. The kitchen is open so you get to see them make the pizza and all the dishes they have to offer. Their pizza selection changes weekly so don't get attached to one. Def a change from the usual large loud restaurants i frequent. Will return soon to try other pizzas.
author: Alex C.

description:
a delightful find in outer richmond.  fantastic wood-fired, thin crust pizza, handmade with the freshest ingredients... on par, if not better than (!) Delfina.  my favs so far are the tomato, mozzarella & basil (simple & tasty) and rosemary, pinenut & fiore sardo.  homemade apple crisp with fresh whipped cream for dessert was also delish!

only tips are: this is truly a hole in the wall, there are 4 tables- so arrive early or prepare to wait!  (this is not a good place for groups).  and they only accept cash.
author: Karen F.

description:
When going to the movies, I'm the type of person who buys the tix online, leaves way, way, way ahead of time, circles the complex for about an hour, enters the theater while the staff is still cleaning up from the previous showing, throws a few kernels of popcorn into the air to see how the A/C is blowing, and then selects a seat. And, then, I never move from it. And I watch the movie trivia repeat a lot.

What I'm saying here is, I plan for success.

Having said that, I have had no problems with service, but I've never eaten here for dinner or had more than 2 people in my party. 3 is stretching it. I really think this is the only way to do it here because the dining area is literally no bigger than my bedroom.

Ingredients? Excellent. The mixed greens salad, of all things, always blows me away. I mean, it's literally lettuce, olive oil and balsalmic, how exciting can this be? Plenty exciting! A lot of people in this town say they use fresh, local ingredients, but one bite of this salad, and I start to think everyone else is lying.

Pizza? Gorgeous. Delicious. It's a seasonal, ever changing menu, as it should be. The last pizza I had was sheep's milk cheese, pine nuts, and rosemary. The one fatal flaw of their pizza, however, is that you pretty much have to eat it in 5 minutes because it gets cold QUICK, and then you have congealed cheese on a soggy cracker.

And, sadly, it's expensive, so it's more of a splurge-y lunch than a regular weekly visit.
author: Stacy J.

description:
Satisfied, but not overly impressed. Overrated. 

After living 7 blocks from Pizzetta for a year now, my bf and I decided to give it a try. The long wait, and foggy weather had deterred us in the past, but last night the weather was especially beautiful, even in the Richmond. 

The waiter was accommodating, continued to check in with us to let us know where we were on the wait list and he brought us our bottle of wine while we waited. They did a good job of turning tables.

We ordered 2 pizzas- tomato, garlic, basil w/pepperoni. The basil was more like a pesto consistency, not chopped basil. 
The 2nd was: broccoli and pancetta. The broccoli was looking brownish/green (over cooked?). 
Our bill was $69, plus tip. 
I love the thin crust, but overall I just found this place to be overrated.
author: Amy J.

description:
I was lucky enough to live close by Pizzetta that they became one of my go to pizza places and I was fortunate to be able to take them home. I love the thin crust pies and the flavors that they attain with so few ingredients are stunning. I am always glad to see people outside enjoying a beverage waiting to be seated in the cozy (small but not a terrible thing) dining area, knowing that this place will not be going anywhere anytime soon.

Outstanding pizzas here:
Margherita
Rosemary and Pine Nuts
anything with an egg cracked on it
author: William R.

description:
I just wrote a review rife with accolades, superlatives and other such "mad props". Then my browser crashed. oh well, i'll get to the point. This place is bloody amazing. The pizza with soft cooked egg, fresh sheeps milk ricotta,  arugula and pine nuts made my eyes roll back in my head. 

The tiny residentially-located spot has an eau d'Brooklyn and a lot of DIY "get yer own utensil" attitude but (BUT!) Carlos, our waiter, had impeccable glasses and wit to match.

$22 bottles of wine (yeay), fru-fru ingredients, phenomenal dough (call ahead for hour-by-hour dough updates as they are known to run out). Crusty, thin and deeeeellicious.
author: Sita B.

description: Good enough. Not quite a homerun, but definitely a double.
author: Guillermo K.

description:
7x7's list of 100 things to eat in san francisco before you die led me here-- and they were totally right. the rosemary and pine nut pizza was to die for. simple, savory, and well worth the trip to outer richmond.

the squash was just so-so.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Folks are right: this place is truly small. My friend and I arrived around 6:45 and were told that we could  wait 20 minutes or sit outside. Although it was freezing, we were starving and chose to sit outside. The heat lamps right above the outside tables and the waitress's offer of wool blankets were nice touches, but it was still cold cold cold. Good thing the pizza (goat cheese, pine nuts, and rosemary) and the calzone were excellent. So excellent that I overdid the cheese and discovered I'm probably lactose intolerant. But for Pizzetta 211, it was worth it.

Minus one star for the quality of service. While I was happy to get my own utensils and water, I was truly confused when it came time to pay. After handing us our receipt, our waitress said to take our money up to the counter when we were done, but when we got up to the counter, the two employees were tending to orders and didn't look up to help us for a while. "There's a jar...with money...do we put our money in the jar?" More questions are whispered back and forth between the two of us. Standing, holding money, in a cramped space wasn't fun. I'd like to think service isn't always like this here. Because the food was great, I'm eager to go back and see if the service is better.
author: Kari M.

description:
Great pizza with amazingly fresh and innovative ingredients for toppings.  Imagine an egg on top of a pizza!   The arugula, prosciutto with egg pizza was delicate and subtle in a wonderful blend of flavors.  In contrast, the pepperoni with basil was bold and delicious.  We also had heirloom tomato/Japanese cucumber salad which is fresh, sweet, full of good flavors.

Two 10-inch pizza + salad ~ $38, slightly pricey but one can argue it's worth the $ and the wait (4 small tables and 4-5 bar stools) for such delicious and creative pizza!
author: MooMoo L.

description: This place is very small - don't try to come with a big group. Feels like Brooklyn. We got two starter specials: squash soup and farro salad, plus marzano tomato and mascarpone pizza. All were exceptionally good - fresh and flavorful.
author: Jesse K.

description:
mmmm man on man, I'm a fan of this place.

Had my first encounter about a week ago and it was delicious! The small staff was really really nice and very welcoming as soon as we walked in. They were all dressed relaxed/easy going but were very professional. 

Had the Rosie's Farm egg pizza....YUMMMM! This is a must try. Also had a mixed green salad. It was very simple with no frills....pretty much lettuce tossed with a really balsamic - basic/simple but fresh and tasty. We also had vino (sorry cant remember the name so this doesn't help anyone). 

We got there about 6pm on a Thursday night and seemed to be the rush so we were able to immediately sit down. Cute atmosphere and worth the wait (if its busy)!
author: Stef E.

description:
Some of the best pizza in the city but the place really makes you pay for it, both literally and figuratively.  There are two inside tables and a tiny two seat bar.  Sure, you could sit outside but in the outer Richmond?  Whatever, sasquatch.  

Pizzas are pricey, service is leisurely, and they're cash only.  But it's just so damn good!
author: Yan G.

description:
we were lucky to grab seats on a saturday night, just shy of 7pm.  the small crowd started gathering outside after 7:30pm.  fortunately they have a lot of outside seating for the wait.

it's a tiny space and everyone is very friendly.

sitting at the bar is a bit uncomfortable with  your back to the door and your knees hitting the bar.  but it's worth it to watch the pizza making in action.   they hand make each individual one into perfect little patted down spheres, each mozzerella cube strategically placed for maximum deliciousness.

the crust is perfectly salty, perfectly crispy.  i actually like it a little crackery like michael l mentioned, it's a refreshing change.

tips:
-parking is difficult, try closer to california.  consider take out.
-cash only
-about $10 to $14.50 per pizza
-serve yourself water near the bar, no ice available
-pizzas are small, need 1 per person if you are of average appetite
author: Josie M.

description:
After reading the generally wonderful reviews on yelp, we decided to give them a try on a Sunday afternoon. We picked a very good time to come because as soon as 6 PM rolled around, there were at least five groups waiting. 

THE GOOD:

We did not experience bad service as some other yelpers had. That said, it was not a place that required much service anyway. The utensils were on a self serve counter and the drinks we ordered were not refillable. Just do not go and expect regular restaurant service (checking to see if the food was as expected, if the customer wanted anything else, refilling drinks, etc.) It is more like extended counter service, which is fine by me. 

We ordered two pizzas: their egg topped potato and chorizo pizza and the tomato with white anchovies. They were both thin crust and good in an artisan pizza kind of way. Our green salad with cheese was delicious as well. 

THE BAD (but acceptable):

It is expensive. The first pizza was around $14 and the second around $12. The salad was $9. With my glass of wine and a non-alcoholic drink, it came to $44 before tax and tip. 

THE UGLY:
EVERYBODY was a (bad) Pacific Heights type, rolling their BMWs and Land Rovers and $800 baby buggies giving lots of attitude to those who are not in their income bracket (me and hubby in non-designer  threads). Reminded me of how segregated San Francisco really is. We were also the only minorities in the place but I think it was our (gasp!) working/middle class looks that they did not approve of. Hey, feel free to buy luxury cars and goods if you want but lose the snotty attitude! After our dinner, we got goceries and dim sum on Clement Street (we were planning to anyway) to wash off the yuppie-scum feel. 

VERDICT:
Would we go back? Probably once in a blue moon when I feel like the pizza is worth putting up with their customers. I can stomach paying too much for food if it is good but as for the snotty attitude, no thank you. 

p.s. Also, cash only and they are eat in only (no take out) on the weekends.
author: Empress C.

description:
Finally pizza the way it's meant to be.  1 - Crust has a crispy outside...across the radius (not soggy in the middle).  2- bottom of pizza is perfectly baked and the oven burns prove it. 

Sauce was a little too sweet and a bit heavier than expected.  But, still the best sit down pizza I've had a while.
author: Sheetal S.

description: This week: Farm Egg, Prosciutto, Skiitake Mushroom, Pea Tendrils, and Crescenza Pizza. Just go... NOW... before it's gone...
author: Al L.

description:
There are few places or people that can put a smile on my bedraggled face after a hard week. Pizzetta 211 is at the top of that list.  I always feel like I'm home, yet someone else is doing all the work.

Cozy, thoughtful food and place.  Friendly servers and pizza throwers.  Perfect pizza and delicious desserts (There's only ever two, one being the chocolate cake, but the other is usually some sort of amazing fruit based cake or tart)  Interesting wines. 

Yes, you will probably have to wait. The place is tinier than you can imagine and isn't good (or even really possible) for large parties. If that isn't something you can deal with, don't go or you will be disappointed.  I'll be sitting there with my glass of wine, happy as a clam that I'm about to have another meal that feeds my stomach and my soul.
author: Celeste S.

description: Loved the pizza here!  Simple menu, fresh ingredients, great combination of toppings and crispy, thin crust.   Highly recommend it.  My new favorite pizza place.
author: Irene C.

description:
Food was delicious!!  A great hole in the wall neighborhood restaurant space.  

As so many others said below they are not so customer focused but  we went right around 5 pm so well before the dinner rush so it was bearable.  Calzone was exceptional and tasted so fresh as if it was made to order, so many restaurants and pizza places have these sitting around for days and serve them every so often (or at least they taste that way) but not this one.  It was delectable.  Pizza was good and they have some fun artisan flair on the basics.
author: jonathan c.

description:
3 1/2 stars. came here for lunch. place is super small. only like 6 tables. they open at 12pm (which is werid for lunch cuz people like to eat around 11am )

at 12pm we still had to wait about 5 mins. the pizzas were good and i think they change their menu weekly. got the sasuage, char, garlic, and cheese pizza. yummy

the basil, cheese, and tomtato was simple, but good. love the thin crust.

they had a salad special that i wasn't interested in. then after our food came i heard our waiter tell the table next to us they had 2 specials. one was a mushroom soup ( i loveeeee anything mushromm) so i knock off another star for that.
author: Karen H.

description:
The place is small and the wait is long , its near the Presidio -- stay away .  Ok- That way those of us who love this place can get in faster .( Trust me there are a lot of people who think this is great pizza)
I have enjoyed ever thing I tried there .
My only complaint is people might start going there and then I cant get in . 

SO FOR GAWDS SAKE STAY AWAY
author: Eric B.

description: Pizzas have always been amazing... now, can I give them an extra star for accepting credit cards (finally!)
author: Tina B.

description: Have been going here for years and was always singing its praises, but the last time I went it wasn't as good as it has been.  I will still go back and tell folks that if they're in the neighborhood they should stop in, but the pizza is not as great as it has been.  The pizzas I've had in the past I still dream about (first clam pizza I ever had was here, and would order it again in a heartbeat if it was on the menu), but this time the crust was more like a cracker.  The place itself is so small and so cute, and every time I've ever been there the people working there have been awesome!  Hoping that the next time it lives up to my memories!
author: Tammy R.

description:
A tiny part of me wanted to give them four stars because the place is so little (there are only four small tables and a couple seats at the "bar," so the wait can be crazy-long) and they're cash-only, but my stomach won out and I'm giving this place five stars because the food is so terrific.

We ordered a salad and three pizzas: one had a farm egg, beer-bbq-braised beef, and broccoli rabe; one had fontina, prosciutto and a vegetable I can't remember; and one had tomato sauce, mascarpone and arugula.  (I think the last one is always on the menu.)

The salad was nice and light; what's on the menu is what you get--organic greens and balsamic vinaigrette.  Don't expect any carrots or tomatoes or croutons.  And it's big enough for two people to share.  (You could probably even split it three ways.)

The crust on the pizzas was crispy and really good.  They didn't skimp on the toppings, but they also didn't overload the pizza so that it felt heavy or the crust was overwhelmed by everything else.

The sauce on the tomato sauce/mascarpone/arugula pizza was slightly sweet.  Normally I don't like sweet tomato sauce, but this wasn't overly so and had a really good flavor that went really well with the creaminess of the mascarpone.

This place also gets bumped to five stars because the hostess was so cool.  I had gotten there really early and put my name on the list for a table.  My friend was taking the bus from her office downtown and was still about ten minutes away when they said our table was ready.  I explained the situation to the hostess and said I understood if she had to give the table to the next group since our entire party wasn't there, but she said, "You've been waiting long enough, it's okay, I'll seat you."  I mean, you think this shouldn't be such a big deal, but I've been to much larger restaurants that wouldn't seat us because we "only" had nine of ten party members and the tenth person was just out walking from the parking lot to the restaurant!

We were tempted to get dessert, but it's a tradition to get ice cream from Joe's whenever we're in the Richmond.  But that's a story for another Yelp review...
author: D E.

description:
Charming gem of a place, with great service and amazing fresh food.  My favorite pizza was the meyer lemon with ricotta and asparagus.

Cash only.

Parking is really tough on the weekends/night around here.

Loved this place, absolutely.
author: Sarah F.

description:
We've been here a couple times now I gotta say that the best time to go is 2:30pm.  There was no wait, but by 3:00pm there was a short wait for an inside table or counter space.  The pizzas here are delicious, beautiful thin crust that is perfectly savory and crisp.  My favorite happens to be whatever they have with an egg on top.  This weekend it was cheese (sorry forgot what cheese it was!), fresh egg, and prosciutto.  We also has the rosemary, pinenuts, and fiori sardo cheese which had a sweetness to it that could be easily had for dessert (if they didn't have such good desserts that is!).  And of course we had to have the classic tomato, basil, mozzarella and white anchovies too.  

For dessert the chocolate cake is good, but if they have the olive oil cake then get that!  We had it with blood oranges and dollop of fresh creme and a blue bottle cappuccino.  This is the ultimate lazy saturday lunch.
author: Edgar C.

description: My boyfriend lives around the corner from this adorable little restaurant. Every time I have driven by, the quaint litle restaurant with charming tea lights outside always beckoned me. When we finally went, it was everything I had expected and more. The menu is changed consistantly so that it always boasts something new with fresh local ingredients. The cozy atmosphere is down to earth, yet nice and you feel right at home. There is always a wait... yes... it can be irritating.. but that is because the restaurant itself is soo small. With only 4 tables inside and a bar, and a few tables outside, it is in part how small it is that makes it so inviting and welcoming! If you love gormet pizza.... you must go to pizzetta! AMAZING!
author: Meagan B.

description:
Ever have that dilemma where you're not sure if you want a fried egg or a slice of pizza? Yeah, me neither. Regardless, you have to go to Pizzetta 211.

And let me tell you, a fried egg on a pizza is insanely good. You have to try it. The menu changes every week, but don't worry, I was informed there is always an option that has a fried egg. 

Still not feelin' it? Well listen to this:

Thin crust dusted with olive oil, arugula pesto, potatoes, pancetta,  parmiggano and two fried eggs on top. Seriously, one of the best combos I have ever had in my life. There's no 'right' way to eat it, but the chef told us most people break the yolk and let it run and then dip the crust into it. 

Additionally, D and I had another pie with hen of the woods mushrooms, green garlic, crescenza (cow's milk cheese) and lemon zest (which sounds weird, but really made the pizza). Great in it's own right.

For starters, we had the cheese salad- organic mixed greens, candied walnuts, olives, crusty baguette slices and two hunks of cheese- a petit agour (sheep) and a truffle tremor (goat).

And even though we were full after all that, we had to try a dessert- citrus olive oil cake (think poundcake- all moist and delicious) with blood orange slices and whipped cream.

All that food is worth 5 stars alone. So to have a really great space was just gravy.

The restaurant itself is warm and inviting. The owner is, too, once you get past the usual customer/employee chatter. The two other employees/chefs couldn't have been nicer, cheerily informing us about the food amongst other things.

BTW, this is a fantastic place for a date. They don't take rezzies, so expect a wait. And there isn't any room to wait inside, nor is there really anywhere nearby to catch a pre-meal cocktail. You can, however, sit outside and enjoy a drink if the weather is nice. 

I'm somewhat regretting the fact that I'm telling everyone about one of my new faves, but that's what yelp is for. So, enjoy.

Egg and pizza?!?! who knew?
author: Billy L.

description:
Unbelievably tasty find in the Outer Richmond! 

Visited Pizzetta 211 a few weeks ago on a Sunday afternoon (5:00ish) and grabbed a sidewalk table with a friend. We shared a salad and the most deliciously fresh & authentic pizza -- prosciutto, goat cheese and "Rosie's Farm Egg". 

As a neurotic New Yorker, I have the clichéd hesitation to try any pizza not served by the slice at 3 AM. The experience at Pizzetta 211 -- from the mouth-watering pizza to the friendly staff to the flourless chocolate cake -- was consistently spot on. The addition of fried eggs to the pizza was risky, yet incredibly good; a strategy is needed to keep the goat cheese, prosciutto and egg yolk playing nicely on your plate and face.

As others have mentioned, the hours (5 to 9 most days) are frustrating but understandable, given that they are located in a very residential / family-oriented neighborhood -- but any kind of a wait is most definitely worth it. 

4 stars because having to walk in and fetch your own water and silverware is just weird.
author: Rob N.

description: Try their specials... Changes every week but so far all devine!!  Had their homemade chicken & pork sausage... So tender :)
author: Cathy F.

description:
love it!!!! 
everything was fantastic, the service was great... i mean, everything!!
loved it, loved it, loved it!! can't wait to go again, which means I'M DEFINITELY GOING THERE AGAIN AND MANY TIMES OVER AS WELL!!
author: Ilovelife Z.

description:
It's such a treat. 

The egg and pancetta pizzetta is awesome. As is the italian sausage one. We also ate the mixed greens and an olive sampler as an appetizer. Pizzetta sure knows how to pick the best olives for their olive sampler.

We tried the flourless chocolate cake, which many yelpers raved about. It was good. But what was better was the lemon and rosemary tart that the seriously nice waiter gave us as a sample. I would return just for that.

In the end, our bill was about $80, which included a bottle of wine, two pizzettas, a salad, mixed olives, one dessert, and tip. So in my book that is not cheap but not expensive.

Be prepared to wait--it is a small restaurant with only 6 tables. But they will let you order wine while waiting, which is fun.  I will absolutely go back.
author: Andrea F.

description: We decided to try this pizza place because it had good reviews.  When we arrived there were only two seats at the counter.  I was able to watch four people work in this tiny restaurant.  I should have left immediately after observing the host handle money then handle condiments that  he placed on the pizza and other food items.  He wore a dirty looking white rag on his belt as he took people's cash (it's cash only) and handled food that went on the to go pizzas.  He also shaved cheese with the same hands that touched the cash.  The pizza was good, but, I am praying that I do not get food poisoning.  If you do not mind going to a place where the food is handled by the same hands that touch money, then go here.  After eating the pizza, I looked at someone else's review that said that 5 people that ordered to go food here received food poisoning.
author: Jerry H.

description:
I went here 3 days in a row after trying it for the first time. You don't  need any of the baroque pizza concoctions with like chard and stuff, a Margherita is an exercise in perfect pie pleasure. I do wish they would accept something besides cash being they sell bottles of wine and all, but i am not gonna take off a star because the pizza is outta sight.

Oh yeah, my food friend on one of my visits, Frogboy Slim, ordered a calzone. Of course it sucked. You don't go to a place like this and order anything besides the pizza.
author: Jackie P.

description:
I really want to love this place, but the pizza I ordered to take home just didn't taste that great.  I loved the restaurant itself in my sleepy little neighborhood and I am absolutely planning on coming back again to give it another try.  I ordered the eggplant and egg pizzas.  Both had super tough, overly chewy crust and no substance.  The egg was nice, but I think the fact I had to walk a few blocks ruined the essence of these pies.  
Because I am adamant to not give up I will bring my gf here for a night out and update this review upon a more thorough examination...;)
author: Sheila Y.

description:
Need to start by saying I LOVE PIZZA!  Heard good stuff about this place, and yelp totally backed up what I heard, but my experience was not so good.  My gripes...
- pizza was just about average (ok im being nice)
- They had a very limited menu
- A couple of items off the limited menu were unavailable
- The waiter seemed like he was too cool for school

Boo!
author: Vivek N.

description:
Deeeelicious!  The pizzas and calzone were great!  Definitely comparable to or better than that of Pizzeria Delfina.  

I have to say, I thought it was a bit weird that the waitress has you order at the counter, but maybe I've become a restaurant snob or something.  It was a nice touch that they offer blankets if you're sitting outside, in addition to the heat lamps they have to keep you warm.

The Peroni I had was refreshing, but one of my friends got this weird beer that kind of tasted like soap (maybe our palates aren't sophistocated enough to appreciate that flavor).

This place is tiny, with only about 3 tables or so inside, and 3 outside, so be prepared to wait (although not that many people know about this place, so you might be ok).
author: Danielle B.

description:
As a virile man, I don't like to use this word often, but this place is "cute."  We just moved into the neighborhood, literally, as we live only a block away.  Could this neighborhood get any more rad?

Kind of looks like a seat yourself kind of place, but its not.  I'm giving you the heads up now.  There's a waiting list so sign up, instead of  looking like a jackass like yours truly who promptly inserted himself in front of a bunch of hungry, waiting patrons.

The Food:
Pizza with prosciutto and an egg on top?  Yowza!
Lamb sausage pizza?  Ba-aa-a-ad ass!
House made sausage of some sorts with farro and tomatoes? Who would've thought?

Great for sidewalk dining, sometimes a long wait, but well worth it.  They even provide blankets for warmth if you're stuck outside.  I like it outside; no blankets for me though.  I'm sold, I'm revved, I'm excited, I'm into Pizzetta 211!
author: Grape C.

description:
3 1/2 stars.

The pizza was yummy but the place was too tiny for my taste--only 3 tables! I'd prefer a larger, more lively space. 

We ordered he Yam and Gruyere pizza- thin crust, beautiful slices of yam on top of gruyere cheese. I didn't eat any until I got home and it was a little cold, but it was still really good. I also ordered the salad with cheeses--this was a little disappointing--the lettuce was kind of limp and the dressing was just ok. Salad came with a hunk of brie and a hunk of some other cheese--the brie was not the greatest brie and Brie is my fave cheese.  The other cheese was great but I don't know what kind it was. Let's just say I've had better salads...I guess I shouldn't complain b/c it is a pizza place, not a salad place? 

I'd like to go back to try some other pizzas..will update this review after my next visit..
author: amy k.

description: so sad.... they quit doing coffee in the morning!  I used to really look forward to having a leisurely walk over there to grab some blue bottle coffee and a scone or whatever other delicious baked item they were serving up.
author: Yvette H.

description:
Like an apartment search in the late 90's, what you'll find at Pizzetta 211 is small, cramped, and it usually has a line of people waiting to get in.

Growing up in NYC and then living in San Francisco, I've found that what Manhattan lacks in Mexican Food, San Francisco lacks in pizza (and Italian Food in general). And I'm not talking about the grotesque (watch my ass inflate as I eat) deep dish variant, strictly the OG thin crust pies.

Pizzetta 211 serves decent thin crust pizza, but avoid the mediocre calzones. A bit too pricey for what you actually get though the place is worth a try if you're out in the hinterlands or going to catch a show at the 4-Star Theater. Also, you may want to BYOW since the $8-a-glass Pinot tastes like $2-per-bottle Charles Shaw.
author: Be N.

description:
This place is in the OUTER Richmond and located right in the middle of a residential area.  I went here with Jon M and Jon P on Saturday after taking Sammy to Baker Beach.  She ran around like crazy and we punted a football as far as we could (Jon P had a 49-yard punt).  

We stopped for lunch and sat outside because Sammy was with us.  She took the fourth seat and we ordered right away and proceeded to sit for forty minutes before we were served our food.  I had margheritta (?) pizza and it was better than the other nasty fancy pizzas that Jon M ordered (he had a fried egg on his) or Jon P's standard Calzone.  Everything is organic (who cares?) and they try different combinations that don't work.  It's not that sweet.  I'd rather go somewhere and get real pizza (like Little Star).

I'm giving it 3 stars because we were sitting there and it felt like a real San Francisco place.  The crowd was mixed, the waitress had some sass, we were sitting outside gazing at the victorian houses, and the fog was settling.  Sammy was pretty happy because she ate some crust.
author: Steven M.

description:
Okay, so yes, you'll have to wait a while or be incredibly lucky to get a seat here, but it's worth it. I started with a salad with Tetilla and Great Hill Blue cheese on the side, then played it safe and got the pepperoni pizza, and it proved one of the best I've ever had.

To finish: flourless chocolate cake with fresh whipped cream. Phenomenal!

If any place can deserve to be called a "gem," it's Pizzetta 211.
author: Patrick G.

description:
3.75 stars.

I'm not entirely sure how I feel about the service set-up at Pizzetta 211, but I did like the pizza a lot.  At first bite, I realized it wasn't nealy as good as A16 or Pizzeria Delfina.  But, after a few more bites, I noticed it was good in it's own way - not quite as good as A16 and Delfina, but still very good.  The sauce isn't as sweet as theirs, but there's more to the cheese.  Pizzetta uses a different cheese, and puts a small amount of delicious pesto on top.  

I also had the mixed green salad - nothing to write home about, but ok.

The marinated olives were a nice pre-dinner snack.

The service overall was good.  The waiter and staff were very helpful, welcoming and friendly.  it was a Monday, and much less crowded than I imagine on a weekend, but that was a good thing considering there's only 4 tables inside the restaurant.  I honestly didn't like how I had to go up to the bar to order.  It makes the tipping process at the end very confusing.  Do you leave the normal 15-20% tip even though you only get 1/2 the service?  I erred on the side of tipping.
author: Angie C.

description:
I used to live 2 blocks from that place.  I've had mixed experiences there.  A few times, they were quite friendly.  Other times the attitude of the staff (I think it was the owner, mainly) seemed like they were doing you a favor.   I guess you have to catch them when it's less busy to get more friendly service.

As for the pizza, it's interesting.  It's tasty and pricey, but it's what I'd expect from this "gourmet" establishment.   

Bottom line:  Not the place for the "6-pack conoisseur."
author: Larry A.

description: Everything about this place was basically radical, except the pizza had disappointing crust, which was pretty much the ball game. Great salad, a nice side, and fresh toppings, but they fumbled when it came to the dough. And a pizza with a bad crust is like a basketball team without pants: disgusting. I'm not sure why I'm using all these sports analogies. I don't even like sports. Another thing I don't like is the pizza crust at Pizzetta 211.
author: Nathaniel L.

description:
Pizzetta 211 flips the bird at the notion of pizza as fast food.

Your pizza will be made to order, you will wait your turn in line and you will be forced to suffer mercilessly as heavenly aromas taunt your senses. All good things come to those who wait, however, and Pizzetta 211 is no exception. What emerges from their oven is nothing short of edible love.

This quaint and cozy nook is located in the heart of the Central Richmond's residential neighborhood, one block north of the hustle and bustle of Clement Street. The restaurant is not much larger than a one bedroom duplex, and after eating your fill of crusty goodness, you're liable to want to curl up and rub your belly to sleep (beds sold separately). 

There are only four tables inside, three on the sidewalk and a few stools at the counter. The turnover of the tables is slow, and so long as there isn't a line of people waiting, your inclination will be to linger over lunch or a late dinner and chat with the other patrons and the servers. 

Their Neapolitan pizzetta (small, personalized pizzas) use locally-sourced ingredients. Even the flour in their dough, which is fresh-made daily, hails from South San Francisco. Our lunch consisted of two pizzettas. One featured two eggs sunny side up, sliced house-cured pancetta, nettle, and a potato and garlic confit. We spread the bright orange egg yolks around the whole of the pizza, and evened out the pancetta distribution so that every slice had a similarly sized portion. My taste buds slow-danced to the flavors of garlic and nettle, while the salt and olive oil crust was the perfect delivery vessel to add texture and chewy consistency to the mix. Our second pizzetta had thin slices of speck radiating out from the center of the pie like bicycle spokes - a spot of speck for every pizza slice. This was layered on a colorful assortment of oven-dried San Marzano tomatoes (keeping true to the Neapolitan-style) and sliced fryer peppers. The flavors of tomato, shallot and a roasted pepper tapenade combined with the speck made for a sweet and savory pie, each mouthful holding different proportions.

In all, the restaurant offers five varieties of pizzetta (technically seven considering that the margarita can be served with pepperoni and/or anchovies), and a calzone, a smattering of salads, cheeses and olives round out the menu. It isn't extensive, nor would you expect it to be given the size of the place (good things always come in small packages) and anything more might detract from the main attraction. I have some biases about styles of pizzas, and this alone holds me back from giving Pizzetta 211 highest marks. Their crust is thinner and crispier than my preference, which is to have more chewiness to my bite and crusts that fold or bend instead of break. Still, I can't complain in the slightest about the flavors, and for that, I will definitely return as this is the perfect place to lounge, indulge, relax and be at one with everyone else who is there to do the same.
author: Nils E.

description:
Pizzetta 211 was worth the trip from San Jose! I had read great Yelp reviews and everyone was right on. I had the rosemary, fior di sarda and pine nuts pizza and it was delicious. My mom had the margarita and she said it was the best pizza she had in a long time and the tomato sauce tasted just like Grandma's. It was also a cute hole in the wall place with only 4 tables and very homey inside. 

Loved it and cant wait to go back. I want to try that pancetta/goat cheese pizza I saw. Mmmmmmmmmmmm looked really tasty too!
author: Marisa B.

description: I love their pizza. The Farm Fresh Egg Pizza was dynamite. I wish it was closer to where I live, but it's worth the trip to the avenues. Really yummy. I tend to try to go there during the week and off times b/c it gets crowded. Cash only, so just be prepared.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Easy cheesy -  4 stars near the 4 Star.

I enjoyed the food (in spite of cursed lactose tolerance issues destined to follow) and the laid back atmosphere; mellow music, nice calm service, and the perfect window bench seats for to cuddle up next to my cutie made for a very nice dinner.

Why not 5 stars you say?  Well I'm a pretty tough customer when it comes to pizza, and as tasty as the one I tried was it was not a perfect 5 stars, very good though. We also tried the calzone which was a nice comfort dish, big and soft and bursting with cheeses, but the sauce was a tad bland and lost in it, perhaps a touch of basil or something would have added dimension.  The special veg appetizer we had was delicious, and, in the end we were too full to try dessert. 

I'm looking forward to returning and trying more pizzas to get the full 411 on Pizzetta 211.
author: GIR ..

description:
A very cute and cozy place. 
what we had:
- cheeseboard
- pizza with cheese, tomatoes, currants, fennel
- salad
- flourless choco cake

and all was good in my stomach.  I'm going back.
author: Julia H.

description:
Four Stars:
1 star for great service (I ate here yesterday and commented on how well the artichoke was prepared and the lady behind the counter told me how she prepared it - nice, not that I could come close)
2 stars for innovative and good food made with fresh ingredients - the portions are small but you will not find these pizzas anywhere else (they have a pizza with two over-easy eggs! and its good!)  they use seasonal veggies and you can watch the person behind the counter make each pizza and see all the fresh ingredients - there is nothing going on behind the scenes here - what you see is what you get
1 star for intimate atmosphere aka its a tiny place and they make use of every square inch

There is only four stars because yesterday we went there and we had:
1. 1 olives
2. 1 cheese board
3. 1 cheese salad
4. 1 artichoke
5. 3 pizzas
6. 8 beverages
Total after tip and taxes $100!!  That is an expensive lunch especially when its counter service so its only four stars...
author: Angela A.

description:
Yes, the produce and cheeses are perfect.  Yes, the space is small and sweet.  Yes the menu is wonderfully seasonal, as we've grown to expect living here.

But maybe I've eaten here at the wrong time, but the crust was awful.  Really dry, like eating breadcrumbs that had been pieced together again.   Like well flavored cardboard.  I was thoroughly underwhelmed, though I could be convinced to try it again.
author: Nora B.

description:
awesome pizzas
amazing desserts

the cutest little bathroom you've ever seen!! 

you've just got to to.

Note: very small restaurant, long wait, but, definitely worth it.
author: Heidi L.

description: Came for the first time. Cute place, great service & awesomeness of food. We ordered: Farm egg & pine nut pizza. For the dessert:  flourless chocolate cake & ricotta cake. Will come back again for sure...Great to meet you Pizzetta!
author: kyla g.

description:
The sausage and cold salad special was unbelievable.  The waiter told me that they have a sausage special every Monday and Tuesday.

The service was great and very informative.  

The best neighborhood Italian.  Wish the dining area was larger.
author: Jeff S.

description: I was able to place and order to go and I liked that they did not put the arugula on the pizza until I picked it up.  The crust was just the way I liked it, but it's getting 3 stars because the staff could have been more friendly.  Considering I was the only one in the restaurant at the time, I think they could have been more friendly.
author: marie h.

description: This place was absolutely lovely.  Cute restaurant with a great cozy and intimate atmosphere, excellent wait staff, and the pizza was delicious.  Extremely thin, crisp, and flavorful crust generously topped with some interesting flavor combinations but without overwhelming the pizza.
author: Kaman C.

description: i had read about the tininess of this pizzeria and was prepared to rub shoulders with my neighboring tables, but reading and actually seeing with my own two eyes are two completely different things. the inside holds 4 tables and 4 counter seats...that's it! but don't turn away just yet, cuz the pizzas they serve are mighty delish! the bf and i came soon after they opened on a saturday and took the last table inside. the server was friendly and didn't make us feel hurried. after we ordered and were waiting for our 2 pizzas, i saw our server bring some blankets outside and left them on the outdoor bench. turns out those were for people to use as they wait to be seated. how thoughtful is that! well, the pizzas came and they did not disappoint. extremely fresh tasting and flavorful. great texture on the crusts as well. this is the definition of a neighborhood gem.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
Very cute but small place. Be prepare to wait outside if you come at certain hours. 

Pizzas are very good. Thin crisp pizza. Among the best Pizza places I tried so far in the area. 

They also have some original appetizers.
The fact that they do not accept credit cards is a major pain though. Also, finding a car parking space can be a challenge at time
author: Patrick P.

description:
wow.
the combination of all of the flavors. really something magical.
plus the atmosphere was great- very tiny, but i think that added to my enjoyment...
wouldve given 5 stars,- the only downside is that they don't accept credit card.
author: Katrina M.

description:
I wanted to like this place more than I did. Long on the list, scheduled and rescheduled among friends. Finally went for a Bay To Breakers carb load.

Things I really included included the piece of my friend's lamb sausage pie. That was tasty. Our waiter was also incredibly knowledgeable. An overall lack of seating made for a long wait, but that's part of the unassuming vibe.

Unfortunately the memory that keeps coming back of my margarita pizza with light cheese was the vat of oil it was sitting in. On top. Coming through the bottom, all over the place. Yeah, yeah, I know, olive oil, good for you. No doubt in moderation. This was anything but. I'm surprised it wasn't listed as the main ingredient.

Lack of veggie offerings were also disappointing. I get the whole we'll run out when we run out, but no alternatives once the squash was gone? Meh.

Saving the third star - great service, great desserts, and despite my complaints, great pizza. They were just saturated in way too much oil. Good thing I had a 7.5m run on tap the next morning to work it off.
author: Jason B.

description:
This place is tiny.  If you make a reservation, don't be late or you will lose your table.  But if you're willing to brave the evening chill of the outer Richmond, you can sit outside.  They have patio heaters and quilts that you can bundle yourself up in, which I thought was adorable.  

Thin crust is not my favorite style of pizza, but it's still pizza.  This thin crust pizza was excellent.  I went with 3 other people.  We split the cheese plate, 3 pizzas, and 1 bottle of wine.  We paid $100 even, and that included a 20% tip.  I loved the casual atmosphere, the waitstaff, the other patrons.... Really great neighborhood place.  Just go.
author: Gaping F.

description: I love having a local restaurant where you can sit outside,  enjoy a glass of wine and have freshly prepared pizzas.
author: Jen T.

description:
The pizza is not bad here, but I really don't see what all the fuss is about. 

The crust is okay, but a bit thick, the toppings are fine, but nothing outstanding or unusual. 

I'd put Pizzetta 211 about equal to (or a bit below) Delfina, and way below Pazzia. 

Check it out if you happen to be nearby (and don't mind waiting), but not worth a special trip.
author: Jacob L.

description:
So I loath thin crust pizza - it is an invention of the devil. Eating thin crust is sacrilegious. That being said, I have to admit - I love Pizzetta! The chi chi toppings, fairly good selection of beer, and delicious choco cake make it one of my fav places in my hood. It's also the only thin crust pizza I will admit to liking. 

The choco cake is a must after stuffing an entire pie in your pie-hole - yeah that's right it's a one pizza per person kinda pie - or maybe I'm just a pig - oink!

The downside is that you have to pay cash and sometimes it's too busy for take out. So hit up an ATM before hand and if you have to wait (yeah it's always pretty busy) wrap up in one of their blankets and get a glass a wine.
author: Lauren D.

description:
An early and light Friday nite dinner for two was the plan; we arrived just after they opened and were the second table to be seated. I had passed this place many times and figured this to be a yuppie snobby place figuring from the not-so-friendly looks of the servers, and left it at that. Now I went in for the first time, and I say this is a true Four Stars, as the attitude towards paying clients has become better.

We began with beets glazed in blood orange, served with a slice of feta cheese (the best I've ever had!),  and continued with the tomato/mozz/basil pesto pizzette, in two varieties: pepperoni and white anchovies. Both delightfully tasty, crunchy and savory! The anchovies reminded me of first class young Dutch hering. Tasty, but not salty. Two glasses of Cotes du Rhone were a good choice, albeit not great wines.

The very friendly server (with freckles and a drum T-Shirt) suggested the olive cake with creme fraiche and cooked strawberries, because "I like it so much myself, so I want others to try it!" What can you say to such argument other than "Yes, bring me one!" So she did, smilingly and it was defintitely a winner. Smooth, moist and later soaking up the strawberry sauce. Put a dash for cream on it---I was in heaven!

The manager Carlos came to bring the check (at $48 not cheap, but worth it) and he seems like a real nice chap, having understood this was our first visit here and he had a bit of explaining to do.

All in all: Come early, delight in the day's special and feel the love in their food!
author: Wolfgang S.

description:
It's good. I finally visited this out of the way pizza place. we ordered the homemade sausage + olive pizza which was amazingly tasty. We also had the pepperoni + anchovies, which was fairly greasy where you can drain the pizza. 

The crust is crisp and light, but the second pizza was just mediocre. I say, go for the small, Potrero place, Picino for cheaper, just as fresh and good, thin crust pizza, but if you are in the hood, stop by in the off hours and wait a second before you burn your mouth, they serve it right out of the oven (which is great).

Nice wine choices too, but for 2 pizzas and some wine, we walked out of brunch for $80 bucks, pretty pricey in my book.
author: Hilary H.

description:
The pizza was good. The crust was nice and thin and crispy (my husband thought too crispy for his taste, too much "like a saltine cracker"). We shared a Margharita and one with potato, pancetta and gruyere as well as the mixed field green salad. He preferred the first pizza while I preferred the second. Both were good. I had a glass of rose that was fine although it seemed like it had been opened for a while.

The staff was really cool and friendly. I didn't realize we were supposed to order and pay at the counter. Luckily, it was early and they didn't seem to mind too much. I definitely enjoyed the little table by the window. Quite cozy.

At the end of the day, it was nice to have a bite to eat with my hubby. I'm not sure I would go out of my way to go back though. I honestly felt it was a touch over priced (really a touch by a couple of bucks per item) for what it was. I guess if I was in the neighborhood... maybe. 

Oh yeah, cash only.
author: J B.

description: Visiting from the east coast.  This was our first dinner in San Francisco . . . a great choice.  Sausage special, pizza with fried egg, shaved goat cheese, all of it was fab.  Also - as a visitor from Philadelphia, we miss byobs wherever we go.  Here the corkage fee is fairly minimal (10.00).
author: Leah G.

description: This place is great.  The food, service and ambiance are all in sync and make it into a adorable neighborhood spot.  I had the calzone and my husband had the farm egg pizza.  The crust on the calzone was one of the best I've ever had, fresh baked/crispy/light.  The place is super tiny, but that is part of the charm.  I noticed they had some outdoor seating and blankets for when its cold.  Overall-- Great for a intimate date night.
author: Sun M.

description:
Teeny, tiny place on a neighborhoody street in the Richmond.  A friend recently moved to this 'hood and, as we wandered around trying to decide on dinner, we were drawn to the twinkly lights that highlight the doorway from the other buildings on the dark street.
We had to wait a little while to be seated, but they immediately offered us wine to soften the wait.  In addition, they are a cash only place, so we had to wander around Clement to find cash during our wait time.

We were seated at the bar, which was great because we could see 5 feet away where they were making all the food, but the bar is really crammed with stuff, so there was little room to actually eat and move around.  We were also disappointed because the one pizza that drew us in and convinced us to wait to be seated--the Butternut Squash pizza--was no longer available.  I ordered a pizza with sausage, egg, red onion, and yummy cheese and it was great.  We also got the cheese salad, which included greens, huge chunks of delicious cheeses, and pears.  My friend got the calzone, which was good, but nothing outstanding--the flavors were kind of muddled.
The atmosphere is cute and cozy and the staff are informal and friendly.  However, there is a very limited menu and seating and the cash only thing definitely lost them a star.  Also, the pizzas are sort of small for what you pay.  I will likely check it out again, but Gialina still wins in my mind.
author: Jessica L.

description:
we came just after dinner opened, with 3 small kids. got a cheese plate salad--yum. also the bean soup, great flavor. had the farm egg pizza--kids were all over that. barely left any for me! the crust is superb. then the kumquat goat cheese tart. who thinks of such a combo? had to take an extra tart to go.

the restaurant is so small. if only i were young and single again, it would be so quaint. kids found some free play on the sidewalk. the service people were nice about our kiddie group.
author: lily rose w.

description:
I finally made it to this place after hearing all this hype about made-to-order Italian style thin crust pizza.  Didn't have to wait long for a Friday night and was seated after a 15-20 min wait.

The ambiance is rather laid back and service is decent.  It has a very organic movement feel, which is reflective of their fresh ingredients they use for their food.

On to the food.  I had the cheese salad and the Margherita pizza with pepperoni.   The cheese salad was fabulous.  Both kinds of cheeses paired well with the salad greens.

As for the pizza, the way I evaluate a place that has great food is how great the simplistic dishes taste -- i.e. the Margherita pizza.  Slather great tomato sauce with fresh mozzarella on a thin crust -- the sky should part and the angels sound their trumpets, right?    However, the Margherita pizza was extremely disappointing.  The pizza was rather unseasoned and flavorless.

I may give this place a 2nd chance.  I've had better pizza elsewhere.
author: Mei C.

description: Great thin crust. Just the right amount of crunch, flavorful,  and not too chewy. They have a well thought out, but simple menu. Great toppings that do not overwhelm the crust, but pair perfectly with it. Well worth a 21 block walk......oh nice bottled beer selection too.
author: Charles M.

description: The food that this place serves is delicious. I've tried a handful of their pizzas and I am impressed with every one. I don't think you could go wrong with anything on the menu.The ingredients are very fresh and simple. I love that this small business prioritizes quality and constantly changes the menu to fit the quality of the ingredients. While parking may be limited and seating space a precious comodity, it is well worth waiting for. The staff was very friendly and quick with helping us get anything we needed. I highly recommend this place.
author: Damon Y.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place since a bunch of my chef friends hyped it up about a year ago. 
My workplace decided to throw me a baby shower and, as the guest of honor, allowed me to pick the restaurant. Obviously, nothing too fancy was in order since we were going to be a small and casual group of four.  Since they opened at noon and closed at 2:30pm for the lunch crowd, we arrived around 12:30pm.  The seats inside were already all taken but we managed to corral two of the three outside tables to enjoy the rare sunny day. 
Three of us started off with salads, two with the cheese salad and one with the green salad. I was one with the cheese salad and it is an amazing deal. For a little over $8 you get a great tossed salad with balsamic vinegar, two little bunches of champagne grapes, candied walnuts, greek olives, a wedge of brie and several slices of a sheep's milk cheese.  It was delicious and extremely satisfying.  I honestly forgot that I ordered the Rosie's Egg pizza with egg, pancetta, mushroom and garlic.  Crispy crust and super fresh ingredients were great! I ate all but one slice to take home to the hubby. Somehow (I blame the baby) I managed to make it through dessert...a delightfully light almond cake with nectarines in the style of a pineapple upside down cake. With a dollop of fresh whipped cream on the side it was the perfect ending to a great lunch. 
Lunch was so filling that I didn't even need to eat dinner and given that I'm eating for two it's quite an achievement!
I will say that this is an extremely tiny space so don't plan on going here with more than one more person. We were lucky with four but not exactly the most comfortable. Hence the loss of the star.
author: Jill D.

description:
This place rocks my world.  Now, I'm secretly hoping that most folks get lost trying to find the place, because seating is extremely limited, but...I can't refrain from giving this restaurant it's proper accolades!  I won't even go into the amazing revolving menu.  The pizza will blow your mind (fresh toppings, creative yet palate-pleasing combinations of seasonal ingredients) and I definitely recommend trying more than one.  I can finish a pizza to myself, so if there are two or three of you, definitely get one per person and share.  Also, try the cheese salad and/or the house-made sausage (only on Mondays).  
What's great is that, even while you wait, the staff provide seats outside, blankets, and bring out drinks for you.  It's amazing to watch them all work in such a small space (most of the time, with only one waiter/waitress) and they definitely deserve large tips!!  This is one of those places that is definitely worth waiting for!
author: Colby J.

description:
Unlike your average pizza place, this is home to artisan pizzas of high quality with a menu that changes regularly serving creative and tasty little pizzas.  
The only drawback is the seating which is limited and cramped.  Long waits aren't unusual either and good luck finding parking in the neighborhood.
Also note, they're closed on Tuesdays.
author: Jon P.

description:
OK, they're not the friendliest people in the world here, but the pizzas and salads are unusual and really, really good.  They use artisanal cheeses and other stellar ingredients (try the one with egg... no, really).  My favorite is the tomato, mozzarella, basil and white anchovy.   The artisanal cheese salad (okay, maybe they overdo the "artisanal cheese" thing a wee bit) is quite good, and the desserts are also quite good, if basic.  The  almond polenta cake was yummy.  The wine list is teeny-tiny, but they change it every three months or so, and it's perfectly adequate.  They have beer also.

The dining room is really small -- like 20 seats, including outside.  They won't even think of seating you until your whole party is there (even though I was pointing to my partner, who was getting Doris Day parking and could be seen through the door, they wouldn't seat me at the bar until he was physically indoors.  I vowed to remain Buddha-calm in the face of such bulls**t and, more importantly, to get the pizza that I'd come all the way across town for).

They don't take reservations, and it's cash only.  Come early (like by 6PM) or be prepared to wait.
author: Jeff S.

description:
super cozy and the pizza is crazy tasty. It's a funny vibe here, though, everyone is secretly peeking at each other...or was it just me? yes, it is pretty pricey, my wife and I had 2 pizzas, 2 salads, and one glass of wine....bill was $48. 

Here's a question...does one tip at a place like this? 

I loved the pizza with runny egg on top of spicy roasted peppers and sausage...
author: slapaham s.

description:
Have been here a couple times and they don't quite seem to get the whole idea that it's a pizzeria and not an art gallery.  

Yes, this cracker crust type pizza is delicious, but as a few folks have noted below:

1. It's pricey for what it is
2. The service is quirky (pour your own water, get your own silverware and get your pizza from a rather disinterested member of wait staff)

If these guys wanted to do an "artisan" pizza kind of thing, they could have a bit more fun doing it and make their customers feel more at home.  Or, they could do their own route and stay kind of a "pizza club"

Take your pizza money and spend it at Amici's (if they're delivering) or Gaspare's (if you're eating there).  

Don't bring kids here either - nightmare.
author: Jim M.

description:
My absolute favorite place to go for pizza in the city (when I have time to wait).  After I started going there it took me a couple visits to figure out the system of pseudo-service and now I am completely cool with it.  Anyway for that food, I would endure almost any kind of service.  

It ends up feeling like you are at a friends house, (a slightly irritated and harried friend, but a friend nonetheless) enjoying every bite!
author: Stacey d.

description:
Just when I thought I had found most of the good little places in the Richmond, I stumbled upon Pizzetta...and the pleasure was all mine.  I'm the type of person who loves to sit outside...I don't care if it's 10 degrees, if it's not raining, I'd rather be on the sidewalk than cramped inside, and Pizzetta fulfills that urge with two miniscule outside tables under heatlamps...and if the blankets aren't already commandeered, you can use them to keep warm too.  

Now onto the pizza...great little thin-crust gems, my personal favorite is the sheep cheese with pine-nuts and rosemary...simple, delicious, and I could probably eat about 20 of them.  It's worth showing up on the earlier side just in case they run out of dough or the daily veggie special, but no matter what you'll be happy...unless you are stuck in a rut and only eat pepperoni anchovy gruyere pizza, in which case you're shit out of luck.  

$10 corkage if you feel like bringing your own wine...you'll be drinking out of water glasses, but you're eating pizza, get over yourself!
author: JORDAN M.

description:
My boyfriend and I just went nuts there this afternoon.  Cheese salad is INCREDIBLE.  The cheeses they gave us were really good ones.  Then the margharita pizza and the eggplant pizza.  The eggplant pizza was so creamy and tomatoey and the margarita was classically perfect.

For dessert, we had one of all they had to offer: a rhubarb cake, a flourless chocolate cake and vin santo with biscotti.  The rhubarb cake was fucking awesome.  Same with the chocolate- light and chocolatey.  But if you go, get at least one- their desserts are fantastic.

If you like rose, you have to get a bottle of what they're offering right now.  Domaine Fontsomething.  

Like I said, we went nuts.  It happens once in a while when we go somewhere we really like and it was ecstasy.  This place is perfect.  Food perfect.  Wine, service, all the bomb.
author: Staci M.

description:
Great little hole in the wall that serves the best pizza I've had outside of Italy.  I can't wait to go back to try the rest of the menu. 
The hours are "-ish" but who cares, the food is great.
author: J. F.

description: Delicious oven fired pizza, Blue Bottle espresso, great neighborhood vibe.  What more do you need?
author: Steve R.

description: It has been a difficult transition moving to the Inner Richmond. Pizzetta 211 makes it easier. It's better than Delfina. So there. And the cheese salad is wonderful and simple and delicious. I wasn't impressed with the flourless chocolate cake. But others were.
author: Nada b.

description: What a HUGE UPSET! I have been a frequent customer to this place; I come here 2-3 a month. I was and still am slightly upset from the service I was met with tonight. To avoid the wait I called in and placed an order for pick up (which I highly recommend). I arrived to pick up only to be told by the waitress that there too many bodies and that I needed to wait outside until it was ready. Thirty minutes of waiting, I went in to ask if I could pay for in advance only to find out that my order had been ready the whole time, and the waitress simply did not ask  or forgot. When I grabbed the pizza, it was cold!, and they would not make another even though this was their fault. It was a disappointment to say the least. Food can be great. but service really does matter!
author: Elise M.

description: Phenomenal pizza with fresh ingredients. Arugula and marscapone pizza was memorable. Neopolitan style. Really great taste, menu changes often. Fresh stone fruit tart for dessert was very fresh... only mildly sweet. Not busy on a weekday at lunch. Cash only though.
author: Tom H.

description:
This is a tiny, TINY restaurant so there's usually a line. But it's worth the wait - delicious, unusual pizza in a cozy setting with candlelight. 

Four stars instead of 5 because service is lacking and there's always a wait.
author: Ms K.

description:
This is the best pizza in SF. Hands down.
You have to arrive early at this mom and pop place because it is tiny and they sometimes run out of dough. They run out of dough because people are crazy for this pizza!
The thin crust melts in your mouth. The toppings are fresh and interesting. There are only a handful of pizzas to choose from each night and you get what you get, but there is something for everyone. I have only tried the vegetarian pizzas, but they are always incredible. The fried egg is a favorite.
I love getting a glass of wine and sitting outside at this little gem of a restaurant.
author: Kelly C.

description: i really enjoy this place.  excellent pizza and staff and good beer choices like peroni.  i also had an olive oil cake that was super delicious and i love that it's such a simple but delicious menu.
author: Angie C.

description: Decent and creative menu however limited with slow service and overpriced items.  Cute with potential to explore further.  Small, however not overcrowding.  Nice but not sophisticated ambience.  Quiet and calm relaxing environment with eclectic music in the background.  Often difficult to find street parking close or far from the establishment.
author: M Y.

description: THIN crust and DE-licious - plus it's only a few blocks from Roshambo, which means unemployed me can wander over with the young ones in the middle of the day - love it love it love it
author: Robyn C.

description:
omg, i cant believe i ate the whole thing!  shoot me now. please.

i ordered their tomato, mozzarella, basil pizza. errr...margherita. i was expecting huge chunks of mozzarella and slices of tomatoes. but i got this instead. *clicky* http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/QOpqNPKpClL48TVVrYobAw?select=hP8by2q4mgfQEvvhfChcbQ  oh Pizzetta 211, you disappoint me.

their pizza is very light. 1 pizza is good for 1 person. the crust is so thin, its like eating a cracker. i actually enjoyed their crust and their pizza was actually pretty good. like i said, i ate EVERYTHING. ugh. i'm such a fatass.

next time, i'll probably be alittle more adventurous and try their other pizza. btw, that margherita pizza was about $10.  kinda expensive. =T
author: B B.

description:
everything about this place is perfect--the ambiance, the pizza, the flourless chocolate cake. even the bathroom is something special. my favorite pizza in sf. and maybe the world.

not a great group option. i suggest 4 ppl or less. 

would make a good first date. not too expensive and totally charming.

just remember--it's cash only.
author: arielle r.

description:
If you're the type of person who gives an establishment 1 star because they put sunnyside up eggs on your pizza (something described on the menu), then you should refrain from coming to PIzzetta 211 and instead stay at home and eat a bag of dicks.

Now that that's out of the way, this place is amazing. The restaurant is very, very small, so take that into account when arriving (so, arriving at 8:45 on a Sunday will probably mean you won't get a seat). My girlfriend and I sat at the bar right in front of the register, and got to see the three strapping young lads at work. Maybe I'm just into food preparation. Or maybe I'm just a sucker for vintage-looking band tshirts.

Our pizzas came out pretty quickly for the place being full (we each got one; that's how we roll). Both were made with quality ingredients and were delicious. We didn't get to try the chocolate cake that was starring us in the face all night, but I bet it was delicious too.

The margarita pizza comes with a drizzle of pesto, so if that's something you're going to cry about, make sure to tell them not to put it on first, or join the other 1-star crybabies.
author: Alexis C.

description:
Although it's not saying much, this is really the best "gourmet" pizza in SF.

I changed this rating from 5 to 4 b/c it's no longer the best in sf.
That would have to go to pizzaiola in oakland, and 2nd to A16 in Marina.

Also, they kind of have an annoying 'tude.  It's pizza, nobody loves it  or respects it more than I do.  But, it's still just pizza, get a sense of humor.
author: jeff k.

description:
Years ago when a friend told me about this fantastic restaurant with egg pizza, I was extremely skeptical.  Egg doesn't belong on a pizza, or so I thought, but I figured they must have other good things on the menu.  On my first outing I suggested to my friend, you get the egg pizza and I'll get the basic pepperoni or something, and we'll share.  The pepperoni was mediocre, but once I had one bite of the egg pizza I was hooked.  My friend reneged on the deal, and only let me have a couple bites.  I still hold it against her to this day.  

I've been back well over a dozen times.  Every time I get the egg pizza, and every time I leave fully satisfied.  I'm so in love with the egg pizza that usually I ask for 3 eggs instead of usual 2 it comes with, and then I'm really in heaven.  

Their salads are decent, and I've had some good side dishes.  The desserts are generally excellent.  One time they asked if I wanted dessert and I said no because I couldn't decide between the 2 fantastic looking desserts, so they gave me a sliver of both!
author: Chris T.

description:
I've eaten at Pizzetta many times, and I love the simple and creative, flatbread style pizza. The food has never ceased to satisfy me beyond mere hunger - from the cheese plate or inventive salad beginning to my delicious slice of fruit tart or chocolate torte ending. There are usually 2 or 3 great european style white and red wines, sometimes a rose. They offer a choice of olives, one salad, and a special cheese for starters. There are about five or so pizzas to choose from, all prepared lovingly and artfully. Never had one that didn't make me smile (though I CAN make my own really good pizza at home - in case you were wondering).

The big problem with Pizzetta, and why it gets only 3 starts, is that the staff is INCREDIBLY snobby. I found that even when I lived in the city and went often, they still didn't warm up. This is something that they really need to figure out. The situation here is that they are working with a VERY small space. I mean the size of a bedroom - dining area, kitchen, pantry, bathroom, and all - everything squeezed in. It's a very charming atmosphere, really, but the conundrum that small space presents should not affect the warmth of the staff.

What I've realized about Pizzetta, is that these folks are obsessed with making really good pizza. That obsession I am thankful for, and I definitely recommend this place. I just wish they would PLEASE, PLEASE be a little warmer.
author: Angela M.

description:
Amazing pizza and atmosphere.  It was a treat

A little misleading with their claims on using only locally sourced items in their menu.  When asked why no Californian or North American wines made their menu list, a lack of local selection was explained to be the rationale.  True? Perhaps.  Greenwashing? Perhaps.
author: Dermot H.

description:
i ate carbs for you! on a week day! 

and it was SOOOO WORTH IT!!

Pizzetta is such an appropriate name for this mini sidewalk cafe of a pizza parlor. it is adorably quaint, nestled amongst the residences of the outer richmond, and is super cozy -- just as if you were sitting in someone's kitchen! as a result, it's a good idea to pop by on a day, say, a Tuesday (like we did), to avoid the crowds.

minimalist pizza is the name of the game here, made deliciously thin crusted and topped with a medley of ingredients fresh innovation. our favorite was the kumquat, mozzarella, and olives! they had inadvertently left off the salami, but we didn't mind! i suggest one per person - they are sized personal, with the option to share! (ie. just big enough to get you full and maybe swap a slice or two with your significant other)

with a fun wine list and festive staff, it was a night completed with perfect parking -- right in front of the resto-cafe. 

eat, digest, repeat.
author: Diana L.

description:
What happened to the service at this place?

The pizza is still great but the service - horrible!  The server was nothing sort of  patronizing surliness. It was like he was trying to make you feel bad that you thought he was horrible.
