It took 45 minutes to get the pizza after ordering. They served folks who arrived 15 minutes later than us in no time flat and then proceeded to server the other two tables who had arrived ahead of us. And because of the wait, my wine glass was empty until he 'served' the pizza - in boxes because we were now late. 

We are done with this place...
author: Jason C.

description: The best pizza pie on the West Coast. Authentic all the way.
author: michael p.

description: I actually thought the food here was 'just okay'. And it was pricier than expected. But they served us wine while waiting outside for our table, which was cool, and the ambiance is very cute. Not a great value, though.
author: Laura A.

description:
Super spot... don't know why people hated on the service, what do you want a stuffy 5 star restaurant?! 

Great pizza, loved the egg with sausage.. very friendly staff 

We live a few blocks away so we will definitely come back.
author: Kyle B.

description: Quite possibly the best pizza in the city. At gun point I would take 1) Pizzetta 2) Gialina 3) A16 4) Little Star (Thin Crust) 5) Pizzeria Delfina for tops in the pizza category. The service is very intimate, professional, and efficient. The setting is very relaxed and mellow. The space is beautiful but too small. The pizzas are very small but I don't mind. My wife and I can eat 3-4 comfortably. The delicious sauce, cheese, and wonderful ingredients put it over the top for me. Now that I live 6 blocks away I will be going here even more. It is off the beaten path but worth the wait and meets the hype if you are a true pizza lover.
author: Nick H.

description:
would have been a home run if not for the staff.  totally somber, weird personal music playing (staff person's fav no doubt).  i have never seen such a joyless place.  outstanding-- really great food, but in 5 trips there hardly a smile.  my wife was once scolded because i was trying to park and she rested at the 4 person bar holding a spot for me

the owner is the source of this unhappy feeling spot.  if he is the one we think-- wow-- what a total lack of personality-- not surprisingly everyone else acted just like him-- not so much one of those hipper-than-thou spots-- just ultra serious and quietand acting as if the customer is an intrusion

eaten at Farina and Delfina and Pizza Antica,and Picco in Marin and people were having fun etc.  here it was like a bad day at a  chemical lab in high school.

so we gave it 5 tries and have since written it off-- i'd rather go to Pizza Hut and laugh
author: clinton p.

description:
I've been circling this place in my neighborhood for awhile now, and finally went in.  It was worth the wait!  We got a table for 3 right away, though it is so small (which is part of its charm) that I imagine this was luck.  

We ordered the cheese salad, Rosie's egg, Broccoli rapini, and tomato/basil/pepperoni.  I liked the thin crust a lot.  They also serve beer and wine.  They make everything with local, high quality ingredients.
author: Allison Y.

description: Where else can you find a Corsican wine - by the glass? Stumbled upon this place, after a Legion of Honor visit, on your middle-of-the-run Sunday afternoon. Food doesn't get better than this. Amazingly flavorful pizza's; seldom tasted a better lemon torte; one-of-a-kind doppio. Wow.
author: Carel v.

description:
The food is great, the setting is intimate and neighborhoody. We brought a bottle of wine, which was a good way to go. The downside is it's sort of half-service. It's funny, too. The place is really small, but I guess the staff is too limited (or lazy) to go for the full-memorable-experience-monty.
If you're looking for casual, delicious, and mellow, the pizzas are excellent.
author: C. A. S.

description:
Fan -F-ingtastic!!
Second Time I have been here and the pizza is NO joke.  Perfectly cooked crust, farm fresh toppings-what more could you ask for?

My only real complaint and I know I'm not the only one I'm sure.  The field green salad needs some real help.  Always under dressed and under seasoned.  Have gotten that salad twice now and the same thing, no salt and very little to no dressing. WTF!!  I know it's all about the pizza, right?  Then why have it on the menu?

Will definitely go there again and again, have never gotten any  "attitude" from the staff.  But that's me!
author: frizzle-fry e.

description:
Could be the best in the Bay area! I have had nothing but good pies here. I can't say that it compares to the greats of the east Coast : Pepe's, Sally's, Patsy's etc. But it is a excellent California pizza though with fantastic ingredients, and a really thin crust  that is good but doesn't really have the chewy /springy effect of a perfect east coast pie. Some times i feel like they are to into the fancy combinations of toppings rather than just putting out a excellent pie but one bite of that prosciutto and arugula pizza with farm fresh egg and ..... i start to become a believer.

 1/22/09 Update: I went to last night and i have to say that i was pretty disappointed. The sauce was full of dry spices and there was way to much of it, also rather than using fresh basil they had basil that I'm sure was fresh at one point but was chopped and in oil ...not cool! Also we ordered the calzone ...because all of the other options were just trying to hard a lamb and harrisa pizza, a pizza with romaine hearts.... too much for me I like the classics. Again the calzone had too much sauce and was a real cheese bomb .. i am not sure what i expected i normally don't get calzones but i felt forced into it by the menu. All that being said the service was really good and i like the place ..so i am not willing to change my rating yet but we'll see......
author: Ben S.

description: THere may be better pizza somewhere, but after eating here I have no urge to try to find it!  No wait on a Tuesday afternoon, found the marguerite well nigh perfect, with the sausage, mushroom & eggplant (and plum upsidedown cake) close behind. Great coffee too!
author: Geof P.

description:
I saw this place listed in Sunset  magazine and ... being a tourist ... the out of the way location appealed to me because I was looking for something that felt authentic San Francisco.  
I hopped on a bus across town, expected a long wait (from previous yelp reviews) and as I walked block after block to get to the location, I hoped that I didn't just waste a lot of my vacation time getting to and from this place.  I wasn't disappointed.
Luckily a couple tables opened up outside - where i quickly jumped at the one under the best heat lamp!  the little lights dangling under the tree in the sidewalk, as well as the stack of blankets available to anyone while waiting, created a cozy atmosphere that was totally enjoyable.  Inside it looked like there were only a few tables, but I was very happy sitting outside.
The pizza was excellent.  Thin crust and kind of healthy feeling! Both the pepperoni and mozza/tomato/basil were excellent and there were no doggie bags to carry around afterwards.
Pizzetta 211 will always be in my memory not only for how great the food and ambience was, but because it was also my first location ever having blue bottle coffee...
I'd say it's worth the trip from where ever you are.
author: Ted S.

description: Organic, yes. Locally grown, yes. Sustainable, yes. Gourmet, yes. They got all the buzzwords right. The food's good, because of the previously listed reasons. The seating is , well, minimal. there 4 tables I think. If you want basic good pizza comfort pizza, this is not one of those places.
author: Greg H.

description: What is the big deal about this place?   It was a very thin pizza..nothing special.  The place is tiny.  It's like dining in a walk in closet with some people packed inside.
author: Bleep S.

description: Very unique pizzas.  Try the one with the poached eggs.  You'll need one pizza per person, however.
author: Taylor C.

description: Best GOURMET pizza I ever tasted. Much better than Tony's Napolitano Pizza, Creative and unique toppings and taste. The crust is so white, it taste so sweet. No burnt crust like Tony's. A little expensive.
author: Robert S.

description: This is a great neighborhood restaurant! Super small space--think it was a mom and pop coffee shop in another life-- and only about a dozen people can be seated but it's worth the wait! Thin crust pizzas are delicious-- fresh and innovative ingredients and the crust is perfection. Love the egg on the pizza. Salads are simple and exactly as described on the menu.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Tiny little kitchen that churns out delicious food!  The specials are always fresh, seasonal and innovative.  The pizza's are arguably some of the best in the city.  I've been here many times and am always impressed.  Last night we tried the house-made sausage as a starter and the plum tart for dessert.  DELICIOUS!!!!
author: Laura D.

description:
yes little star is excellent and so is delfina pizza and zacharys in berkeley but if you want that extra homemade goodness with the FRESHEST ingredients its only at pizzetta. its in a down to earth neighborhood placed between a street of homes around the corner from a liqour store. 

the place is TINY they make the pizza right in front of you and always have the best desserts made daily. its like going to someones house to eat. plus blue bottle coffee which makes it that much better.
author: Mohammad G.

description:
I was really beyond impressed.  I was hanging out at my buddy's place in the richmond and he suggested we order from this place and pick it up while we watched the basketball game.  

We got a cheese salad, two of the pizzas, and a calzone.  Everything was pretty fantastic.  I'd say the weakest part was the calzone, but even that was good.  It wasn't all that expensive for the ridiculous amount of food we ate, and I would definitely go back.  I only wish I had tried their desserts too!
author: Amit M.

description:
The WORST service in San Francisco. These people have a serious attitude problem. We went there on Saturday around 2pm. They were unpleasant from start to finish. We had decided we were going to check these supposedly great pizzas no matter what so we stayed. Any other restaurant I would have walked away.
They refused to take our order before we had a table "in case the food arrives before the table", when they had a number of tables about to finish and nobody in line before us. By the way I am in my last month of pregnancy and anybody with a brain understands that a pregnant woman needs her food. Then we had to wait for at least 30 minutes (at the very least) before our ridiculously small pizzas arrived. When I was done, I was ready for the main course, but wait, that was the main course. This super thin crust with precious little filling are pretty much tasteless. I think they are targeting people on a salt/seasoning-free diet. The only good part was the thin crust and the insufficient dribbles of good pesto on one of the pizzas. Oh, did I not mention that they are expensive? When you pay over $10 for lunch and you leave the table starving there is a problem, especially with the bad taste in the mouth that this hippie staff did you a big favor by allowing you to spend your money there. Won't go back ever.
author: Elsa T.

description:
If you dine here while squash is still in season, try their butternut squash pizza with ricotta, fried sage, and brown butter.  Sounds (too?) rich, but was surprisingly light.  

At the risk of using too many fluffy adjectives for you fact-seeking yelpers, I'll conclude that I found Pizzetta 211 positively charming!

Don't bring more than three people to this quiet hole-in-the wall, and don't go when I'm there (which will be soon), lest I should be made to wait longer for my food!
author: Daniel S.

description: Excellent pizza, really thin crust with emphasis on freshness of ingredients and flavors. Charming hole-in-the-wall in a quiet neighborhood with execellent service. Very nice beer and wine selection too!
author: Zaax A.

description:
The Soup Nazi moved to San Francisco and took up Pizza.

Don't go here unless you are willing to grovel for your food. Exceptionally rude hippy staff goes out of its way in order to make you feel insignificant. Our greeting was "we're closed" followed by "but some character didn't show up so if he doesn't come you can have his place".This was at 8pm; the place officially closes at 9. Another couple shows up and takes the spot that was supposedly ours. An inquiry is met with a tart "you're last". 

After helping ourselves to the free water, we bumped into a few acquaintances who were dining there. One of the girls tells us that  she was forbidden from coming here by her husband who was bitten by the so-called service. We are told to be mindful of the "attitude". 

We joined them at the table and figured that we could order. Not so. Apparently, this  violates one of the rules (commandments?).  All orders from a table have to be taken at once. I tried to negotiate this point with one of the waiters who cracked his first and only smile informing me that  the manager would be  equally glad to illuminate my standing vis-a-vis the rules -- nevermind that our friends were no were near completing their meal and that we would all likely leave in tandem.

After relaying my thoughts regarding the "service" to the staff,  I was told to leave and found myself being "manhandled" by two weak, grody hippies.

Supposedly the Pizza is good, but nothing is worth this kind of sanctimonious BS. One star because this interface doesn't allow for anything less.
author: Peter B.

description:
Yay!  I love Pizzetta!  I  make it out here as often as I can, which is not often enough.  The menu rotates with what's seasonal, so that's a feature that makes it worth going back for.  And I'm rather embarrassed to admit that the bathroom is one of my favorite parts of the whole experience!  There's great lavender soap, there's a movie showing with great music, neat!  I love the atmosphere because it's so small, cozy, intimate and warm.  I love to bring visiting guests for an evening of catching up.  However, you have to be prepared for a possible wait, especially if going at dinner-time, rather than at 5pm.  And waiting outside in the Richmond means fog.  Although Pizzetta thoughtfully provides blankets you can bundle up in!  So you just have to be prepared for this experience.

And now, the pizzas: They're super-thin crust, which is generally not my favorite since I'm a Stuffed Deep Dish Chicago Style girl!  But they're still tasty, with only the best ingredients available, in fun combinations.  All their salads, sides, and sausages are terrific.  They really do put a lot of care into what they produce.  It's not cheap, and oh, super-important to know THEY ONLY TAKE CASH.  But I'd say it's well worth it.  I wish I could eat there more often.  Please go there because I hope you'll really like it too.
author: Jenny W.

description: Love love love the pizza, but am not a fan of the staff. Ever. This is not fine dining, so why are the servers so pretentious? Nothing ruins a good restaurant like employing a bunch of assholes that think they are curing cancer. Guess what? You are serving pizza. Your job is to make customers feel welcome, as opposed to feeling like an inconvenience. And no one likes being talked to like they are stupid. I asked about a particular type of cheese, whether it was a hard or soft cheese and was told that I had had it before, or something similar. How the hell do you know?! Other than the unfriendly, un-hospitable staff, you are left with a pizza that rivals the best.
author: Peter B.

description: Pizzetta 211 is my favorite pizza place in the city.  I used to think Delfina was the spot to go but Pizzetta beats them hands-down.  The ingredients are so fresh and their specials always capitalize on the season's best produce.  It's super small so you can wait a bit but I always go right at 12pm when they open for lunch so that I can guarantee getting a table.  They would be worth the wait though!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
pizzetta 211 does the neighborhood pizza place thing right. parking around there sucks, so you're lucky if it actually is your neighboorhood pizza place and you're within walking distance. you lucky ducks. expect to wait for your seats too, but it's worth it. plus, they'll let you start off with drinkies while you wait. that is, if you're allowed to wait. see, they only have a set number of doughballs pre-made. so if you arrive late, after they've baked up all the pies, you're out of luck.

pizza crust and variety of toppings are excellent. all the combinations sounded so great, it was tough choosing just one. i think we ended up ordering a couple. one margherita and one with egg. and the staff is quite friendly. and it was fun watching them work in concert in the cramped kitchen area. even cuter watching them make their own mini pizzas for after-service dinner. definitely coming back soon. and perhaps this time we'll try some of the chocolate cake. it looked so good, i still can't remember why we didn't order it.
author: spiff e.

description:
gnarly pizza! 

so crispy and so fresh. the flavors blew me away. you can tell it's all done with the good stuff. closest thing to ny i've had since...ny. even the anchovies are delicious. if you blink you might miss it on the street. best way to go is early afternoon on a push bike. 

great way to end an epic tour of land's end, or marin mountains. prop your steed against the shady tree or a meter, down a fine italian or belgian and get ready for the best pizza in the city. if you ride a full day, it's definitely one pizza per person. they apparently change the selection weekly. i had one with rosemary. it was so good i ordered another one with prosciutto and sunny-side up eggs. 

the sign says fresh homemade sausages on monday. i know where i'll be tomorrow. 

oh, and conveniently located just around the corner from the absolute best margaritas in the city, Tia Margarita. given the irish bakery down the street, i could party in this hood for many hours.
author: Mulberry S.

description: First, yelp has the address wrong: it's  ** 211 23rd Ave, 94121**: the Richmond. Probably to save you from trying it.   Now the review: I hated this place. Is anything worse than telling your customers that bad service is really something else, in this case part of the 'intimate charm' of the oh so twee dining experience?  Gourmet ingredients, pathetic service. Anyone who would go here should instead walk over to Gaspare's, experience what REAL service looks like, eat a great traditional pizza and leave $20 in my mailbox (I live in between the two). That way you'll have good pizza, good service, and still pay as much as you would have at pizzetta 211. Or, go to Thom's Natural Foods on Geary, buy some good cheese and tomatoes, and make a pizza yourself at home. Then if you want some water or something, make yourself wait 20 minutes. It'll be about the same thing.
author: jim b.

description:
Probably in my top 10 favorite restaurants in the city. Sadly I only get here a couple of times a year, cause my lady isn't the biggest fan of thin crust "fancy" pizza (hey, she's a Texan, you win some, you lose some). But I love this pizza so much, I could almost marry it. There is also something about this place that reminds me of Europe. I like that it is small, and I don't mind waiting, there is something really relaxing to me about sharing a bottle of wine with a friend while waiting to sit down for a superb meal. It's like, slow down already. Just chill. Enjoy life. Don't let it pass so quickly. Savor it. Stop and smell the roses. 
Back to the food. I have tried most of the pizza/s on the menu. They are all fabulous. The one with the egg is heaven in the form of a pizza. They really seem to take pride in their food and their service. I think the only problem with this place is that I really could eat three of their pizza's, and well, that definitely starts to add up...
author: Natalie D.

description:
True story: I was a Domino's delivery dude when I was a punkass teenager.  I had to wear running shoes and RUN the five feet from the parking lot to the store.  I kept getting in trouble for my cool amble, which was apparently harming their brand.
I am scarred and wear hiking boots when jogging -- on principle.
True story: I noticed dents in the cans o' tomato sauce one time and asked where they came from.  Answer: an earthquake YEARS BEFORE.
True Story:  A millionaire in an enormous mansion gave me no tip on a $80 order.
True Story: A family of impoverished immigrants gave me a crisp $20 bill as a tip on a $15 order.
I learned about human nature in its endless diversity.
We were given free pizza.  The dude who owned my Domino's made millions and drove a ferrari.
True Story: I developed a powerful allergy to most American-style pizza: the kind which is about size, quantity of cheese, and breadiness of crust. 
Pizzetta is the exact OPPOSITE of this kind of pizza.  It is thin, subtle, and sublime.  the flavors bloom in your mouth.
Ok, so the waiters don't run around in running shoes.  OK, one of them dropped me from the waiting list by accident. Ok, so the place is the size of a running shoe box.  Ok, so parking can be a byatch.
SO WHAT??  Deal, people.  This is the BEST PIZZA IN SF.
author: James F.

description: Anybody who says there's no good thin crust pizza in this city should be shot.
author: Gil S.

description: I like it.  It's good.  I like it more than just about any other pizza in SF that I have tried.  I will eat it in a box, I will eat it with a fox.
author: Jim H.

description: Adorable, tiny eatery in the Richmond.  The staff are welcoming and the crowd seems to be mostly regulars.  There's very little seating, so come with one or two other people and prepare to wait up to a 1/2 hour.  We tried several of the pizzas and they were all delicious.  Definitely get the Artisan Cheese salad which includes olives, cheese, peaches, salad, and yummy bread.  I can't wait to go back!
author: Rebecca G.

description: Finally had a chance to try this Sunday 10/11 night, normally busy and difficult to get seats.  Pizzetta is kind of a SMALL and Cozy restaurant with only 4 tables, its a small restaurant hidden in the Richmond district of San Francisco.  We had a tomatoe/tomatillo salad, Roasted eggplant, arugula-walnut pesto & ricotta, and the Rosie's prosciutto,cheese and farmer's egg pizza's.  We ordered 2 pizza's and it was enough for 3 people and ended it with the chocolate cake.  This is not your normal round table pizza, its better and different.  You gotta try it to understand.  Now I know why there is so many people waiting outside, the food is great and there is wine and Italian beer as well.  Bravo Pizzetta 211.  I would have given 5 stars, but -1 because of the tight seating arrangement.
author: Ronald L.

description:
I wish I could give Pizzzeta 211 4 1/2 stars.  

The food?  FIVE STARS ALL THE WAY.  This is some of the best pizza I've had anywhere, and I've had it in Tuscany.  You have to like truly authentic-type thin crust pizza.  They toss the dough for each individual pizza right in front of you.  All the ingredients are fresh and very tasty.  

Don't expect a Round Table-type pizza loaded up with cheeses and toppings.  Don't get me wrong-- I love those kinds of pizzas too, but Pizzetta 211's pizza is tasty in a more straightforward kind of way, using nothing but obviously topflight ingredients.  And it doesn't leave you feeling full and bloated afterwards.

Cons: truth is, it's a little spendy, given the price and size of each pizzetta.  I could eat three of them if I were super hungry.  But they are SO good!  Ever try Pauline's Pizza?  I think that Pizzetta 211 is MUCH better.

Also, it's such a tiny location, you will have a very hard time getting a seat at any time resembling a meal time.  We went there on a rainy day sometime between lunch and dinner and they were STILL full.  I believe that they do to-go orders, but it would be a good idea to order well in advance.

Overall, a great little place with great food.  I just wish it were more accesible.
author: Dave N.

description: I absolutely love this place! We were tipped off by the owner and chef at Quince--when we asked them "where do you go when you have the night off", they said Pizetta 211. Simple, cash only, but just wonderful flavors in the pizzas (much written about this) and clean choices, plus a totally satisfying desert. I'd rate the food as highly, in its own way, as any other place we have eaten in the city. The service? part of the appeal. low key all around
author: Peter F.

description:
We arrived very close to closing (9pm) so we were worried about the no dough situation and wondering how happy they would be to make a pizza 10 min to closing.  They had dough and were very happy to seat us.  The tiny place was packed so we sat outside (which has heaters), until something opened up inside.
  
Their menu changes every week so the items we had are not always available. 
-Rosie's Farm Egg, Housecured Pancetta, Potato, Roasted Garlic:  Very savory breakfast on a pizza.  We were a bit hesitant as to how to attack the egg yolk and one of the cooks could tell by our looks so he helped us out and recommended just jumping right in and using it as a crust dip.   
- Butternut Squash pizza:  The squash was slightly sweet which made for a very different pizza than the farm egg pizza.  This one was my favorite and it fed me for lunch the next day.   
-Apple cake:  We were the last ones in the restaurant so one of the cooks offered us some of their apple cake, which does not come around very often.  I am pretty sure they were trying to get rid of the rest of it, but they gave us a large piece with whip cream and did not charge us for it.   It was the perfect way to finish off a great meal.
I really enjoyed the intimate small space, which was quiet, welcoming and perfect for a date.  I also enjoyed how friendly and helpful the workers were even when we came so close to closing and were the last ones to leave.  
I look forward to returning and trying out some of their other pizzas.
author: Tonia D.

description: Pizzetta has some really great tasting pizzas. Although the service/staff is not that great, the pizza makes up for it :)
author: Really G.

description: Pretentious Pie...That is what this place should be called. I went there the other night with my girlfriend. We waited for about 15 minutes which is fine...But what is not fine is that the employees here would rather have its paying customers freeze outside then clean one of their four table promptly to get the customers out of the fog.Then when the customers come in because they notice an empty table they are scolded like children. It seems everyone who works here is a pretentious prick.  If you don't mind being treated like shit this is your place. The pizza is good but not worth the ego it's staff flawlessly displays.
author: elliott a.

description: This place has the rudest staff I have ever encountered.Pizza ought to be fun, not unfriendly. Dont go out of your way, there is better pizza in town.
author: Taylor W.

description: This place has the best pizza in the city and the worst staff in the continental United States. The owners are also the waiters and the pizza makers, so there isn't even anyone there who might be open to some constructive criticism. I've been to Pizzetta 211 at least a dozen times and every single time I swear that never again will I spend one thin dime for atrocious service and an I'm-doing-you-a-favor-by-letting-you-eat-here attitude. But I think tonight actually sealed the deal. We gave the owner/waiter/pizza maker with the creepy animal-spine necklace $80 and got change for $60. When we pointed out the error -- graciously, by the way -- he shrugged and said, "Whatever. I guess I'll take your word for it. No skin off my nose if you want to make $20 off me." WTF? Who behaves like this? I know I should feel sorry for someone who's so unhappy that he gets joy out of being unkind to people, but I just can't be that charitable right now.
author: Jennifer L.

description: You know what, Pizzetta 211?  Your pizza is so damn amazing that I am willing to put up with your lack of table service and unwillingness to accept credit cards.  It is so tasty that I don't mind that your restaurant is so small or that your heat lamps are sometimes broken.  It is so fulfilling that I don't mind too much that I need to eat two of your pizzas to get full or that they are a bit over priced.  It is just so good.  I don't know how you do it.  I want to eat your pizza every day, you bitch.
author: Brad K.

description: Some of the best pizza I've had since moving into the Bay Area has been from Pizzetta 211. Sure, parking and getting a table can be be a pain, but it is so worth it. The whole setup reminds me of a eating at a cafe in Europe; few tables inside and a few tables outside. Not only is the pizza fantastic but their cheese plate is a combination salad and is definitely worth your time. Not that this should influence whether or not you should visit Pizzetta, but they have a cool little TV/art installation in the bathroom which I find interesting.
author: Bucky K.

description: Great thin crust italian style lil pizzas.  This is not your standard order a piece of cardboard to go pizza place.  It's a tiny dining room with great service for a meal meant to be cherished and enjoyed.  A place for neighborhood people, best to walk else take the bus or taxi since street parking isn't likely and the neighborhoodies don't want your car here anyway.  Come early or be prepared to wait for a table since there's only like 4 tables inside and 2 outside.  ...with expectations set, prepare to enjoy  a simply fresh meal and a bottle of wine.
author: P H I L H.

description: Really enjoyed the space, the service was down to earth and pretty fun and the food was terrific!  It's a great place for a simple tasty meal, how lucky for those that live nearby to visit often and try their flavors as they evolve!
author: Lindsay B.

description: Pizza is so good. It's the olive oil mixture Pizzetta drizzles on the pizza at the very end that makes it so good...i think.  I've only been once though...the limited seating and potential of a long wait kills it.
author: Wakako U.

description: Pizzetta 211 is the perfect name for this joint. Just like the pizzettas are smaller than traditional pizzas, so too is the restaurant in comparison to traditional pizza places. The flavor, however, is huge! Plus, the servers are very nice, and it's quite delicious. My favorite was "Rosie's Farm Egg." I can't recommend this little joint enough! Just be prepared to wait, though it may not be for very long. Somehow, despite the few tables it has, it seems to  move pretty quickly!
author: Bridgette A.

description:
I went to Pizzetta 211 really wanting to like this place as it came highly recommended. So many positive reviews leaves me wondering if possibly I visited on an "off day". Not that it was bad in the least - just not the kind of experience that left me thinking I can't wait to go back!

It's a tiny little place - every table and counter space was taken - and I found the guy working that day to be rather cold and offputting - as if I had walked into his home and he really didn't want me there. Not particularly gracious or welcoming. We ordered and decided to wait outside and actually ended up eating at one of the two outdoor tables. It was a freezing day and the small heaters above took a bit of the chill off, but it was still cold! You'll want to be indoors if it's chilly.

I ordered the pizza with the fried eggs on top - quite unusual, but suggested as a favorite by the woman behind the counter. It was prepared nicely, but I just didn't love the flavors - I suppose pancetta and grilled raddichio are not faves. My daughter loved her margarita pizza and my husband ordered the goat cheese calzone and made all gone. Very good, but not quite a knock out.

Great reviews here, but not a total winner for us - we'll still wait in the line out the door for the slice of the day at Arizmendi Bakery.
author: emily b.

description:
134 reviews. Can I really add something? Maybe, because I'm Italian and I love rustic places. Where in the city they bring you wine, they open it, you say 'thank you' and the owner/waiter says 'you're welcome, enjoy' and he leaves without pouring? To 75% of Americans that may sound rude. Well I'm one of those who doesn't like to be served too much and pouring the wine is something personal to me. The guy impressed me since the very beginning and even if it was a non-vintage Pinot noir, it was a real good choice (they had only three wines at that time) and not expensive at all.
Stunning tasting glasses? No, a small thick 'osteria' glass, perfect!
Pizza, crunchy and thin, perfectly seasoned and not overwhelmed even if I'm not a fan of eggs on top of a pizza. 'Do you guys want dessert?', 'No thanks, we're good, we'll finish the wine and take coffee'.
Happens that we were the last customers, so dessert ( a nice cake with fresh whipped cream and strawberries) came as a generous gift from the owner with which we had a nice and comfortable conversation. Coffee was great and the pizza-guy was looking at us like saying:'Are you guys going or not? I wanna go home!'. Even this was perfect, the pizzaiolo MUST give you an attitude, Italy 100%. A real shelter. I'm not telling you anything about the bathroom, go there and check it by yourself. So decadent.
author: Dario B.

description: One of my favorite places!!!  The space is great for a date.  The staff is always nice and the food is wonderful.  Get there before they run out of pizza dough though!  It is definitely worth a go and be prepared to wait and hour or so for a table as there is only four tables inside and two outside.
author: matt g.

description: . Theyre food gets A++++ their pizza selection is the best in san francisco and they use the freshest and best ingredients for them, i would eat it every day of my life if i could
author: Anthony F.

description: what a neighborhood gem! too bad they don't deliver - they'd probably triple their business. but takeout is available and if you can eat it fast enough, it's still amazing. my favorite is the farmhouse egg pizza, but the tried and true margherita is good too. i'm less enthusiastic about the specials - too contrived and busy to enjoy the fresh ingredients.
author: C K.

description: If only I liked eggs, I'd be all over that pizza with the chicken fetus.  I suppose I'll just have to stick to the other choices, which are, by the way, DIVINE.  Ahh...I'm drooling.
author: Sarah S.

description:
this place imbues a vibe that i love... cozy, intimate and casual.  i enjoyed wait-list-wine-sipping, trying to steal pizza making secrets while sitting at the counter, having friendly conversation with the servers and eating the great food. 

the margherita pizza was best, crispy from the cornmeal dusted on the crust and the sauce was tangy and dotted with basil puree. the squash, ricotta and chive pizza tasted fresh-from-the-garden-good, but bland when sequenced after the margherita. lesson-learned: leave more room to fully appreciate the amazing strawberry shortcake. also, they make a solid cappuccino here.
author: jane d.

description: Delish. I love how teeny it is, though I can guarantee I won't ever come here at a peak time - I can see having to wait an insanely long time for a table. Luckily, I came at lunch and they weren't busy at all. Got the most basic pizza - tomato sauce, mozz, and basil - and it was great. Nice crispy crust and a lovely drizzle of olive oil on top. Service was friendly and I am anxious to try the rest of their delightful menu, perhaps next time with a glass of wine.
author: Beth T.

description: I actually didn't have the food, so not sure how the pizza rates.  We had heard great things about the pizza and decided to make the trek all the way to the outer Richmond.  We got there on a Sunday night at 8 pm and the waiter informed us they had run out of dough!!  And then he opened the door for us to leave.  You may want to call in advance to make sure you'll be able to eat ...
author: seta a.

description:
Smug , Arrogant, Pompous

To Management: WHY!?!? no ,.. Really .... Think about it.... I know you read this. Why would you continue to suck at service.

I have been here 5 times  over 5 years and each time if not me someone in your restaurant has left unhappy strictly due to your service.  

Advice :Take out an ad on Craig's list. I almost feel like I should be charging you  a consulting fee because you have for so long been the worst front of the house staff in the Richmond .

You should swap your guy at the register with the guy at Round table your bank account and customers would be better off for it.

I would give you zero stars if I could .
author: Paul-William S.

description: California raised and thereby a default food snob, I was an easy sucker for Pizzetta 211's tiny tiny open kitchen, hand thrown pizzas, wine in short glasses and sturdy wood tables.  The service was casual but the attention to top-flight ingredients was not: The simple and impeccable menu included a salad of field greens, summer squash pizza with roasted walnuts and feta and flourless chocolate cake. We came back after playing at the Bazaar to share another glass of wine at one of the outdoor tables, a perfect balm by which to watch the seasons change.
author: Deborah C.

description:
everything at this pizza joint are puny, limited, insufficient, cramped:

they only have seven tiny tables that could seat 2-3 people or 4 if the fourth is a toddler/baby/or if it is your bagpack or your  trendy oversized bag that wouldn't mind being squished!!!...and don't expect to have a leg room either! furthermore, there are 4 uncomfortable stool bars available for you, if you don't mind eating your measly portions on a restricted counter.

their heavenly, budding with flavor "mini thin crust pizza" (tomato, mozarella, basil & pepperoni) were also petite in size. one order was not sufficient to feed our hungry stomach. in a whole pie, you could only have 6 dinky slices!!!

the organic green salad with balsamic vinagairette was just a "handful"....really! nothing special about this one!!! what a waste of our $5.50 each.

the only thing that are enormous at this joint are the prices!!!! yes, they are quite expensive.

so, what's up with the 3 stars??....it was for their good crunchy dough, flavorful sauce and fresh tasting basil and also for the friendly service we got!!!
author: Nelle A.

description:
this is one of the places my hubby took me while we were dating.  i've been meaning to write a review about it but sadly, it took me this long to get to it.  but that's not because of the food or service quality. quite the contrary.

this little restaurant is tucked away in the richmond district -- if you didn't live in the neighborhood or a friend didn't take you there, you may never have found it!

i love this place for their simple, little pizzas. using the freshest ingredients, their pizzettas are delicious and completely hit the spot.  when my husband lived in the city, we would go there any chance we get -- we love the down to earth atmosphere, friendly service and great food. parking can sometimes be challenging and since their restaurant is very tiny, this place gets quite crowded. but it's worth the effort .

my favorites there are their caprese  (tomato, basil, mozzarella) and  rosie's farm egg pizzettas.  yumm!  too bad we don't live closer  or in their neighborhood -- this would be a regular spot for us to order takeout or pop in for a meal!
author: yvonne g.

description:
you know how once in a while, you have a dining experience that leaves you with an almost post-coital glow of divine satisfaction? 

yeah. it's like that at pizzetta 211. 

and you should take your date here. 

crammed between houses, this place is a true gem. yes, it is tiny, but not in the sense that your personal space is constantly being encroached upon or that you can hear your dining neighbor's conversation better than your own. it's intimate, it's the picturesque neighborhood joint, and it gives you that slight feeling that you've walked into a warm, friendly person's kitchen. the dimmed lighting, rustic interior (serendipitously cool), the neighborhood feel - it's all very charming and romantic. 

the pizza is sumptuous. upon discovering that i could add eggs to my pizza (cracked right over the pizza before it's thrown in the oven), i knew pizzetta 211 was after my heart. sitting at the counter's fun. you get to watch your pizza being made (with much TLC). my personal pizza (the special) was amazing - thin, yet robust crust cushioned the mozzarella, basil, crumbled goat cheese, and these spectacular tomatoes that they had air dried themselves. they were juicy and bursting with flavor. 

i was wary of the staff, fearing that the whole experience would be ruined by rude, haughty service. however, everyone was really sweet and down to earth. 

best time to go is dusk.
author: jennifer y.

description: First time I write a review of a restaurant where I've never eaten. We went to Pizzetta on Thursday and when we got there we got this answer: "We've run out of Doh". They were very nice with us and indicated some good restaurants in the area. In one answer they are telling you, we care, we use daily fresh ingredients, we'd like to have you here next time,... and can't think about a better way to say no. We'll definitely go again to PIzzetta, we got the impression they are great.
author: Alex A.

description: Near perfection. Tops my previous fave, Pazzia
author: Yum Y.

description:
There are those restaurants that remind you, though you didn't know you needed the reminding, why you go out to eat in the first place. There's a scene in 'Melinda and Melinda' (one of Woody Allen's latter, slightly-less-about-himself films), two writers* and their SO's/wives are out to dinner in Manhattan^ somewhere and they're all debating the better way to tell a particular story. The camera pans around the table or maybe there are a bunch of jump cuts, and in and through the scene swim witty remarks, excited banter, and gentle forearm touches between spouses. Waiters slide by amidst the tables in the background, at which sit other, similarly animated groups of diners. It is a clean, well-lighted, lively urban restaurant, and you get the sense that everyone there is, if not happy, then at least the authors or recipients of pleasantly complicated lives, and a meal out with real food and real people is one among their pleasant complications.

If you are, as I was then, of a certain age (early-20's), having just made the big move from town to city (as I had just done), then that scene, and that restaurant, pretty much sum up how adult city life should be.

Pizzetta 211 is, in its own, San Francisco kind of way, how adult city life should be. Whereas Allen's fictional Manhattan restaurant is vibrant and abuzz and peppered with silver platter steaks and has Wallace Shawn cackl-/tittering at a table for four, Pizzetta 211 is tiny and quaint and behind a non-descript storefront on a non-descript street. 23rd Avenue, about 1/5 of the way in (they've gotta be bending some zoning laws). No reservations*^, but they have blankets and places to sit, and if the wait's at all substantial--say, more than 15 minutes--they'll begin to serve you wine. Seating capacity is around 25: four smallish tables and four-person bar and two to three tables outside for the hardy and/or blanketed (though heat lamps are suspended by the awning).

I've been here six, seven times. Without exaggeration, the service has gotten friendlier over the years as they've made more and more of a name for themselves; this alone should tell you something. It is ideally lit--not too bright, not too dark--and the decor is minimalist but not spare, and not at all pretentious. Their bathroom is right out of a late David Lynch movie, and I mean that in a good way (just go in there and see for yourself). 

Their salads, olives, bruschettas and cheese plates all taste beautiful: fresh, real food that is carefully and simply done in a way that lets the food speak for itself. The wine list is what it is--short, with good wines (as far as I can tell), but, Dear Pizzetta 211, Why don't you also source your wines, locally?--ibid. as to the dessert list. The pizza, though, is perfect. And since pizza, perhaps more so than any other genre of food, is a subjective experience, let me run down for you why I think it's perfect:

+ great crust (thin, crispy without being crunchy)

+ great sauce (plenty of places fuck this up; it needs to be a little sweet, but more importantly not just one-note (ie, tomato)) 

+ inventive combinations that are never shark-jumpy

+ real ingredients, sourced from real people and/or real farms that aren't too far away and that, again, they let speak for themselves

It's funny. As I come to the end of this review it seems to me that the components don't exactly, or don't obviously, add up to 5 stars. Maybe I'm just a sucker for tiny places, or for awkwardly zoned places, or for places with David Lynch bathrooms...I don't know; I can't explain it. It's just the kind of restaurant to go to to help you fall in love with this life we live.

Go and see for yourself.


*Male, obviously ("obviously" because it's Woody Allen, not because I'm a misogynist.)

^Not that this matters, and if I can write this here without seeming like an insufferable Manhattan-knower, but I always think this restaurant is Pastis, in the Meatpacking District.

*^If you're annoyed by this, fine; if this is a deal-breaker for you, get over it.
author: T U.

description: I'm in love.  I had a terrific pizza here yesterday for lunch on the sidewalk at this tiny pizza place that isn't really like any other pizza place.  I devoured every bit of my asparagus, pea tendril, green onions, fontina cheese and hazlenut pizza.  Who thinks up combinations like that anyway?  Pizzetta 211 does, and with great success.  Service was excellent and attentive, too.
author: Blue L.

description:
Yum Yum and Yum!  I have been here at least six or seven times now, and have never had a bad experience.  I will wait as long as necessary to be one of the privileged 15 people who get to dine at Pizzetta.  In fact, I have waited over an hour before and it was well worth it.

Tips: 
-They only take cash, so bring some (minimum $20 a person just in 
  case)
-If there are only two of you, I highly recommend sitting on the stools 
  at the counter.  You will get to see all the pizza getting made and will 
  get to chat with the staff, who I have found to be very friendly
-Flourless chocolate cake--super good, and I am not usually one for 
  dessert!  It is very rich though, so think about sharing!
-Ask about a special dessert, sometimes they have one that is not 
  listed, depending on the day.
-Stray outside of the typical margharita pizza--while it is very good, I 
  don't think it will provide you with the full amazingness Pizzetta has to 
  offer.
author: Whitney T.

description:
I salute the owners of Pizzetta.  You guys are wonderful, and I can tell that you have a passion for good quality food.  It is places like Pizzetta that make San Francisco a great city for food.  There are hundreds of  restaurants in San Francisco, and it takes something special to rise above.  You have achieved that. 

The pizzas are fantastic and the flourless chocolate cake is superb.
author: Adam S.

description: My boyfriend took me here on a date.  I pizza is fantastic!  The people working there are polite.  It was freezing out so everyone wanted to sit inside and they are a very small place.  I don't think they let you wait inside because of this... I think there might be 1 or 2 spots to wait inside at a little bar area.  I actually liked that though because when it was finally our turn to be seated it was nice to not have people watching us like hawks!  There were places to sit outside while we wait and a very nice man offered us a drink menu while we waited.  No one wanted to eat at the two tables they have outside under the heat lamps because of how cold it was so they allowed us to sit there as long as no one else wanted to eat outside.  The entire staff was fast and friendly.  They checked in on us when needed and left us to talk otherwise and even though there are probably always more people waiting to be seated due to how small this place is they never made us feel rushed.  I had the margarita pizza, pizza is a splurge for me but this place is going to have me eating it a bit more than I should!  It was light and crisp, the sauce was fantastic!  It was honestly the best pizza I have had in I can't remember how long!  They have a good wine and beer selection too!  Once my boyfriend and I were done with our pizzas the staff didn't seem to mind at all while we stayed around and talked while we finished out wine.  Eventually we did try to hurry out as we knew others were waiting and the place being so small we didn't want to take advantage.  This is going to be my top place for a date night near my boyfriend's house that's for sure.  I think for all the fresh, local and organic ingredients this place is very reasonable.  I have already told my mother about it and how we have to go here when she comes to visit!
author: Christina H.

description:
i never anticipated san francisco to be such a heavy influencer of my pizza choices in life. from this city, so many different pizza experiences have come to my attention and shaped my entire being, forever changing me as a person - for the better. from fast, cheap pizza late at night to deep dish to gourmet, i've found so many ways to enjoy this seemingly simple food.

last night i went to pizzetta 211 with three close friends for a birthday dinner. i was immediately impressed with the size of the restaurant (small), location (quiet, residential neighborhood in the outer richmond), seating options (there are heaters for the outdoor tables and it was cold last night), coziness, and design. as an additional bonus, there is nothing gimmicky about this place. one of my personal favorites was in the bathroom. above the toilet is a tiny television with its own stage and curtains.

the menu was very nice. we decided to get a few pizzas and a salad so we could share. the waiter remembered some of my friends from a few months ago and was extremely friendly. he even brought us over a free appetizer because he knew we'd love it - the sausage-stuffed squid in tomato sauce with polenta. we had a pizza with hen of the woods mushrooms, one with pepperoni and white anchovies, and the potato and fried egg pizza with prosciutto. the crusts are thin without being too crispy and everything went down smoothly with a french red.

i'm not sure how i had not heard of this place before, but i would definitely love to return soon.
author: Jeremiah W.

description:
it's off the beaten path, but they still have to back crowds back with a stick. the style of the place makes me think of french peasants begging for bread rations at neighborhood boulangeries during the revolution. yes, it is small, in demand, a bit snotty and it has an awesome brick oven. let them eat pizza!

it's really all about the pizza-- thin crust, tossed in front of you, and EGG!  oh hallelujah! way too rare in the states. you can get drippy, runny yolks on anything-- best on the four onion special though.

this is the kind of place where you literally see hands on the food, and that's a good thing. maybe i'm a masochist, but i enjoy the wait when i know it's for quality. everyone else in line seems to have a peaceful understanding of the quest for quality as well. you can also bring your own wine bottles. i think the corking fee is reasonable, like 5 or 10. reservations are not allowed. go on a dark and stormy night when you want to cozy up, and fill up."
author: Chelsea B.

description:
pizza oh how i love thee, let me count the ways... as a former new yorker, i find eating pizza to be a challenge in the bay area - not worth eating most of the time - it will pale in comparison to anything i grew up with... until pizzetta 211

love the cool & funky ingredients on pizza here - goat cheese on pizza? figs? they put the most incredible ingredients together on a delicious little pizza that are just so ... darn ... tasty. i don't know how they do it but it's so good "when it touches your lips it's so good" (will ferrell, old school movie quote)

wanna know why it's not 5 stars? "hey rich & z, let's go to pizzetta 211 tonight" "cool, sounds good." (20 minute drive later & we're in front of pizzetta 211) "uh oh, it's 9:15 pm on a saturday night and they ran out of pizza dough..." 

note to self: leave early on saturday night to eat @ pizzetta 211
author: Heather F.

description: Hands down this is my favorite pizza place. I have been going here for years and it is hard to choose between my regular favorite the rosemary/pinenut or the special- whatever it is you can't go wrong. The cheese salad is delicious and flourless chocolate cake lives up to the hype. The bathroom is worth checking out. Minus one star for snooty staff and being cash only.
author: Nicole G.

description: Our favorite neighborhood restaurant. Great thin crust pizza without being a cheesy pizza parlour. Always try their special sides or salads for the day. The fresh ingredients combined with the simple recipes make for real, unencumbered, pure food. Who would have thought eggs on a pizza was a good idea? Cheeze is fresh and high quality. Cozy, romantic, and won't break the piggy bank. A great date spot for those who want to impress another with a hidden, intimate, simply great thin crust pizzas. Low lighting makes everyone look good.
author: Lauren C.

description: I love innovative pizza. Seriously. And this place has crazy neat pizzas. I had a pizza with pine nuts, rosemary, and really yummy obscure cheese that I had never heard of before (I don't even remember the name). Their menu isn't overwhelming, just a handful of quality choices. I think everyone I went with was thoroughly content with their food. We came here for lunch, and there were only two other people inside. We sat outside and it was overall an enjoyable dining experience.
author: Tatiana J.

description:
Fantastic food using fresh local organics.  Very romantic, a cozy dining experience.  
Cash only, no reservations so be prepared to wait- the food is worth it!
author: Ondy S.

description: Yum.  The pizza here is good.  The toppings here change occasionally, but I usually get the one with egg on it.  It's hard to go wrong though and it's nice to sit at the counter and watch them bake the pizzas and eye the last of the desserts.
author: April Y.

description: Surely one of the best kept food secrets in the city, tucked away on a residential street in the Outer Richmond.  The people are awesome, the vibe is fun and laid back (check out the restroom decor), and the Neopolitan style pizzas are creative and delicious.  Pizzeria Delfina doesn't hold a candle if you ask me.
author: Buzz A.

description: I'd like to quote yelp for this restaurant, "Woohoo! As good as it gets!"  I just wish they had more seating, so I could bring a bigger party there.
author: Sarah A.

description:
good for what it is. foofoo fancy pizzas and some small plates. dont even think about dining in, the place is very small. 

i must admit though, even though the pizzas are like the size of a single blondies slice, there are damn good and you can tell they take pride in their work. they only use the best ingredients. the crust is super good. i would like to get just a pizza crust and smack that up into bread sticks. yum. 

for me however, the whole pizzetta experience was not my thing. i guess you can take a person out of the food ghetto, but you cant take the food ghetto out of a person. 

would add another star if it was only a bit damn easier to dine in.
author: Euge L.

description: I really love eggs and I love my yolks to be runny. The farm egg pizza is right up my alley and I order it every time. I am completely obsessed. Yeah, I see all the other options and they have a rotating menu so you would never feel stale - but how can I pass up a delicious farm egg pizza? I can't! The ingredients are super fresh and nothing beats having a crispy hot pizza right out of the oven to call your own. And it's such a cozy little neighborhood place with great food and Italian beer and wine, friendly service, and big heat lamps. What's not to love? Well, I don't love the wait but it actually does go by pretty quickly. I've sat outside and I've sat at the bar, where you can make nice convo with the staff and learn interesting stuff about beer and food in general. Just be careful when you sit on the stool next to the wall though - I smacked my head against the bookshelf on the wall a few times when I was sitting in this seat. It could just be that I'm taller but you just gotta be careful when moving around in such a tight space.
author: Queenie C.

description: Don't drive cause you will NEVER find parking in this neighborhood.  The pizza is delicious and well worth the money in this nice local place.  I believe it was voted 'most romantic' or something which I could see if you actually got an inside table.  I don't think I've ever sat inside before but that is fine if you don't mind hanging with the locals sipping wine out front.
author: Anna L.

description:
It's actually 4.5 stars, the half point deduction is for the size of the space.  I felt like I was dining in someone's closet!  Also, I was a little skeeved-out that the desserts sit on the counter, uncovered, while people dine around them.  One sneeze and they'd all be done for- that is, if the sneeze was heard by the right person.  Otherwise, they'd just be served to unsuspecting folks.  Eeeww.
The pizza was an absolute delight...light, crisp, and somehow, vegan.  They adapted one of the special features for me, but straight up told me I'd have no choice what went on it, that would be up to the chef.  (Uhh, OK, the Chef is right behind you, and I can see every ingredient she's grabbing?)  That was the only time I felt the weird pretentious vibe that others have referred to in their reviews, but it was indeed an odd feeling.  
The glass of wine I ordered came in a tumbler-- it had to be like a 10- ounce pour.  I'll be the last to complain about that.  
Between the two of us, we had 2 personal-sized pizzas, a beer, a wine and shared a (non-sneezed-upon) dessert.  Needless to say, we nearly fell off our stools when the bill came to 71 bucks.  I guess it snuck up on us, so be in tune to that if you're on any type of budget.  However, it was worth the yumminess and cozy couple time we enjoyed at the 'za bar, without even having to wait one minute outside.
We shall return!
author: Lea N.

description: I love what they did with the place!  Tiny, tasty and true.   I tried the Margherita, which was good by San Francisco standards.  Also had pizza with pine nuts and goat cheese, which was VERY GOOD.   The menu is short, but when food is like that, I do not care for endless choices.  Wholeheartedly recommended.
author: Matteo F.

description: This place was a great surprise! It is thin crust, fresh home-made pizza. Their pizzas are more original and gourmet opposed to the typical pepperoni. Also, their homemade chicken sausage appetizer was amazing, as was the chocolate simple flouless cake with cream. This place is small (8 tables or a counter area), so arrive early or eat there for lunch.
author: Vanessa B.

description: Excellent pizza!  It's a small place, so there may be a wait -- but it's worth it.  I love thin crust pizza and they do it perfectly.  The pizza selection at the top of the menu varies, but they have a couple standards that are always an excellent choice.
author: Chris R.

description: I love their pizza, their atmosphere and their beer. Love that its in my neighborhood too, and that they have some outdoor seating.  BUT their hours stink and they can be unaccomodating. Guess you can do that when you've got something good going.
author: JB S.

description:
Although I'd never heard about Pizzetta, I'm glad I did.  Made for a great, pre-show dinner.  Knowing ahead of time that the wait could be long, the 20 minutes we waited for a table didn't seem so bad once we put our names on the list.

Dinner consisted of the cheese salad (mixed greens, with two types of cheese, olives, bread, and candied walnuts), the rabini pizza (prosciutto, broccoli rabini, a lemon wedge, and cheese), Chimay.  Dessert was some sort of glazed pear with a nice wedge of ginger cake and a dollap of whipped cream.  $40.

The salad was a nice intro to the pizza.  Although I'm a sucker for cheese and bread, you wouldn't think to get cheese and bread as a prelude to pizza, but it worked out nicely.  My one complaint is that the rind on one of the cheeses tasted a bit like chlorine.  Easy enough to fix: cut off the rind.

With regards to the pizza, I hate it when people describe food as "sublime," but I'll have to say the pizza was just that.  Nice, thin crust that you could fold in half without it breaking or dumping out the contents.  The fresh lemon squeezed over the top made gave the broccoli rabe a nice bite with the salty prosciutto.

The ginger cake was, to put it simply, a nice finish.  I'm not sure how the pear was prepared (it looked like it had been caramelized in a pan with sugar), but it finished things up nicely.

As far as the service goes, they were very pleasant.  Maybe it was because we didn't try to cram into a tiny restaurant instead of waiting outside for our names to be called, or we didn't insist on sitting in an empty chair, despite the fact that there was a list of names ahead of us.  Either way, the server brought the check to the table, apparently something of a rarity at Pizzetta, and thanked us for coming in.

That said, if you, like the lady below, are 8 months pregnant, don't want to wait, there are plenty of other places a block down on Clement that you'd probably like.
author: Chris D.

description: This place is my favorite hideaway. The simplicity is what wraps it up with a big bow. Only a few tables, a simple yet worthy selection of wines, amazing pizza, delicious desserts and consistently friendly service. They always remember me when I come in and treat me so well. Being a server myself, I appreciate the thoughtful reception every time I visit. It is like sitting in your favorite friend's kitchen and enjoying a cozy and delicious night. Love this place....
author: Nathalie P.

description: One of the best pizza places to go to if you're a foodie. If all you want is generic pizza, then you might not like it as much, as the place is a bit tiny and parking can get nuts in this area. The salads are always good and desserts are real lovely. Try to taste the more unique combos - anything with the farm egg topping is awesome!
author: Tami Y.

description: The best pizza in town.  It's light and very tasty.    It is small and they don't do carry-out every day, but when they do, jump on it, you will not regret it.  I recommend the margarita (I know that is not spelled right.....)pizza.
author: John c.

description:
Forget Little Star, this is the best pizza in SF! 

Try the anchovie pizza, the anchovies are soaked in olive oil and provide this tangy deliciousness that is out of this world. It's the only anchovie pizza I will ever eat.

Desserts are good and the chefs will talk your head off about jazz and blues if you give them a chance (sit at the bar).
author: nathan s.

description: I'll keep this short.  This is some of the best pizza I've had in San Francisco served in a cozy quaint setting with fun and attentive service and a decent wine selection.  I would go back any time.
author: Chad W.

description: I found the white anchovies that they use. They are so delicious! They are Dinon brand and come in a white tray with clear top. I found them at Canyon Market in Glen Park. Hurray!
author: Marina N.

description:
cute little pizetta makes you feel european. as you bite into the luscious egg, pine nut,and rosemary delight pizza, and sip wine from your small glass, and fork the homeade single dessert of the day, something feels just oh so right. like you could be in some nameless town in france, or italy, or the french part of switzerland, perhaps. 

(just dont be too authentically european, and go here for a late dinner, cause they frequently "run out of dough" anytime after 7:30pm. and then just stare at you with a smug look that says all too loudly.. you're american, dude! give up the dream"
author: miss lisa k.

description: I am not a big pizza person. Most pizza just doesn't get me too excited. Well, I really liked Pizzetta 211. We got there right about when they opened for lunch on a Saturday. We snagged a cozy table in one of the front windows. The appetizer was great - I wish I cold tell you what it was called, but it was basically melted savory cheese with basil leaves in a ramekin, roasted beans and tomatoes with crostini. It was delicious. The olives for $3 are also yummy. Beer selection very good for a place this small. I had a Grand Teton Sweetgrass APA (http://www.grandtetonbrewing.com/SG.html) -- yum, it was good! For pizza, we had the egg with Tunisian spices and peppers. It was delicious. The peppers were a mixture of sweet and hot...the spices were perfect, not overpowering. The crust (most important part of a pizza) was crispy -- not doughy. Unfortunately, we also split a piece of peach pie....again...yum!! Crust was not overworked; crispy in the right places. The peaches were fresh and delicious. An extremely generous dollop of freshly whipped cream made it even more special. I would go here again and again and again.
author: Susan G.

description:
Love this place.  Has my favorite pizza in the city.

I cannot understand why this place would get less than 4 stars.

The food is amazing.

Important facts to remember:

Come on the early side.  They DO run out of food. Coming at 8 pm on a wednesday will probably be fine (no promises though!).  Coming in at 8 on Friday evening when it's unseasonably warm?  You are probably screwed.

I never go later than 7pm. And so I'm never disappointed. If I feel like dinner around 9pm, I don't go to Pizzetta 211.

The menu changes and I ALWAYS order one of the special pizzas.  They are always delicious.  

Wine is reasonably priced.

Staff is nice (although I've been going for YEARS and there is never even a glimmer of recognition!  It's my one pet peeve, and it's tiny, so I didn't remove a star- the staff ALWAYS SAYS, "and we are cash only" to me as if I havent been going at least once a month for 5 years! WTF?)

Sides are delicious, but also tend to "run out" earlier in the evening.

desserts are YUMMY.

I give this place five stars based on the fact that the food is excellent and I am never disappointed.  If you too want to love the food and not be disappointed with menu items running out, then come early and come often!
author: Bianca G.

description: Small but cozy place, good  for lunch or a date night. Love their Pizza, dessert and coffee all good.
author: christy l.

description: I may have just eaten the best pizza of my life. Fresh egg, prosciutto, potato, with pesto. Amazing!  I ordered to go, and forgot my dessert when I left. Someone actually chased me all the way down the street to bring it to me. Now that is great service!  The dessert was phenominal as well.
author: Scott K.

description: I'm amazed that this place still has legs, with A16 and Pizzeria Delfina in play. Seriously overrated.
author: Tonya M.

description: I have visited Pizzetta 211 a few times and have to say that the people working there are great. First experience was horrible because of the rude waitress but she isnt there any longer. Everything from the Pizza to the salad to the wine is awesome. A must if you are in need for a great, not so traditional pizza. Bon a petite.
author: Edson C.

description: Delicious!  If you're hungry, order one for yourself, but they're plenty big enough to share unless you've just worked out or something =)  I'm a fitness professional and I'm often extra hungry after a workout or a class, and these little pizzas hit the spot..  Parking can be a challenge, and expect to wait for a table, but it will be worth it.  Next time I'm trying the yummy-looking chocolate cake for dessert!
author: Nicholle B.

description: Great little place for pizza. Heard about it a few times from different people so thought I'd give it a try. Went on a Monday and had to wait a little while, so can only imagine how it gets on the weekend (there are only about 4 small tables inside and two outside). However, totally worth the wait. The staff is friendly and the place is just super mellow. Great sausage (homemade), got the special which was sausage with squash, cheese and toasties - YUM. Pizzas change daily (I think). Good variations of toppings. Prices are ok. Definitely recommend and will go back. Not good for large groups and I wouldn't take kids unless they can stay seated the entire time.
author: Michelle W.

description: nice place for a date. very enjoyable & worth the trip out.
author: Matt J.

description:
The pizzas are delicious, and I love that I always still have room for dessert.  My boyfriend likes the olives and the by the glass wine selection. 

I have always had great service, the wait staff has never been rude, and I have never had to wait long for a table.  I do have a habit of going to restaurants at odd hours though.
author: Susie O.

description: My older brother introduced me to this place a couple of weeks ago. Definitely the best pizza I have had in the city. The place is great, but SMALL. We made the mistake since we were a group of 5. It took some time (not long though) to get a spot. We sat outside (needed two small tables) and luckily they had heat lamps which made for a great atmosphere. I kept it simple and got a margherita  (i know i know, not creative), but i was looking for something simple and it ended up being great. I have a soft spot for thin crust and this place fit the bill. This place would totally be a good spot for a date. High fives for pizzetta 211.
author: Cameron R.

description: I can't believe I've lived in SF for 9 years and only discovered Pizzetta a few weeks ago. I've wasted so many precious moments on inferior pizza. This place is t-i-n-y, you can't even wait for a table inside. But the pizza is truly divine. They also have really good coffee (Blue Bottle).
author: Pamela S.

description: This place is a great find.  Delicious food and a neighborhood atmosphere.  I have tried almost everything on the menu and it all has been great. I highly recommend the cheese and olive plate.
author: Ryan R.

description: Delicious and inventive pizzas in a cozy intimate setting. I love that its nestled in a very residential area near my hood! The ambiance evokes the feeling of dining at a friends house. The pizza had a great thin crust with just the right amount of toppings. Tried the special heirloom tomato, green and wax bean salad in a thyme vinagrette that was phenominal. It was perfectly balanced - fresh and flavorful. We went on to the Farm Egg, Pancetta, Roasted Pimento Pepper, Arugula, Manchego and Squash-Sorrel Pesto, Cherry Tomato, Goat Cheese, Chive pizzas. Delicious. Its not the heavy NY style pizza people think of when they go out for pizza. This is neo-p style. Thin cracker-like crust with a light application of toppings. The only negative is that each pizza is pretty small. I ate a whole one by myself and could've tacked on a few more slices if we hadn't polished off everything in front of us.
author: Stacy T.

description: OMG amazing thin crust pizza.  The rosemary-pine nut is divine.  They change the pizzas weekly (or daily - I don't check that often).  The salad w cheeses is great too.  Really tiny space - only seats about 8 people.  I've never had to wait but I go on random weeknights kinda late.  I've found the staff really friendly also.  Maybe I was wearing the right outfit (gym clothes).
author: Janet S.

description:
my husband would call this place "raw gourmet". what does that mean you might be asking...dare i try to explain. words can't explain it. pizzetta is an experience - an experience which includes excellent thin crust - gourmet - pizza. 

* have fun with this place let it go if you come too late and they run out of pizza go somewhere else - think of it as a gift if you get to dine.

* enjoy every morsel of your visit (including the decor).

* bring cash.

* hubby says, just come in a pair.

* pass on the green salad (have one at home).

* enjoy the experience.

ps. our friends got engaged here...
author: Jill R.

description: This place is solid.  I love the vibe - tiny, cozy spot with very friendly and hip staff.  There's a little waiting area outside and they provide blankets for chilly, foggy evenings.  The cheese salad is incredible, and their ingredients are usually organice and very fresh.  Minus one star for running out of the pizza we wanted, though.  Oh, and the deserts are incredible -- we had a rhubarb pie, and it was mouth-wateringly good.
author: mazzy r.

description: deducting points for slow service, your ovens are big enough to cook several at a time. then why does it take Sooooo long to get a pizzette? tomato, mozzarella basil pizza  is more like tomato sauce, chopped basil and cheese. I was expecting to see chunks of tomato or slices of tomato with Basil leaves or freshly chopped Basil. great crust, very small portions, this pizza should be slightly larger or it should be called an appetizer. Friendly staff working and running this place.
author: Max M.

description: Possibly the best pizza you'll ever eat. It's not your traditional style and is certainly more experimental but check it out because it's probably the best pizza I've ever had.
author: Jonathan Z.

description: i've been wanting to come here for YEARS but was always discouraged by the long wait.  since i was in the city early today, we decided to come for dinner.  around 615 pm, there was no wait for a table outside, but the inside was full already.  we shared two pizzas and a salad.  we got the tomato, mozzarella and white anchovy pizza and the pizza w/ farm egg, arugula pesto, and goat cheese, w/o the prosciutto.  everything was delicious, and i LOVE egg on pizza.  the pizzas are the perfect size for one person, b/c they are very thin.  i also tried a bite of the carrot, feta, almond pizza w/ salsa verde, which we got to-go.  there was a very garlicky kick and fabulous.
author: Helen T.

description: They really do have a problem here.... last night, at just around 7pm, I arrived with a friend of mine. He ducked in and asked the waiter, "How long for a table?" The response, "Tomorrow. We're all sold out"... no "Gosh I'm sorry we're slammed tonight", no "I hate to have to say it, but...", just a rude waitperson. Again. I've been to Pizzetta many times, I live right nearby, but this has become a pretty regular thing. So the question is: is it worth it? I'm thinking no.  The folks at Little Star are often just as slammed, but never rude. It's a restaurant. You get busy. Deal with it.
author: Trixie K.

description: Tres Delicieux!!!! Mmmmmmmm, the menu changes seasonally, or maybe more like weekly, anyway, if it's there, try the rosemary pizzetta or the spinach currant pizzetta(the salads are always  good) OH and you MUST try the flour-less chocolate cake, mmmmmmm.
author: Holly Golighty M.

description: Not that it needs another great review, but I love this place. It is that perfect neighborhood place everyone is always looking for. Because of its size though (or lack there of) I have taken the "geriatric" dinner approach and am usually there between 5 and 5:30. So completely worth it!
author: Katy D.

description: My favorite place to get pizza in SF! Amazing thin crust pizza.
author: Meg P.

description: good thin crust pizza with a ever-changing fresh ingredients with weird combinations. Small, homey, but they always see to run out of dough too early... I've been turned away more than once becuase of this! silly
author: Hamayun N.

description: quite simply the best pizza in san francisco. and i've looked all over this fair city of ours. i've eaten here about 30 times and have never had a meal i didn't love (though, one time i ordered the calzone and wished i had just gotten the pizza). everything is fresh and it shows. it's a small dining room, so be prepared for a little wait. i promise it'll be worth it.
author: David G.

description: oh wow. Amazing pizza. This place is very unassuming on the corner of california and 23rd, and only sits about 6 tables inside, and 2 outside (there is always a line - so prepare for 30 min wait) but the food is amazing. Delicious pizza - though they serve pepporoni pizza, i would suggest trying one of their unorthodox pies; everything I have had has been great. Service is great, its a charming restaurant - great for dates. It is cash only.
author: Steve S.

description: I hate to sound cliche but this place is a neighborhood gem.  Delicious EVERYTHING- and all made right there in the tiny kitchen.   The pizza guy even humored my attempts at speaking Italian.
author: laura a.

description: PIzza's were excellent! Beer selection was solid and service was great. Definitely a 'must try' in the Outer Richmond. Farm egg pizza with speck was amazing as well as the San Marzano pizza. The cheese salad was stellar. How can you go wrong with cheese salad!
author: Nikki T.

description:
i've only been here one other time and it was at least two months ago.  the chef (and possibly part-owner?) recognized us tonight walking up and gave us a hiddy-ho and a wave.  this set  the stage for an evening of divinity.  no, jesus was not present at pizzetta 211, but he might as well have been as i took my first bite of the cheese salad.  don't even know what types of cheeses they featured tonight - as they rotate weekly - all i know was they were dang good.

brandon, the aforementioned owner/chef, brought us a complimentary pork-sausage stuffed squid just for the hell of it.  he didn't even know it was my fiance's birthday, which really just made the kind gesture that much sweeter.  i was grinning from ear to ear.

three pizzas ordered:  fried-egg w/ pesto (seems like the iconic "must" for this place), anchovies with other yummy goodness, and hen of the woods.  all different, all blessed by the hand of god, surely.

brandon, we all agree: your stellar food and service make this place very worthy of a repeat visit.  rub a dub dub, thanks for the grub.  yay god amen.
author: Julia J.

description: Don't go here.  The pizza's terrible.  The service is awful.  Dont tell anyone about this spot. It's the worst.   Now do your job and keep it the best kept secret in town.  :)
author: Chris D.

description: Absolutely delicious.  In line with all the other reviews, the place is tiny, but well worth the wait.  The outdoor heaters and blankets make the wait comfy and cozy, even on a foggy San Francisco evening.  Once inside, you don't feel rushed.
