The wait staff is warm and friendly, and the guys making the pizzas are awesome at what they do.  My husband had the rosemary & pinenut pizza, my friend had an off the menu, specially made vegan pizza, and I had the arugula & marscapone pizza.  All three were so mouth wateringly satisfying that we all just wanted to keep eating more.  The pizzas are the perfect size for an individual and fill you to just that point of contentment where you feel good about what you just ate. Good wine and beer selection, and tasty desserts.  Do remember that it's cash only, so come prepared with cash on hand or an ATM card to make a visit to the machine down the street.
author: Jessica G.

description: was craving New York pizza and came to this place.  Wow. SO freaking great.  only problem, place was small.  they need a bigger facility so I can go every week.  one of top fives as for now.
author: Maricel A.

description: This place is a little gem.  I've been a handful of times, never disappointed.  The best was one foggy Saturday, and the pizza special was delicious, as was the wine and dessert.
author: Pam R.

description: Does anybody know why this place doensn't offer pre-order/ takeout on the weekends?
author: Fred X.

description: I love this place. They use all organic ingrediants and the food is great.  But expect to wait for a table as it is a very small place. Also be sure to check out their hours - they close earlier than other places.
author: Stephanie I.

description: The perfect place for an out of the way, intimate, and quiet lunch or dinner Euro pizza.  I've only been at off times when it's relatively empty and I haven't had to wait for a table. Pleasant decor, decent counter staff, and yummy pizzas and salads. I hear they're having roasted chicken one night a week at dinner too.
author: Candice L.

description: This ain't your typical round table or domino's pizza.  this place actually makes the pizza seem more focused in flavors and texture.  just think of it as a more natural pizza, instead of all that crap other places use.  if those types of pizzas are what you're looking for, then try out Tomaso's out by North Beach.  but yea, this is a nice neighborhood pizza place, just a block from where I live.  and they have great flavors of cheeses.  Try the salad too.
author: Vincent K.

description: I've only had good experiences here. We had a tip from a friend that this place is tiny and usually really busy...so we went the first time at 3 on a Saturday afternoon. Food is plentiful, the staff hasn't had time to have a bad night yet and we don't have to wait for a seat. We'd never try to go at the usual feeding times. No way, no how. So far, my favorite thin crust pizza in the city (or pizza period, since I can't really find a slice I like here. I'm taking suggestions!). I liked it much better than Delfina's pizza, which I found pretty flavorless and overly crunchy.
author: Pam D.

description: The best pizza in San Francisco if you exclude my kitchen.
author: Philip M.

description: I checked this place out when my sis lived in the neighborhood a few years ago, but it was pretty memorable. the thin crust margherita pizza was/still is one of the best i've ever had, anywhere.
author: Chris C.

description: It is really small and cute here. It is werid that they have egg in their pizza. The service is really good here, but it is really hard to find this resturant.
author: Janet Z.

description:
First visit tonight:

First off, whether they were responding to Yelp commentary on their snobbery or not, the staff was super friendly and pleasant.  The place had a great vibe.

Pizza was great, though I do not think that oven is a wood-fired oven - it looks like every other old-school gas fueled pizza oven.  We had salads, a margherita, and a pepperoni.  Dessert was a slice of citrus olive-oil cake with fresh cream and blood oranges.  $50.  We'll be back.

Parking in the neighborhood (on a Saturday night with good weather) sucks.
author: Rob P.

description: My favorite thin crust pizza in the city, the margherita + white anchovies is delitioso!  Gets crowded, and was featured in SF magazine a couple months ago, so I expect more-so soon.  Small but comfortable, outdoor dining is nice when warmer.
author: Ken and Yuri Q.

description: Not sure what the big deal about this place is.  It took me and my friend 3 tries to actually eat there - they have the oddest hours - but when we finally got in, it wasn't anything special.  Yes, the pizza was good, but nowhere near the quality of Pizzeria Delfina, A16 or even Zuppa.
author: Serena Y.

description: Excellent thin-crust pizza in a tiny Richmond location. If I'm in the 'hood and craving pizza, this is where I'll go, as long as there's room to sit down inside (outside, too, if the weather happens to be nice enough). Can't speak to the allegations of surly service, but I've gotten my food in a relatively timely fashion.
author: Tara M.

description:
yummmm!  my friends who live in this neighborhood treated me here to lunch one day.

thin crust pizzas that have great toppings.  i mean i could eat a whole one to myself.  we had one that had pine nuts and sheep's milk cheese, or was it gorgonzola?  well anyway it was a white pizza.  my gf's bf had the calzone and that was good too!  they have a yummy tomato sauce, and i feel that the sauces are what makes or breaks a pizza.  or one of the qualities that do, at least.

we had a flourless choc cake and the apple crumble thingy for dessert.  both so tasty!  

god i want their food,  NOW!

it's a small spot.  not crowded when we got there, but i'm sure it gets very crowded.  i mean like 4-5 tables small. 

they have a cute tree that has wooden benches lined around it.  eat your pizza there if u like..
author: Sheri N.

description:
Went here last week with the bf.  We had read about it on Gwyneth Paltrow's blog: goop.com.  I had been craving some thin crust pizza for a while, so I do admit, my expectations were high up there.
We had been told by friends that this is a tiny place, and parking is hard, so arrive early and expect to wait.  Going with this, we got there at 6:30pm(really early for us, as we tend to eat around 7:30).  I guess it was our lucky night, since we got a parking spot right out front, and there was one table open right when we walked in the door!
Since it was still early, and we weren't that hungry, we opted to just skip appetizers and go straight for the goods!
The bf had the classic pepperoni pizza that he loved.  And I went for a rosemary, fiore sardo cheese and pine nut pizza.  It was delicious.  And I LOVED how thin it was!  Although, not the BEST pizza I have ever had, but it definitely was good enough for me to finish the whole thing and leave happy.
What I loved the most about this place is that you feel like you are the West Village or even a little place in Europe.  The fact that it only has 4 tables and 3 stools at the bar, makes it all the more special and intimate.
I highly recommend checking this place out if you love thin crust pizza served in a friendly and quaint place.
author: alex f.

description: If you're looking for a very romantic little Neopolitan pizza place that makes you feel like you're in Italy, this is it. This is not much of a a take out place, and you shouldn't come here looking for salad (as one Yelper did and felt disappointed). This sweet little locale is for thin-crust pizza lovers. As a vegetarian not vegan) my favorite on the menu is the Rosemary and pine-nut. Never would have brought those two together myself, but I salivate just thinking about that pizza. They have special desserts made daily, and often have a wonderful vegetable offering, like fresh organic asparagus with a thick goat cheese sauce. Well worth the sometimes long waits. Bring a blanket if it's cold out!
author: Kath R.

description: Great place! Small, but awesome!  Changing their pizzas every week, they always keep it simple (not too many ingredients), but extraordinary (those ingredients are so interestingly combined) and, of course, delicious!! AND they also carry Blue Battle coffee which is amazing!
author: Anastasiia G.

description: This place is in walking distance of my house!  This is my MOST favorite pizza place in SF, small and quaint, awesome service!!!  The food is to die for!  I love sitting at the bar watching them make their pizza.  We even talked to the owner (I think) who was very friendly, nice and told us about the business.  And they have Blue Bottle coffee my favorite!!!  I love riding my bike there for dinner!  This is a good as it gets!!!
author: Melissa F.

description: Best piazza on the left coast
author: Mark W.

description: Yum! May I suggest the cheese salad. The pizzas are all fantastic.
author: Angela K.

description: I've been wanting to try it for a while and I finally got to go here 1/8/06. We (3) got there around 4:00 p.m. and immediately got seated inside at a rickety table. The staff was really helpful and let us sample the three red wines so we could choose a bottle. You do have to get your own silverware and stuff, but they came to the table to take our order and to deliver it. It was as good as I had read about and as good as it looked when I peeked in through the window. They used tasty cheeses and toppings (my friend had whole anchovies on hers). I love thin, thin pizza. YUM! It's a bit pricey, to be sure, but what good food in SF isn't?
author: Dana B.

description: Great little spot in the Richmond that obviously gets a little too close for comfort during most nights (due to only 4 tables). However, I was able to go on a slower night, where we actually got a table for four. Great staff, great service and great ambiance are the highlights here. Of course the pizza is good, however I should have requested mine to be a little crispier. Its all hand-tossed and the ingredients are fresh and change weekly. I tried the tomato, basil, mozzerella and white anchovies which was very tasty. The Fig pie concoction was good too, even though I'm not a huge fan of figs...
author: Nicolas H.

description: This teeny-tiny joint is a bright, warm spot in the overcast Richmond district.  Their thin crust pizzas kick ass and they also have delicious appetizers and dessert.  Plus, they serve Blue Bottle Coffee.  It don' get much better than that!  Yes, it is a major pain in the ass to wait for a table here, but I've found it quite easy to get a table in the mid-afternoon on the weekends.  Since we have a young baby, we can't go out late anyway, so we just treat the meal like a late lunch/early dinner and splurge.  I love their basic margherita pizza but I start drooling just thinking about their pork shoulder, avocado and tomato pizza I had on one visit.  And I've had no issues with their service, unlike others who have posted reviews....
author: Sharyn F.

description:
if memory serves me, pizzetta is the infamous place where some customer's dog bit my friend outside! oh what a scandal when they weren't in the least bit apologetic.

there are many things i like and dislike about pizzeta. i happen to enjoy the small quarters and cozy atmosphere. the size of the place makes you feel as if you are part of a small community. oh how sappy, but true. the pizzas were delicious, especially the one with the eggs. light, thin, and flaky as if they were exotic delicacies. ha! the prices i think are reasonable for food this fresh and satisfying. and that upside-down-must-have-crack-in-it cake was amazing. moist and soaked with those whole cranberries! 

what i don't like about pizzeta is the customer service or lack of it...the space is small enough for servers to handle the "crazy" crowd. what a joke. might as well put up a sign that says self-service.
author: Faye P.

description: A cozy little pizza joint with good food and plenty of character.  If you like thin-crust pizza, you will love this place.  They change their menu weekly.  The four indoor tables and counter fit about 16 and there are two outdoor tables which means it could be a long wait.  Grab one of the blankets, order a bottle of wine and the wait flies by.  One thing I love is that you can bring your own wine and corkage is only $10.  Hidden but not so unknown gem.
author: Mei B.

description: Showed up at 5pm and was the only one there, ordered the hen of the woods, hazelnut piccada pizza and the beet salad, and was hella impressed.  It was all delicious.  Service is ULTRA casual, like ain't nobody in a hurry here.  They don't have to hurry.  You'll wait.  It's that tasty.
author: Betsy K.

description:
Cute, quaint place.  Nice for two, not good for a large group.  There were two of us and we ordered baby mixed greens with assorted cheeses and candied walnuts, finnochio (sp?), arugula and egg pizza, and a basic pork sausage pizza.  Both were VERY good.  Thin crust was amazing.  We also split a "persimmon pudding" dessert, which was good.  Only wished that the server would have told us it cotained nuts.
There is one strange thing about this place.  You are seated, but then YOU are responsible for placing the order at the register-and it can be a little hard to get TO the register because the place is microscopic inside.  Then you are responsible for getting your own water, and silverware.  The food is brought out to you, cleared and then the server brings you the dessert.   After, you have to go back up to the register to pay?!?!? Its a wierd set-up as far as the service practices are concerned but the food is good.  Nice to share with someone you can be intimate with.  Good date place for sure.
author: Suzanne L.

description: Although this place has a small menu, and an even smaller interior, it is a worthy place to get some tasty thin crust.  You might need two rootbeers for the wait, but it is worth it.
author: Tim G.

description:
super good.

some weird combos of flavors, but i am totally into that.
they have amazing options and the ambiance is sultry.

i could dine here all night if there were more tables.

all in all, a beautiful experience.

oh, and delicious.
author: linden d.

description: I'm not a huge fan of pizza in general, but I have to admit that this place makes fantastic food. Very original topping combinations and great, thin crust. Bonus points for being a cozy neighborhood spot.
author: Diana Z.

description: If you get here early, you might not have to wait for a table. Tiny restaurant, great pizza and if you don't order the chocolate cake for dessert you are blowing it because it is super fine!
author: Mar D.

description:
Came here a few weeks back with a friend on a nice cold night. The hostess was a bit cold also but our waiter (young guy with a beard) was great. very down to earth. cool, and knowledgeable.  he let me taste a few wines before deciding on what I wanted and did so again for my second glass. 

we got the margherita pizza and another one which i can't remember. the margherita was really good, although i had asked for the crust to be well done and it could have used a bit more time in the oven, it was an overall great pie. like other people have said there was a bit too liberal pouring of oil but it didn't really bother me.  the other pizza was good also but not as memorable as the margherita. 

the real standout though was the tiramisu. holy shit! i've been eating homemade tiramisu for many years (my aunt makes some of the most amazing i've ever had and my other aunt, whose i've only gotten to taste a handful of times, also makes an equally amazing tiramisu) and this is the first time a tiramisu has come close and honestly it was almost as good. i kept asking myself - is this as good? and i was torn. it was truly amazing. there was something that made it just one hair under my aunt's tiramisu. not sure what it was (maybe the coffee used and the amount) but i would go back for two slices just for myself not to share it was so damn good. 

overall, i really loved this place and am so happy i finally went in after trying for many times to go over the years but not because it was either too packed or closed. it's a really great place and i'm looking forward to going again.  damn - i'm craving the tiramisu!
author: ezra d.

description:
I eat here at least 2 times a month.

A fresh menu every week with a variety of delicious pizzas and new (carefully chosen) wines and cheeses. And, great deserts to finish it off (I recommend the flourless chocolate cake and the Blue Bottle espresso.)

The place is amazing - unique, very romantic, great music, great service.  

Pizzetta is an experience.  I could go on and on.  The only complaint I have heard is the wait, but come on - sit outside under the well-lit tree (grab a blanket if it's cold) and have a glass of wine!

Also, be sure to check out the bathroom. It's neat.

That's all I got.
author: Wilson K.

description:
My husband and I adore this place - it's decidedly our "date restaurant".  Amazing individual pizzas made with exceptional local ingredients.  Great wines.  Delicious house made desserts.  Casual friendly staff.  Really, it's quite charming.

That said...it's not for everyone.  As others have mentioned, it's tiny, so if you don't get there early in the evening, there's a high likelihood you'll have to wait out in the foggy Inner Richmond cold for a table.  And if your're looking to be waited on hand and foot, go someplace else.  Like I said, the service is very casual - most of the time you set your own table and place your order inside at the counter.  

But if you're looking for a romantic cozy place with magnificent food, Pizetta is a great choice!
author: Kate R.

description: The best pizza in the San Francisco. I just can't get enough of this place and am just happy that I don't live too close for fear of weighing 300 lbs. Also, please visit the bathroom.
author: Papaya S.

description: This place is tiny and adorable -- if you can find it, it is a great date spot.  Be sure to get there before they run out of dough (it's happened to me).  Thin crust "fancy" pizzas, both classic and nouveau (eg. butternut squash).  YUM.
author: Ellen O.

description:
They make this really strange pizza with an egg on top of it. They crack the egg on top before they stick it in the oven, so when it comes out it's still kind of runny.. like a sunny side up egg on a pizza. I didn't like it that much because I thought the egg was just a weird flavor on a pizza. However, they made a wonderful farmhouse goat cheese pizza that was very tasty.. thin thin crust. Oh, and the salad was good too. Lots of yummy cheese on it! I think the menu changes daily, so apologies if you can't order the goat cheese one! I didn't have problems with the service because we got there really early (5:30) and it seemed to be basically self-serve.. i.e. get your own forks, napkins, water, etc. The bathroom is really weird, the best one I've ever seen in a restaurant, as it has a strange little Italian video in this weird decorated box. Pizzetta only has like 5 tables, so get there reaaaaaaaally early.

New update!! I had a wonderful pizza last time I went. It was nectarine and proscuitto. I know that may sound weird, but the flavors melded so perfectly together. It was wonderful!
author: O K.

description:
holy shitballs. this is great pizza. great flatbread pizza, great desserts and cheeses too. VERY cramped. an easy stop off the One-California on MUNI if you orbit the midriff of the city. the cheese salad KILLS.

Pizzetta 211 makes a spot-on espresso, even for non-coffee drinkers like me.

I xo the richmond.
author: John M.

description: This is a great little neighborhood restaurant.  We had the summer squash pizza with a mixed green salad and the appetizer of the day Stuffed peppers with sausage.  The pizza was original and very fresh and tasty.  The mixed green salad was nothing special, it did have a nice vinaigrette which was tasty.  I didn't care much for the stuffed peppers with sausage, to me it was a little dry and could have used some sauce or cheese.  I really like how tiny and cozy this place is and the service was excellent too :)
author: Michele G.

description:
i went to pizzetta tonight for dinner and it was beyond excellent. the sausage and farrow salad was delicious--they make their own sausage on mondays and tuesdays. it was probably the best sausage i'd ever had, it had amazing texture. i split the special and two pizzas with two friends, and we left feeling completely satiated, but not too full. the crusts are delicate, and they don't overdo any of the ingredients on the pizza in a way that overpowers any part of the meal. 

the owner and staff were very friendly, and they all engaged in conversation and answered any questions that we asked. the place itself is lovely, it feels like you're sitting at the breakfast nook table of your friend's house watching them make you dinner. 

i really, really enjoyed my meal here tonight and would reccommend it to anyone who likes the ingredients in their pizza to shine for what they actually are, rather than just globs of sauce from a can.
author: emily r.

description: A friend living in the neighborhood told me about this small pizza place that has 4 tables an 4 bar stools. We tried it...and haven't stopped eating there for the past year. At least twice a month we go there. Jack is the cool waiter, laid back but responsive and welcoming. The pizzas are so tasty and crunchy and delicious that makes my month water just to think about it. They also make great salads and offer bottled root beer - all I need for a cool meal. I almost did not want to post a comment on yelp because I wanted to keep this hidden jewel for a selected group. But it is not fair. Everyone should have a chance to taste the best pizza - once at least!
author: Me G.

description: The cheese salad plate is still my favorite there.  Best cheese almost every time.  It's so tiny so you almost always have to wait so go with a small party.  It's far away (in the outer richmond) but worth the trip.
author: Ellie C.

description: The place is cozy and great for a rainy Saturday. I believe that each week they change the menu up a bit. When we came in this past week we had a yam and ricotta pizza, a sausage pizza, and a plain mozzarella and tomato pizza. For creativity they get 5 stars....but for taste...probably a 2.5 to 3 stars. The only one of the pizettas that I actually liked was the sausage pizza...my problem with these pizzas is that the cheese on them isn't melted...so it just sits there hardening by the minute. If you're going to make a thin-crust style pizza then make it thin crust...if you're going to make regular crust make the crust tasty. This was something in between the two thicknesses and the result was a disaster. I appreciate the spirit of this restaurant and the ideas behind it but based solely on taste this place failed to deliver.
author: Sasha B.

description: I'm pretty picky when it comes to pizza.  This is the best gourmet pizza I've ever had.  Amazingly fresh, tasty ingredients.  Yum.  Their chocolate dessert is pretty amazing too.
author: Cristina G.

description: A very yuppie style pizza place.  Pizza's are kind of small and there is a complete lack of service due to how the restaurant is designed but it serves some delicious pies.  Egg pizza is a must.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Pretty cool spot, tiny (4-5ish tables), get some pizzas (one per person, about, $10-15) with wine, and make sure to ask for an egg on any of em. Thin is in

Can be a bit oily, one time it was overcooked (way too crispy) so I gotta knock off one star

They could use cheaper wine by the bottle

Oh yeah, CASH ONLY
author: xo x.

description: This is a hidden gem of a restaurant in the Outer Richmond. The ingredients are fresh and the dessert makes me knees weak.  When it's cold and you're waiting for a table, you can grab a blanket and a bottle of vino outside.
author: Katie M.

description: Exactly the kind of pizza I enjoy eating: thin, crispy crust, local fresh ingredients, fried egg as topping...scrumptious. Its a tiny pizza place for those in the know, but don't be intimidated. First, nab a seat, then go up to the bar, place your order, pay in cash, grab a carafe of water, and have a seat. One pizza could probably fit 2 moderately hungry people, but what's the fun in that? Order 2 and take advantage of the always-changing menu. Don't forget to go back for desserts like upside-down cake, or flourless chocolate cake. Perfect date place with perfect little pizzas.
author: Sabine S.

description: It's been about a year since I've been to Pizzetta, but I used to go frequently and it never failed to impress me. Their pizzas really are amazing and unusual.  Their ingredients are the best. Their wine selection is very good, and it's so cozy inside. What a gem in this neighborhood!
author: Linda T.

description: cute place.  4 tables inside with small bench seating, a few tables outside.  the pizzas are $10-$14 a pop.  the sausage special they have for monday and tuesday nites was delicious, a chicken and pork sausage.  the farm fresh egg pizza was good too, but maybe a bit on the borderline too salty and oily..  fresh side salad for $5.50 was well worth it.  service was friendly, helpful.
author: Ethan L.

description: We tried three pizzas. All of them were about 10-12" and had a light crust that balanced well with the toppings on each pie. The red sauce, mascarpone, and arugula was buttery and delicious with a wet feel in the mouth. The rosemary and pine nut was a tastey white pizza. It had a slightly smokey ...almost forest like, earthy taste... The mozzarella, basil and red sauce was classic. A good spot for five or less, the food was served in cozy ambiance. The waiter was knowledgeable, sincere and efficient.
author: Dave S.

description: Possibly the best pizza in SF. I've had the mozzarella, the marscapone and the pine nut pizzas and all were great. Don't go if it is really cold because with so few tables there is often a wait streetside. Awful to be shivering while delicious pizzas float by to the plate of others. On the few sunny days in this windy neighborhood you can eat outside on little tables. The salads  and dessert while limited in selection are wonderful too.
author: D. L.

description:
What they do here they do really well -- gourmet, innovative, thin crust pizzas, basic salads, olives, wine and one dessert special. If you haven't eaten here you are in for a treat but come for the experience on its terms not through the lens of your past pizza eating experience. 

This is a small operation -- they keep the menu simple, the food is well-prepared and seasoned, the choices are few, and if something is popular they sometimes run out. They serve six different pizzas options each night (three are standard on the menu and three are rotating specials) and two salads, they have olives, and two desserts (one regular and one special). In the summer, I suggest the special fruit dessert (often a tart) -- they make excellent flaky pie/tart crust. Have them hold a slice for you so they don't run out. 

This is not a typical pizza place. You will be disappointed if you want to order hot-dog slices and pineapple on your pizza, if you expect 93 beers on tap, big screen TVs, topless waitresses, a dart board, etc. 

It is somewhat expensive and cash only. The service is good but not great. If you dint take yourself too seriously then they wont either. 

Started by Chez Panisse Alum what they do here they do very well.
author: david s.

description: we had dinner at 6pm and it wasn't satisfying.  friend's brother suggested this place.  2nd dinner at pizzetta after 30 min of circling the richmond for parking, getting flipped off for reckless driving, and it was still worth it.  (sorry about the reckless driving, my friend drives like an idiot)
author: thb t.

description:
pros:
- amazing thin crust pizza with the freshest ingredients
- cozy neighborhood feel

cons:
- it's cash only and the nearest ATM isn't really that close
- parking may be difficult. i'm a street parker at heart, but when my parking karma didn't kick in on time, i actually thought about paying $3 an hour at the lot. in the outer richmond, that's ridiculous.
author: kirti p.

description: Very good pizza. I think it's the most like the good New York pizza (Lombardi's and Grimaldi's style) that you can find in SF.  Better than Delfina's. Cozy place if you can get a table.
author: Val U.

description: I had a great experience when I visited Pizzetta but that was a while ago and things seem to have changed since then. A girlfriend and myself went on a gal-pal date here and we had fabulous food and a great experience. The place is ridiculously small, three tables, but if you get the window spot it seems all the more charming. This pizza that we got was simple and delicious. It was a classic margherita pizza with delicious sausage. Paired with a good bottle of red it seemed almost magical. The biggest surprise was when I went to use their restroom and they had a little window with a small tv in it showing a montage of Parisian culture. It made me feel like I was backstage at the Moulin Rouge. The prices are expensive but it is definitely worth it every once in a while. Very intimate setting, wonderful date spot.
author: Sugey G.

description: When a true Italian dough meets the Californian approach with success...
author: Serge D.

description: We found the staff friendly, professional and kind.   After reading the reviews here we were a little worried  that there may be attitude.  I don't know if the A team was working tonight, but they were great, the only attitude was good attitude!  The pizza was delicious, as well as the salad.  The atmosphere is cozy and warm.
author: mi m.

description: The pizza just rocksI It is so good that it is worth the pain involved in getting it... the wait is long, the place is dinky and they only take cash.... and fairly frequently they run out of ingredients (i.e. dough) for the day. But the pizza really is worth it!
author: David G.

description: This is one of my absolute favorite places to go. The pizza and the ambiance, both, are wonderful. I always get a fairly basic pizza, salad, and wine - and quite often the chocolate cake and coffee - and it's a satisfying, well-sized meal. Cash-only, though. It's a good date spot, or a good place to eat with your girlfriends (or I took my mom, once), as it's very small and cozy.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
I honestly can't believe that there are negative reviews about this place.  Definitely the best, most mouth-wateringly delicious thin crust pizza I've ever had (and I've had Chez Panisse cafe's pizzettas several times).  

I went with 3 other people, we all tried different pizzas, and all were delicious.  They use great seasonal ingredients, which are paired creatively, and all the pizzas looked beautiful as well.  

As for the service, I thought it was excellent.. maybe because we were there at a slow time on a late Saturday afternoon, but the waiter stopped to talk to us several times, even recommending other local coffee places to try because their Blue Bottle was out of commission.
author: Kristin S.

description: Pizza was great ..small n simple menu...super small place....they do very smart n efficient business here...only seat when your partys complete..they give you menus when your outside waiting so you can get an idea of what to get before your seated...i reallie like their bench seating around the tree in front of the restaurant...nice area to wait n have a drink. They have a couple tables outside with heated lamps.
author: stephanie n.

description: Most favorite spot in the city. Romantic, quaint, Euro Italian pizza spot in the city. It doesn't get any better. If you want to feel like you are in Tuscany, this is the spot. And...it's cheap! The pizzas and the desserts are incredible, and the wine is perfect.
author: Cristen F.

description:
Delicious! Got the tip from a waiter at Hyde 1550. 

The honey and I went spur of the moment style, happily early enough (around 6 or so) to miss the Sunday night crowds. We sat at a table, had yummy wine and mixed olives and two really good pizzas. One was a lamb sausage with ricotta salata - nice salty spicy combo with red pepper. Could have used a touch more cheese. The other was pinenut white pizza - my husband was in heaven. 

A mixed green salad, and saffron biscotti w/ vin santo to finish.

Out of our way, but when we have a car, we'd definitely go back. Really good and not nearly as scene-intense as the mission pizza joints. Go!
author: Lady L.

description: You will probably have to wait, but it's worth it. Fabulous pizza, good salads and drinkable wine. What more could you ask for?
author: Carol L.

description: Wow ! This is the best pizza I have ever had and actually redefines what I have always thought a pizza should be.  If you go you MUST order the pizza with the egg on it. I have never in my lfe had egg on pizza and thought this was amazing. My boyfriend and I also ordered the anchovie pizza and also the arugala pizza. Yes...3 pizzas between the two of us.  I have never eaten so much in my life, but it was for a reason...this stuff was amazing.  We also had the flourless chocolate cake at the end which of course, was also amazing.  Just FYI, this place is incredibly small; only 4 tables where the kitchen is the biggest part of the restaurant.  If you want the best pizza ever, TRY THIS PLACE!
author: Christina C.

description: Wonderful thin crust pizzas, flavorful and crisp.  But my God, the service?  There isn't much, but it's not a big place so you have to go get your own silverware.  But, why are these people so sour?  Check to make sure they are open, Take cash and eat the carmelized potato pizza and smile though all that sullen service.
author: Susan F.

description:
My absolute fave pizza joint in the city.  Rivals Pizzaiolo in Oakland for sure.  

Staff is usually friendly though it's not a full service restaurant.  Order at the counter, grab your own place settings and water, they bring the food to you.  

Pizza is always amazing.  Nice weekly changing menu with seasonal ingredients, housemade sausages, and delicious combinations.  The Rosie's Farm Egg pizza is a must if you like runny yolks.  Smother the pizza with yolk, mmm.  Salads are fresh, though I usually opt for the daily appetizer (most recently had grilled asparagus w/ crostini topped with a white bean paste).  Desserts are always delicious and love that they have Blue Bottle Coffee.  

I wouldn't suggest coming with more than a party of 4 as seating is definitely limited.  And I like to come either before the lunch rush or after as the small kitchen and small staff limit their production and speed when it is actually busy.  I have brought so many friends here to experience the delicious pizza.  Small wine and beer list, but very nicely selected and very reasonably priced.  Note:  cash only!
author: Haxter G.

description:
Their thin-curst pizza is some of the best in the City.  Unfortunately they have allowed this to go to their head and treat customers as an annoyance rather than a source of livelihood.  Don't even think of bringing your kids.  You'll be turned away even if they are well behaved and if you ask for take out 8 out of 10 times you'll be told an abrupt "no".   

We live in the neighborhood and have been here at least 5 times, but no longer go because of their attitude and rudeness.
author: Joe J.

description: Fantastic pizza! Great crust, great tomato sauce, this is my idea of pizza heaven. The people who work there are very friendly, which is good because the place is so small you almost feel like you're eating in the kitchen. They really make you feel welcome.
author: Paul F.

description: Pizzetta is tiny, cozy, and fun. The pizzas are truly delicious, and the servers are very friendly. The wait can be a little painful, but it's worth it once you get inside. Highly recommended!
author: L T.

description: the cutest and teeniest pizza joint!  there are only about 4 small tables and 4 stools at the counter.  pizzetta was a cozy oasis on a blistery day.  i came here for lunch with a friend who lives in the neighborhood and is an avid fan.  we shared two pizzettas: the rosemary, fiore sardo cheese, and pine nut (a regular on the menu) AND a brussels sprouts pizza.  both were delicious and made with care.  it was the perfect amount of food for the two of us, and we both left very happy.  the flourless chocolate cake sitting in front of us was very tempting, so i'd like to try it sometime.  i hear this tiny joint gets very crowded (no reservations and so small) so a late weekend lunch was perfect!  yet another great pizza place in the bay area. woot!
author: micaela r.

description:
The gourmet pizzas are delicious!  We have tried most of the pizzas, and they are all very tasty.  The pizzas are unique, and you don't feel gross and unhealthy after eating them.  

We saw some negative reviews about the service at this place, but we've never had any problems.  The staff was helpful and courteous.  The cheeseboard salad is wonderful because the cheeses are well selected, and paired nicely with the salad, figs, pears, and walnuts.
author: Howard-Daisy L.

description: I had read the negative reviews about the attitude at Pizzetta 211, so was a bit concerned about ordering a vegan pizza, since every pizza on the menu contained tempting cheeses (I am new at this vegan business and very vulnerable).  The waitress was sweet and accommodating and said no problem. The chef created a fantastic pizza with pine nuts and arugula.  Another day without succumbing to dairy! I  will definitely be going back when I am in the City!!!
author: Joan K.

description: the first time i came here for dinner, i was greeted at the door by the manager who informed me that "sorry, we've run out of dough." run out of dough? what kind of half-assed pizza places runs out of dough? since that first unfortunate visit, i've returned MANY times and this place remains a perennial san franicsco favorite. running out of dough exemplifies the wonderfully quirky quality of this place that frustrates some and [for others like me] makes it such a pleasure. their pizettas (especially the margarita) are great, and they have a ever-rotating selection of delicious wines. save some room for the sharffenberger chocolate cake at the end with freshly whipped cream. oh, by the way, take a trip to the ATM before you come. they don't take cash.
author: Stephen G.

description: i liked it.  a lot.  in fact, i made numerous moaning noises during the meal that might have been embarrassing if i were with someone other than my boyfriend.  the ambiance was charming.  the staff was friendly and attentive.  the food was prepared and served quickly.  the pizza was GREAT.  i have a feeling i'll be back.
author: Sarah B.

description: Oh Pizzetta! I have eaten at Pizzetta four times over the past year and it never fails to impress me. If you want pizza with the freshest (locally grown) ingredients, just the right amount of seasoning, and a thin and crispy crust, eat at Pizzetta. The menu changes frequently, to incorporate the best local ingredients. My two friends and I decided to swing by Pizetta for dinner this past Wendesday. We started out with the special of asparagus with a lemon vinagrette, topped with bruschetta with fresh goat cheese. The asparagus were perfectly ripe and tender. Two of us ordered the classic pepporoni pizza- which I have found to be a staple on the menu. I love how they finish this pizza off with fresh dollups of basil. And although past reviews have bagged on the service, I have never found the service to be a problem. In fact, on Wednesday evening, there was a guy manning the door and wait list. Best pizza in the city!
author: Laura D.

description: Okay so after hearing about this place for a looonng time I finally went last night, because it was my friend Harrison's last night working there.  Yes this place is tiny, but that makes it soooo cozy and you feel like you are dining with your extended family.  There are 4 tables inside with 4 stools at the counter (definitely recommend sitting there, you can chat with the really nice staff who have interesting stories to share.  My friend and I got the last order of the night (because people they do run out of dough) last night they ran out at 8:00pm.  We got the Squash pizza,  the pine nut with rosemary pizza, a bottle of the Lazy Creek pinot noir, and a slice of flourless chocolate cake, we also got two glasses of desert wine with cookies. This place made me feel like I was in Europe, I love it! They aren't snobby people they just aren't gonna rush around for anyone, this is the European way of dining.  So my suggestion is go there before you are really really hungry and plan to make a night out of it, relax and don't rush.  Type A people will not be fond of this place, but then Type A people aren't fond of most places... The food and the wine mmmmm!! Seriously I wish I had gone earlier...
author: Cassie L.

description: I live two blocks from here and this place it ALWAYS crowded, so I finally decided to check it out. This place is definitely small! We had to sit at the counter. The menu was quit short, but there were definitely more than one gourmet pizza I wanted to try. My sister and I ended up sharing the squash pizza and the fennel pizza. The squash was my favorite. It was made with no "sauce" just olive oil, cheese, yellow squash and topped with fresh riocotta. The crust was thin and it had a really unique taste. The fennel pizza was very different as well. It was topped with cheese, kumquat tapenade, fennel, argula, and this salty ham. It was good, but I thought it was too salty. The combination of the tapenade and the salty ham was a little too much. I thought $13 was overpriced for a tiny pizza. This place was worth the try, but I probably wouldn't go back.. I rather pay that much for gourmet pizza at a restaurant with better location, decor, and service.
author: Denise L.

description: I may never be able to show my face at Pizzeta again. I don't know that they want more clientele, but I just can't keep this one to myself. Ok, the FOOD IS AMAZING. I have only had a few dishes, but they were all impeccable. I sampled the pizzeta bolognese and a crazy little salad.. the Artisan Cheese salad was comprised of fabulous little baby greens, delicately candied/spiced walnuts, a medley of olives and two of the softest and most delicate dates ever (walnuts were not over sugared kind you find in most places),but the part that will melt your panties off are the two hunks of cheese.. one goat and the other bleu.. every bite of the blue made me want to lay down and close my eyes. (note: returned last night and discovered that the cheeses vary by day.. last night it was raclette and something else, but the panties still came off.. oh my God.) I think I can say that their pizza's are as close to authentic Italian pizza as I have had in the US. They had a special Roast Poussin (teeny chicken).. I abstained from making the obvious poussin reference. :O) There are about 2 tables to the left and 2 tables to the right and a few outside with heaters above them. There is a counter that features a few different wines that they are featuring that day. They have no problem letting you sample the wine before you buy. The place fills up quickly, but is worth the wait. And if the story couldn't get better, it is super casual. Pizzeta supports local growers and they try to stay organic wherever possible.
author: Claudia O.

description: This is a wonderfully beautiful hideaway nook of a place.  I sat outside under the heated lamps and yet still felt cozy.  The pizza was delicious and the salad I got was also fresh and simple.  The wine, I was told from a friend-was good for it's price.  Sometime I will come back for dessert.  The service was not the same as you would expect from a full service restaurant.  But, it is not a full-service restaurant and therefore it seemed perfect.  All staff seemed to be thoughtful and attentive.  There were many people waiting outside after we had gotten there.  But they weren't grouchy.  Everyone seemed actually to be happy and flirty.  There must be something in the air in front of Pizzetta 211. I have to say it made me want to rush out and date a hot hipster with a cool hat just so we could look longingly into one another's eyes, whispering sweet nothings at Pizzetta 211.  Bring cash with ya.
author: Lauren S.

description: I too am very tempted to NOT tell anyone about this place as it is 3 blocks from my house and I like to think of it as our not so hip neighborhood's hip little secret. But for Yelp I will share, and also everyone should know that this is an idiosyncratic little place (no, they don't care that you complain about getting your own cutlery and salt and pepper - but I have never known any staffer there to be rude and have been dozens of times), so don't come if you don't want to be part of their zeitgeist.  It is a teeny, tiny oasis of perfection cooking - meaning nothing hits the daily changing and very short menu unless they love it and are sure their customers (huge amount of regulars) will love it too.  It is absurdly expensive for pizza and the menu very limited -- like I said, go away if you do not like it -- but it inspires cult-fetish love among those who frequent it.  When our newborn was a wee one, we were going there every other day and sitting outside, and watching the sunset over Sea Cliff with good French red in our tumblers and eating the perfect pancetta and egg pizza.  And don't get me started on the flourless chocolate cake - I don't know what is in it and I don't even want to it's so good.  Anyway, don't come it you don't like waits, it could randomly close on you (when they run out of food), but if you "get" what they are going for - ie small, perfect, gem of a gourmet pizza-only boite, then do come, and enjoy that rare neighborhood place that feels truly unique.
author: Kirsten M.

description: We travel all the way across the city as often as we can to eat this pizza.  Its our favorite place in the bay area.  The ingredients are fresh, the dough is incredible, and the atmosphere is intimate and relaxing.  Its the perfect way to spend a Sunday afternoon.
author: Patrick F.

description: they have delicious thin pizza. the only thing is this place is really really small - 2 or 3 tables inside and a couple tables outside. i would also be careful with the wine... i went on my anniversary and wasn't paying attention to my order of glass after glass after glass... and i ended up spending $50 bucks on wine by the glass. I wish the waiter suggested a bottle after my husband and I finished our first glass at the beginning of the meal.
author: Jesica M.

description: Around the block from my house which is perfect. I was waiting leisurely outside for my boyfriend, and went ahead and ordered a bottle of wine and drank it while watching the kids leave the elementary school (cementing my status of the creepy neighborhood lush). No, seriously the area is so cute and this hole-in-the-wall completes it. I had the egg pizza, which is a really cool idea. Points to the place and the server for letting me drink wine outside and vicariously hating my boyfriend for being an hour late. One star docked, unfortunately, for having to wait for him again while he went to get cash at the laundromat (out of order), then the movie theater (wouldn't take his card), then the liquor store. So maybe he was late and cash-less, but by that time I had had a bottle of wine and was feeling pretty good about the relationship. Slapping down the Visa and heading for the apartment would have been nice.
author: Katie T.

description: I think it's funny to read the love/hate reviews of this place, I can see how the service can be slight but what do you expect from indie/hippie kids running an upscale pizza place. It was while we lived in the avenues that we happened upon Pizzetta 211 on a walk one night. We sat at the bar and had a swiss chard, potato, and gruyere pizza. It was a great experience not just because the food was great, but because the atmosphere was great as well. We have since moved out of the city. Last weekend I took my wife on a mini vacation back to the city for her birthday and her being a vegetarian, I wanted to take her somewhere nice, Greens, Millennium, etc...But we decided to try and find that little pizza place off of California. Once again the experience and the food were excellent. There wasn't a lot for her to chose from, but she loved the pizza margarita and I had the fig, house made prosciutto , and gorganzola pizza. The crust on these pizzas are just right, crisp and flavorful. The sauces taste fresh as do the toppings. The service isn't outstanding, and I am a stickler for good service, especially when I'm paying good money, but there is something about this place that is redeeming, the atmosphere? the laid back feel? You don't go here to be waited on hand and foot, you go to relax in a communal environment and eat great food while engaging  your friends or loved ones.
author: Jeremy D.

description: this place is the best period.  the bathroom is even amazing and if you died and became a pizza here it'd probably be a step up.
author: Today Y.

description: I LOVE this pizza place!  Granted the wait can be long even on a weeknight and the place seats about 12 people, but they make up for it with their creative pizza combinations, intimate atmosphere, and great service.  I had a pizza with pesto, cheese, pancetta, and a fried egg and it was too die for!  My friend had one with pear and hazelnuts, which was a more delicate choice, though still very good.  We also had their flourless chocolate cake, which was just OK.  I love that their menu changes frequently and that they cook everything right in front of you (literally, since i was sitting at the bar).  I thought their portions were well-sized, certainly not on the small side.  I only ate half and saved the rest for the next day.  Great value for the price!
author: Marianne L.

description: i've been back a number of times now and Pz211 just keeps getting better. i still LOVE their egg on any pizza they make and somehow they never mess up the egg! unlike other places i've now had egg on pizza, the other places always have it partially hard boiled (yuck) or the egg is on a pizza that just doesn't fit. not so at Pz211. their eggs are always *perfectly* cooked and somehow every single pizza they make tastes good with egg. also, my pizza fell off my table the other night and they *replaced it for no charge* wow. what awesome customer service. i wish all restaurants treated their customers like they're old friends instead of like wallets with legs.
author: lisa w.

description: This isn't your Pizza Hut or Round Table, this is the best pizza in all of SF. Great thin crusts with imaginative choices changing every week and the standards like the Margarita are hard to beat even in Italy. Great cheese selections change regularly and the salads are fresh and tasty. Yeah, its a little more pricey than your average pizza and yeah the staff aren't over the top friendly especially the grumpy guy tossing the pie's, but what do you want. The food is great and the space is comfortable. That's why they run of of dough and you might have a 1hr wait, its because it tastes so damn good.
author: willie l.

description: So... where to begin. Super small to begin with and wait was like 20 min. Then after we got seated it took the waitress a few min to bring us a menu. Our server then didn't come back for a little while. So when she came back we decided to order our dessert with our dinner so we could have that ready when we finished. Well we also had to ask for water which was tap water no ice and the cups were dirty. So finally after waiting like an hour our waitress brings out forks for our dessert. Mind you that we never got our pizza. Then she brings it out and I questioned it and then like finally another 15 min later she brought out our pizza with our dessert again. We did not have any plates or napkins and had to ask for napkins. Over all experience and service was horrible and food was ok. Not worth the hassle or the wait. I wouldn't waste my time again.
author: L C.

description: Really good thin, and i mean thin pizza. You do have to get there early if you are going on the weekend. We got there around 6pm and were ok but we saw the owner turning people away at 7pm as I guess they only make enough dough for the day. Super nice staff, i don't know why all these people on yelp are complaining about the staff. They even gave us a free dessert!
author: Amelia L.

description: pizza was decent, but when you factor in the price, the wait, and the attitude, it just doesn't work for me.  sorry!  i'm not really gonna go off on the attitude....as the evening progressed, i just realized that the dude had very poor interpersonal skills, and wasn't trying to be a jerk or anything.  of course, that's really no excuse, but what can you do?  the world is filled with them, i guess!
author: Miss P.

description: Some of the workers seem to have bought out the rude woman owner, so the customer service issue appears to have been solved.  Nothing but friendliness on my recent visits, and food as good as ever!
author: Ritch G.

description: simply an amazing little gem tucked away in the richmond. sit outside under the heat lamp, cuddle up in a blanket, sip some wine, and nosh on  some delicious food (like the cauliflower soup with creme fraiche and parsley oil, and the roasted eggplant pizza!). remember to take plenty of cash and don't be bothered by a little wait. it's worth it.
author: Bee H.

description: Deliciousness.  I just had the calzone last night.  I'd come here more often but it is VERY hard in since its small and there are lots of ppl in line.   We were lucky and only had ot wait about 10 minutes at about 6:15 or so.  Anyway, I dont hold their popularity against them!  They make great pizzas and its a great place to enjoy them.
author: Rainforest C.

description: My wife and I used to love Pizzetta 211 but something has happened and it's fallen so much that it's sad.  This was not a bad day either, I've been here twice in a few months.  On both occasions the staff was just a notch above surly, but they don't make any effort to make you feel welcome or appreciated.   It's as if they're pissed that you're taking them from hanging out in the kitchen.  The service was also really slow on both occasions and the last time we waited 45 mintes for our pizza when there were only two other tables taken.  Lastly, the pizza is fine but the sauce is bland and the toppings nothing special.  With so many other good pizza places in the city there's no reason to go here.
author: David M.

description: pizza does not make up for arrogant/ignorant/wannabe hipster staff.  I thought it was me and I tried to be open minded.  But by the third time, I just gave up.Stay away!  Plus it's in the Richmond, you wouldn't like it out here....it's foggy, it's cold, and not very hip at all.
author: john h.

description: The food is pretty good. The staff on the other hand: rude, rude, rude... The Richmond is very laid back with friendly down to earth people. This place however has bad vibes. I cannot recommend this place at all.
author: Jonas K.

description: I have to admit I like this place, even for their little pizzas.  But they're good lil pizza.  I think you need 2 pizzas to fill up.  @ $10-$15/pizza, it's expensive to come on a empty stomach.  It's very thin crust and sparcely spaced ingredients, but like other yelpers say it ain't no RoundTable.  Their salads are also very good.  Only if it was a little more affordable, I'd go more often.
author: gummy j.

description: I'm from the east coast, and I'm ready to believe that this is the best pizza that San Francisco has to offer.  It's good pizza, but it makes me wonder what's missing here on the west coast.  They've got the ultra-thin crust, great toppings(I remember we had one with an egg cracked on top), and I really respect what they're doing, because no one out here is doing it.  It's a little cramped inside, so you feel like you're fighting for a table, but once you get one, it's worth it.  One note-they recommend one pizza per person, if I remember right, they cost around $9.
author: eh k.

description: Some of the best pizza in SF. Limited menu, all done very nicely. Hard to get a table.
author: Stephen S.

description: oh my word, it's so adorable here! everything is tasty, tasty, tasty. the service is great, the restaurant is tiny, the pizza is divine, and the salads are both fresh and savory. i love it here. by far my favorite restaurant in san francisco.
author: julia r.

description: I love this teeny tiny little pizza joint way out in the Richmond. Just head down California and look for the little yellow awnings once you hit 23rd.  Chances are, there will be a wait.  No matter, there's a sweet coziness about the place, both inside and outside.  You can bide your time on a bench under the twinkling light adorned tree out front, and sip some vino.  Once you get in, order anything. All the thin crust pizzas are good, even the weird looking one with the fried egg on top.  They are fun to share.  Same with the salads.  I'm not a huge dessert fan, but it's so cozy in there, you won't want to leave, and you'll probably want to order something.  We shared a yummy chocolate cake.  But the reality is that others are waiting, and you'll probably want to extend the same courtesy others before you have, and you'll make your way out.  The service is a bit relaxed, but goes well with the relaxed ambiance of the place.
author: Sabrina K.

description: My good webcontent manager friend from work turned me on to this place & he took me one day b/c about a good two years ago, I seriously broke my left arm...to help me recover & lick my wounds, he told me this is where you go when you need a remedy  if you find yourself accidently eating "cardboard" pizza...I had a spinach, fetta pizza which the made right in front of us while we drank Italian beers & it was an experience.  Yes the place is "cozy" but that's the whole part of the ambiance...plus, I found the service warm & friendly, not sure what happened to the other reviewers here...we were even complimenting each other on our choice of eyeware -- um, I know only in San Francisco bu there you go, I'm a proud San Franciscan :)  Represent!  Anyway, the bread tasted fresh & crisp & when I tried my web friend's slice of pizza with the egg ontop, I was dubious about eating it but wow, good things come taste buds that are adventurous...
author: Elle F.

description: This place is great.  But you have to understand a couple of things before going or else you'll end up feeling like Sarah l. and Elsa T.  This place has great food.  Pizza's that are thin and nice salads and wine and a good desert (usually whatever they made that night)  But what it's not, is a place that you will get pampered like in most restaurants.  It's a hang out really.  You go, you treat the employees with respect, they treat you with respect, you get what you need (water, fork, napkins) yourself - kind of like going to a friends house who you know well.  Anyway,  go there...hand out, wait for a table, eat some delicious food, and go home happy.  Don't go here if you are on an American timeline or attitude...i.e...if you need to hurry everything and need people to serve your every need.  You can go too a million other places for that....
author: Hagop K.

description:
i heart pizzetta 211.  first of all, the pizza is damn good.  i adore thin crust pizza -- cracker thin, that is, and they do it so well.  i also love their short but fresh gourmet menu that rotates frequently.  i despise tomato sauce and love unique ingredients, so pizzetta 211 is just the right place for me.  

they're located in my 'hood, whose ebb and flow i understand well, so i have never once had to wait for a table.  sorry to those of you who don't understand how to play this game in the richmond.

i also have zero complaints about the waitstaff.  they've been nothing but highly efficient every time i've been there.  the first few times, i agree, they were not too warm but not too snotty -- but who cares? i'm there for the pizza, not to improve my self-esteem.  lately, i've developed a pizza-crush on one of the servers.  i think he might have been flirting with me tonight and as an added bonus, a super cute girl cashed me out and i'm pretty sure she was checking me out as well.  so what's not to love?

i would give them 5 stars if the tables weren't so wobbly!
author: pitter k.

description: the pizza is awesome, as is the cheese salad and chocolate cake -- but most of the staff are definitely surly.  it's also expensive, but you're getting really quality food.  also, it's SMALL, so be prepared to either WAIT, or feel like you're in EVERYONE's way while you're eating.
author: Kate M.

description: OK I JUST got back from this place and their pizzas are like 1/3 smaller than they used to be! I was bed ridden for like 3 days with the flu and was just regaining my appetite back and I finished the entire thing by myself! I got take out and it took 20 minutes when they said like 30 or 40 which wasnt bad. I was walking home with it and opened the box up and let out a large GASP*** it was so little the pizza! I ate two slices on my way home and finished the margarita in its entirely after 10 minutes. I can't believe they downsized! And the prices didnt get cheaper either, its like $10 for a standard margarita pizza. But it was GOOD,  thin crust and nice and chewy pizza. They have many gourmet type of toppings including prociutto, pancetta, goat cheese, etc. You won't find round table quality pizza here but very thin and crusty good pizza. Last time I tried the prociutto one which was a tad salty due to the ham, but it was good. The single pizzas range from $9-$13, and are big- you can share with someone else and a salad. Good neighborhood joint but nothing over the top good.
author: Petri Y.

description: I've tried them all and Pizzetta 211 is the best pizza in san francisco, hands down, bar-none.  Better than Delfina (although Delfina is pretty good), better than Picino.  It's all they do, they do it flawlessly and in small, very careful quantities.  The crust is perfect, the oven just the right temperature, the ingredients fresh and always interesting, and with the wine, simple salads, espresso and desserts, it is quite literally one of the most satisfying meals in San Francisco.  This place is special.  Waiting for a table sucks, but welcome to San Francisco, what are you gonna do.  Part of the reason it's so good is because it's so small.
author: Thom L.

description: Pizzetta is a lovely and cozy spot. The pizzas are delicious with an authentic homemade taste to them. Be sure to get there early or you will be waiting outside.
author: C R.

description: Good pizza is hard to find in the Bay Area, but this is one of the best ones.  I think Picco (in Larkspur) is still the best but Pizzetta is close behind.  There are only a few tables in this small establishment, so bring a coat while you wait outside.  It's worth the wait.
author: Aron L.

description: totally fresh ingredients, made-to-order, thin crust, light, and an all-around delightful eating experience. tucked away in a residential neighborhood. tiny hole-in-the-wall with a small dessert selection. if your pizza taste is anything like mine (i hate corporate pizza and cheap berkeley pizza), this place will capture a little piece of your heart.
author: Catherine H.

description: Pizza here is ok.  Good quality ingredients, but the service is terrible, they have way too much attitude.
author: Aaron H.

description: Great atmosphere (but think small, tight, and cozy)... if you're a bit on the larger size you may feel a bit squeezed to say in the least. Great food (but not my favorite pizza in the Bay Area - think Gialina, Delfina, or Beretta). However, I'd go back to try some of the different flavored pizzas - I liked that breakfast-like pizza we had although I'm still a dinner person more than an egg on my pizza type of person.
author: Jeannette L.

description: I'd like to give this one more half star.  This place was closed the first two times I went to eat here.  The time it was open, I was fortunate enough to because it wasn't crowded.  I got pizza, a roasted beet salad and sat outside watching people walk by.  It was very charming, so I'd recommend going at off hours and with a relaxed attitude just in case.
author: Jo G.

description: Very simply, this place is worthy of its reputation.  Been there 5 or 6 times now, and there just isn't a bad thing to say about it.  Even the wait is okay, as you can have a glass of wine and hang outside.  We generally go on off hours to get quick seating.
author: Larry M.

description:
many yelpers seem to moan and groan about the service everywhere they go... or maybe they only write reviews for places they have unpleasant experiences with...  I will tell you this - the service here is fine, in my experience, the wait can be long, but the staff are willing to bring you beverages and blankets while you wait for a table... they only have a few tables and they are popular, so you do the math. 

regarding the food...  i have to say that this little place is one of the best and a neighborhood gem.   they are dedicated to fresh ingredients and food prepared with care.  if you want a schlocked together pizza  made fast go elsewhere.
author: andrew p.

description: Even though it is a small place it has a great vibe to it. If you can, go on a warm night and enjoy your meal outside. The food tastes great because it is made out of quality ingredients. It is worth the money you pay for it. For dessert, the flour-less chocolate cake is wonderful. The service good too. This place is definitely worth checking out.
author: paige s.

description: Five stars for doing what they do so very well. SImple, classic, rustic Italian-style pizzas. Simple, classic, rustic salads. Simple, classic, rustic chocolate cake. Simple, classic cafe ambiance, complete with limonata. When the place is open (limited hours) and there's a seat (limited space), I sigh a great, huge "ahhh" of relief.
author: Midori S.

description: Inspired by the Chronicle's "Pizza Friday" reviews and a neighbor's recommendations, I made the very short drive with a friend recently to this cozy pizza place in the Outer Richmond.  My friend dropped me off to put our name on the list and drink wine while she parked.  (It may have been a four star, not five star, experience for her.)  We shared more wine, two yummy thin crust pizzas and a salad, and talked so much that we ended up shutting down the place.  The wait staff was delightful and not only did not rush us out of the restaurant, but treated us to dessert and an interesting discussion of the presidential candidates.
author: Sarah F.

description: The pizza here reminds me of the cafes in Italy.  The pizza is exactly what you would be eating all over Italy.  Thin crusts, fresh pesto and just the right amount of cheese and sauce.  Mama mia!
author: Karen B.

description: the pizza here is delicious (try the fried egg or home made white anchovies on top!)  as are the salads, cheese plates & other little fresh, organic starters they may have that day.  the ambiance is cute & sweet, and once inside you will forget you are in the outer richmond completely.  the only drawback to this great little restaurant is the long wait, and because pizzetta 211 is so tiny they don't take reservations.  however, on a nice day you may wait for your table outside with a glass of wine and have plenty of time to contemplate exactly which delicious cracker crust pizza to order.
author: Maiko D.

description: True they only seat about 20 people a night, but those 20 people are always stoked to eat there.  True the service can, at times, be a bit uptight or snooty, but it's more laughable and entertaining than meal ruining.   The food is always, always delicious and fresh, which I love.  The service, even if snooty, is attentive if called upon.  Bring your own wine, as their list is short, though good.  The prices are completely fair, especially considering the very small number of eaters they have a night.  The ambiance is intimate and great.  Warm nights outside are just as great as cool nights just inside the window seats.  What else can I say, I love this place.  I'd recommend it, but be prepared for what it is, a sometimes snooty, hard to get a table, fresh, delicious hole in the wall.  Try the flourless chocolate cake if they have it.
author: Your E.

description: Fantastic little hole-in-the-wall with the best thin-crust pizza.  But make sure to go early, as there are only 3 or 4 tables in the whole place.
author: Molly C.

description: Excellent crust & sauce but not worth the price and wait.  Everything is self serve.
author: Howard W.

description: Good simple freshly baked thin small pizzas with fresh ingredients, although plan to spend about $30-40 per person (or more if you're hungry) on just a small pizza ($10-15) and a salad (~$10) and wine ($7-12) since the portions can be small.  Excellent Belgian beer, wine by the glass, and freshly baked desserts, too.  Great neighborhood place for couples, not good for groups since it seats very few people inside with a few 2-person tables outside.  Nice place to sit outside on a warm evening with the dog and a glass of wine.
author: Melanie G.

description: unreal good.  this is a cozy nook of a place that has amazing pizza.  it makes A16 pizza seem pedestrian.
author: Margo H.

description: This place rules!  Tiny little space, but as long as you have a few minutes to wait, it really adds to the atmosphere.  The pizza is ridiculously good...maybe the best in the city.  Very thin crust, not at all greasy, top notch ingredients.  Decent selection of wines by the glass, an excellent cheese salad, and fantastic desserts, and you have a neighborhood joint that's a keeper.  My only fear in writing this review is that I will help attract more people to this place, making it that much more difficult for me to get one of the four tiny tables in the place.
author: Mike L.

description: OMG - Fabulous!  I love ths pizza - best in the city.  Intimate restaurant, friendly service, amazing ingredients and flavor!
author: Erica H.

description: My favorite pizza find in the city.  If you love 'thin crust' pizza this is the place.  Great flavors and quality.  Simple menu with 2 salad selections, about 5 varieties of pizzas and 2 delicious desserts.  They serve wine as well!  It only has about 4 tables in the space so you need to get there by 6 or 6:30 latest to avoid the lines.  If you do have to wait, it's worth every minutel--especially as you cut into the chocolate cake...yummy!
author: Peter V.

description: what a great pizza spot.  yes it's definitely a bit pricey (10 bucks for a personal pizza) but it's definitely quality.  they try to use local fresh ingredients and their pizza definitely tastes like it.  i had a half pepperoni and half anchovie and it was really good.  reminds me of the italian pizza places back on the east coast. the crust is so thin and delicious.  the lady had a calzone with goat cheese and it was better than the calzones i've had before.  the braised artichoke app was incredible.  check this place out.  it's tiny but we sat outside under the heat lamps and had a wonderful evening.
author: shar d.

description: one of my fav pizza places. it's a small hole-in-the-wall that's cozy and nice. the pizza combos are great! usually i don't like pizza because if feel like a piece of lard after eating it, but the pizzas here are light... or so i think:)
author: Young L.

description: such a great out of the way gem!  i was brought to pizzetta by a friend who is always exploring new places (and has a car, which comes in handy) and had a wonderful experience.  pizzetta is a tiny place with only a handful of tables, but we were lucky enough to not have to wait, and were greeted by a warm and friendly staff.  the pizza menu changes often, but the night we were there we tried the cauliflower and salsa verte (my favorite), a rosemary pine nut concoction, and another pizza with prosciutto and goat cheese, all of which were flavorful and delicious.  we started with the cheese salad, which was a generous portion of two kinds of cheeses, the mixed greens, and some walnuts and olives, and ended the meal with a slice of flourless chocolate cake, which sent us on our way very happy (and stuffed) campers.  the only downside for me is that it is such a trek to get there, but it is definitely worth the trip.
author: ali l.

description: this place rocks. it is the most adorable restaurant ever opened. and the pizza is AMAZING.
author: steven w.

description: tasty pizza. nice, laid back atmosphere. drink some wine and youre set.
author: cr b.
